column2: LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has signed a directive curtailing the Pentagon's use of private consultants in response to the investigation of such outside experts in the procurement fraud inquiry.
LEAD: Federal officials said today that they were still evaluating documents and other materials seized late Wednesday and early Thursday in searches of some legislative offices at the state Capitol.

LEAD: The 147th anniversary of Antonin Dvorak's birth will be observed with an all-Dvorak concert on Sept. 10 at 7:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. The composer's actual birthdate is Sept. 8.

LEAD: Rueben Mayes softened a bit yesterday on his statement that he has no future with the New Orleans Saints, but the running back still believes he will be playing somewhere else in 1989. Mayes, a Pro Bowl pick in each of his two seasons in the National Football League, walked out of the Saints training camp Aug.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Five days of auditions for the New York Choral Society will begin at 5:30 P.M. Tuesday at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street. The society, which celebrates its 30th anniversary this year, makes annual appearances at Carnegie Hall and other performance halls around the country. Auditions, which are by appointment only, will also be held Wednesday, Thursday and on Sept.

LEAD: Reggie Jackson's rumored return to the Yankees appeared to fall through today after the 42-year-old retired player and his agent denied that Jackson was interested in a comeback. But Bill Goodstein, a New York lawyer Jackson has used on occasion for business matters, stood by his account that Jackson has been contemplating a return.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: After slipping for several weeks, copper prices have begun to rebound again because of a renewed tightening of supplies brought on in part by copper workers' strikes in Peru and Canada.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: Two Federal police officers were arrested yesterday and charged with assaulting three 14-year-old boys who trespassed on Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island because they wanted to play soldier. One of the boys suffered a broken nose.

LEAD: A report in the Washington Talk Briefing column yesterday on a speech by Richard F. Schubert, president of the American Red Cross, misidentified the organization he addressed in some copies. It is the World Jewish Congress.

LEAD: The Transportation Department today proposed relaxing the fuel economy requirements for 1989 and 1990 model automobiles, saying the move would save American jobs. But the reduction would be less than was granted auto makers in the last three years.

LEAD: Joshua Robert Lipkin Sautter, age 5, will begin kindergarten this fall at a public school in Washington. His parents have bought him a shiny backpack, and his uncle has given him a ''Ghostbusters'' lunch box.

LEAD: For more than a week, George Bush has been taunting Michael S. Dukakis for vetoing a Massachusetts law that would have required teachers to lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance. Governor Dukakis has retorted that such a law would be unconstitutional, and that Vice President Bush would not be qualified to be President if he had signed it.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a sharp critic of the Strategic Defense Initiative, said today that he was pleased to hear Vice President Bush saying that deployment of the proposed missile defense system should be contingent on the outcome of further research.
LEAD: It was a sultry August afternoon, a scorcher, when the heat smokes you like a Lucky and stubs you out in the overflowing ashtray of Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Enzo Fano, an internationally known water-resources specialist at the United Nations, died of a heart attack Thursday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Investigators for the New York City Council found medical equipment or possibly infectious wastes in 10 of 17 city ambulances sold at an auction last week, Peter F. Vallone, the council's Democratic majority leader, said yesterday.

LEAD: Large crowds gathered Friday at the Shwe Dagon Pagoda in Rangoon, where speakers called on the army to support the peaceful but leaderless insurrection that has turned much of the Burmese population against the Government.

LEAD: For people closing summer homes, one chore is deciding what to do with outdoor furniture. Some of it, expecially the new ornamental teak and cast-aluminum models, is sturdy, durable and made to be left outdoors. Other popular styles, though, are prone to rust or are too flimsy to withstand harsh weather.
LEAD: As if bank statements were not onerous enough, there will be some new reading material stuck in with your canceled checks in the next few weeks.
LEAD: Donald DeLue, a sculptor known for monuments and memorials, died yesterday in his sleep. He was 90 years old and lived in Leonardo, N.J.
LEAD: A group led by Rosewood Financial Inc., a Dallas investment firm controlled by Caroline Rose Hunt, has acquired a 6.2 percent stake in the First Executive Corporation for more than $54 million.

LEAD: Late in August George Bush refused to debate Michael Dukakis before late September. Political analysts figured Bush wanted to wait and look at the polls. If they showed he was sure to be elected, he would say he couldn't debate until October, when, if his polls were still terrific, he'd say, ''I'll be ready in February.

LEAD: The evolution of traditional African music will be discussed by a panel of musicians at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, from 2 to 4 P.M. today. At 3 P.M. on Sunday, Cheryl Byron and Something Positive will present a program of songs, chants, dances and stories reflecting African-Caribbean culture.

LEAD: A Federal judge today barred Eastern Airlines from dismissing 4,000 workers and then threw Eastern and the airline industry into confusion by leaving open the question of whether he will allow the airline to slash its flight schedules next week.

LEAD: Eddie Chiles, the majority owner of the Texas Rangers, announced last night that he had agreed to sell his controlling interest in the American League baseball team to a group of investors who have been associated with efforts to secure a major league franchise for Tampa, Fla.

LEAD: Joey Dillon, the title character in ''The Fighter'' by Daniel Keene, comes home to his seedy apartment and goes through his nightly ritual. Changing to his sweat pants and putting a towel around his neck, he steps on a scale, winces at his weight and then removes the towel and tries again. The silent scene goes on so long (at Theater for the New City) that it seems less like a prelude to a play than a play itself, somewhat on the order of Franz Kroetz's ''Request Concert.
LEAD: Even the adroit direction of Tony Richardson cannot conceal the patched-together quality of ''After Midnight,'' a one-hour drama to be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on ABC.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Davis Water & Waste Indusries Inc (NYSE) Qtr to July 31 1988 1987 Sales 50,456,433 39,309,316 Net inc 842,523 733,783 Share earns .26 .23
LEAD: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a patent on two new sweeteners that are 2,000 to 2,500 times sweeter than sugar.
LEAD: Iraq Takes Tough Line
LEAD: Two years after it reopened after extensive renovations, the New York Hall of Sciznce in Queens has been so successful that the city wants to expand and improve it further, officials say.

LEAD: In the Dining Out column in Weekend yesterday, an incorrect star rating was given for the Gotham Bar and Grill, 12 East 12th Street. The restaurant received a three-star rating when it was reviewed on Oct. 4, 1985.
LEAD: Weddings are becoming precarious occasions here.

LEAD: ''Hot to Trot,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, bills itself as ''the funniest talking horse movie ever.'' That's not so very much to live up to. But even so, ''Hot to Trot'' doesn't qualify, since its biggest innovation is the idea of a horse named Don who's as wisecracking, irreverent and messy as the human characters.

LEAD: Mike Reid, a slim golfer who surprises people when he does well on strong courses against big, powerful golfers like Sandy Lyle and Greg Norman, surprised himself a bit today with a three-under-par 67 at the long Firestone Country Club South course.

LEAD: Rusty Wallace, the Winston Cup season point-leader, survived a crash and escaped serious injury yesterday afternoon at the Bristol (Tenn.) International Raceway during practice for the Busch 500 Nascar race, which will be run tonight. The 31-year-old driver's Pontiac slid into the fourth-turn wall on the half-mile track, climbed to the top of the wall, turned over and rolled five times along the straightaway before coming to rest on its wheels just past the finish line.

LEAD: Burma is now witness to an elemental display of pure people power. Changes are occurring without covert or overt help, sanctions or the carefully confected phrases of diplomats, and without even visible leadership for the protest movement. The Burmese people seem near to sweeping away the one-party
LEAD: Clattering in toward central Gdansk from Nowy Port to the northwest, the No. 10 tram lurches along right under the sooty brick walls and idle, rusty cranes of the Lenin Shipyard.

LEAD: The Steel Heddle Manufacturing Company, a producer of textile mill supplies based in Greenville, S.C., said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $105 a share by an investor group led by its senior management. The $75 million leveraged buyout is subject to the execution of a definitive agreement and requires shareholder approval.
LEAD: Resorts International Inc. adjourned a special stockholders meeting today because not enough votes had been cast to approve Merv Griffin's offer to acquire the gaming and real estate company.

LEAD: Tons of food, clothing, blankets and other aid continued to flow into the region today despite heavy rains that slowed relief operations after a strong earthquake that struck last Sunday. Doctors from Britain, Japan and France joined the effort to treat the injured and prevent epidemics from breaking out as the rains flooded many neighborhoods in Biratnagar, Nepal's second-largest city.

LEAD: Horse racing is a game in which human will is not supposed to matter. The race may not always go to the swift but, as Damon Runyon said, that's the way to bet it. The best horse usually wins, racing luck evens out in the long run, and the best jockeys are simply the ones who ride the best horses.

LEAD: A Federal Court of Appeals has rightly upheld contempt citations against the city of Yonkers and four of its councilmen for refusing to remedy decades of official racial discrimination. It's possible the city will now take the case to the U.S. Supreme Court - thus solidifying its dubious reputation as a national symbol of resistance to racial progress.

LEAD: The wreckage of a Long Island Rail Road train that was hit by a commuter train that had derailed Thursday night in Huntington. Yesterday, thousands of commuters were forced to find other routes as the railroad scrambled to repair damaged tracks.

LEAD: Residents of two towns on the edge of this park were warned today that they might have to evacuate because of a 30,000-acre forest fire. Inside the park, rangers shepherded convoys of tourists down roads otherwise closed by fires burning nearly 20 percent of the park.
LEAD: American officials here have challenged assertions from Washington that the Government of Panama has stepped up harassment of United States military personnel and their families.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: British film censors, rejecting demands of some church leaders, decided Thursday to allow Martin Scorcese's film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' to be shown without cuts.

LEAD: A judge ordered the seizing of jewelry and other luxury items today that Maria DeSillers is reported to have purchased with some of the $690,000 donated by strangers for her dying son's liver transplants.

LEAD: The leader of New York City's largest police union yesterday defended the actions of police officers during the clash with demonstrators at Tompkins Square Park earlier this month, and predicted that most of the 111 brutality charges filed against the police would be found invalid.
LEAD: Bernard J. Meislin, a corporate lawyer, died of pancreatic cancer Aug. 17 at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 60 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: The captain of an American warship is being permanently relieved of his command and has been ordered to prepare for a court-martial because of his failure to rescue a boatload of Vietnamese refugees, Pentagon officials said today.
LEAD: The revived Mets rolled in from California last night and opened a nine-game homestand with fierce pitching, outrageous good fortune and a 3-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

LEAD: One of the longest criminal trials in the United States ended abruptly today with the acquittal of 20 defendants accused of making up the entire membership of the Lucchese crime family in New Jersey.

LEAD: Interco Inc. said it had begun discussions with third parties, including commercial banks, about alternatives to a hostile takeover offer of $70 a share from the Rales brothers of Washington. Interco has rejected the $2.53 billion bid by City Capital Associates, a company controled by Steven and Mitchell

LEAD: A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said tonight that the group had decided to declare the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip independent and to form a government in exile for the territories.
LEAD: The Yankees' game against the Angels began too late to be included in this edition.
LEAD: It was a tableau meant to show just how well the new campaign was doing.

LEAD: Last summer, the Beaux Arts Trio underwent a personnel change that was, to all appearances, odd. Its founding cellist, Bernard Greenhouse, had retired, and rather than disband the ensemble, the remaining members - Isidore Cohen, the violinist, and Menahem Pressler, the pianist - decided to find a replacement.
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: The first third of the trumpeter Don Cherry's set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night was filled with musical hemming and hawing: the group's tenor saxophonist, James Clay, who had Mr. Cherry's trumpet, hadn't appeared. Jazz is about improvisation, so the group, made up of members of Ornette Coleman's early, radical, ground-breaking group -Charlie Haden on bass and Billy

LEAD: President Reagan's allergist has determined that there has been no essential change in his sensitivity to pollen, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today. The President, who receives weekly shots to control the allergy, has been undergoing a series of annual checkups during his August vacation.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is using surveillance and an unfounded investigation in an effort to intimidate the attorneys for 311 Hispanic agents who have charged the bureau with discrimination in a lawsuit, the lawyers have asserted.

LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that the financier Marvin L. Warner cannot avoid paying $22 million in restitution stemming from the failure of Home State Savings Bank, as he was ordered to do by an Ohio court.
LEAD: For those students who thought their lack of money made college an impossible dream, there is good news: funds are available, even at this late date.
LEAD: Two youths have been charged in the slaying of a man who was stabbed to death in Central Park Monday night during a fight with a group of about 20 teen-agers, the police said.

LEAD: The Entwistle Company said it had raised its stake in Frequency Electronics Inc., a maker of precision timing equipment, to 8.2 percent from 5.6 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Entwistle, a maker of insulated wire, said it had bought 132,800 Frequency shares on the open market for $10.31 a share.
LEAD: A marathon jazz-radio broadcast devoted to the saxophonists Charlie Parker and Lester Young continues through Tuesday at 1 A.M. on WKCR-FM, (89.9).

LEAD: International 2-4, 26 Two brothers arrested in Sweden have admitted working for the Hungarian intelligence service, Swedish officials said. The Hungarian-born brothers were arrested when Western officials broke up a spy ring. Page 1 A growing sense of futility in Gdansk has set in as a strike continues at the Lenin Shipyard.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 1943 decision in West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette, declaring unconstitutional a state law that required students to salute the American flag and recite the Pledge of Allegiance. Justice Robert H. Jackson wrote the opinion.

LEAD: The Yankees will allow John Candelaria to decide whether he can pitch despite a sore right knee, but they have apparently told the left-hander that the option portion of his two-year contract will be renewed only if he agrees to continue working.

LEAD: To help prevent art forgeries, Ioan G. Crihan, an engineer in New York City, has developed a radioactive ''fingerprint'' that is to be placed on valuable works. Mr. Crihan's procedure calls for mixing a radioactive isotope with a resin and planting a speck of the material on the painting or sculpture.

LEAD: An independent prosecutor said today that she would not seek criminal charges against a former senior Justice Department official who had been accused of misleading Congress in 1983 about the handling of Environmental Protection Agency documents.
LEAD: Israel closed the offices of Palestinian unions representing doctors, lawyers and other West Bank professionals today, saying the groups had begun associating with ''terrorist organizations.''

LEAD: A father-and-son team won a patent this week for a tool to clear human arteries of plaque, a primary cause of heart disease.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, who last week proposed a new-fangled manure catcher to solve a problem at the tail of the carriage horses in Central Park, revealed yesterday that he has an old-fashioned idea for a problem at their heads: straw hats to keep them cool.

LEAD: The Cetus Corporation of Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week for a new form of the anti-cancer drug, interleukin-2, or IL-2. Company officials believe the new compound, which entered human medical trials in April, can be administered in lower doses and with fewer side effects than the existing version of IL-2.

LEAD: Thousands of people today paid their last respects to the Pittsburgh Steelers' founder, Art Rooney Sr., who died Thursday. Rooney, who was 87 years old, died of complications of a stroke he suffered last week.

LEAD: On Aug. 2 the City of Yonkers and four Councilmen were held in contempt of court for refusing to approve part of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. Following are the requirements of the housing order and the actions taken against the city for its refusal to approve them. The Consent
LEAD: Interest rates were little changed in credit markets yesterday. Securities dealers said a combination of too much apathy and too many vacations kept the prices of debt securities steady.

LEAD: ''Once the Yonkers City Council approved the terms of the Consent Judgment, the Council became obligated to carrying out its commitments. If a member of the Council is unwilling to abide by such commitments, his option is to decline to serve on the body that is bound, not to act in defiant disregard of the commitments and the federal court judgment that memorializes them.
LEAD: The Silence in the Garden By William Trevor 204 pages. Viking. $17.95.
LEAD: Two questions that chess players ask themselves instinctively, but that bridge players often forget, are ''Why did my opponent do what he just did?'' and ''What is he up to?''

LEAD: Bolstered by the biggest increase in wages in seven months, Americans' personal incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July. The pace of consumer spending slowed in part because fewer people bought automobiles.

LEAD: The jockey Steve Cauthen fell and was knocked unconscious by two horses while racing yesterday in the Country Club Hotels Handicap at the Goodwood race course in Chichester, England, but he was not believed to be seriously injured. A spokesman at St. Richard's Hospital said that an examination revealed no broken bones, but that Cauthen would be kept overnight for observation.

LEAD: Greg Norman reacting as his putt dropped in for an eagle on the second hole yesterday in the second round of the World Series of Golf in Akron, Ohio. Mike Reid and Ian Baker-Finch shared the lead. (AP) Page 46.
LEAD: A Queens man was charged yesterday in the stabbing to death of a pizza deliverer in a midtown building two weeks ago.

LEAD: At a time when people are grumbling about the quality of small electric appliances, many manufacturers are not listening. Or so it seems, judging by the flimsy toasters, corn poppers, hair dryers and other disposable appliances that have given plastic and tin a bad name.
LEAD: Talks between North and South Korea ended in a deadlock today, with the two sides saying they had no plans to resume meetings until after the Olympic Games in Seoul are over in October.
LEAD: Macmillan Inc. said today that it had rejected the $2.1 billion takeover offer from Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, calling it inadequate.

LEAD: Poland's leaders today proposed direct negotiations with representatives of ''different social groups'' and with ''workers' representatives'' to defuse the labor confontations shaking the country.
LEAD: A couple whose hard-luck stories netted them up to $200 an hour from good Samaritans were apartment managers who moonlighted as confidence artists, the authorities said Thursday.

LEAD: The peace talks between Iran and Iraq ran into potentially serious trouble today when an old dispute resurfaced between the two countries over the ownership of a waterway, diplomats and United Nations officials said.

LEAD: Immigrants having trouble getting work because employment of illegal aliens is prohibited are now finding it even harder because of a Federal crackdown on their makeshift hiring halls: street corners.
LEAD: A black union organizer and opponent of apartheid who was detained without charge for 26 months died in a hospital today, three days after collapsing in his prison cell, the police said.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had arranged to merge nine more insolvent saving institutions with healthy ones. It said it had committed almost $1 billion in assistance to the transactions.

LEAD: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Thursday, about the export of microwave ovens to 11 European countries, incorrectly described the plan. The exporter is the Sharp Electronics Corporation, the United States operation of the Sharp Corporation of Japan, and the ovens will be American-made.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from the ruling by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on appeals by the City of Yonkers and four City Council members held in contempt for refusing to adopt legislation needed for a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. The unanimous opinion was written by Judge Jon O.

LEAD: Canadian scientists announced a program today for testing people at risk of developing Huntington's disease, the devastating and fatal brain condition that usually goes undiagnosed until symptoms show up in adulthood.
LEAD: An eye surgeon has developed what he calls ''liquid sunglasses'' - eye drops that absorb 98 percent of the sun's ultraviolet rays without affecting vision.

LEAD: William M. Bradt, the embattled chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, resigned late Thursday after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission found he had acted in an inappropriate fashion in some exchange matters.

LEAD: Carlos Morton's musical comedy ''The Garden'' (''El Jardin''), which the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater has been performing at locations around New York this month, is just the sort of production we have come to expect from the exuberant street theater company. Loosely based on the story of Adam and Eve, the show is a freewheeling mixture of domestic farce and political allegory.

LEAD: Stacey J. Moritz and David M. Brodsky, partners in the New York law firm of Schulte Roth & Zabel, were married last night at the Water Club in New York. Judge Jose Cabranes of Federal District Court in New Haven officiated.

LEAD: Tim Belcher, a rookie, won his seventh straight decision and a two-run double by John Shelby highlighted a five-run fourth inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-2.

LEAD: Richard E. Merriam, a former Chicago alderman who lost to Richard J. Daley in a 1955 mayoral race and then became an adviser to three Presidents, died Thursday of a heart attack at his Chicago home. He was 69 years old.
LEAD: Tramps, the longtime blues and rock club at 125 East 15th Street, will close at its present location tonight after the last set, by Otis Rush.

It said the deadline had passed for a group of 700 people who said that they had been injured by asbestos to appeal to the United States Supreme Court to review the plan. The group's objections to the plan had previously been dismissed by lower courts.

LEAD: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bay Shore, L.I., Mary Eleanor Murphy, a daughter of Mrs. John J. Murphy of Bay Shore and the late Dr. Murphy, was married yesterday to Robert L. Gaumer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Gaumer of Chambersburg, Pa. The Rev. Charles A. Lennon performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Teachers throughout Massachusetts continue to lead children in the Pledge of Allegiance each day, on the voluntary basis supported by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

LEAD: The Giants, who seemed so dominating in three previous games, closed their exhibition schedule this evening by taking a battering from the Cleveland Browns in a 17-13 defeat at Cleveland Stadium.

LEAD: Dr. Lionel Deckle McLean, a dental surgeon and the first black to serve as president of the New Jersey Dental Association, died of respiratory failure last Saturday at University Hospital in Newark. He was 88 years old and lived in Jersey City.

LEAD: In a city that exalts successful artists in the fashion of rock stars, Jean Michel Basquiat seemed blessed. When he burst onto the art scene in 1981, his paintings of anguished figures were hailed by some critics as works of genius. Admirers besieged him at Manhattan's hottest night clubs. Sales of his art grossed millions of dollars.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the Italian auto maker Maserati said today that they had reduced the scope of their joint efforts, setting the stage for a complete severing of relations.

LEAD: Ten days after he announced that he was leaving Loyola of Chicago because of academic problems and that he was investigating the possibility of attending Oklahoma or Nevada-Las Vegas, Kenny Miller changed his mind. On Thursday, the 20-year-old sophomore, a 6-foot-9-inch center who last season became the first freshmen to win a National Collegiate Athletic Association rebounding title, told Chuck Schwarz, the Loyola athletic director, he had decided to return to Loyola even though he will be academically ineligible to play basketball during the fall semester.

LEAD: The head of a diagnostic laboratory in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with illegally disposing of medical waste, including two blood vials containing the Hepatitis B virus. He was also charged with creating a risk of serious injury to others.
LEAD: Said Aouita of Morocco easily captured the mile today, wrapping up the men's overall season title in the Grand Prix final, the last major international tuneup before the Seoul Olympics.

LEAD: Miles from the intense emotions of their campuses, nearly a week before another college football game will take place, the Aggies of Texas A&M and the Huskers of Nebraska attempted to define the significance of the sixth Kickoff Classic.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Anchor Savings Bank said yesterday that it would cut back on some of its non-mortgage lending activities. Donald Thomas, Anchor's chairman, said the savings bank would no longer arrange auto loans through car dealers and was de-emphasizing commercial lending. Anchor, based in Hewlett, L.I., said it would make new commercial loans only to its current customers.

LEAD: A question in the News Quiz last Saturday incorrectly described the succession to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan. After General Zia's death on Aug. 17, Gulam Ishaq Khan, the leader of the Senate, became Acting President under the Pakistani Constitution.

LEAD: Scotty's Inc., a manufacturer of building materials and retailer of hand tools, said yesterday that its chairman, James W. Sweet, had retired. The company also said its president, Dennis Stults, had resigned to pursue other interests.

LEAD: A kidnapping and attempted-murder trial has been postponed after the defendant's lawyer said it would hurt the Oakland Athletics' pennant chances and harm the career of his client's brother, the relief pitcher Dennis Eckersley.

LEAD: Though Personal Finance 101 may not be in the curriculum, the first year of college can be a test for students and their families on such matters as bank accounts, credit cards and insurance policies.

LEAD: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway Dances'' has a new name: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway.''

LEAD: Texas may be the capital of sick savings and loan institutions, but the Northeast is by no means exempt from the problem. The number of troubled institutions in the region is growing, and with interest rates rising that trend will continue.

LEAD: The city and the N.A.A.C.P. today settled a challenge to an agreement over a non-discriminatory public housing plan worked out in June between the Boston Housing Authority and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

LEAD: While Congress mulls yet another omnibus drug bill, street gangs spreading violence and addiction roam free in much of urban America. Angry voters are asking local officials to take effective action now.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 10.

LEAD: Greg Windsperger, who was the jumping coach of the United States ski team during the Olympic Winter Games of 1984 and 1988, has resigned, team officials announced yesterday. According to John Bower, the Nordic program director for the ski team, Windsperger expected to begin work soon for Airtex Industries in Minneapolis, where he has been hired as general manager of the consumer-products division.

LEAD: Talks on a timetable for withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola were suspended today to allow negotiators to consult their governments. The negotiators, from Angola, Cuba and South Africa, agreed to reconvene here in the week of Sept. 5. Earlier, the parties had agreed to set the timetable by Sept.

LEAD: The Atomergic Chemetals Corporation of Plainview, L.I., has patented what it contends is the bitterest flavor in the world. ''It's vile,'' boasted Mel Blum, the compound's co-inventor and president of Atomergic. ''It has a lingering, terrible taste.''

LEAD: Little League Hawaiian Team in Final: A team from a small Hawaiian city has won a pair of one-run games to earn a game against a Taiwanese powerhouse in the Little League World Series championship game today in Williamsport, Pa.

LEAD: President P. W. Botha and his wife, Elize, trying out a marimba as they visited the Crossroads squatter community. Hundreds of cheering, flag-waving black children greeted Mr. Botha, who traveled to the community to underscore the Government's ambitious program to rebuild the camp after it was devastated in civil unrest two years ago.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An obituary Aug. 18 of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. omitted two survivors. They are his brothers, James, of Santa Ana, Calif., and Elliott, of Indian Wells, Calif.

LEAD: Two Hungarian-born Swedish brothers who were arrested this week when Western officials broke up a major espionage ring have admitted working for the Hungarian intelligence service, the Swedish authorities said today.
LEAD: Vice President Bush offered politically conservative East Texas a scathing attack on Michael S. Dukakis today, alleging that his Democratic rival was hiding a litany of ''liberal'' faults.
LEAD: * Air France will introduce direct service on Fridays between San Juan, P.R., and Paris, starting Nov. 4.

LEAD: Joanne Brackeen, a pianist, is to perform tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway (718-638-5000). The concert is free with museum admission, which is $3 for adults and $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12 years old.

LEAD: Thirty years ago, the violinist and conductor Paul Wolfe founded a string quartet and began a series of concerts at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan. The pull of other musical activities eventually led to the disbanding of the ensemble, although the chamber series would become a community fixture.
LEAD: James Traub quotes the judge in the Beech-Nut trial as saying that it was ''unusual for a corporate executive to do time for consumer fraud'' (''Into the Mouths of Babes,'' July 24).
LEAD: MANY stocks have come down to earth since the market peaked on Aug. 25 of last year, but few have made a thud as loud as the Digital Equipment Corporation.

LEAD: The Texas Aggies were not going to take this game sitting down. They never do. The Twelfth Man, by the thousands, stood throughout the evening in the north end of Giants Stadium. The ''Aggie War Hymn'' carried through the humid air in the Meadowlands.

LEAD: Lynda J. Gould, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce I. Gould of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening to Steven Rand DeLott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart C. DeLott of Great Neck. Rabbi Mordecai Waxma, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel, performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel.

LEAD: Solomon A. Klein, the former chief counsel to the Judicial Inquiry on Professional Conduct of the New York State Supreme Court, died of cancer of the prostate Friday at his summer home in Shelter Island, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Long Boat Key, Fla.
LEAD: COWARD shoes, Champion batteries, Ansell medical gloves, Lifestyle condoms, Telectronics pacemakers.

LEAD: The first shots erupted at 12:23 A.M. when a group of six men surrounded two others, killing one and wounding the second. An hour later, a few blocks away, gunfire from a passing car raked a group of 25 listening to rap music on a streetcorner, wounding seven. Police recovered cartridges from military assault rifles.

Knight Jr. of St. Louis. The Rev. Ross Doyel, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Freddie Fourie, performed the ceremony at the Community Church (United Church of Christ).

LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHERS who like to try new films, the way some people like to try on new clothes, have been busy lately. Within the last 12 months the parade of chic and stylish emulsions has gone on practically nonstop, joined by such model revamping as the relabeling of Kodak's VR-G color-print films as Kodacolor Gold.

LEAD: Reagan Administration officials are engaged in a bitter internal debate over whether to appeal a Federal court decision that upholds the right of the Palestine Liberation Organization to keep an observer mission at the headquarters of the United Nations in New York.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH some initiatives now under way could slightly improve conditions along New Jersey's coastline by next year, marine scientists and others say the worst of the state's coastal pollution problems will persist for years, or even decades.
LEAD: East meets West and old meets young in an innovative program here that has become a model for other cities in helping elderly refugees break out of isolation and restore self-esteem.

LEAD: Troy Aikman had completed 6 of 7 passes for 131 yards against a defense that would be in two national championship games. He was trying to overcome Miami's 14-7 lead with 9 minutes 18 seconds left in the first half. Then the classic dropback passer was sacked by Jerome Brown, a defensive tackle, and Aikman left Oklahoma's fourth game of the 1985 season with a broken left leg.
LEAD: Afghan guerrilla forces today sharply accelerated attacks on Kabul and on troops of the Soviet-backed Government within 10 miles of the capital.

LEAD: It's ''Dallas,'' Delhi-style. In the last few days, a single story has tantalized newspaper readers, radio listeners and television viewers across northern India with a scenario that mixes not only scandal, murder, sex and class, but high-level politics as well.

LEAD: THE TUNNEL. By Ernesto Sabato. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $4.95.) Ernesto Sabato is best known for the second of his three novels, ''On Heroes and Tombs,'' a massive, intricate chronicle of murder and passion set in the Argentina of the 1950's. In his 1948 debut novel, ''The Tunnel,'' these themes are already on display, but in a simplified, almost fabulistic form.

LEAD: Cesar Chavez is eating again. The 61-year-old president of the United Farm Workers of America broke his 36-day fast last week surrounded by thousands of supporters of his boycott of California table grapes. Twenty years ago, Mr. Chavez ended a 25-day fast by sharing a Roman Catholic Communion with Senator Robert F.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time, when power was cheap and everyone thought progress meant using more of it, utility companies used to advise architects and developers on ways to raise electricity consumption in new buildings. The theory was that workers could be more productive in buildings with more artificial lighting and with cooling systems built without regard for the sun and other natural factors.

LEAD: TIME was when ''folk art'' meant work made in innocence of industrial reality and intended to serve a purpose - furniture, trade signs, portraits and the like. Now, the term covers just about anything made by the untutored and largely for self-expression. Purists grind their teeth in vain, but naivete for its own sake is a business that is here to stay, and no one person has done more to make it so than Herbert Wade Hemphill Jr., part of whose collection is on view at the Noyes

LEAD: In recent years, attention has focused on the negatives as many tennis players have come to view the United States Open as a necessary evil, such as visiting the dentist at least once a year. There are the jets thundering overhead, trains rumbling nearby, boisterous crowds, scheduling quirks and sticky, late-summer New York City weather, all of which make the Open unique, but also the most disconcerting of the Grand Slam tournaments.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''The Train From the Plane, European Style'' (Travel Advisory, June 19) listed 10 cities in Europe that have direct train service from the main airport to downtown. Included was information on London/ Gatwick and Paris/Orly.

LEAD: Q. My patio consists of a concrete base over which is a layer of pebbles. The pebbles are cemented in place with epoxy and form a layer a little over 1 1/2 inches thick. Some of the pebbles are starting to loosen, leaving pockets or holes that are uncomfortable to walk on. What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

Robert Buckwalter, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A front-page article July 24 on the Presidential race and an accompanying map incorrectly summarized 1984 election results. Walter F. Mondale received 40 percent or more of the 1984 major-party Presidential vote in 18 states; he received 37.93 percent in Indiana, 39.64 percent in Kentucky, 39.80 percent in Georgia and 39.98 percent in Missouri.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN ''Murder by the Book,'' now being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Company in East Farmingdale, a vitriolic book critic and successful author of mystery thrillers has an argument with his estranged wife, who then brandishes a gun and shoots him.
LEAD: One of the Navy's highest-ranking admirals has asked to retire after being disciplined for unspecified ''improprieties,'' a spokesman for the Navy said today.
LEAD: HE gave it the old college try, but since he's never been to college, there was hardly any shame when Alonzo Mourning was cut yesterday from the United States Olympic basketball team.

LEAD: HAVING city and suburban youngsters train for health-care careers together, study marine sciences and take field trips everywhere from farms to city skyscrapers are among the first proposals for ways to help break down the racial dividers between school districts across Connecticut. They will not be the last.
LEAD: Eugene S. Daniell Jr., a champion of the underdog who was known for his oratory in the state Legislature, died Friday at a local hospital. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: WHEN John Inglis Hall's ''Fishing a Highland Stream'' (Viking, $16.95) surfaced in a carton of books sent to me for possible review, I began to scan it idly and discovered that I had been neglecting a gem.

LEAD: For years, watching helplessly as the rising power of the cocaine barons spread violence and corruption along the Andean backbone of Latin America, United States drug experts shuddered at the thought that Brazil would someday be drawn into the narcotics trade.

LEAD: ON the Metro a chic young woman, in black leather pants and reading the latest Sagan, sits near a Tunisian woman in sky-blue yashmak with her husband, clad in djellaba, and five children. I express surprise to her husband that she wears the veil in Paris. ''Why not?'' he laughs, flashing gold teeth.

LEAD: AS fans across the country look forward to the beginning of the U.S. Open tennis championships tomorrow, members of the industry are pondering the future of a sport rife with factional disputes. Since 1968, when professional players were allowed to compete in all tournaments, dozens of not-for-profit and for-profit institutions have staked out claims on the game.

LEAD: TWO national developers are building an 863-unit, mixed-income, rental apartment complex here in a rundown waterfront district of decaying warehouses. The site is in one of the last developable areas in a city with a vacancy rate of 2 percent or under.

LEAD: For all the effects of television on the country's political conscience at the time and for all the wide-screen, technicolor power of ''Platoon'' and ''Full Metal Jacket'' now, it is still the black and whites that best call up the visual memories everyone over a certain age has of America's longest war.
LEAD: Frank J. Prial might have suggested, in his article ''Half Is Better Than None'' (Wine, July 24), that readers save some of those empty half-bottles for use later on.
LEAD: THE worst of this summer's searing heat may be over, but the concerns that it raised about a global warming trend - known as the greenhouse effect - seem certain to linger.

LEAD: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: Last week in Seattle, 400 union and non-union workers bought WFI Industries, a privately held tugboat manufacturer that had been in financial difficulty for more than two years. The purchase was made using an employee stock option plan financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Donald Liddel, the leader of the Inlandboatmen's Union of the Pacific, will assume the post of chairman and chief executive of the company, renamed Unimar Industries Inc.

LEAD: Jeanne Clare Feron's article [ ''Offering Temporary Care for the Elderly,'' July 31 ] will go a long way toward informing care givers about where they can get relief from their exhausting responsibilities. Your long list of day-care programs provides invaluable information for thousands of people who feel they have nowhere to turn to for help.

LEAD: The rule for boxers seems simple enough: Inside the ring, it pays to punch; outside the ring, it costs. Mike Tyson apparently forgot it last week. The heavyweight champion was in an all-night Harlem clothing store in the wee hours when in walked Mitch (Blood) Green, a rather contentious fighter whom Tyson had defeated in 1986.
LEAD: The first-place Mets are first in home runs, second in runs batted in, and fourth in batting average in the National League.
LEAD: A taxi driver was found shot to death in Upper Manhattan early yesterday after what detectives think was a robbery, the police said.

LEAD: To the Editor: As an old South Pacific buff, I was pleased to see a remote and distant shadowline of nigh-forgotten islands reappear in print. Thanks in no small part to the illustrious Richard Tregaskis and his epic ''Guadalcanal Diary,'' the very name of Guadalcanal must long remind the world of the legendary feat of arms performed there by our forces.

LEAD: Plowing through ''The Commodore Recordings, Volume One'' (Mosaic Records, 197 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford, Conn.,06902; albums only) is a bit like exploring ''Moby Dick'': it's stuffed with all sorts of odds and ends, it takes a long time to get through it, and by the time the experience is over, it's changed you.
LEAD: West German politicians have acknowledged a catalogue of errors that contributed to the deaths of two teen-age hostages in a 54-hour episode last week.

LEAD: SOMEWHERE in the minds of a lot of busy, high-powered people there lurks a vision. The vision is of themselves, in pajamas or robe, in bed or sprawled in a capacious chair, reading and occasionally running to the refrigerator. Not in the evening, but all day long. And the all-day-long, for goodness sake, is not a day off or a weekend, but a weekday, a business day.

LEAD: RARE MANUSCRIPTS ''The Medieval Book,'' an exhibition of rare Middle Ages and Renaissance manuscripts from the Yale University collection, may be seen through Nov. 1 at the Beinecke Library on the Yale campus.

LEAD: Six bombs exploded in Northern Ireland's two main cities and demonstrators fought with the police to protest the extradition of a convicted Irish Republican Army guerrilla, the police said today.

LEAD: Mike Scott left the Houston Astros' game with the Pittsburg Pirates tonight becuase of a strained left hamstring. Scott suffered an injury to the same hamstring on June 21 and was placed on the 21-day disabled list. Scott (13-4) reinjured the hamstring while pitching in the top of the first inning tonight.

LEAD: THE MAN IN MY LIFE placed his hands lightly on my temples, stepped back a half-pace and said, ''Your face is dear to me.'' Such a world of tender scrutiny was implied in those words that I knew I would remember them long after assorted ''you're beautifuls'' had been consigned to the dustbin of personal history.

LEAD: THE slaughter in Burundi this month of thousands of members of two warring tribes is a reminder that, for many Africans, the most threatening kind of ethnic hatred is black against black.

LEAD: The latest round of negotiations toward peace in Angola and Namibia has ended with a narrowing of differences but no breakthrough on the crucial issue of a timetable for the withdrawal of South African troops from Namibia and of Cuban forces from Angola.

LEAD: PROBABLY the oldest mystery to vex mankind is what, if anything, occurs after death. For a decade, Kenneth Ring, a psychology professor and researcher at the University of Connecticut, has looked into the question through the near-death experiences of others.

LEAD: IT is getting hard to remember when memory was cheap. Prices for computer memory chips have climbed in recent months as 256K D-RAM's have been in short supply. That chip, more formally known as the 256-kilobit dynamic random access memory chip, is the most common memory chip used in personal computers.

LEAD: Local governments in New York would be allowed to negotiate the interest rate on new bond issues rather than selling the bonds at interest rates set through competitive bidding, under terms of a bill the New York Assembly is expected to consider next month.

LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said today that Yasir Arafat, the Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is ''playing with'' the idea of setting up a government in exile to represent Arabs in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: IT is safe to say that the Hunt brothers of Dallas have never recovered from the collapse of the silver market in 1979 and 1980. Neither has the metal. Silver soared from $9 an ounce in September 1979 to $50 an ounce in January 1980, only to collapse to $10 within two months; the debacle was relived last week.

LEAD: Ever since the tumultuous 1960's, when artists as unlike as Andy Warhol and Robert Smithson helped broaden the boundaries of art by challenging its accepted hierarchies, the medium in which an artist chooses to work has seemed less important than what that artist makes of it. Today it is possible - as by and large it was not in the 40's and 50's - to work with a variety of materials concurrently, and to draw directly from the supermarket of everyday life.

LEAD: FOREIGN MATTER. By Robert MacLean. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Not all the mentoring goes on in the business world. Here we have an aspiring humorist receiving instructions from the dead - in this case, P. G. Wodehouse. Bounteous internal evidence in this first novel proclaims that Robert MacLean has closeted himself with a stock of Wodehouse's most representative works, from which he has abstracted archetypal Wodehousian characters and plot devices.

Whitey Herzog held both jobs at the same time, and then he readily relinquished the general manager's duties and continued managing. Lou Piniella fled the front office after seven months and later returned to the dugout.

LEAD: The face suggests a man encumbered by imperial burdens, and no doubt he was. Among the 22 ancient Roman busts now on display at the Emory University Museum of Art and Archeology, this smoothly carved rendering of an older man with close-cropped hair, slightly turned-down lips and heavy brow might well strike a viewer as the sculptural embodiment of authority.

LEAD: New holding cells needed for dozens of defendants awaiting court appearances in lower Manhattan have been completed for more than a year, but they stand empty because their special locking and alarm systems do not work properly.

LEAD: THE Music Theater of Connecticut is getting on the bookless bandwagon. With its current revue, ''Jukebox Saturday Night,'' the fledgling but nomadic theater, which has moved from Fairfield to Wilton in less than a year, is manifesting the latest trend in New York City's musical theater: compilation musicals, or shows that consist of hit tunes from past decades.

LEAD: The July 24 article ''Checking Out Houses on the Market,'' was undoubtedly an ego trip for the three firms written about, but did little to inform the public about the all-important issue of credentials. New York State Education Laws dictate that only licensed professional engineers or registered architects, may serve the public in the evaluation of mechanical and structural systems.

LEAD: RESTAURANT explorers on the prowl for the unexpected will be in their glory at Riverhead's Peconic House. It is an almost total surprise. The name surprises. It says seafood but is Italian. The menu surprises. It reads like standard cliche Italian-American, but the cooking here is anything but routine.

LEAD: AS a growing number of elderly Americans become more affluent and live longer, healthier lives, many are finding themselves more in need of companionship than long-term custodial care. An increasing number of real estate developers are responding to this demand by building group residences that, for those who can afford them, combine the convenience of a hotel with the community spirit of summer camp.

LEAD: The first condominium community in Connecticut to surround and own a lake is being built in Torrington on the shores of a brass company's conceit. Stillwater Pond was created in 1911 by the Coe Brass Company to insure a supply of fresh water for its growing business. The Naugatuck River was dammed, and Stillwater grew to lake-size dimensions - a mile-and-a-half long and 700 feet wide.

LEAD: DEATH TAKES THE STAGE by Donald Ward (St. Martin's, $15.95) is an unusual first novel. Hard to pin down, it is a combination of tragedy and a kind of comedy that often verges on farce. It also has moments of terror, including a Grand Guignol scene that will be hard to forget. It pokes good-natured fun at the little-theater movement of Los Angeles and the egocentric types who slave there hoping for the big break.

LEAD: THE debt burden of the less developed countries can no longer be treated just as a banking problem. More fundamentally, it is a trade problem, a jobs problem and a geopolitical problem. LEAD: Behind the green plywood at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 57th Street, workers for Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company are preparing for Veteran's Day weekend and the parade of armored cars that will arrive at the door. At 3 P.M. on Thursday, Nov. 10, the Manufacturers Hanover branch down the block at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street will close, and movers will use the long weekend to bring teller computers and 2,500 safe deposit boxes - in sections that weigh a ton -to the new location, which will open the following Monday.

Take cuttings of geraniums, impatiens and begonias to root and grow indoors as house plants.

But in popular music, everything conspires to shrink that distance, and fast.

LEAD: TUAREG CALLIGRAPHY Some 50 pieces of calligraphy in the obscure language of the Tuareg, a Berber people of the Sahara, will go on exhibition Thursday through Oct. 2 at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. Ashe was black and he was a tennis player, a combination that made many people uneasy in a sport in which everyone wore white.

LEAD: A WOMAN ON PAPER: Georgia O'Keeffe. By Anita Pollitzer. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $12.95.) By showing Alfred Stieglitz some drawings by Georgia O'Keeffe, Anita Pollitzer brought about what is perhaps the most storied conjunction in American art. Pollitzer's account of that incident in January 1916 anchors this epistolary memoir-cum-biography, written more than 30 years ago but unpublished until now because O'Keeffe, who died in 1986, refused to approve the manuscript.

LEAD: JUST FLASHY PACKAGING, smoke and mirrors, glitz without substance - at least that's the skeptic's view of the cosmetics business. LEAD: CAN two six-man teams go to battle without anyone on the bench? Apparently not. Their opponents moved one table in the opposite direction to the boards, before the imp scores were calculated.

LEAD: Reflecting on 100 years of royal Court history, one could be forgiven for misquoting Oscar Wilde. To be responsible for one theatrical renaissance might be luck. LEAD: For most of this century, birds and Roger Tory Peterson have enjoyed a kind of symbiotic relationship, each profiting by the other's company. He has introduced more birds to more people than anyone else - and the birds, in turn, have made him the best known of living naturalists. Today he celebrates his 80th birthday, or ''birdsday,'' in the bird watcher's play on words.

LEAD: Hugh John Lofting's ''Story of Doctor Dolittle,'' the first of 12 adventures starring the bluff and rotund physician from Puddleby-on-the-Marsh who loved animals and learned to speak their language, was published in 1920. LEAD: THE sending of United Nations peacekeeping forces to Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf and the possibility that other contingents will soon go to other unstable areas shows that the dispatch of soldiers is becoming an important function for the world organization.

LEAD: Wine in half-bottles (375 ml.) will mature faster than in full-bottles (750 ml.). This is caused primarily by oxygen permeating the cork in relatively greater proportion because of the smaller quantity of wine in the half-bottle. Thus, a young half-bottle may be more drinkable than its full-bottle counterpart.

In a day when inventors of flying machines often belonged among those who claimed to transmute lead into gold or to communicate with the dead, the Wright brothers had to convince the world that their Wright Flyer was indeed worth paying for.

LEAD: The Mets' incompetence at the plate can be attributed to the blatant impatience of their hitters. Most of them simply refuse to accept a walk and consequently they swing at first pitches and balls out of the strike zone when they're ahead of the count. The Mets are also guilty of overswinging, which could be because of their tremendous egos.

LEAD: The first permanent disposal center for household hazardous waste on the East Coast opened today in this Martha's Vineyard community. The center, financed by a $28,000 state grant, will hold household wastes like paints, solvents and pesticides from the six towns on the island. James Gutensohn, commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Management, said, ''We are reducing the threat to the water supply that stems from disposing of these wastes in a landfill.

LEAD: FOR Joseph Balestrieri, the new co-owner of the Lake Compounce Festival Park in Bristol, it was a bittersweet experience. Thousands of cars were trying to get into the amusement park, but for the most part, they were unable to move because of a huge traffic tieup.

LEAD: YANGTZE: Nature, History, and the River. By Lyman P. Van Slyke. (Addison-Wesley, $14.95.) The Yangtze River flows 3,900 miles through China from its glacial source at 20,000 feet on the Tibetan-Qinghai plateau to the East China Sea, watering regions where nearly 350 million Chinese live. Yet sections are so rugged that the world's third-longest river (after the Nile and the Amazon) was not navigated from source to mouth until 1986.

LEAD: IN CASE YOU DIDN'T know, the world's only full-sized replica of the Parthenon is in Nashville. It has been thus since 1897, when a plaster model of the great, columned temple was constructed, for some reason, as part of the city's centennial celebration. In the 1920's, the model was used to cast a permanent structure in concrete.

LEAD: Near the end of Jonathan Demme's acclaimed new farce, ''Married to the Mob,'' the undercover F.B.I. agent Mike Downey has a bad moment. LEAD: I KNEW that I was a child of the 60's, and that the world has changed a whole lot since I was 20. For I have been rather proud of the sensibility of my formative years.

LEAD: DEATH IS GRAY, AN ASHEN dusky gray. It comes as a fog, sometimes creeping in stealthily, other times dropping like a curtain. The eyes often register it first, drifting off to a distant horizon beyond mortal knowledge. Curiously, those who know death intimately will look not only in the eyes, but also at the fingernails.

LEAD: HOLLYHOCK ISLAND in Norwich once was the city's landfill and it lies 13 miles upriver from Long Island Sound. Its views include a junkyard and a sewage treatment plant and it seems to be an unlikely spot for a $50 million marina and office project.

LEAD: Interest rates headed higher in Europe, led by West Germany's central bank. The Bundesbank lifted its discount rate to 3.5 percent, from 3 percent, and similar increases were imposed in Britain, France, Switzerland, Austria, the Netherlands and Canada. The German move was accompanied by strong words from Karl Otto Pohl, the Bundesbank president, who said it was intended as an ''important signal'' to the world markets that Germany would act aggressively to curb further gains in the dollar's value.

LEAD: The sale of the Maxim's de Paris Hotel to a Hong Kong company for $127 million, a price that many experts call outrageously high, reflects a boomlet that is expected to add 3,000 hotel rooms in New York City this year.
LEAD: The frustration in the clubhouse has become commonplace. Players mope; the manager wrings his hands in distress. Nothing helps.

LEAD: TENNIS - especially tournaments featuring the grand old players - is increasingly being used as a promotional tool and a form of business entertainment. LEAD: A videotape made by the Navy has provided the public with its first close-up glimpse of the dramatic scene aboard the cruiser Vincennes during the incident in which it mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger plane, killing all 290 people aboard.

LEAD: After 30 years, Yves Saint Laurent can still create a collection that brings an audience to its feet and sums up, in the most perfect and superb way, the current international mood of fashion. LEAD: THE fire that swept an illegal social club last weekend, killing six people and injuring 33, raised a number of troubling questions. LEAD: What kind of film works a word like ''mangel-wurzel'' into the conversation? The kind of film that a lot of us secretly enjoy more than we should. LEAD: It will be possible this college football season for a defensive team to score during a conversion attempt. The defense can block a kick behind the line of scrimmage, recover the loose ball and return it the length of the field. Or it can return a kick that is deflected in midair. Or it can return an intercepted 2-point conversion pass, or a fumble caught in midair.

LEAD: * Japan's vehicle production rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July from a year earlier, the sixth straight month of year-to-year gains, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said. LEAD: A second day of calm weather aided firefighters in their battle against forest fires today, and near-freezing temperatures slowed flames in Montana.
LEAD: The Rev. Al Sharpton and 15 other people were arrested yesterday afternoon when they blocked traffic on the F. D .R. Drive for a few minutes during a march to protest racism by the police.

LEAD: Dan Quayle's legislative record reflects a solid conservative bent, but it could pose problems for him with farmers, senior citizens, women and others in the nation's heartland, where he is counted on to help the Republican ticket.

LEAD: ''Day fines,'' long used in Sweden and West Germany to punish criminals, have now been introduced to this country in an experiment in Staten Island. The concept offers promise for overworked American courts and city jails.

LEAD: Running winners can create problems for the defense even when there is no prospect of a squeeze or an end play. An illustration is the diagramed deal from a social game in Sydney, Australia. Sitting South was Tim Seres, who after three decades as the brightest star Down Under seems to have opted for retirement from tournament play.

LEAD: Ralston Chex Cereals has tapped Avrett, Free & Ginsberg as its advertising agency after a five-way race. The account billed about $13.5 million last year, according to Leading National Advertisers.

LEAD: As the University of Nebraska Cornhuskers approached the point of last season that would either satisfy an annual demand or create another disappointment, some uncharacteristic sounds were coming out of Lincoln.
LEAD: A sensor that clips onto an earlobe, fingertip or your chest can provide a digital readout of your heart rate while you exercise, and a new version can talk.
LEAD: Three more teen-agers have been charged with beating and stabbing a man to death in Central Park last week, the police said.
LEAD: In the closing weeks of a mostly miserable summer, the Yankees have suddenly discovered one more opponent in the American League East: themselves.
LEAD: A Federal judge is expected to decide tomorrow whether Eastern Airlines will be allowed to begin its curtailed September flight schedule.
LEAD: Striking nurses at six hospitals voted today to end a four-week walkout, approving a contract that will raise their pay three times over 34 months.

LEAD: Queenie A. McFarland, who was ac tive until two years ago in the manage-ment of Sweets seafood restaurant, a family business at Fulton and South Streets, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. She was 91 years old and lived in Caldwell, N.J.

LEAD: Richard J. Dennis, the multimillionare renowned for his prowess as a commodities trader, said today that he was quitting to concentrate on politics.

Pedro Guerrero, who was 12 for 28 in his first full week with the St. Louis Cardinals after being traded for John Tudor, was named National League player of the week.

LEAD: Q. Does a compass work on the Moon? A Theoretically, yes, but ''you wouldn't want to depend on getting back home using it,'' said John W. Dietrich, curator of lunar samples at the Johnson Space Center, Houston.

LEAD: The indictments involving college sports handed down by a Federal grand jury in Chicago last week focused on the dubious activities of three player agents. LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.7 percent in the first seven months of the year, to $4.66 billion, from $5.53 billion a year earlier, the Government reported today. Officials attributed the reduction to Korea's revaluation of the won. Korean merchandise exports to the United States rose 10.8 percent, to $11.39 billion, in the period, while imports from the United States surged by 41.5 percent, to $6.73 billion, the report said.

LEAD: Taxicab passengers headed for church can put an extra dollar in the collection plate or their pockets on Sundays as a result of a fare discount approved by the City Council on Monday. The discount was offered last week by the Red Bird Cab Company when it received approval for a rate increase, City Attorney Bryant Aldridge said.

LEAD: It is six months since the weekend of horror when Albert M. Mamedov called his Armenian neighbors to gather the children and come quickly because a mob was going door to door, hunting for Armenians.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mike Schmidt has a small but complete tear of the rotator cuff in his right shoulder, but the Philadelphia Phillies third baseman said today he will get a second and third medical opinion before deciding on his future.

LEAD: The three major television networks and the Hollywood studios that create most of their programming are joining in a coordinated attack against drinking and driving that will include dialogue in popular entertainment shows as well as public-service advertising.

LEAD: The Pentagon said today that six Americans were among those killed on Sunday when three Italian jets collided at an air show at the United States air base here and one plunged into the crowd in flames.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The index of leading indicators fell 0.8 percent in July, to a level below that of early spring. The drop in the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge was the steepest in eight months. Economists said the fall in the index, along with other recent data, seemed to suggest that the brisk economic conditions of recent months may be waning.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today announced the completion of a campaign to seize drugs that involved agencies from 30 nations, including Panama, whose de facto leader is under indictment in the United States on charges of narcotics smuggling.

LEAD: Sometime next year, the National Archives will make available to the public about 60 hours of President Nixon's White House tapes - the first such since 12 1/2 hours were entered into evidence in court trials, including cases concerning Watergate. More tapes will be made public in subsequent years.

LEAD: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.369 percent, up from 8.36 percent last week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A homeless former marine barricaded himself in historic Fort Vancouver Monday to protest what he said was a lack of help for troubled Vietnam veterans, then surrendered in exchange for a chance to talk to reporters.
LEAD: At times, the bureaucrats in charge of revising Pentagon buying practices in the wake of the latest scandal have seemed like physicians in a frenzy of exploratory surgery.

LEAD: The marriage of Jane Carpenter Watson, a registered nurse, and Walter Ronald Bailey, a partner in the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells, took place yesterday in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Fanny Erickson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: On the night after David Cone shut out the San Diego Padres on one hit, the Mets came up with a creative encore in Shea Stadium last night: Bob Ojeda shut out the Padres on six hits.
