LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: The United States said today that the Soviet Union had violated the Geneva accords on Afghanistan by sending aircraft from Soviet territory to bomb guerrilla positions inside Afghanistan.
LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday as volume remained at the extra-slow pace of recent days.

LEAD: * Mark IV Industries, New Haven, has filed suit against the Armtek Corp., accusing Armtek's board of misusing anti-takeover measures to prevent shareholders from determining whether they want to accept Mark IV's $44-a-share, or $500 million cash tender offer.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bergdorf Goodman said yesterday that it would open an additional store across the street from its base at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street. The building, at 745 Fifth Avenue, is the former home of F.A.O. Schwarz.
LEAD: Orders received by the nation's factories for manufactured goods fell sharply in July, pulled down by the biggest drop in military orders in more than four years.

LEAD: FOR Young & Rubicam, winning the $30 million House of Fraser account last week was a major coup. House of Fraser Ltd., owned by the Fayed family, is Britain's largest retail chain, with 65 department stores throughout the country. And it will be Y.&R.'s biggest account in Britain, surpassing British

LEAD: The University of Vermont, prodded by a tiny but restless number of students who are members of minority groups, is moving on several fronts to promote racial and cultural diversity on its 10,000-student campus here.

LEAD: There is usually not much of a breeze off the coast of San Diego at this time of the year. But try to tell that to Duncan MacLane, who was awash in a wall of water Monday aboard Stars & Stripes, the America's Cup defender.
LEAD: One of the area's largest inner-city medical centers announced today that it would close because it cannot pay its bills.

LEAD: An article yesterday about limits on new construction in Los Angeles because of air pollution misquoted Lee M. Thomas, the Environmental Protection Administrator, on the need to renew the Clean Air Act. Mr. Thomas said: ''Failure to reauthorize the Act could lead to many more sanctions on areas as well as mandatory Federal pollution plans and litigation, which will only further delay the goal we all want: clean air.

LEAD: AN opulent dessert wine made by the Great Western Winery in the Finger Lakes region of New York State won the Governor's Cup for the second consecutive time in this year's statewide wine competition.
LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Mexico today announced a $250 million cost-cutting program and immediately eliminated 799 jobs, or more than 19 percent of its 4,126 staff.

LEAD: The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals denied a request yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation to dismiss parts of a protest filed by the Hughes Aircraft Company over a $3.6 billion contract to build a new air traffic control system for the Federal Aviation

LEAD: A spokesman for Solidarity said tonight that the Government would begin talks here Wednesday with Lech Walesa, the founder of the union movement, on ending labor unrest and introducing political and economic changes in Poland.

LEAD: Danny Jackson became the National League's first 19-game winner tonight, and Luis Quinones's two-run double capped a six-run first inning as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-4.

LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett today presented his version of the ideal elementary school curriculum, a course of study that emphasizes classic children's literature, rigorous mathematics lessons and foreign language instruction beginning no later than the fourth grade.

LEAD: When he was growing up in Brentwood, L.I., James (Buddy) McGirt used to sit behind the wheel of his father's white Cadillac, an unlighted cigar in his mouth, and pretend to be driving the vehicle the way the father, also named James, did.

LEAD: An 18-year-old mother of three who was ordered to practice birth control throughout her child-bearing years is pregnant again, but the judge who sentenced herfor child abuse says she will not revoke the probation.

LEAD: Baseball's club owners will learn today if they are guilty a second time of conspiring against free agents. Lawyers on both the players' and the owners' sides expect George Nicolau, the arbitrator, to rule against the owners in the case involving 1986 free agents.
LEAD: International A3-13
LEAD: The earthquake last week in eastern Nepal is likely to deal a serious setback to the country's economic development, according to officials here.

LEAD: In an affidavit unsealed today in Federal District Court here, a special agent of the Internal Revenue Service maintained that high-ranking executives of the Georgia Power Company and its parent, the Southern Company, had engaged in a complex six-year plan to evade millions of dollars in corporate taxes.
LEAD: State employees formed a united front today for protests against the Government, striking another blow at the embattled regime of the President, U Maung Maung.

LEAD: The Islanders announced yesterday that they have signed two defensemen who helped take St. Lawrence University to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament last spring. Those who signed were Hank Lammens, whom the Islanders had selected in the eighth round of the 1985 draft, and Pete McGeough, the Islanders' 12th-round selection in 1983.

LEAD: A picture caption on Aug. 24 incorrectly described the problems surrounding a new building, Cityspire, east of Seventh Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets in Manhattan. The assembly of a dome on top of the building, which is taller than permitted, apparently violated an agreement with New York City in which the developer had agreed to stop working on the upper floors.

LEAD: By his own admission, John McEnroe is not among the favorites to win the United States Open. That status belongs to any of the top five seeded players, he said. McEnroe, though, will never be a bit player as long as he remains in the game. Even when his matches are uneventful, the quotations from Chairman

LEAD: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said yesterday that the remarks by a Toronto Blue Jays' executive about the possibility of the Yankees' trading Don Mattingly is a matter that could attract his attention. The Yankees, however, said they did not plan to bring it to the commissioner's attention.
LEAD: A Chinese Trident jetliner carrying 89 people crashed into the water while landing at the international airport in Hong Kong today and 6 people were killed, the Government said.

LEAD: Every time I mention Adm. Arleigh A. Burke in this column, I get two or three things terribly wrong. For this reason I have been hesitant to report that Admiral Burke, a hero of World War II, is alive.

LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. said it had entered an agreement with Nynex Information Solutions Group Inc. under which the New York company will integrate and market Tandem products in large-scale systems aimed at the finance, manufacturing and telecommunications industries. Nynex Informations Solutions is a subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, the telephone operating company in the New York area.

LEAD: In the fourth-largest Japanese acquisition of an American company, Gould Inc. said yesterday that it would be acquired by the Nippon Mining Company for $23.25 a share, or about $1.1 billion in cash.

LEAD: In California, high automobile insurance rates have inspired a consumer revolt and a set of ballot initiatives aimed at controlling costs. In New Jersey, where rates are even higher, residents may be forgiven a certain cynicism about efforts to control costs. Every time Trenton has put its collective hand to this problem in recent years, the result has been higher rates, not lower.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time, there was an exquisitely quiet wooded area in a community called Travis in western Staten Island. Travis is still there, but what had been secluded and sylvan is now a bustling multi-screen movie theater alongside a giant bowling alley, with their attendant parking lots and traffic jams.

LEAD: Negotiators for the Presidential candidates predicted today that there would be debates between the contenders this fall, but they disagreed about almost everything else, such as how often, when and under what ground rules the debates would be held.
LEAD: The American writer Susan Sontag and writers from seven countries held a reception tonight at the International PEN Congress to dramatize the imprisonment of five South Korean literary figures.

LEAD: John F. Riordan, a mathematician and engineer who was on the technical staff of Bell Laboratories for 42 years and later taught at Rockefeller University, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at the Ocean Manor nursing home in Scituate, Mass., where he lived. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: A jail opened here today on the banks of the St. Lawrence River, hard by the Thousand Islands wilderness, a few hundred yards from the Canadian border. A New York City jail. Faced with overcrowded jails, neighborhood opposition to new jails and a three-year wait before the opening of a 1,000-inmate jail on Staten Island, city correction officials are flying prisoners to this remote and sparsely populated land of big skies and permafrost winters, some 280 miles northwest of Rikers Island, the city's major jail center in the East

LEAD: The financial rewards have been few, crumbs compared with what Steffi Graf, Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova have earned. Kim Steinmetz is one of the starving artists of tennis, a dwindling few who play for the sheer enjoyment of a game. She has long since reconciled the fact that she will not find her name associated with a line of tennis apparel or listed among the winners of the United States

LEAD: Frederick Wiseman, public television's determinedly mute yet consistently eloquent guide to surprising corners of American life, takes us tonight to Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to look in on young officers who are being trained to man the launching-control centers of the Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles.

LEAD: As most anyone who grows tomatoes will tell you, the tomato tastes and smells best if it is picked, sliced and served - all within a few minutes. Such empirical knowledge has passed down through generations of gardeners, cooks, and tomato eaters. Now, chemists at the Department of Agriculture have confirmed this, and hope their work will point the way to enhancing the flavor of the scourge of the winter salad - the refrigerated tomato.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: With peace talks between Iran and Iraq apparently making no headway, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was quoted today as having said that the eight-year-old conflict was not over and that Iranians should feel they are still at war.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice is considering an offer by Tawana Brawley to testify before a Congressional hearing.

LEAD: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants reversed a longstanding position today by voting to allow the group's 270,000 members to sell securities, insurance and other financial services.

LEAD: In less than a decade, ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat'' has gone through several startling and successful incarnations - an essay became an opera, which is now a film. Each version reinforces the haunting atmosphere of loss in a story that began with the neurologist Oliver Sacks's 1979 observation of a patient he called Dr.

LEAD: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn, Batya Spirn, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Charles A. Spirn of New York, was married last evening to Ari Jerenberg, the son of Natalie Jerenberg of Hillcrest, Queens, and the late Dr. Norman Jerenberg. The bride's father, the head chaplain at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and Rabbi Simcha Krauss officiated.
LEAD: For blacks in journalism, passages from the Kerner Commission's report of 1968 have become as familiar as the words of Frederick Douglass or W. E. B. DuBois.

LEAD: The judge in the case of five Queens homeowners convicted of setting fire to a planned shelter for foster-care babies contended yesterday that the city's actions might have driven them to commit the crime.

LEAD: A former fugitive, identified by the authorities as the leader of a drug organization linked to the Colombo crime family, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of racketeering and extortion.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in dull trading yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Acme United Corp., Fairfield, Conn., a maker of medical equipment, shears and scissors, promoted Stephen T. Bajda to senior vice president, finance.
LEAD: An article in Science Times yesterday on recycling plastics misstated the affiliation of Jeanne Wirka. She is with the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A provocative footnote in a Federal court decision earlier this month has reignited a dispute over who really pioneered the method for producing new substances through genetic engineering.
LEAD: ''Meet me at the Raceway Diner,'' Henry (Hank) Spallone said when he telephoned. ''I'll show you around.''

LEAD: The prices that farmers received for grain and other raw products rose 2.1 percent from July to August, an increase that was partly a result of this year's drought, the Agriculture Department said today.
LEAD: One is a retired New York City detective who carries a .38-caliber revolver in the trunk of his car and worries about Yonkers becoming another Bronx.

LEAD: Burlington Motor Carriers Inc., the trucking subsidiary of Burlington Northern Inc., has been spun off to an investor group in a leveraged buyout for $90 million. The buyout group includes the company's senior management, and investment bankers from Lepercq, de Neuflize & Company; Chase Manhattan Bank, and Alex.

LEAD: Representative Mario Biaggi, who has been convicted on Federal charges twice in the last year, will be honored at a rally sponsored by Bronx social and community organizations and several unions four days before the Sept. 15 Democratic primary.

LEAD: In the largest such deal ever, the J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would borrow $700 million from big insurance companies and give the money to an employee trust so it can buy Penney's stock.
LEAD: For a while, a general in New York City's war on drugs feared that he would become the nation's ''only homeless prosecutor.''
LEAD: The number of Americans behind on their mortgage payments rose in the April-June quarter for the second time in two-and-a-half years, The Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

LEAD: AFTER years of planning, negotiations and delays, the steel framework is rising for a 50-story office tower that will cover the full western blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas between 45th and 46th Streets.

LEAD: A former president of the Southern Baptist Convention said that while abortion was ''an abomination before God,'' he opposed tactics being used by opponents of abortion that have led to hundreds of arrests this summer.
LEAD: ''Solipsistic! I'll be. . . .'' said the professor, beaming with pleasure, as he looked over his students' work sheets.

LEAD: For the last two weeks, George Bush has been defining himself and Michael Dukakis. He presents himself as patriotic, tough and caring. He portrays the Massachusetts Governor as a closet liberal who favors unilateral disarmament and furloughs for felons and hates the Pledge of Allegiance.

LEAD: Neither contender for a contested board seat at the R. P. Scherer Corporation will take part in meetings or board votes until a court rules on the dispute, the company said. The gelatin capsule maker also said a shareholders meeting scheduled to resume Thursday would be put off until Sept. 26 pending action on court challenges involving the board election.

LEAD: The comic was hitting his groove. ''Let me tell you about the night Jerry Falwell and I slept together,'' Abbie Hoffman announced, leering lewdly at an adoring audience. ''Jimmy Swaggart took movies.'' The clown prince of 60's radicals, who 20 years ago helped nominate a pig for President, was appearing at Stand-Up New York, an Upper West Side comedy club.

LEAD: The General Services Administration yesterday awarded Diners Club Inc., a subsidiary of Citibank, a one-year contract to provide credit card service to more than 400,000 Federal employees who travel frequently on Government business.
LEAD: Univision Holdings Inc., which is owned by Hallmark Cards Inc., yesterday announced the appointment of Joaquin F. Blaya as president of its Spanish-language television network.
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, set the interest rate for a $750 million issue of four-year debentures to be offered through various securities dealers.
LEAD: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, is reportedly heading for the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it planned to cut its lowest urestricted fares by an average of 55 percent on 38 routes from Denver. The service has been plagued by overcapacity and decreased travel because of the depressed oil economy.
LEAD: In Michael S. Dukakis's first semester in 1979 as an unemployed politician and Harvard faculty member, he got bad grades from his students.
LEAD: Western diplomats said today that the Soviet Union had taken steps to integrate northern Afghanistan's economy with that of Soviet Central Asia.

LEAD: The agent for Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker who has been suspended for 30 days for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse program, said yesterday that Taylor was at home in New Jersey awaiting a directive from the league on a rehabilitation program and had ''a sincere desire to overcome this problem and get it behind him.

LEAD: The National Cancer Institute recommends yearly breast X-rays for women over 50, but health insurance doesn't normally cover the procedure, which may cost up to $200. Only eight states now mandate insurance coverage of mammography screening. A sensible bill approved by New York's Legislature and awaiting Governor Cuomo's signature would make New

LEAD: The redesigned space shuttle booster performed virtually perfectly in a critical firing earlier this month despite being peppered with intentional flaws, the manufactuer, Morton Thiokol Inc., announced today.
LEAD: Morocco and the Polisario Front guerrillas agreed today to a United Nations peace plan to end the 13-year-old war in the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara.

LEAD: Filming has just been completed on the first production for next season's ''American Playhouse'' series on PBS, a new three-hour version of Lorraine Hansberry's play ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' to be broadcast in January. The television production, starring Danny Glover and Esther Rolle, will include scenes written by Ms.

LEAD: The Senate campaign of Charles S. Robb, the former Virginia Governor, has filed a complaint with Federal election officials objecting to a private detective's investigation of reports linking Mr. Robb to people who used drugs.

LEAD: Domtar Inc., a Montreal-based manufacturer of pulp and paper products, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.79 to yield 9.68 percent though underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are noncallable and yield about 68 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

LEAD: FOR most of his life, a Japanese man named George Ohsawa devoted his time to developing and promulgating the concepts of macrobiotic eating, which he believed would lead to a healthier, more balanced life. While Mr. Ohsawa lectured all over the world, his wife, Lima, was always with him. It was her job to develop the application of the theory: to create the recipes and cook food that would exemplify the macrobiotic way.
LEAD: While the drought this summer is imposing new water restrictions on many Americans, water use is already down nationally, partly because of a declining supply of water.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation increased cash incentives for its Eagle Premier automobiles to $750 from $600, retroactive to Sunday. The nation's third-largest car maker said the incentives would be available on 1988 and 1989 models and the offer would be available indefinitely. The company said it sold 2,058 of the cars in the first 20 days of August, down 10.8 percent from the 2,281 sold in the July period.

LEAD: Vice President Bush came to the political homeland of Senator Jesse Helms today, and to the delight of many of the audience he outdid the conservative North Carolinian in the fervor of his attacks on liberalism.

LEAD: ''I see schools as places that feed children, educate their parents and provide early childhood education.'' This is how Richard R. Green, New York City's Schools Chancellor, described the schools' modern mission in a New York Times article last week. In cities, he explained, the teachers may be the most important adults in children's lives.

LEAD: The Suffolk County Legislature passed a bill today that puts a $5 refundable deposit on automobile batteries sold in the county, a move to encourage recycling and remove the batteries from everyday waste.

LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorp is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1993 at a price of 99.92 to yield 9.77 percent through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
LEAD: After a much-heralded entry into the telecommunications marketplace, hookups that allow callers to socialize by telephone from home are fast fading in popularity.
LEAD: WHAT is the real worth of the Wickes Companies? From Wall Street's perspective, Sanford C. Sigoloff is trying to buy the huge maker of auto parts and home furnishings for a song.
LEAD: It's back to the drawing board for 35-year-old Wilmer C. Ames, who had a dream to start a black-oriented magazine, but failed to come up with enough financial backing.

LEAD: SEAWEED is classified by color. Of the eight major groups, three are used for food. Red seaweed, or Rhodphyta, includes dulse, purple nori, ogo, agar and Irish moss. Brown seaweed, or Phaeophyta, includes kelp, kombu, wakame, arame, hijiki and rock weed. Sea lettuce belongs to the Chlorophyta, or green seaweed group.
LEAD: * Chief Executive Magazine says its rate base climbed 7 percent, to 30,000, and will increase its ad rates 11 percent, effective with its January/February issue.
LEAD: Federal investigators have seized documents related to the Northrop Corporation's work on the MX missile program, a company spokesman said today.

LEAD: At least 1,000 demonstrators held a candlelight vigil at Broadway and 100th Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last night to protest recent violence against homosexuals and the police arrested more than 100 of them for blocking traffic.

LEAD: An ancient quarrel over the vital waterway separating Iran and Iraq threatens to scuttle the gulf war truce even before talks begin in Geneva. Iraq now balks at compliance with the terms of the United Nations cease-fire resolution, insisting on full naval access to the disputed Shatt al-Arab in advance of peace talks.

LEAD: The Bank of New York yesterday reiterated its position that it was prepared to raise its bid for the Irving Bank Corporation slightly if Irving dropped the defenses it has adopted to protect itself from a hostile takeover.
LEAD: Now a ramshackle town of one-story houses on the banks of a torrent, Garam Chasma was once a popular resort for Pakistanis who came for the natural hot springs. But there is little tourism now.

LEAD: Amid a fierce interagency battle, the State Department has recommended that the United States allow the export of communications satellites for launching on Chinese rockets, officials at the department said today.
LEAD: A 65-foot tall Latin cross erected 22 years ago at a Marine base in Hawaii must be removed or replaced by a nonreligious symbol, a Federal judge ruled today.

LEAD: Two real-estate owners and developers whom Donald J. Trump outbid for the Plaza Hotel in March have settled instead for another historic Manhattan hostelry, the Barbizon on East 63d Street, the seller reported Monday.
LEAD: The Yankees lost again tonight, but they also made a last-ditch attempt to save their season by acquiring a relief pitcher for their weary and overworked bullpen.
LEAD: The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, slipping below its level of early spring.

LEAD: A well-known Swedish businessman and novelist has given the Stockholm Government new evidence he says shows that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat presumed to have disappeared in Soviet prisons after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, was alive as recently as 1986 and may be alive today.

LEAD: The seven City Councilmen of Yonkers, Edward J. Fagan Jr. notes with some satisfaction, have been called -both affectionately and pejoratively -Big Bird and the six Smurfs. At 6 foot 3, he is Big Bird.

LEAD: Steve Jones, a former world record-holder in the men's marathon, declined yesterday to accept a spot on the British Olympic team, saying he would not be able to prepare properly for the marathon, which will be run on Oct. 2, the closing day of competition at Seoul. The 33-year-old Welsh runner, who set a world record of 2 hours 7 minutes 3 seconds at Chicago in 1985, had been picked on Sunday to replace Hugh Jones, who was forced to withdraw because of an injury.

LEAD: THE reserved smile is the same; so are the restless energy and the rugged frame. Adversity comes and goes, but you have to keep in shape. Only the reading glasses - very proper; no aviator chic here - hint that Sam Sebastiani has put on a few years.

LEAD: FOR the young actor named D. B. Sweeney, Shoeless Joe Jackson started out as a role, but turned into something of a cause. D. B. Sweeney got turned around by Shoeless Joe, both at home plate and in his heart.
LEAD: A Federal judge has barred the railroad police union from shutting down the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, a railroad spokeswoman said yesterday.

LEAD: The brain is equipped with a sophisticated barrier that keeps foreign substances in the blood like bacteria and toxins from reaching brain tissue. But this blood-brain barrier, as scientists call it, also keeps out potentially useful substances like drugs to treat cancer and AIDS.
LEAD: An off-duty New York City police officer was seriously wounded last night in a shootout with two other police officers who were responding to a report of a disorderly man, officials said.
LEAD: According to the Federal Election Commission, special interest political action committees are contributing at a record rate to this year's Congressional races.

LEAD: Neil Bush, citing a possible conflict of interest with the Presidential campaign of his father, has resigned from the board of Silverado Banking Savings and Loan, an insolvent Denver thrift institution facing a Federal bail-out.

LEAD: A Bit of the Old and New The Jewish New Year, Rosh ha-Shanah, begins at sundown on Sept. 11, and of timely interest is ''Kashruth'' by Rabbi Yacov Lipschutz (Mesorah Publications), which explains the ancient principles behind kosher food rules, and also discusses some concerns of the modern cook.
LEAD: People laugh when Charles J. Gibson, a California Highway Patrol officer, pulls over their automobiles and trucks.

LEAD: A South African Army officer serving coffee to Cuban officers yesterday in Rundu, South-West Africa. The Cubans were there to witness the withdrawal of the South Africans from Angola two days early. Page A3. (Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: IN 1948, Preston Tucker marketed ''The Car of Tomorrow Today'': a fastback four-door sedan with a rear engine, a windshield designed to pop out in a collision and a Cyclops headlight linked to the steering mechanism so that it turned in same direction as the front wheels.
LEAD: A principal who was dismissed after accusing school committee members of interfering too much in his high school's operations was ordered reinstated Monday by a Middlesex Superior Court judge.

LEAD: The promoting, encouraging and marketing of child prodigies may not constitute child abuse, but it is a form of robbery. When children are deprived of childhood the loss to all of us is great. Children show us things about ourselves we would not otherwise see. They offer us an education at least as valuable as the one we extend to them.

LEAD: When the Smithsonian Institution accepted the industrialist Charles Lang Freer's gift of his collection of Oriental art and a magnificent gallery in which to display the pieces, it also accepted his condition that the works never be shown elsewhere.

LEAD: With Mats Wilander, Brad Gilbert, Tim Mayotte and Yannick Noah by his side, Hamilton Jordan, the chief executive officer of the Association of Tennis Professionals, reiterated yesterday that the players will organize their own international tour in 1990 because of the inability of the Men's Tennis Council to effectively govern the men's game.

LEAD: The waning days of August have brought a fresh, even autumnal tingle to New York City's weather. But the last day of the month has also brought a more serious reminder of what is in the air: As of midnight tonight, New York City will be in violation of a Federal law for failing to meet air-quality standards established under the Clean Air Act of 1970.

LEAD: In bridge, as in life, there is a big difference between being very poor and being destitute. The player who appreciates this can sometimes make a positive move in the bidding because his hand is not as bad as it might have been.

LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi announced that it had filed an application to list its shares on the Tokyo stock exchange, and that it expected to begin trading in mid-October. It has already filed a securities registration statement with the Japanese Finance Ministry for a public offering of 1.56 million shares, at a price to be fixed at the time of issue.
LEAD: President Augusto Pinochet of Chile, nominated yesterday to run in the Oct. 5 single-candidate election, in Santiago on Monday. Page A3. (Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: Events in the Middle East are moving to a crossroads. For many years, hard choices have been put off because, on the Israeli side, so many people wanted to believe they need never be made and that the impasse would melt away with time; and because, on the Palestinian side, leaders felt more secure by temporizing than by taking political risk.

LEAD: A coalition of advocates for the homeless won a Federal court order today temporarily blocking the Department of Housing and Urban Development from selling foreclosed single-family homes to the highest bidder.

LEAD: On the wall of Ann Mills Griffiths's office in Washington is a framed rubbing of her brother's name from the Vietnam War Memorial. Lieut. Cmdr. James B. Mills has been missing since Sept. 21, 1966, when his Navy F-4 was lost on a night mission over North Vietnam.

LEAD: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Jerry Hairston, outfielder-designated hitter. Purchased the contract of Carlos Martinez, third baseman-outfielder, from Birmingham of the Southern League. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Optioned Tom Filer, pitcher, to Denver of the American Association. Activated Paul Mirabella, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list.

LEAD: The USX Corporation said its steel division had concluded an agreement to provide the Soviet Union with 88,000 tons of seamless steel tube for oil well casing. ''As best we can tell, it is the largest order we've been involved with in the Soviet Union,'' a company spokesman, Thomas Ferrall, said. The price of the deal was withheld.

LEAD: If Clyde Lee Conrad, the retired Army sergeant accused of heading a major spying ring, had needed anonymity but did not like a long commute, he could hardly have picked a better spot than Bosenheim.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the former Democratic Party presidential candidate, swept through New York City yesterday in a campaign-like swirl of cars, police and press. Mr. Jackson was running, he said, ''to keep hope alive,'' making little mention of the party's nominee, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, and pressing his own themes of racial fairness, consensus, aspiration and voter registration.
LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle says he has not spent much time studying the drug issue but plans to learn more about it in his campaign for the Vice Presidency.

LEAD: Brian Shaw, a guard who was the first-round draft choice of the Boston Celtics, was the final player cut yesterday as the United States Olympic men's basketball team reached its 12-player limit.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Marjorie Draper, a leader in New Jersey civic and community affairs, died Sunday at her home in Montclair, N.J., after a brief illness. She was 60 years old.

LEAD: IN 240 B.C., Lu Buwei, the Prime Minister of China under the first Emperor of the Qin dynasty, directed the compilation of an encyclopedia of all that was known. Called the ''Spring and Autumn Annals,'' the encyclopedia included myriad tales, this among them:

LEAD: Vyacheslav Fetisov, the captain of the Soviet national hockey team, has been given permission from the highest authorities to play this season in the National Hockey League, according to an article in The Toronto Star. The article quotes Lou Lamoriello, the general manager of the Devils, who hold the draft rights to Fetisov.

LEAD: VINNIE BLACK'S COLISEUM (''The Cadillac of Caterers'') in Greenwich Village is a shade less glittery than Leonard's of Great Neck, L.I., the service a touch clumsier than the Rainbow Room's and the food not quite as haute as the Manor's in West Orange, N.J. Nevertheless, it's been booked solid for months.

LEAD: Benjamin C. Willis, who as Superintendent of Schools in Chicago in the 1960's was accused of perpetuating segregation by refusing to move black children into white schools, died at his home in Plantation, Fla., on Saturday, his family said yesterday. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: Chrysler's 1,500 Jeep/Eagle dealers, which sell the Eagle Premier and Jeep Cherokee, have decided to pool their resources in celebrating their first anniversary with a jointly purchased media campaign scheduled to make its debut Sept. 6.
LEAD: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Eastern Airlines could sharply reduce its service today, as planned, but could not lay off 4,000 workers without negotiating with their unions.
LEAD: A Federal district judge today sentenced two former bank officers to prison for contributing to the near-collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in 1984.
LEAD: Hazel Dawn, a celebrated singer and actress in the early decades of the century who was known as ''The Pink Lady,'' died Sunday at the home of her daughter in Manhattan. She was 98 years old.
LEAD: Irving Honigsberg, a real-estate lawyer, died of complications after surgery Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: A Federal judge ruled that Eastern Airlines could sharply reduce its service today, as planned.
LEAD: PASTRAMI is as much a part of the New York delicatessen scene as corned beef, kosher dill pickles and cheesecake.

LEAD: Walter Foy Prude, who helped to direct the careers of Arthur Rubinstein, Marian Anderson, Isaac Stern and many other artists during his more than four decades in concert management, died of heart failure Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long bout with emphysema. He was 78 years old and lived in

LEAD: The City of Yonkers and the four Councilmen who are blocking a court-ordered housing desegregation plan applied to the United States Supreme Court today for continued relief from contempt fines against them.
LEAD: Six people, including an 11-month-old child, were wounded yesterday evening when a dispute between two teen-agers during a basketball game in the Bronx erupted in shooting, the police said.

LEAD: A caption with an article in Science Times yesterday about a private space venture by the EPrime Aerospace Corporation gave an incorrect date for the planned launching of the company's first rocket. It is Oct. 6.

LEAD: After weeks of being pummeled by his Republican Presidential rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis counterpunched today with a broad new assault on Vice President Bush's conduct in the Iran-contra affair.
LEAD: Stockholders of Resorts International Inc. today approved Merv Griffin's offer to buy the gaming and real estate company.

LEAD: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who has ruled Chile for 15 years, was formally nominated by the armed forces and the police today to seek a new eight-year term as President in a one-man plebiscite on Oct. 5.

LEAD: Black & Decker Inc. has agreed to send owners of 500,000 electric miter saws kits to fix a faulty blade guard. A company spokeswoman, Barbara Lucas, said the guard sometimes jammed, leaving the blade exposed. The company said owners should call (800) 541-7136 for kits for these models: 1703 (type 1), 1703-1, 3090 (types 2 and 11), 3091 (type 1), 3417 (type 11), 3417-04 (type 3), 7715, 7715-1 (types 1, 2 and 3), 7715-04 (type 2), 7716 (types 1A1, 2, 11), 7716-04 (type 1), 7717 (types 3, 11 and 21), 7718 (type 2), and Sears Model 901.23470.

LEAD: THE technique of breading meat and fish, properly performed, is a quick and easy way to impart extra texture and flavor. Unfortunately, it is often done incorrectly, leaving foods soggy and greasy. I recently made a batch of chicken nuggets in herbed breading for a quick, casual summer dinner.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: WHEN the Great Depression slammed into the economy in 1929, professional forecasters never knew what hit them. That is understandable, given the primitive state of their science a half century ago. But now that economists are armed with sophisticated mathematical models and big computers to crunch the numbers, forecasters could not possibly be caught asleep at the switch.

LEAD: The Environment Yesterday in Michigan, George Bush started to talk about something serious. Diversions about the Pledge of Allegiance or Mr. Dukakis's alleged lack of patriotism were laid aside. Mr. Bush addressed the mounting evidence of deterioration in the environment and promised to convene a global conference to discuss remedies.

LEAD: When Franklin Roosevelt nominated Felix Frankfurter to the Supreme Court, in 1939, voices of the extreme right called Professor Frankfurter a Communist. They cited, especially, the fact that he was a member of a national committee of the American Civil Liberties Union.

LEAD: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, called today for Polish strikers to return to work. The call was issued after Mr. Walesa met with members of the Polish leadership for the first time since Solidarity was suppressed in 1981.

LEAD: UP on the bluff, a blue and white Sea Spray flag flutters gracefully in the breeze. Two Ferraris dot the circular tan gravel driveway, and towels embroidered with the Sea Spray logo are neatly folded on the roomy chaises that line the pristine swimming pool. The tennis net is exactly on axis to the Tennessee orchard stone steps that lead ceremoniously up to the porte-cochere.

LEAD: Texaco said late last night that it had reached an agreement with Texaco Canada on procedures for the sale of the subsidiary, of which Texaco owns 78 percent, to protect the interests of minority shareholders.
LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals acquired a utilityman, Denny Walling, for a right-hander, Bob Forsch, in a trade with the Houston Astros, who are trying to stay in the race in the National League West.

LEAD: A memorial tribute to Anthony Holland, an actor, is to be held on Sept. 26 at 5:30 P.M. at the Public Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival, 425 Lafayette Street. Mr. Holland died on July 10.

LEAD: Even in his younger years, Walter Smith was not the best of drivers. But as age began to rob this rural Minnesotan of good vision and hearing, agility and quick reflexes, he became an increasing hazard on the road.
LEAD: In 1910, a now-forgotten British writer popular in his time, Holbrook Jackson, wrote: ''In a beautiful city an art gallery would be superfluous. In an ugly one it is a narcotic.''

LEAD: ''The moment it's not fun, it's time to do something else,'' Robert R. McMillan, the Republican who hopes to topple Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in November, said over a roast beef sandwich in a Great Neck diner the other evening. He sounded like he meant it after three grueling months of campaigning that, right now, looks like an exercise in futility.

LEAD: Grant Gondrezick, a guard who was implicated in the drug scandal involving the Phoenix Suns in 1986, signed a one-year contract yesterday to play with the Los Angeles Clippers of the National Basketball Association. Gondrezick played last season with a team in Caen, France. Gondrezick, after being charged in the Phoenix case with three drug counts, pleaded guilty to tampering with a witness and was fined $200 and placed on three years' probation.
LEAD: Rudi Voeller scored two goals and led West Germany to an easy 4-0 victory over Finland in the opening Group 4 World Cup soccer qualifying match tonight. The West Germans led by 2-0 at halftime.
LEAD: The headquarters of the South African Council of Churches and several leading civil rights groups was destroyed in a bombing early today in which 23 people were wounded.

LEAD: CARTRIDGE faucets, found in many newer kitchens and bathrooms, are easy to repair. Such faucets are turned on with a single lever or knob. They can be readily distinguished from other single-control faucets: a rotating-ball faucet, for example, has a dome-shaped top; a tipping-valve faucet has a spindle-shaped control handle at the rear; a disk faucet has a short control lever that is part of a stubby, large-diameter cap covering the top of the faucet.

LEAD: AMONG the greater pleasures of early September I number the vines that cloak the pergola above our backyard deck. LEAD: Two men meet in ''The Summit,'' which will be performed by Ralf Ralf at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater this weekend. Dressed in drab business suits, they are participants at an international conference. Representing opposite sides at the conference table, they hector and cajole each other in a stream of political discourse that ends with fleeting moments of closeness before the battle lines are drawn again.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Albert E. Suter, who left the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company this summer after a short stint as its president and chief operating officer, was named to similar posts yesterday at the Whirlpool Corporation.
LEAD: Leonor K. Sullivan, a 12-term Democratic member of the House of Representatives, the only woman ever elected to Congress from Missouri, died today of heart failure. She was 86 years old.
LEAD: One man was killed and four people were wounded yesterday, one critically, when a gunman fired into a crowd of 350 outside a memorial rap concert in Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: The crew of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed in Texas Wednesday spoke of an engine problem in the seconds after it took off and before it fell back to the ground and skidded to a flaming stop 3,000 feet past the end of the runway, a Government official said yesterday.

LEAD: President Augusto Pinochet today ended the enforced exile of many relatives and close associates of former President Salvador Allende Gossens, the Marxist overthrown by the armed forces 15 years ago.

LEAD: George Bush got a big laugh from the mostly affluent Republicans who heard his acceptance speech when he derided Democratic references to ''a Swiss cheese economy.'' Now the Census Bureau has confirmed that the economy is, indeed, riddled with holes; and that's no laughing matter.

LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle campaigned across the deep South today, showing new political confidence and vigor as questions about his earlier personal life appeared to be slipping deeper into the background of the 1988 Presidential race.

LEAD: At an uptown subway station, commuters wait with special desperation for a light at the end of the tunnel. On the stuffy platform, a man plays an electronically amplified flute, a noise that invades every corner. The music is Mozart; the flautist, first rate. Why is it so offensive? Because it's nine o'clock in the morning - an hour when most recently awakened people prefer to read or have a few moments to themselves before being swept into the business of the day.

LEAD: While many might argue that art should be seen, not heard (or read), the loquaciousness of the visual is clearly on the rise. At that time, Conceptual art loosened a flood of words - used singly, in provocative phrases and long texts - into what has become, increasingly, the mainstream.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Presidio Oil Company has agreed to buy a group of oil and gas properties from the Standard Oil Production Company of Houston for Presidio common stock and cash estimated at $55 million, the two companies said. The acquisitions include proven reserves of six million barrels of oil and 22 billion cubic feet of natural gas as well as 30,000 acres of non-producing lease acreage.

LEAD: Neither may have been favored to win the United States Open, but some of the color and excitement will be missing for the rest of the tournament after John McEnroe and Boris Becker were eliminated yesterday.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said in Atlanta that he wanted no big job in the Democratic campaign and no title. What he wanted was respect - to be accepted as a man with useful advice and as a politician capable of delivering a constituency. Apparently he's still a long way from achieving these objectives.

LEAD: The former Dallas real estate consultant Jack D. Franks agreed today to plead guilty to one count of aiding and abetting bank fraud at the Vernon Savings and Loan Association as part of a plea agreement granting him immunity from other criminal charges, Federal investigators said.

LEAD: The Century Communications Corporation, New Canaan, Conn., which owns and operates cable television systems, said yesterday that it had concluded a $600 million long-term credit agreement with about eight banks led by Citibank. The agreement includes a competitive-bid commercial paper facility.

LEAD: The WPP Group P.L.C., the British advertising conglomerate, has reported large earnings gains for the six months that ended on June 30, mainly because of new business and operating increases at the J. Walter Thompson Company, which it acquired last year, and at Hill & Knowlton.

LEAD: A real computer crash today halted a mock space shuttle mission in its final hours just before the five Discovery astronauts were preparing to simulate landing on a flat tire.
LEAD: Construction spending in July posted its sharpest increase in four months, but only partly recovered from a slump in June.

LEAD: The police detained a Jewish settler in the occupied West Bank after he accidentally shot and wounded two Israeli soldiers while chasing a Palestinian who hurled a firebomb at his car, officials said today.

LEAD: ''Br'er Rabbit,'' a musical based on the Uncle Remus stories by Joel Chandler Harris, is being featured this weekend at the Driftwood Floating Theater Showboat, docked at Eddyville, N.Y., near Kingston. The original musical is by Richard Smithies and Maura Cavanagh. Performances are at 8 P.M. today and tomorrow; at 2:30 and 8:15 P.M.

LEAD: ''Freedom of association,'' the right to belong to groups of one's choosing, is nowhere mentioned in the Constitution. It is a concept often read into the First Amendment by lawyers, argued by lawyers, written and refined by lawyers, expanded and expounded by lawyers. But now the principle has been applied to lawyers and the legal profession is aghast.
LEAD: A United Nations development organization called on commercial banks today to forgive at least 30 percent of the debt of 15 heavily indebted developing nations.

LEAD: Conversations revolve around Steffi Graf's bid for the Grand Slam, Martina Navratilova's renewed efforts to stop her, the promise of Gabriela Sabatini and the perseverance of Chris Evert. But for Pam Shriver, this year's United States Open was another wasted opportunity, even briefer than most, the 11th annual chapter in her bid to win a major championship that seems more elusive than ever.

Assets of the 126 institutional funds decreased $637.6 million, to $69.04 billion. Assets of the 221 general-purpose funds declined $333.8 million, to $85.04 billion.

LEAD: Larry Parrish's two-run home run keyed a four-run sixth inning that lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 4-2 victory over the California Angels tonight.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis today attacked the Reagan Administration's record on education and charged that Vice President Bush's pledge to be the ''education President'' was the product of ''an election year conversion.''

LEAD: THE summer season traditionally comes to an end with Labor Day, a misnamed holiday distinguished by the decided absence of work and a day that is actually stretched into several days over a weekend that starts today and concludes Monday evening. It is a day so identified with the somewhat saddening exit of summer languor that it is easy to overlook a weekend calendar so filled with activity that little time may remain to mourn the low-key, if humidly deadening, months behind us.

LEAD: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average barely above the 2,000 mark.

LEAD: The director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry has caused political ripples here and in Israel by saying that Palestinians see the Palestine Liberation Organization as their ''national organization'' and that there is no replacement for it. Israel has steadfastly refused to deal with the P.L.O., which it deems a terrorist organization.

LEAD: The duo of Bill Mays on piano and Red Mitchell on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

LEAD: LABOR DAY 1988 is bound to yield a great deal of partisan oratory on the economic status of American working men and women and how to improve it. The Republicans will focus on the long spell of economic expansion since 1982, the lowest rate of unemployment in 14 years, the increase in the number of workers employed and the huge increase in employment that lies ahead.
LEAD: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company rejected a sweetened takeover bid of $2.35 billion today and vowed to pursue its own merger plans with the Tucson Electric Power Company.

LEAD: The Treasury Department said Wednesday that it would scrap a four-month-old program that offered investors a 24-hour, toll-free telephone number to buy United States Savings Bonds with a credit card. Investors used the program to buy $4.5 million in bonds from its inception on May 3 through mid-August.

LEAD: Cuban officials and American-backed Angolan rebels held secret face-to-face meetings for the first time last weekend, both sides said today, and State Department officials and rebel representatives characterized the encounter as a welcome development in the 13-year-old Angolan conflict.

LEAD: While Brian C. Beazer continues to seek buyers for the chemical operations of his newly acquired Koppers Company, the Pittsburgh concern's engineering department announced Wednesday that it was breaking away to form a consulting firm. The new Chemtech Consultants Inc. will employ about 30 people, 18 of whom will be investors.

LEAD: American Airlines has filed lawsuits against four ticket brokers, accusing them of buying frequent-flier mileage from American's passengers and reselling it to people who cash it in for airline tickets.
LEAD: * American Capital and Research Corp., Fairfax, Va., a financial holding company that owns professional and technical services companies, named Kenneth T. Nelson treasurer.

LEAD: When Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak was named recently to hold talks with leaders of various social groups to seek ways out of Poland's crisis, many Poles reacted at first with a kind of surprise, and then - after a double-take - with a nod of understanding.

LEAD: Federal officials said yesterday that they had completed the framework of a program to permit the Soviet Union and the United States each to exchange up to 1,500 high school students a year by 1991. Until now, such exchanges had been limited to 50 students a year.

LEAD: Doctors will soon be able to tell needle-sharing or sexual partners of AIDS-infected people that they are in danger of contracting the fatal disease under provisions of a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

LEAD: Martin Gottfried criticizes my ''so usually impeccable'' rhyming by citing the rhyme of ''liaisons'' with ''raisins'' in ''A Little Night Music.'' He misses the point. As is clearly indicated by the normal (i.e. Anglicized French) pronunciation of ''liaisons'' throughout the rest of the lyric to which he refers, it is a deliberately false rhyme, meant to express the wry contempt of the character who sings it (meant, too, to get a laugh, which it usually did).

LEAD: To the Editor: Christine S. LEAD: A FRIEND used to suffer from packer's block, which is like writer's block, if less fashionable. An episode usually begins when the suitcase is opened preparatory to travel. The victim abruptly seizes on some other problem, like alphabetizing the medicine cabinet or waxing the kitchen floor. My friend, unable to get the first pair of socks into the valise, would call at bizarre hours on Friday nights to get help.

Indeed, the incidents were not parallel, but there were important similarities in the way the parties involved responded.

LEAD: One reason why the feature-length documentary has lately been in decline is that the fiction feature has subsumed its role. We're as apt to get our facts from lightly embroidered versions of real events as from the events themselves. The television movie, which can proudly base itself on a true story and then touch up the story to suit the audience's taste, has paved the way for this development, but television drama in itself is rarely alarming.

LEAD: KNEES flexed, weight slung back, we neophytes poised at the top of the beginners' hill at Mount Snow, Vt., and prepared for our first descent. From the bottom, the slope had looked like a gentle rise. Now from above, it was a different matter entirely. This wasn't a downhill. This was a crater. Waved down by the instructor, we pushed off one by one and soon were fishtailing through the thick grass and rocks, squeezing the bike's hand brakes for dear life.

Probably for the same reasons that many of us work in the first place - to earn money, to meet new people, to develop new interests, to add another dimension of interest to conversations and to use one's skills.

LEAD: ''Just about everyone on Long Island knows this site,'' said Robert Krieger, who with his father, Maxwell, and brother, Steven, is building 44 town houses on three acres in Elmont. But not just any three acres. On this lot between Stewart and Franklin Streets on Johnson Avenue was a recreational complex that included a huge, above-ground pool and the Wal-Cliffe Rollerdrome, a roller-skating rink.

LEAD: The position of the Public Advocate respecting New Jersey Bell Caller ID (''New Jersey Bell Seeks to Add New Services,'' Aug. 14) has no merit for the simple reason that once an individual has invaded the privacy of another by calling him on the telephone, he has given up any claim to anonymity.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I WAS ONCE DISTURBED by my hunger for working with wood because it stole time from writing, the craft with which I have earned my living for nearly 40 years. Give me the choice between striving to corral thoughts into an essay or building a cabinet, and I will usually head for jointer plane and saw, pushing my writing deadlines to the limit.

LEAD: GARY Kasparov knows what's good for him when he takes his turn with the black pieces - semi-open games. The games not only provide the best situations for a brilliant tactical imagination like Kasparov's, but they demand it. Especially in the set of positions where kings are castled on opposite sides of the board, routine play is fatally slow.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: 'Massive layoffs are not, and never shall be, business as usual.' - Judge Barrington D. Parker, of Federal District Court in Washington, who ruled that Eastern Airlines could cut service, but could not lay off 4,000 workers without negotiating with their unions.

LEAD: The players see Pete Rose suspended for pushing an umpire, Billy Hatcher suspended for corking a bat, Kevin Gross and Joe Niekro suspended for having forbidden objects on the mound, Pedro Guerrero suspended for throwing a bat and they wonder. Why are they punished for breaking the rules, but the owners are not?

LEAD: FINALLY, everything is for keeps. The 1988 election campaign has been going on for the better part of two years. But during most of that time, most Americans were not paying much attention. ''Nothing matters until Labor Day'' were words heard scores of times from political professionals who were working furiously, as if they didn't believe their own words.
LEAD: Ferit Melen, a former Prime Minister and Defense Minister of Turkey, died Saturday of a heart condition, it was reported in Ankara. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: ZONE JOURNALS By Charles Wright. 101 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. THE SQUANICOOK ECLOGUES By Melissa Green. 78 pp. New York: W. W. Norton. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $7.95.

LEAD: A fragile labor peace settled over Poland today for the first time in 20 days after striking coal miners in the south of the country and dock workers and bus drivers in the north agreed to return to work.
LEAD: Arthur E. Voss, a publishing executive and former owner of Financial World magazine, died Thursday in Naples, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: There seem to be two sides to everything in the Cradle of Democracy. Athens abounds in history, but suffers from unchecked modern development: On the Acropolis, the 2,500-year-old Parthenon stands above a television antenna-dotted skyline. The city is renowned for openness and hospitality, but the noise and congestion would try the patience of Hercules.

LEAD: It is reported to be the largest and longest-running children's circus in the country, and the only one in Westchester. It is also, in the shining eyes of its performers and their families, the greatest show on earth.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was quite interested in Betsy Wade's article about children flying alone (Practical Traveler, July 24) - and aghast at the huge number - for I flew alone from San Francisco to Chicago in 1939, at the age of 6. My picture was on the front page of The Chicago Tribune, where it was said I flew ''across the country.
LEAD: The mark of the National Football League's 69th season, which kicks off this afternoon, is that last year's surprise teams will not be surprises anymore.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Contrary to popular belief, the Jets do have a chance to succeed this season. The team still has nearly all of the talented offensive players that led them to the playoffs only two years ago.
LEAD: JACK OF DIAMONDS And Other Stories. By Elizabeth Spencer. 184 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

LEAD: Karoly Grosz, the Hungarian leader, has angered colleagues in the Communist Party leadership and Government as well as many other Hungarians by his performance in a meeting last Sunday with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, Hungarians in contact with party leaders have reported.

After buying nine adjacent town houses on East 52d and 53d Streets in 1985, Peter Sudarsky watched the value of his investment plummet.

LEAD: If Mark Gastineau, the most often-quoted spokesman for the Jets, is any indication of what we can expect, jettison the Jets. LEAD: ESTRAGON: ''I can't go on like this.''

LEAD: Joey Meyer hit a three-run home run tonight and Jeffrey Leonard added a two-run shot as the Milwaukee Brewers beat slumping Detroit, 7-3, to send the Tigers to their 10th loss in 12 games. The loss cut the Tigers' lead over the Red Sox in the American League East to a half-game. The Red Sox had a later start in Anaheim, Calif, against the Angels.

LEAD: Against the hard-edged rivalries of the Middle East, to be described at once as ''a happy Israeli and a proud Arab'' would seem a contradiction. But to many the phrase aptly describes Mohamed Massarwa, Israel's consul general here.

LEAD: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.
LEAD: Time and trouble will tame an advanced young woman, but an advanced old woman is uncontrollable by any earthly force. - Dorothy L. Sayers

LEAD: Last year NBC had the highest ratings of the three major television networks. This year it begins the fall season with some very strong programming, including the summer Olympics and following with the World Series and the Superbowl. NBC has already sold 98 percent of the advertising time it has available for the Olympics.

When I managed on a recent trip to England to do all three on the famous battlefield at Hastings, a working vacation I had planned for a year was suddenly in ruins.

Instead, an estimated 3.8 million births were recorded, 3 percent more than in 1986, according to the Department of Health and Human Services. And the number is expected to increase slightly this year, too.

LEAD: RESTORATION and renovation of a 200-year-old Glen Head farmhouse destroyed by fire five years ago are part of a plan to incorporate the historical landmark into a new shopping center.

LEAD: The St. Francis Residence in Manhattan's Chelsea section has a steam-cleaned 19th-century brick exterior, lovely oak doors, a spotless hallway and 80 guests. Having a room at this hotel may be the best luck most of them have ever known. If they were not here, they would probably be living on a park bench, over a hot-air grating or in a bus station - the usual haunts of those who are both homeless and mentally ill.

Even in summer places, out on Long Island and on Cape
LEAD: FOR almost 100 years, the fragrance of chicken and onion soup wafted over Mamaroneck, emanating from a large white building at 746 Mamaroneck Avenue that housed the Pure Foods company.

LEAD: This play, effective for so long for the Redskins, is now being adopted by more N.F.L. teams. 1. Backs take a counter-step in opposite direction of play; three linemen block that way, too. 2. Backs reverse direction; left guard and tackle pull and help tight end clean out right side, as does the H-back.

LEAD: Two and a half years after Guatemalans elected a civilian President in an effort to end decades of military dominance, progress toward democracy is slow, and frustration is increasing. Although trade unionists and other protesters have greater freedom to organize than they did in the past, men in uniform still exercise ultimate political authority.

LEAD: THE children who will enter New York City's public schools as first graders this fall will become the Class of 2000 - that is, those who remain in school that long. If current trends continue, fewer than half will graduate on time; a little under a quarter of them will never graduate.
LEAD: A St. Louis police official was taken hostage today by a former police officer facing a prison term for his part in a pension fund scandal, the police said.

LEAD: When Randy Travis and Dwight Yoakam helped pull country music out of its 1980's commercial tailspin, they brought country's long-running identity crisis a new twist by making anti-pop country a resounding popular success. LEAD: Steve Taylor ran for two touchdowns and passed for another today as Nebraska routed Utah State, 63-13, for its second victory of the season.
LEAD: Teen-agers afraid to ask parents or teachers specific questions about AIDS now have a toll-free alternative, a hot line based here that is run by their peers.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that discussions were continuing with the Robert M. Bass Group over its proposal to acquire the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the nation's largest insolvent thrift.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Eastern Airlines may begin dismissing 4,000 workers as soon as the troubled air carrier posts $4.7 million in collateral to assure that laid off employees are compensated in the event the union wins on further appeal.

LEAD: To the Editor: Michael Brenson's essay was, sad to say, a quite accurate portrayal of the museums of today. As a frequent visitor to museums I've had experiences with loud, inaccurate lecturers, an absence of chairs, and the horrendous crowds of the blockbuster shows.

LEAD: ''The nation's economic situation is hard, and strikes do not help. But until now, we have been unable to reach agreement. We did not strike for the fun of it. We struck so that there would be no need to strike tomorrow, or the day after.'' - Lech Walesa. [ 11:1. ]

LEAD: I WISH to argue a case in favor of a Federal deficit as a normal aspect of sound economic policy. This is to enter a plea in the face of overwhelming public opinion as well as against the views of many, although certainly not all, economists. It would therefore seem to be a hopeless case. I hope to show that it is not.
LEAD: THE memorably uncomfortable summer of 1988 has left many Americans with a suspicion that nature is at last getting even for mankind's wanton pollution of the atmosphere.

LEAD: The state's fuel assistance program that helps poor families heat their homes will start a month later this year and end a month earlier because of a lack of funds. The program will begin on Nov. 1, instead of Oct. 1, and will distribute money through March instead of April, Susan Merrow-Kehoe, the program director, said.

At a meeting Friday, the judge, Leonard B. Sand, asked city officials to agree to sign a new consent decree that would establish an independent commission to administer the housing plan.

LEAD: DOCTORS began reporting an increasing number of cases in 1977. By 1980, the reported number had peaked at 890. The diagnosis: toxic shock syndrome, a sometimes fatal disease.

LEAD: If you build a better mousetrap than your neighbor, you are quite liable to get your fingers caught in it. In 1946 Preston Tucker set out to produce the car of his dreams, the ''Tucker Torpedo'' - a vehicle that in terms of design, performance and safety was far in advance of its period. By the time he went out of business, in 1948, he had been forced into bankruptcy and put on trial for fraud: he was acquitted, but his great days were over.
LEAD: AS the European Community pushes to form a barrier-free market by the end of 1992, other countries are crowding to join the 12-nation organization lest they miss out on the economic benefits.

LEAD: After years of delay, the way seems to be clear for the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, even though it will not be open by the time President Reagan leaves office, as originally planned.

LEAD: BEFORE statehood, jet planes and resort complexes, family-operated lodging houses catered to traveling salesmen who brought their wares and order forms into the rural towns of the Big Island of Hawaii. Most of these small hotels are gone now, except in scattered country villages. The tariffs are low, the rooms basic and clean, and the old-time island atmosphere is kamaaina (relaxed and friendly).

LEAD: LAST summer, algae depleted oxygen in Long Island Sound. Fish and lobster were killed, and black muck covered much of the bottom. This year, many beaches have had to be closed when sewage and other debris washed up.

LEAD: A LONG, long time ago, in a place far, far from Washington, a new President came to town with his entourage. Politicians and reporters breathlessly watched the comings and goings of Presidential advisers, recording their every utterance and carefully noting their every nuance.
LEAD: Old embalming tools, a 1917 Ford Model T hearse, intricately braided wreaths of human hair and a 1,500-pound glass coffin - these are some of the memorabilia in Fred Hunter's funeral museum.

A Time magazine correspondent at the Vatican for more than 25 years, Wilton Wynn has written a gentle apologia for the recent pontiffs, in whom he sees a common journey of faith.

LEAD: Vartan Gregorian is about to be checked out of the New York Public Library. Mr. Gregorian, who presided over the revival of the library as president, was appointed last week as the 16th president of Brown University. Mr. Gregorian was an adroit fund-raiser for the library, and such skills are doubtless needed at Brown, whose $360 million endowment is the smallest in the Ivy League.

LEAD: S FASHION DESIGNERS CONTINUE to open stores along the world's major shopping streets, a trend has begun to emerge: minimalism in retailing. These shops have a deliberately spare look, not just in their architecture, but in the small amount of merchandise on display. ''There is a direction on the part of retailers to show less but show it better,'' says the London architect David Chipperfield.

The Seahawks and the Broncos play their National Football League season opener in Denver today.

LEAD: To the Editor: For those who find eating in the hotels in Tokyo too expensive ($8 for tea and toast!), I suggest trying the cafeterias that exist in many office buildings. Our family of four ate quite inexpensively ($3 for a delicious beef stew). We stayed at the Tokyo Hilton International Hotel, and the office buildings were across the street from the hotel.

LEAD: A court-ordered study describes in vivid detail the ways in which New York City's deeply troubled foster-care system has temporarily kept hundreds of children in violence-plagued, cramped and poorly equipped field offices.

LEAD: THE school term is starting quietly for most New Jersey schools this year, but several longstanding issues are coming to a head, threatening fundamental changes to the state's system of public education.

LEAD: BELEAGURED county officials trying to administer the increasingly overcrowded corrections complex in Valhalla received a double dose of bad news last week. The inmate population reached 1,401 - the highest level in county history - as a Federal judge ordered further restrictions on the use of inmate lounges to house extra prisoners.

LEAD: THIS summer the state of Pennsylvania began closing Philadelphia State Hospital, whose nickname - Byberry - had come to symbolize the snakepits that public mental hospitals were and sometimes still are. Where 5,500 patients once slept in filthy hallways and ate wormy food, only about 400 remain.

LEAD: A STOREFRONT restaurant called Main Street sounds like a casual salad and sandwich spot. But Port Washington's Main Street Restaurant is much more than that. This snazzy charmer is a serious dinner only establishment with exciting appetite seducers.

LEAD: The Presidential election campaign is focusing attention on two trends that many economists have trouble reconciling: While the nation's economy has demonstrated a spectacular ability to create plenty of jobs, wages generally have not kept up with inflation.

LEAD: IT WAS 1973 and Ansley J. Coale was fed up with academia. So he bought 2,000 acres in Ukiah, Calif., in Mendocino County. It's only two hours north of Berkeley, where he'd been teaching Greek and Roman history, but - emotionally at least - it's about as far from faculty meetings as it's possible to get.

LEAD: AT the beginning of this century Britain's King Edward VII was a bridge enthusiast and usually played a social game - auction in those days - after dinner. The royal family has been distinctly short of players since then.

LEAD: THE NAME AND ADDRESS YIELD a delightful polyglot: Hsi Lai Buddhist Temple, Hacienda Heights, Calif. The ''west-coming'' temple, now being constructed by the Fo Kuang Shan Buddhist society, based in Taiwan, consists of 10 buildings on 15 acres in a suburban community 20 miles east of Los Angeles. The complex, which includes shrines, a monastery and a Buddhist museum, constitutes the largest Buddhist temple in North America.

LEAD: Two of the wealthiest foundations in the United States are starting multimillion-dollar programs to curb unwanted population growth in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

LEAD: Eight of the 16 seeded players in the men's draw and six of the seeded women were eliminated in the first week of the United States Open, and the men's third round has not yet been completed. Thus, the rainy-day question yesterday was whether that was good or bad news for tennis. Critics often complain that the game is dominated by a handful of players, which can make the weekly results repetitive.

LEAD: Lynda Susan Bolnick, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Bolnick of Millville, N.J., was married yesterday to Neal Martin Eiseman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Eiseman of Little Silver, N.J. Rabbi Charles Gelernter performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club. The bride graduated from Georgetown University.

LEAD: He wasn't chosen by his party as its candidate for President, but Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, is the Senator most respected by top Senate aides, while Chic Hecht, Republican of Nevada, ranks last.
LEAD: A Queens teen-ager has been charged in the slaying of a mother of five who was shot to death in her Mister Softee truck during a robbery attempt.

LEAD: It's New York City Marathon time again, at least for those planning to run in it. For the benefit of first-time marathoners and veterans with short memories (all marathoners have short memories ), here's a training guide that should put you in good stead for the big day.

LEAD: It will not be surprising if the World Team Olympiad, scheduled to begin in Venice on Oct. 8, proves disappointing for the favorites. Some of the countries that have won in the past, like France, are not at full strength. And many countries that have never won have closed the gap by developing new talent.

LEAD: For organized labor, the Reagan era has been a long and painful period of retreat: membership declined, union wages stagnated and Federal officials have often been passive in enforcing the thousands of Government rules that labor leaders see as essential to protecting workers' health and safety.

LEAD: While both major Presidential candidates are embracing family issues, a battle is continuing in Congress over a bill requiring certain employers to provide workers with unpaid leave to care for sick or newborn children. With a vote on both the Senate and House versions of the legislation possible this month, a variety of groups are scrambling to be heard.

LEAD: The first group of Soviet athletes participating in the Seoul Olympics arrived over the weekend by ship from Vladivostok. The 27 members of the yachting team, sailors and officials, disembarked 300 miles south of here in Pusan, South Korea's second-largest city, where the yachting events will be held.
