LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel will visit Hungary later this month, Hungarians and foreign diplomats say.
LEAD: ''I'm sitting here right now with a stack of invoices trying to decide which subscriptions to cancel,'' said Keith McKinney, the chief of periodicals at the New York Public Library.
LEAD: A ruling from a New Jersey judge suggests that the national movement for parity in funding of school districts, which lagged in the late 1970's, is gaining again. That's cause for celebration.

LEAD: James E. Preston, president of Avon Products Inc., has been named to the additional post of chief executive. Mr. Preston, 55 years old, was named president in May, becoming the heir apparent to Hicks B. Waldron, 64, the chairman and chief executive, who plans to retire at the end of the year. As president, Mr.

LEAD: Great egrets glide over the peaceful Suisun Marsh and antlered tule elks trumpet for their mates in these warm final days of summer, oblivious that something of a revolution in wildlife management has begun around them.

LEAD: In the first major test of the degree of campaign freedom to be allowed opponents of President Augusto Pinochet, more than 100,000 people rallied today and called for his defeat in the coming plebiscite.

LEAD: Ken Green was leading by three strokes with seven holes to play in the final round of the 79th Canadian Open today when thunder, lightning and heavy rain forced the Royal Canadian Golf Association to postpone completion of the tournament until Monday morning.

LEAD: When the Freer Gallery of Art closes tomorrow for renovations, its colony of turtles will be boarded out among employees of the Smithsonian Institution, of which the gallery is a part. Because turtles normally are not among the items displayed at an art museum, one might wonder how they got there.

LEAD: Shortly after he arrived to become New York City's Schools Chancellor last March, Dr. Richard R. Green accepted an invitation to what he thought was a cocktail party to meet some of the leaders of the city's Hispanic advocacy groups.
LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, ended a five-day swing through the South today with a continuation of the strong attacks on Mr. Dukakis that he began last week.

LEAD: Surrounded by several thousand followers, the 86-year-old Grand Rabbi of Lubavitch put a shovel in the earth and broke ground last week for a new $23 million headquarters for the Hasidic group he heads.
LEAD: A police investigator who believed a large metal spoon was a pistol fatally shot a man during a drug raid, an Essex County prosecutor said.

LEAD: While farmers and ranchers are still cursing this summer's drought, beachgoers in Chicago and all around the Great Lakes are reveling in the hot, dry weather at beaches that were under water only a few months ago.
LEAD: A new English-language newspaper began here Friday, published by American investors who think native English speakers form Israel's most affluent and educated community.

LEAD: By early September the Arctic winter is closing in on this 32,000-ton exploratory oil rig, with plunging temperatures bringing a rapid freeze-up to the surrounding sea. Then, as the polar region moves into the 24-hour winter night, heaves in the icepack thicken to as much as 13 feet, pressing the rig's huge steel skirt with forces that have crushed dozens of ships.

LEAD: A week earlier, callers to radio stations in Tallahassee were clamoring to hear the ''Seminole Rap,'' the self-congratulatory recording that made Bobby Bowden, the football coach at Florida State University, swallow hard and wonder about its timing.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, faced with protests from the press, the legal profession and members of his own party over a new defamation law, said today that the bill would not be put before the upper house of Parliament on Monday as planned. The proposed law, which editors say would curtail investigative reporting and endanger the traditional independence of Indian publications, was passed by the lower house of Parliament last week.
LEAD: These days, most of the things Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush do on the stump are carefully staged media events.
LEAD: Worried about having interest on their savings taxed at the source, West Germans have joined foreign investors in a significant exodus out of mark deposits.

LEAD: NEW YORK Parade: Starts at 11 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, travels north to 72d Street, then east to Third Avenue. Government offices: Closed.
LEAD: About 250 people joined hands by the shore in heavy rain yesterday to call for the cleanup of the seas.

LEAD: James N. Black, a jazz drummer who played with such musicians as Lionel Hampton, Cannonball Adderley, John Coltrane and Dr. John, died Tuesday. He was 48 years old. The cause of death was not announced, pending the result of an autopsy.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a Geneva conference to review compliance with the Antiballistic Missile Treaty misstated the American position on a disputed Soviet radar. The United States said it would consider declaring the Soviet Union in ''material breach'' of the treaty if it did not dismantle the radar; it was not the first such warning, and the United States did not say it would necessarily take the action.
LEAD: Japan posted a current account surplus of $6.48 billion in July, down 11 percent from $7.28 billion a year earlier but up slightly from $6.43 billion in June, the Finance Ministry said Friday.
LEAD: The Pizza Connection Lawyers, Drugs and the Mafia By Shana Alexander 352 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.
LEAD: Tony Zendejas kicked a 35-yard field goal 3 minutes 51 seconds into overtime today to give the Houston Oilers a 17-14 victory over the Indianapolis Colts.

LEAD: ''Saint-Gaudens: Masque of the Golden Bowl,'' a film about the 19th-century American sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens, is a mild and at times schizophrenic docudrama. Made in 1985, the film was written by Will N. Goetzmann and directed and produced by T. W. Timreck. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

LEAD: Jennifer Lee Altshuler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Altshuler of Belmont, Mass., and Barry D. Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Green of Maplewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Harrison Inn in Southbury, Conn., by Rabbi Robert Levine.

LEAD: The Transit Authority, facing an increasing concentration of homeless people living in open squalor in subway stations and on the trains, is in midst of an anguished internal policy debate over how to resolve a problem that officials believe has implications for ridership levels, revenues and public image.

LEAD: The A. H. Robins bankruptcy has turned into a battle for control over the case between a Federal judge who engineered its settlement and a tenacious law firm that has played a significant role in the proceeding.
LEAD: The transition to a younger generation in Singapore's leadership may not be complete, as Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew asserted early this morning, but it is well under way.
LEAD: A restaurant chain will pay $15,000 each to 23 people who sued, alleging they were denied service because of their race or ethnicity.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fighting and seasonal flooding are blocking Western relief efforts in the southern Sudan, where local reports indicate that 8,000 people have starved to death in recent weeks, the authorities say.
LEAD: A body found today in Long Island Sound was tentatively identified as that of a man blown off a tanker that exploded last week.

LEAD: Seeing an enormous opportunity in all the Americans who are dollar rich and too time poor to go out to eat, a rapidly growing number of restaurants and food service companies are beginning to deliver prepared food.

LEAD: One of the nagging doubts created by the exercise boom is the possibility that all this rushing about in the name of fitness might turn out to be harmful many years from now. That might seem unlikely, given the care with which most modern medical research is conducted. After all, the evidence seems persuasive that becoming aerobically fit has a number of positive health benefits, particularly in staving off heart disease.

LEAD: In the rain and gloom of opening day, the Jets' offense slipped, and the surprising New York defense finally gave way today to older, cooler New England players as the Patriots produced a 28-3 victory.
LEAD: Mickey Hatcher, the Los Angeles Dodgers' resident wit, noted the steady rain that was drenching Shea Stadium and said, ''I told you our luck would change.''

LEAD: Nancy Beer and Glenn Patrick Tobin, who both received master's degrees in public policy from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, were married at Old City Hall in Boston yesterday. Rabbi Benjamin Rudofsky and the Rev. Dan Graham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Something is afoot in shoes, and it's a boon for women who walk a lot. Those towering heels that have been de rigueur for dress-up occasions in recent seasons are inching downward.

LEAD: The benefits of an improved economy have bypassed young American families, who face an era of vanishing dreams, according to a new study by the Children's Defense Fund.

LEAD: 11TH DISTRICT Representative Edolphus Towns, 54. Seeking fourth term. Second black Congressman from Brooklyn. Graduated from North Carolina A & T and holds a master's in social welfare from Adelphi University. Deputy borough president under Howard Golden for six years before his election to the House in 1982.

LEAD: While exploring inland waterways in one of the last tracts of rain forest left on the island of Madagascar, scientists from the American Museum of Natural History recently identified a previously unknown species of fish.
LEAD: A RESEARCH institute here is abuzz with biological ammunition for a war to save Africa's largest food crop.

LEAD: The painting, cleaning and waxing are done, the desks arranged and the supplies and class lists checked in New Jersey's 2,247 public schools. But this year, as more than a million students return to class, there are new concerns about the quality of education in poor urban districts.

LEAD: Pernod-Ricard S.A., France's largest wine and spirits company, today announced a friendly takeover offer for Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. and said it already owned or had been promised 51.8 percent of the shares of Ireland's leading whisky maker.
LEAD: A man on a disabled boat was rescued when a lifeguard swam to it through fog and a heavy sea and used his orange surfboard to attract a Coast Guard searchlight, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: Fifty people were arrested today when a group trying to distribute free food and leaflets scuffled with the police, who had previously warned the group to get a permit or move.

LEAD: People old enough to remember Kate Smith or Bugs Bunny singing ''Buy a Bond Today'' on behalf of the United States Treasury in World War II may think that kind of promotional effort is a thing of the past.

LEAD: An official is promising to close a legal loophole that allowed bullfights to be held here over the weekend, but Hispanic residents argue that a ban would strip them of their culture and heritage.
LEAD: Pizza Hut will soon join Kentucky Fried Chicken in bringing American fast food to China's capital.

LEAD: Wad-ing through waist-deep water late last week in the Muhammadpur residential district of the capital, Iqbal Ahmed, his few belongings on his shoulder, headed for the school on the Mirpur Road, which was still unaffected by the devastating floods.
LEAD: Talks on the future of American military bases were indefinitely postponed today after the Greek Government notified United States negotiators that it would close one of the bases.

LEAD: Vice President Bush began his final push for the Presidency today, extolling American patriotism, slashing his Democratic opponent and, with equal enthusiasm and less precision, taking a knife to an inert but telegenic white sea bass.

LEAD: A Congressional bid to grant Ivan Lendl immediate American citizenship so he can play on the United States Olympic tennis team has failed because Czechoslovak officials refused to provide the necessary waivers, lawmakers said.

LEAD: THE proliferation of word-processing programs, all accomplishing pretty much the same basic tasks and each requiring a largely different set of commands to do so, can present a serious problem for many users.

LEAD: Bruce Springsteen, Sting, Peter Gabriel, Tracy Chapman, Youssou N'Dour and other performers in Amnesty International's rock concert tour made the French capital their second stop, with concerts yesterday and today.

LEAD: Alexander & Baldwin Inc., founded in 1880 by two Hawaiian missionaries, is making plans to select its 14th chief executive. The preparations for the management shift that is not expected before April 1991 are as gradual and deliberate as the company's style.
LEAD: The military's bomb squad is nearly doubling as the United States tries to respond to world terrorism, a Navy officer says.

LEAD: The Jets' long season is under way. The players had an unscheduled practice today to go over mistakes in Sunday's 28-3 loss to the Patriots, and Coach Joe Walton spoke of having patience ''up to a point.''

LEAD: AFTER more than a year of haggling in Congress, significant revisions to the 15-year-old law that gave health maintenance organizations entree into American health care are close to being enacted. By eliminating some protections and restrictions for health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, the legislation could make them more attractive to employers.
LEAD: A MAJOR new round of probes to the inner and outer reaches of the solar system could yield important clues about how life began on Earth, say scientists who study the mystery of life's origins.

LEAD: The snap in the air that signals the onset of autumn also prompts clothes-minded shoppers to seek out the newest styles. At least this is the hope of retail executives. Still reeling from months of flat sales, they are facing the season with a mixture of cautious optimism, carefully planned strategies for recovery and an urgent need for a look that will lead the way.
LEAD: Bolts of lightning strike far more often than weather records indicate, making electrical storms more dangerous than previously believed, according to a weather researcher.

LEAD: A nuclear power plant caught fire in Lithuania today, but automatic safety systems put out the flames before radiation was released, the official Tass press agency reported. Tass said no one was injured in the blaze, which began at 12:50 A.M. in a control cable of the second reactor at the Ignalina nuclear power plant, about 60 miles northeast of Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian Republic.
LEAD: The 50 states and the District of Columbia spend widely differing amounts to represent criminal defendants who cannot afford a lawyer, the Justice Department reported today.

LEAD: Three United States Governors met with Japanese officials today and appealed for more investment in their states. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Buddy Roemer of Louisiana and Ray Mabus of Mississippi said their states' economies have been damaged by declines in manufacturing and the oil industry. But they emphasized that the region is rich in assets Japan needs.

LEAD: At a Labor Day rally at the base of the Statue of Liberty, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, Dan Quayle, began a new attack on Michael S. Dukakis for the Democrat's opposition to making the Pledge of Allegiance a mandatory start of the school day.

LEAD: THREE years ago Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut, gave the first commencement address at a most unusual graduation ceremony: for one student who received a master's degree from the newly formed National Technological University.
LEAD: This is George Adamson country, five miles south of the Equator, a harsh region blanketed with sandy soil and prickly gray thorn bushes and populated by wild game and Somali nomads.

LEAD: For the last 20 years, a specter has periodically haunted the closets of capitals in the Western alliance: fear of a major reduction in the number of American troops stationed in Europe and Asia.

LEAD: The Israeli Labor Party opened its campaign for the Nov. 1 parliamentary elections today, vowing to ''terminate Israeli rule over 1.5 million Palestinian Arabs who are inhabitants'' of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
LEAD: Treasury financings for the holiday-shortened week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

LEAD: Doug Gilmour, the center who is the target of a lawsuit alleging sexual misconduct with a minor, was traded by the St. Louis Blues yesterday to the Calgary Flames along with the right wing Mark Hunter and two other players. In return, St. Louis received the forward Mike Bullard, the defenseman Craig Coxe and the rights to the defenseman Tim Corkery.

LEAD: After a week of controversy and uncertainty, the Giants opened their season this evening by edging the Washington Redskins, 27-20.
LEAD: The 37-nation International Cocoa Organization began discussions here today to resolve their differences regarding price supports for cocoa.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The most expensive rescue of a single savings association was announced. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board agreed to the sale of the largest insolvent institution, the $30 billion American Savings and Loan Association of California, to the Robert M. Bass Group. The Fort Worth-based investor group will inject $550 million into American.
LEAD: Parking next to a fire hydrant in Manhattan's theater district is, for many visitors, as much a part of a night out as a drink at intermission.

LEAD: IN a novel approach to teaching the intricate details of human anatomy, some medical schools are experimenting with advanced computer-imaging techniques to create electronic ''cadavers.'' Systems are being designed so that young medical students can ''dissect'' electronic images, rather than using real cadavers for their initial lessons.

LEAD: ''The Brutal Craft'' takes us back 150 years, to an era when limbs were sawed off without benefit of anesthesia, cleanliness was of little matter to surgeons and blood transfusions were unknown. This first installment of a new four-part series on ''Nova'' called ''Pioneers of Surgery'' will be shown tonight at 8 on Channel 21 and at 9 on Channel 13.

LEAD: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., Julie Greifer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Greifer of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Swidler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Swidler of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A MID growing suspense and excitement, two separate teams of paleontologists in the West are slowly extracting from the ground enormous fossil bones. One of the groups may soon be able to claim the discovery of the longest dinosaur ever known.
LEAD: IN the first half, the Redskins' defense was jumping around and confusing the Giants' offensive line as Phil Simms called signals.
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency has formed a new task force to coordinate its responses to the threat of pollution by medical wastes.

LEAD: Canada passed a major milestone today on the way to a long-delayed land settlement with its indigenous people. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney signed an agreement that will give 39,000 Indians, Eskimos and people of mixed ancestry living along the boundaries of the Arctic Ocean ownership of an area the size of
LEAD: It is one thing for a defense to force turnovers. It is quite another for a defense to score off them.
LEAD: It will be a case of the former regulators assessing the current regulators.
LEAD: One person was killed and nine others aboard a commercial aircraft were injured today when the plane crashed near a lake shortly after taking off from Sitka, the Coast Guard said.

LEAD: The sudden death last year of Mario Merola, who had served with distinction for 14 years as District Attorney of the Bronx, left a sizable gap in New York City's criminal justice hierarchy. In a race that may be the most important in New York's Sept. 15 Democratic primary, four men seek to replace him.

LEAD: With $192,000 in contempt-of-court fines due today, the Mayor and the City Council of Yonkers struggled again yesterday for a compromise to carry out a court-ordered housing desegregation plan and resolve the political turmoil that has threatened the city with bankruptcy.

LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to act as a ''white knight'' and acquire the Essex Chemical Corporation for $36 a share, or about $366 million. The offer was $2.25 more than the Friday closing price of Essex's stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: A Westchester County man was arrested on drunken-driving charges after his car slammed into a telephone pole, killing one passenger and critically injuring another, the Southampton police said yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Hollywood summer of 1988, which ends this week, has been as big a blockbuster as its major movies - ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' ''Coming to America,'' ''Crocodile Dundee II'' and ''Big.''

LEAD: The season's first week reminded several teams of an ugly lesson already learned: no matter how much preparation goes into preseason, no method prevents the havoc injury can bring. Especially at quarterback. Ask Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback. Montana threw three third-quarter touchdown passes against the New Orleans Saints and then had to leave the game due to a bruised elbow on his right, or throwing, arm.

LEAD: FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Activated Rick Bryan, defensive end; Scott Case, cornerback; John Rade, linebacker, and Rick Donnelly, punter. Placed Tim Green, linebacker, and James Milling, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Released Lewis Colbert, punter, and Tom Strauthers, defensive end. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Re-signed Darrell Colbert, wide receiver.
LEAD: A 22-year-old Navy recruit was arraigned on a murder charge yesterday in the fatal shooting of his older brother.

LEAD: A new Ford Mustang convertible rolls off the assembly line here every few minutes, ready to be shipped to a Ford dealer for sale to someone who thinks the sunshine and wind in their hair is worth an extra $4,000.

LEAD: The economy's robust growth rate slowed in August, but healthy gains are expected in the third quarter, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.
LEAD: GOLD, one of the heaviest chemical elements, is the basis of a new lightweight plastic foam under development as a radiation shield.

LEAD: The calendar says that autumn does not begin until the equinox on Sept. 22, but as everyone who goes back to work the day after Labor Day can tell you, it feels as though it starts today. The same is true for thoroughbred racing's best season.

LEAD: It is a bit of a journey from the capital to West Branch, Iowa, but for connoisseurs of Presidential trivia, it might be worth the trip to view the Herbert Hoover Library's exhibition of artifacts relating to 39 Presidents.

LEAD: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi resigned Monday after seven years in office, but will remain as a caretaker premier until a successor is named, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported today.

LEAD: THE first detailed studies of babies exposed to cocaine before birth suggest that this widely used drug is causing an epidemic of damaged infants, some of whom may be impaired for life because their mothers used cocaine even briefly during pregnancy.

LEAD: Barneys New York, which started out six decades ago as a clothing discounter and evolved into a major retailer of international men's wear, opens its first satellite store this morning in the World Financial Center, right on the edge of Manhattan's financial district.

LEAD: THE reigning king of American elms, a 125-foot behemoth on a farm in Southeast Virginia, is stricken with Dutch elm disease and has only a year to live, according to experts in arboreal medicine.
LEAD: * Comdisco Disaster Recovery Services Inc., Rosemont, Ill., a subsidiary of Comdisco Inc. that provides computer disaster-recovery services, named John A. Jackson executive vice president.

LEAD: The traditional Labor Day opening of a Presidential campaign that has really been under way for weeks was observed yesterday by thousands of Americans who spent part of their holiday in the company of the candidates and millions more who watched them attack each other on television.

LEAD: Most American colleges had modest beginnings, and Barnard, about to embark on its yearlong centennial celebration, was no exception. It started out with several rooms in a Madison Avenue brownstone, a handful of students, a few teachers and some chairs with writing arms.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis set out on the final stretch of his Presidential campaign today with a rallying cry for the middle class, asserting that average families could not afford four more years of Republican rule and promising to ''bring prosperity home.''
LEAD: The Attorney General of California, John Van de Kamp, has filed suit to challenge the American Stores Company's acquisition of Lucky Stores Inc., contending the merger was anti-competitive.
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson/USA has won the Computer Associates account over Della Femina, McNamee WCRS and Campbell-Mithun-Esty. The budget is $7 million.

LEAD: Larry Parrish hit his fourth home run in five games and Mike Smithson earned his first victory since July 23 as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1, tonight and took sole possession of first place in the American League East.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Tuesday New-Car Sales August Wednesday None Thursday Consumer Credit July Friday Producer Prices August
LEAD: THE science of genetics is fast becoming what geneticists always knew it was: the central and most provocative science of life.

LEAD: The Town of Hempstead started its crackdown on June 25. There were reports that a man was bringing his own chair to the town beach at Atlantic Beach Estates, a clear-cut violation of 78-41! Town law requires that anyone at that beach who wants a chair must rent said chair from the concessionaire. Or else!

LEAD: Chun Kyung Hwan, younger brother of South Korea's former President, was found guilty today of embezzlement and bribe-taking in a corruption case that has become a lightning rod for public anger at the abuses of his brother's Government.

LEAD: Vandals slashed seats at the Cineplex Odeon Showcase Theater and spray-painted threats against a studio executive early today in an apparent protest against the film ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' the police said.

LEAD: Marvin Zindler, the man who closed the real-life ''Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' has succeeded in a new mission. He has gone to Hanoi, the capital of Vietnam, and rescued ''two brave children who were trapped there after the war.''
LEAD: From all appearances, Robert M. Bass is having an active year as a deal maker.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 4,1988: TUESDAY Chyron Corp Cincinnati Bell WEDNESDAY Ames Dept Stores Portland Gen Co Browning-Ferris Ind Premier Industrial Handleman Co Stanhome Inc Louisville G & E LS Starrett Co Penwalt Corp Witco Corp Phillips-Van Heusen THURSDAY Allegheny Power Hancock Fabric Brown Group Idaho Power Engelhard Corp Rykoff-Sexton Inc General Host SPS Technologies Green Mountain Power Trinity Indus FRIDAY Aluminum Co America Mercantile Stores DeSoto Inc Nerco Inc $

LEAD: IN his final address last week, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett praised seven schools as models for excellence in elementary education. One of them was School No. 59, Science Magnet, in Buffalo.
LEAD: ''I've been accumulating stress points,'' said Alan Benasuli, a securities analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''I've got a new job, I'm moving to a new town, and I just got married.''

LEAD: ''Lightning apparently does not command the respect it deserves as a dangerous killer.'' - E. W. Friday, director of the National Weather Service, commenting about a rise in lightning-related injuries last year. [ C7:6. ]

LEAD: Samsung Semiconductor, a South Korean company trying to increase sales of its computer chips in the United States, achieved a major breakthrough in July. Arrow Electronics Inc., the nation's second-largest distributor of semiconductors, agreed to sell its products.

LEAD: Revo Inc. of San Jose, Calif., has awarded its sunglasses business to Tarlow Advertising, which opened in January. The current budget of $2 million is expected to rise significantly. Advertising will be print, mainly in magazines. The former agency was Della Femina, Travisano & Partners in Los Angeles.
LEAD: Utility crews completed repairs today on the last of six electricity cables damaged in a fire that caused a loss of power in 50 blocks of downtown Seattle for nearly four days.

LEAD: Pushed by Peugeot, France is battling other European nations over proposals to tighten automobile emissions standards, and some environmental groups are now threatening to boycott the auto maker for its role in scuttling an agreement to reduce standards for small cars.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WOMEN taking estrogen after menopause were half as likely to die from a stroke as women who had not taken the female hormone, according to a new study in the British Medical Journal.
LEAD: A generation after the civil rights movement began on their hometown streets, Southern newspapers have emerged as a major voice in the coverage of national politics.
LEAD: Commercial television advertising grew 7.9 percent, to $11.83 billion, in the first half of 1988, from $10.96 billion a year earlier, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: There is a word for people like Bill Lajoie. It's ''class,'' and there are too few occasions to use it.

LEAD: For each of the three plays in Sir Peter Hall's cycle of late Shakespeare at the National Theater - ''Cymbeline,'' ''The Winter's Tale'' and ''The Tempest''- there was a note inserted in the program informing us that ''owing to the indisposition of John Bluthal,'' certain roles would be played by other actors.

LEAD: North Korea pledged today that it would not disrupt the Olympic Games in South Korea and charged that any incident marring the Games would be an American-South Korean plot to create an excuse to invade the North.

LEAD: Beber Silverstein & Partners, Miami, has set up a theatrical advertising unit in its New York office with the help of Peter LaDonne and Jon Wilner. They previously ran Fisher/ LaDonne/Wilner Entertainment, which totaled more than $10 million in billings last year from creating ads for Broadway hits like ''La Cage Aux Folles'' and ''Into the Woods.

LEAD: A tentative deal was reached Friday for the French business executive Bernard Tapie to take a majority share in Donnay S.A., the Belgian sporting goods maker that went bankrupt last month, officials said.

LEAD: Pressure on the Federal Reserve Board to push up short-term interest rates again soon has eased somewhat, credit market analysts say, as the Government's first report for August activity showed signs that an economic slowdown may have begun.

LEAD: Roger Ailes, media consultant to George Bush, calls it ''baloney'' that a series of Bush-Dukakis debates would be good for the country. Voters would watch only one or two of them, he told a recent interviewer, and besides, ''I don't think you learn anything about the issues'' from Presidential debates.
LEAD: A group wants to start what it believes would be the first television station in the country that offers a full slate of programming aimed at a Jewish audience.

LEAD: The United States has offered to more than double its aid commitment to the Philippines in exchange for guarantees on the use of American military bases there for the next two years, a State Department official said today. But the official said the Government in Manila had rejected the offer, which amounted to about $360 million a year, and was seeking an annual aid package of $1.2 billion.
LEAD: Geidar A. Aliyev, the former party leader of the Azerbaijani Republic, is recalled by his admirers as a gracious host and by his detractors, including the Soviet press, as a notorious toady.

LEAD: The marriage of Ann Gail Schaumberger, an associate at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, to Steven Nicokiris, a manager with the accounting firm of Mahoney, Cohen & Company in New York, took place yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club. Rabbi Ronald Millstein performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Mars will move to within about 36 million miles of Earth this month, the closest it has been in 17 years.

LEAD: Aaron Krickstein was supposed to be the next dominant American player, a role that was unclaimed until the emergence of Andre Agassi this year. He was only 16 years old when he made headlines at the 1983 United States Open, becoming the youngest player ever to reach the round of 16 in the men's draw.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in The Week in Review Sunday inaccurately characterized the electoral outlook in Indiana. That state appears to be strongly Republican.

LEAD: Shipping companies, the Coast Guard and the Army Corps of Engineers are joining in an effort to make sure the bottlenecks that idled Mississippi River traffic during this summer's drought will not recur, a shipping executive says.

LEAD: In a blow to space scientists, two of the nine space shuttle flights planned for next year are to be delayed, and with them key astronomical missions, according to a new shuttle-launching schedule made public last week by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
LEAD: Gert Frobe, the German actor who starred as Goldfinger in the James Bond film of that name, died of a heart attack today in a Munich hospital. He was 75 years old.
LEAD: Soviet athletes who win medals at the Seoul Olympics will be paid the equivalent of up to $19,000 for their winning performances.

LEAD: Following Viktor Korchnoi's success in the Royan International Tournament in France, the former challenger for the world title continued his climb out of the doldrums by taking another first prize, this time in a much stronger event, the O.H.R.A. Crown Group International Tournament in Amsterdam.
LEAD: Eleven victories over the Pittsburgh Pirates in 15 games played. And now, 10 games in front with 25 to go.

LEAD: Oil production from Federal waters off California should double by 1992, according to an Interior Department official. William Bettenberg, director of the department's Minerals Management Service, said last week that production from platforms for which permits already had been granted should bring the total to 200,000 to 225,000 barrels a day.

LEAD: The congestion around Court 16 made it nearly impossible to move, people milling, shoving, blustering their way toward the small grandstand already filled above capacity. On the court, Stephanie Rehe said, she could almost feel the crowd, the noise and commotion a constant distraction. It was just the kind of scene Gabriela
LEAD: To many of the people marching in the parade up Fifth Avenue yesterday, the point of having a Labor Day holiday was clear.

LEAD: An old master and his protege scored with 3-year-old colts on different fronts yesterday as Woody Stephens sent out Posen to win the $147,500 Rutgers Handicap at The Meadowlands and Phil Gleaves, his former assistant, saddled Evening Kris to win the $294,000 Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park.

LEAD: Three prison guards were injured, none seriously, when about 100 inmates surrounded the officers during a recreation period at the Elmira Correctional Facility, a union official said. The officers were injured Sunday night after they tried to break up a fight between two inmates, one of whom was stabbed, said Dennis Middaugh, president of Local 1240 of the municipal employee union.

LEAD: The trial of Yuri M. Churbanov, son in-law of the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, began here today with court officers offering a lengthy reading of bribery and corruption charges and a defense attorney venting indignation over sensational pretrial publicity, in a display worthy of an American trial lawyer.
LEAD: * Seymour L. Leikind has been appointed publisher of Jobson's Beverage Alcohol Group publications.

LEAD: Q. If osteoporosis occurs more often in postmenopausal women because of estrogen deficiency, why don't men get it even more often, and at younger ages? A. It is true that men don't have as much of the hormone estrogen as women, but ''the male hormone androgen, which normal men have in considerably supply, appears to exert similar protective effects on the skeleton,'' said Dr.

LEAD: An explosion in a fireworks display marking Labor Day weekend killed a 28-year-old man in his hometown, officials said today. The victim, Scott F. Broster, who returned to practice law in this southern Illinois town of 2,300 people about a year ago, was helping set off the fireworks when the accident happened Sunday night, Mayor Jack Hagedorn said.
LEAD: When the season began, Roberto Kelly was the Yankees' center fielder. Five months later, he shares a clubhouse locker with Randy Velarde.
LEAD: The Epson Worldwide Pairs, played early in June, was a popular success with an underlying political problem. Should South Africa be included?
LEAD: REMEMBER when diet soft drinks were promoted on television only by curvaceous women in bikinis?

LEAD: Laurie Nell Mayers, a daughter of Audrey Poole of Bedford, N.Y., and Lawrence S. Mayers of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Gaston Rosenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rosenberg of Weston, Conn. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: Iva Mack nearly always orders a hamburger when she eats in a coffee shop. She is not especially fond of hamburgers. But she cannot read a menu and is fairly sure a coffee shop will have a hamburger.

LEAD: Lawyers representing investors in the Washington Public Power Supply System said yesterday that they had reached a $20 million settlement with one of the defendants in a huge securities fraud trial scheduled to begin this week.
LEAD: The 330,000-member electricians' union was expelled from the Trades Union Congress today, causing the most serious split in decades in the once all-powerful British union movement.

LEAD: Iraqi troops pursuing rebellious Kurdish guerrillas dug in today at their border with Turkey, hoisting aloft their banners to assert authority over an area the rebels had long claimed to control themselves.
LEAD: Federal, state and local government offices were closed yesterday because of the Labor Day holiday. The stock and commodity markets, banks and many businesses were also closed.
LEAD: If George Bush wanted Dan Quayle on his ticket partly to close the gender gap, the choice has already produced one advance for women.

LEAD: Space Clues to Life on Earth Space probes are seeking evidence to support the theory that the universe is awash with the chemical precursors of life. Science Times, page C1. Japan's Foreign Policy Shedding a shyness born of its defeat in World War II, Japan is beginning to assert itself on the diplomatic stage.
LEAD: An Iraqi opposition group backed by Iran said today that its agents in Baghdad had shot and seriously wounded the eldest son of President Saddam Hussein.

LEAD: Does the budget deficit really matter? The Presidential candidates have certainly been told by their advisers that a failure to bring down the deficit will make it far more difficult to steer a safe course between inflation and recession in coming years. But neither George Bush nor Michael Dukakis seems to see political advantage in advancing a realistic proposal for deficit reduction.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Man With No Name is joining the movies' great names - the Capras, the Welleses, the Hitchcocks, the Walshes, the Bergmans (Ingrid and Ingmar) and all the others whose life and work have become the subject of serious film study.

LEAD: This city has confirmed the old capitalist adage that there's money to be made on poverty, and in the process, it has become a pioneer in providing attractive low-cost housing for the homeless and the working poor.

LEAD: The loss of war plans for the defense of the American-controlled sector of the NATO front could be the most serious aspect of the espionage operation uncovered in West Germany last month. Western officials say

LEAD: Encouraged by sunny skies and enabled by an extra day off, New Yorkers thronged city streets yesterday for a pair of outdoor events - one featuring the Caribbean, the other organized labor, but both tinged with the political striving that Labor Day, as the unofficial end of summer, traditionally begins.
LEAD: Cold, strong winds put a touch of fear into Ken Green this morning even though he held a three-stroke lead with seven holes to play in the 79th Canadian Open.
LEAD: Because of a production error, some copies of the Times were incorrectly assembled yesterday. No pages were missing, but page 23 should have been the start of the second section.
LEAD: Share prices closed higher in London today, helped by bullish sentiment from United States employment figures released on Friday.

LEAD: A memorial tribute to Don Erickson, an editor on the staff of The New York Times Magazine, who died on Aug. 2, will be held on Wednesday, Sept. 14, at noon in the second-floor auditorium of the McGraw-Hill Building at the Avenue of the Americas and 49th Street.
LEAD: Japan is struggling, sometimes against its own instincts, to break away from its follow-the-leader foreign policy and take more initiatives on its own.

LEAD: A Titan 2, the first of a new generation of American rockets intended to diminish the military's reliance on the troubled space shuttle, successfully carried a secret payload into orbit yesterday.

LEAD: From coast to coast, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis attacked each other yesterday as they observed the traditional Labor Day opening of a Presidential campaign that has hardly paused for a kind word in weeks.

LEAD: Drug abuse is an issue that is cutting across the lines of Congressional Districts and urban, suburban and even rural constituencies in seven primary contests for Democratic Congressional nominations, from poor areas of Brooklyn to middle-class and affluent Hudson Valley towns and counties.
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced the most expensive rescue of a single savings and loan association on record in a transaction that will cost the agency $2 billion.

LEAD: Q. Now vee may perhaps to begin. You were born in Newark, on March 19, 1933. Your parents, Herman and Bess Roth, named you Philip. You are a writer, primarily a novelist. But now, seated in your publisher's office at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, you say that you have written an autobiography, entitled ''The Facts.

LEAD: Daniela Costain of Rumania, who had the longest discus throw of the year at one point and was considered a medal contender for the Olympics, has been granted asylum in Turkey and is seeking to immigrate to Australia. A spokesman for the Australian immigration department said the request was being considered and that Costain could be allowed to enter the country under a special category for ''people with something to offer.

LEAD: South and Central Americans, overshadowed for years by the Cubans in the large Hispanic community here, are making significant demographic and economic gains, Latin leaders and other experts say.
LEAD: Mike Tyson remained in stable condition yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after an automobile accident Sunday in Catskill, N.Y.

LEAD: Hot off the press is the premier issue of Corporate Video Decisions, issued by Act III Publishing. With a controlled circulation, the new publication is intended for some 40,000 decision makers in the corporate video market. Joseph J. Allen is the publisher, and James Kaminsky is the editor. The cover price is $5.

LEAD: An all-star cast of the international left - Karl Marx, Mother Jones, Fidel Castro, Lenin, Malcolm X and other leaders of the working class -is appearing in a new but very old-fashioned political wall painting. The huge work, known as ''The Pathfinder Mural,'' is nearing completion on the side of a building at West and Charles Streets in Greenwich Village, and its creators are braced for controversy.
LEAD: The Japanese Finance Ministry yesterday announced major changes in Japan's government bond market that greatly increase the role of American and other foreign firms in underwriting new issues.
LEAD: A Federal drug enforcement agent was shot and critically wounded in a raid on an apartment in Harlem last night, officials said.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: They call the gray stucco apartment block the bullpen. Officially, it is a workers' hotel; actually, it is more like a cage for young men.

LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation entered the debt market yesterday with a $250 million offering of 10 1/4 percent debentures due in 2018 at a price of 99.25 to yield 10.526 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: Donor nations have pledged millions of dollars in aid to Bangladesh, where the worst flooding in 70 years has left much of the country under water and as many as 28 million people homeless or stranded.

LEAD: Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry, who is offering a $172 million plan to regain control of the ministry and its religious theme park. received a two-day extension today to produce a $3 million line of credit supporting his bid.

LEAD: Ainslee Cox, the longtime conductor of the Goldman Concert Band, died of complications arising from Hodgkins disease on Monday afternoon at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $350 million of floating-rate notes due March 9, 1989, at par through various securities dealers.

LEAD: Janice Groman, a former member of the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater who later founded a chamber dance company, died at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx on Friday after a long illness. She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A 45-year-old Manhattan man shot 14 policemen from his apartment yesterday during a daylong siege that ended eight and a half hours after it began with the man's 2 young children dead and the gunman mortally wounded by police gunfire.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The board of Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. said today that it and the company's shareholders had approved an employee stock ownership buyout plan worth $173 million, or $84 a share in cash, of which a portion will remain in escrow.

LEAD: The United Nations has long been lurching into disrepair, ineptitude and impotence. The main thing done about it was to ignore the world organization. But since the Soviet Union unexpectedly changed its position, chances are starting to improve for making it work.

LEAD: A 21-year-old woman drowned Sunday while diving in a water-filled cave when her air tanks ran out after she panicked and swam in the wrong direction, the police said. Her body was found Monday in a dead-end corridor in a cave at Orange Grove Sink. The police said that the woman and a partner had been following a marked course but lost sight of the line and drifted apart.

LEAD: With so-called chat lines, the faddish party-line hookups that allow socializing by telephone, declining in popularity nationally, a French company has added a high-technology wrinkle, computer party lines whose users are billed by the telephone company.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Some of the rare specimens of the zoological world are never imported into North America, and the same is true of the bridge world. Bizarre bidding ideas originate on other continents but are barred from these shores by the vigilant officials of the American Contract Bridge League.

LEAD: A favorite indoor sport among educational pundits in recent years has been to predict how many private colleges will be folding because of the declining number of 18-year-olds in the population.

LEAD: There's a sense in which Sade's mostly brilliant show at Radio City on Monday night was seen more than heard. Her band members, resonating cool, were dressed in suits that would have looked fine for the mid-1950's Miles Davis group. The lighting and backdrops, spare and ascetic and changing for each tune, radiated an Asian formality.

LEAD: ONE of the nicest attributes of a microwave oven is the way it can make everyday fare of the grains and cereals that normally take a long time to cook and that must usually be stirred with jealous attention.
LEAD: AS far as food is concerned, Maine is best known for its lobsters, blueberries and potatoes. Somehow, bagels never make the list.
LEAD: The New York branch of Sumitomo Bank Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9.40 percent notes due in 1993 at par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: The Financial News Network, the cable television network that provides 14 hours of business news daily, said yesterday that it would expand its programming to prime time, beginning Oct. 31.

LEAD: An enthusiastic gathering of bidders, spectators and fans, many suitably dressed for a Wembley Stadium rock concert, filled a London auction house today and paid tribute to the pop singer Elton John, buying everything from his rhinestone-studded spectacles to his diamond-studded earrings.
LEAD: The Israeli Army says it has arrested dozens of people in connection with bribes paid to avoid compulsory military service.

LEAD: An article in some editions of Business Day on Friday, about the awarding by the International Business Machines Corporation of its advertising account, incompletely described the status of Charles Moss, the former chief creative officer of Wells, Rich, Greene. LEAD: A musical memorial service for the jazz bassist Slam Stewart, who died last Dec. 7, is to be held tonight at 7 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street. The Rev. John Gensell is to officiate, with music organized by Major Holley, a bassist and associate of Mr. Stewart.

LEAD: Twenty-three of the 65 players who attended the Rangers' rookie and free-agent camp, which ended yesterday, will join 45 others Saturday when the team opens its regular camp at Three Rivers, Quebec. Jim Latos, a free-agent right wing, will not attend. He underwent surgery on the right shoulder injured in an intrasquad scrimmage.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: The authorities today ordered the evacuation of all 150 residents of two small canyon communities bordering Yellowstone National Park after wind threatened to drive a wall of flame through the towns.

LEAD: Since the early years of the Reagan Administration, the map of the world behind the speakers' dais in the State Department press room showed the continents a pumpkin orange against a midnight blue sea. Print reporters didn't mind, but the orange grated on television producers because it tended to turn the complexions of the State Department press aides into an unhealthy pallor.
LEAD: Bangladesh is a nation seemingly founded on unstable footing.

LEAD: THE notion of combining fresh orange juice with seafood might sound odd, but if used judiciously, the juice can add a dynamic touch of sweetness to scallops, lobster, shrimp, even tuna and salmon.
LEAD: The Cincinnati Zoo has closed its special exhibit of the giant panda Chia Chia for at least five days because the visiting panda is apparently homesick.

LEAD: The average salary of major league baseball players this year will reach a record $433,000, according to the Player Relations Committee's executive director, Barry Rona. The figure represents an increase of $31,000 over the 1987 average. The official average is computed from the Aug. 31 roster. The Major League Baseball Players Association will issue its report of average salary later in the year.
LEAD: The Yankees are as low in the standings now as they were the day before they opened the season.

LEAD: Clustered on a riverbank, more than 8,000 residents of this town in Bangladesh, about 100 miles south of Dhaka,were forced today to take shelter any way they could.

LEAD: Alexander Dubcek, the former Czechoslovak Communist Party chief who led the short-lived period of liberalization in 1968 known as Prague Spring, is to travel abroad for the first time in two decades to visit Italy, a Government spokesman said today.

LEAD: It has been five years since Aaron Krickstein first poked his head through the open door of professional tennis, a painfully shy 16-year-old phenomenon who was going to be the successor to John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors. In 1983, Krickstein was the youngest male ever to reach the round of 16 in the United States Open.
LEAD: Leo Henry Rosenberg, a retired advertising executive who was one of radio's first announcers, died in his sleep Monday at a nursing home in Dunn Loring, Va. He was 92 years old.

LEAD: A compromise has now been struck: George Bush and Michael Dukakis will square off in two televised debates later in the campaign. Two is better than none, but this is still a disappointing conclusion that cheats voters and leaves the campaign too much in the hands of the image-makers.
LEAD: Students begin returning to New York City's public schools today in an atmosphere of intense public concern over whether the school system will improve or whether that is even possible.
LEAD: The police today seized a tape of a sermon in which Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu defied the Government and called for a boycott of October elections, a spokesman for the Archbishop said.

LEAD: A defendant in the $7 million Wells Fargo robbery case pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to transport several thousand dollars in stolen money to Hartford to pay for a toy giveway for Puerto Rican children in 1985.

LEAD: After the United States Supreme Court suspended contempt fines against four Yonkers City Councilmen last week but reimposed fines on the city, Governor Cuomo said that the court's decision ''raised troublesome legal questions'' about removing the Councilmen from office and that, for the time being at least, he would not act against them.
LEAD: In a candidates debate at the State Fair here, Senator David Karnes drew boos from the crowd and criticism from his opponent when he said, ''We need fewer farmers at this point in time.''
LEAD: The Magic Lantern An Autobiography By Ingmar Bergman Translated from the Swedish by Joan Tate. 308 pages. Viking. $19.95.

LEAD: A 24-year-old Queens man who was being sought for fatally beating a referee who made a disputed call during a housing project basketball game, surrendered to the police yesterday afternoon, officials said.

LEAD: ''Keep the Spirit Irish'' is the message trumpeted from billboards on street corners. But as the long-running battle for control of the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. draws to a dramatic finish, the only near-certainty is that soon the Irish whisky industry will be in foreign hands.
LEAD: More may be less when it comes to homework, the findings of a study of elementary school teachers, students and parents show.

LEAD: Motorola Inc. has sued a Silicon Valley competitor, the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, and five former Motorola employees, accusing them of taking part in a conspiracy to steal trade secrets.
LEAD: State securities regulators warned today that investors could lose an estimated $250 million this year to telephone sales pitches for investments in bogus gold mines.

The aircraft, powered by twin Rolls-Royce engines, seats 84 to 107 passengers. It entered service with Swissair in April. Wardair's purchase brings to 110 the number of Fokker 100's sold.

LEAD: THE smart money on Wall Street is increasingly beginning to feel that the outcome of Roy E. Disney's slowly simmering takeover battle for the Polaroid Corporation depends more on the Eastman Kodak Company than on Mr. Disney.

LEAD: The Presidential candidates seem to be having difficulties getting their arms around the issue of jobs versus joblessness in America.

LEAD: WHEN Sue Greenberg of Washington started keeping kosher 26 years ago, she said goodbye - forever, she thought - to crab meat, Italian sausages and meat tortellini with cheese. Today, however, Mrs. Greenberg, a 47-year-old graduate student in business administration, eats kosher sausages, a crab meat look-alike and taste-alike, and meatless tortellini made from tofu sprinkled with cheese.

LEAD: ''THE Victorian view of a white wall was diametrically opposed to ours,'' said Bruce Bradbury, whose California company, Bradbury & Bradbury Wallpapers, has been selling reproductions of Victorian wallpaper since 1976. He emphasized his point by quoting Christopher Dresser, an avant-garde 19th-century wallpaper designer: ''A white wall is always appropriate for lavatories and pigsties.

LEAD: Continental Health Affiliates Inc., a regional home-health-care concern, has offered to purchase the shares of Healthdyne Inc. that it does not own for $6 a share, or about $82 million. Healthdyne, based in Marietta, Ga., provides home-health-care services through its Home Nutritional Support division, based in Pine Brook, N.J.

LEAD: A Soviet astronaut and his Afghan crewmate were welcomed with relief at the Baikonur launching center in Kazakhstan today while the ground commanders of their problem-plagued flight tried to explain how a routine re-entry maneuver went awry not once but twice, stranding them in space for 25 tense hours.

LEAD: The six oil ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council will meet Oct. 16 to review ways of stabilizing the world oil market, the Kuwait News Agency said today. Officials of the council acknowledged that the ministers would meet but declined to confirm the date. The council consists of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, all OPEC members, and Bahrain and Oman, which are not.

LEAD: The first official delegation of Russians to cross the Bering Strait since it was closed 40 years ago arrived in this historic gold-mining town today, seeking to improve contacts between the superpowers' most remote regions.

LEAD: Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder yesterday and is expected to be ready for spring training next year. The 45-minute operation to repair a tear in Schmidt's right rotator cuff was performed in Birmingham, Ala., by Dr. Jim Andrews. The 39-year-old Schmidt, who last played Aug.

LEAD: Yankee Stadium is supposed to be the site of a critical pennant-race series beginning tonight, but the only thing that appears to be critical is the Yankees, as in the patient is in critical condition.
LEAD: THEY did a terrible thing the other night, stirring up old memories. Tennis magazine held a party at the West Side Tennis Club, right on the gritty green particles at center court.
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that the United States sold $2.93 billion in dollars at the end of June and in July, in an effort to slow the dollar's summer rally.

LEAD: Using a rundown school building in Harlem as a backdrop, Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and Richard R. Green, the New York City Schools Chancellor, tried yesterday to increase pressure on the State Senate to enact legislation intended to make school construction more efficient in the city.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, in Harlem yesterday to visit a dilapidated school, jumped out of his car to help the police chase a suspect in a Manhattan subway token theft.

LEAD: Three Democratic candidates with no experience running for elective office and a fourth who has lost three races are seeking the Democratic nomination for Bronx District Attorney, a leading office in the borough that has taken on even more significance because of corruption investigations.
LEAD: New Yorkers vote next Thursday in a primary election. Here are The Times's endorsements for State Assembly races, all Democratic, in which primary victory is tantamount to election.

LEAD: A memorial service for the actress Jo Henderson will be held tomorrow at noon at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street. Miss Henderson, who appeared in a number of Broadway and Off Broadway productions over the past 30 years, died in a car accident in Arizona on Aug. 7. Speakers at the service, which is open to the public, will be Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, and Tanya Berezin, artistic director of the Circle Repertory Company.

LEAD: Some of the elderly may be delighted to learn that the magazine 50 Plus, recently acquired last January by Reader's Digest, will change its name in December to - get this -New Choices (followed in smaller type by For The Best Years). It was announced by Gerald G. Hotchkiss, publisher, who is one of the crowd himself.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The authorities seized 183 pounds of nearly pure heroin with an estimated street value of $1 billion and arrested four people today, Federal and local law enforcement officials said.
LEAD: The Italian police said today that they had broken up Italy's most violent leftist terrorist group with the arrest of 21 people in raids before dawn in Rome and its suburbs.
LEAD: The Town Council has voted to donate 14 acres of land and spend $7,000 to help establish the proposed National Purple Heart Museum in Enfield.
LEAD: Children's sandboxes, normally the place of castles, sculptures and imaginary wars, are at the center of an actual battle over what some people charge are dangers lurking in the sand.

LEAD: IF the ''greenhouse effect'' pushes temperatures up and rainfall down, which way will energy stocks move? Some analysts on Wall Street believe a global rise in temperatures could attract new interest in fuels and energy technologies that produce little of the ''greenhouse gases.''
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., won investor support yesterday to convert T.W.A. into a private company.

LEAD: Five astronauts today made an inspection of the space shuttle Discovery, which they hope to ride into orbit late this month. The commander, Frederick H. Hauck, reported, ''It all looks clean; it all looks good.''
LEAD: A 25-year-old West Bank Palestinian man has confessed to strangling an Israeli teen-ager to death and then burning her body last month, the police said today.

LEAD: THE word scrim mostly has to do with the theater. A scrim is a thin gauze curtain behind which actors and scenery can be seen when lights are on them. But they are seen as if in a mist, which softens their outlines and causes them to lose definition.
