LEAD: FEW features distinguish a house as readily as a tile roof, especially in the United States, where tile roofs have never been common except in the Southwest, California and Florida.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds ended slightly lower after a choppy session yesterday, as market participants took profits and cast an apprehensive eye on the dollar, which came under pressure for the second day.

LEAD: The board of the Tennessee Valley Authority announced today that Steven A. White, the man who was hired to restart the agency's troubled and much-criticized nuclear program, would leave the agency in November.

LEAD: The Boeing Company said the Chinese Government had ordered three Boeing 757-200 jets for about $125 million. The twin-engine jets are scheduled to be delivered to the Civil Aviation Administration in China beginning in December 1989. They will be equipped with RB211-535E4 engines made by Rolls-Royce P.L.C.

LEAD: Wind-driven flames feeding on tinder-dry trees and brush swept into the tourist complex near the Old Faithful geyser today, burning a dozen park buildings and forcing some 40 firefighters to flee.
LEAD: Vice President Bush made a slip of the tongue today when he declared, ''Today is Pearl Harbor Day - 47 years ago from this very day we were hit and hit hard at Pearl Harbor.''

LEAD: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day on Monday about the new chief executive of Talbots Inc. misstated the apparel chain's ownership. It was sold by General Mills to Jusco of Japan in July.
LEAD: A movement to help parents cope with intense grief after losing a child to miscarriage, stillbirth or infant death is spreading rapidly around the country.

LEAD: Search the speeches of Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael D. Dukakis for evidence that they think safer motor vehicles are a matter of national concern. You'll wind up in a dead-end street. This is astonishing, for injuries related to the use of motor vehicles are the leading cause of death to most age groups - starting with newborns.
LEAD: English Country House, the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6868.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch have agreed to have a screening panel recommend a new executive director of the New York City Board of Elections - but the Board of Elections has already chosen someone.

LEAD: It's almost tempting to feel sorry for Sean Landeta. The Giants' punter missed nearly all of training camp because of a contract dispute before agreeing to a two-year deal worth $445,000. The ink had barely dried before things began to sour.

LEAD: If there had been an award for the best defensive play of this summer's International Team playoffs in Memphis, it would probably have gone to Bob Wolff of Dallas for his effort in the West seat on the diagramed deal, played on June 1.

LEAD: In agreeing to take over the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the nation's largest insolvent savings unit, the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass is betting that the resurrected company will be able to make a lot of money by operating the major part of the business as a traditional savings unit - that is, taking deposits from customers and making mortgage loans and other consumer loans.

LEAD: A man who chopped down a neighbor's 83-year-old oak tree to improve reception on his television satellite dish received two years' probation yesterday in Superior Court and was ordered to stay off the neighbor's land.

LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly described the ownership of the Adolf Coors Company. The family-operated company's class B common stock is traded over the counter under the symbol ACCOB.

LEAD: Two major art collections - Edith Mayer Goetz's holdings in Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and modern works, and Emily and Burton Tremaine's postwar and modern art - are to be auctioned in November at Christie's.

LEAD: The Champion International Corporation reopened five Pacific Northwest mills on Tuesday after workers ratified a three-year contract. The wood products company will bring back its 2,400 union workers on a staggered basis, Dennis Elder, a spokesman for Champion, said. The mills had been idle since the strike began on June 6.

LEAD: As a full moon rose big and yellow over the Tuscan hills, streams of people began making their way from parking lots in bulldozed corn fields to a little city of circus tents where the largest Communist party in the West was celebrating its identity crisis.
LEAD: The nation's shortage of literate workers has spawned some unconventional partnerships between business and education.

LEAD: A Washington consulting concern whose principals hold prominent positions in the Bush Presidential campaign was paid $800,000 to improve the image of the Bahamas at a time when the leadership of the island nation was under fire for purported ties to drug traffickers.
LEAD: The Federal Government has gone to court to try to confiscate nearly 45,000 condoms that it says are defective.

LEAD: The effort in Congress to deal with a relatively new problem, the need for day care for millions of young children whose mothers are working outside the home, has become mired in one of the oldest debates in American life: where to set the boundaries between church and state.
LEAD: Both Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis appeared today before B'nai B'rith and denounced the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''I CANNOT, in whole conscience, recommend architecture as a profession for girls,'' the architect Pietro Belluschi once wrote. But if one really insisted, he said, he would give her his blessing. ''She could be that exceptional one.''
LEAD: The Other Italy The Italian Resistance in World War II By Maria de Blasio Wilhelm 272 pages. Illustrated. W. W. Norton. $18.95.

LEAD: POPULAR literature on American design has largely focused on interior decoration or architecture. In his book ''New American Design: Products and Graphics for a Post-Industrial Age'' (Rizzoli, $35, 1988) the writer Hugh Aldersey-Williams tries to change that.

LEAD: One way to get attention in Washington is to make heroes of officialdom's adversaries. An outfit here that is proving adept at that is a glossy year-old magazine, The International Economy, published by two sometime political consultants, David Smick, a Republican, and Richard Medley, a Democrat.

LEAD: The entertainer Merv Griffin has extended his $205 million offer to buy the common stock of Resorts International Inc. until Friday because the deal has not been approved by New Jersey gaming authorities. In announcing the extension of the $36-a-share tender offer, the Griffco Acquisition Corporation said the holders of 81 percent of Resorts' class
LEAD: In one room, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas served chocolate brownies and fruit juice to the Republican Vice-Presidential nomineer, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana.

LEAD: Ten days from the opening of the Seoul Olympics, only 147 of the 161 nations that accepted invitations to participate have supplied entry lists to the International Olympic Committee, even though the deadline was Sept. 2 for all sports except track and field,which has a Sept. 9 deadline. Michele Verdier, an I.O.C.

LEAD: The United Nations official overseeing aid for Afghanistan plans to spend much of this winter on a campaign to teach Afghan refugees how to defuse the hundreds of thousands of mines, booby traps and unexploded munitions that litter their homeland after eight years of civil war.
LEAD: International A3-17

LEAD: MARKETS Drexel Burnham Lambert was charged with a two-year scheme of illegal insider trading, defrauding clients, stock manipulation and other securities violations. Some of the long-awaited charges by the S.E.C. were more severe than had been anticipated. Four Drexel employees were named, including Michael Milken, the head of its junk-bond department, whose lucrative deals have been responsible for the firm's enormous growth within the last decade.

LEAD: Doctors should use caution in prescribing antidepressant drugs to alcoholics who are under treatment to stop drinking, a new study suggests, because in many cases the depression will lift without drugs.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 300,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said today. More than two million tons of corn have been sold by private exporters to the Soviets in the last week, according to Agriculture Department announcements.

LEAD: * Coleman Co., Wichita, Kan., a maker of camping and outdoor recreation products, marine sports products and products for the home, named Jeffrey Curtiss chief financial officer, succeeding Richard Curry, who has retired.
LEAD: If the Major League Baseball Players Association prevails in its position and the Detroit Tigers cooperate, Fred Lynn will get to play in postseason games after all.
LEAD: An accountant for the Georgia Power Company who acted as an Internal Revenue Service informant has been placed on leave, the company said today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today dismissed a popularly elected state government of former insurgents in the northeastern state of Mizoram and ordered direct rule by New Delhi after more than a week of political instability.
LEAD: A Federal judge refused today to order former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to answer questions under oath about his decision to allow the partial merger of Detroit's two daily newspapers.

LEAD: Michael Milken: The 42-year-old head of Drexel Burnham's high-yield bond department. Has almost single-handedly made ''junk bond'' financing one of the principal tools used to finance corporate takeovers. Born in Los Angeles, the son of an accountant. Attended the University of California at Berkeley, where he majored in mathematics.
LEAD: The New Jersey man who introduced a slice of America to Muscovites with a mobile pizza truck last spring said today that he wants to build the Soviet Union's first full-fledged pizza parlor.

LEAD: No one knows how many Americans are illiterate; many millions, for sure, and the number is increasing even as their opportunities for employment are decreasing. Without a literate work force, the country often described as the first to enter the 20th century will stumble into the 21st.

LEAD: Eric Metcalf, a tailback who is the key to the University of Texas offense, has been declared ineligible for the game at Brigham Young tonight by order of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Metcalf, a senior who ran for 1,925 all-purpose yards last year, accepted money from the Texas athletic department to pay for summer school this year but failed to attend either of two summer sessions at the school.

LEAD: The House of Representatives today began debating legislation to combat drugs, one of the major issues of the Presidential campaign, with Democrats criticizing Vice President Bush and the Reagan Administration as failing to enforce anti-drug laws.

LEAD: A week ago, I raised an eyebrow at the way the Dukakis crowd had used the job-creating credit of the State of Massachusetts to set up a ''telemarketing'' operation that then was used to raise money for the Dukakis campaign.

LEAD: As the pace of her match became more dizzying, as the potential match points came and went and the sounds from the crowd at Louis Armstrong Stadium became more and more desperate, something good happened to Zina Garrison yesterday afternoon.

LEAD: President Reagan, having polished a farewell routine that has become familiar in recent months, will say goodbye today to T. Kenneth Cribb Jr., his domestic policy adviser, in a private White House ceremony.

LEAD: A picture caption yesterday, with an article about an agreement between the Bush and Dukakis campaigns on televised debates, gave an incorrect date for the meeting between the campaign managers shown in the picture; the meeting was Aug. 30. The agreement on the debates was accomplished Tuesday by telephone.
LEAD: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian writer, has declined an invitation to join a Soviet committee responsible for building a memorial to Stalin's victims.
LEAD: The only university institution for Jewish studies in the Communist world will begin its first year of full operation this fall at Budapest University.
LEAD: The state Pardon Board refused today to recommend freedom for a man who built a new life in Tennessee during more than 17 years as a fugitive from prison.

LEAD: The Houston Oilers' general manager, Ladd Herzeg, who has been embroiled in a paternity suit, resigned yesterday, but the team's owner, Bud Adams, refused to accept the resignation. ''I submitted my resignation from the Houston Oilers as executive vice president and general manager on the basis of a very personal and private matter,'' Herzeg said in a statement read by his attorney, Steve Underwood.

LEAD: For years, this Himalayan kingdom, renowned for its tough Gurkha soldiers, its Hindu traditions, its spectacular views of the world's highest mountain range and as a trekker's paradise, has lived uneasily with a growing flood of foreign tourists.
LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company paid about $1 million in bribes to officials of the Iraqi Government several years ago in a bid to obtain tire contracts, a company spokesman said today.
LEAD: The sun was shining in Dhaka today, the water was receding, and for a moment at least, there was a more hopeful air in city neighborhoods.

LEAD: American investors may buy French Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange later this month after the exchange completes arrangements for listing the bonds as American depository receipts.

LEAD: Winning Colors, the 3-year-old filly who won the Kentucky Derby May 7, will make her first start in three months when she takes on the undefeated 4-year-old filly Personal Ensign in the Maskette Stakes at Belmont Park on Saturday.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company may replace production of its popular Escort car with a truck at its Edison, N.J., plant, the auto industry journal Ward's Automotive Reports said this week. The publication quoted sources who said that Ford might be nearing an announcement that it plans to build Ranger-size trucks at the plant.

LEAD: William D. Ruckelshaus, who twice headed the Environmental Protection Agency, was named chairman and chief executive yesterday of one of the nation's largest waste-disposal companies, Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston.

LEAD: The union representing 1,300 Queens bus drivers and mechanics agreed to a contract yesterday with the city. A strike deadline had been set for 12:01 A.M. today. The walkout would have affected 300,000 riders.
LEAD: Democrats expect to break a record for political fund-raising in New York by collecting more than $5 million at a dinner Thursday at the New York Hilton.
LEAD: World Sports Promotions, a four-year-old events marketing company in St. Louis, has been acquired by McCann-Erickson USA, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, for an undisclosed sum.
LEAD: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company sent an extensive scientific assessment of its new ''smokeless'' cigarettes to members of Congress yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Veterans Administration's nationwide hospital network was described at a Congressional hearing today as being in a deep financial crisis that has left it understaffed, poorly maintained and forced to use money meant for medical equipment to pay salaries.
LEAD: Dennis Conner sailed his first race in defense of the America's Cup today like a doctor afraid of a malpractice suit.
LEAD: President Reagan has invited the Israeli and Egyptian Foreign Ministers to meet with him in New York to discuss prospects for Middle East peace, American and Israeli officials said today.

LEAD: The two sellers of chlordimeform, a pesticide used on an eighth of the nation's cotton crop, have agreed to quit marketing the product and will recall leftovers from farmers after the current growing season, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. The agency said it would make the distribution or use of the chemical, a suspected cancer agent, illegal after Feb.

LEAD: As the Christmas holidays approach, Fortune magazine's advertising sales staff always tries to conjure up ways of profiting from the practice of corporate giving, getting ads from the marketers of items suitable for giving.

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation plans to introduce a longer version of its wide-body MD-11 aircraft by 1994. LEAD: Two Chicago actors who have admitted misrepresenting themselves in appearances on three nationally syndicated talk shows return to ''Sally Jessy Raphael'' today to confront one of the most outraged victims of their ruse.

LEAD: Joyce Brown, the homeless woman who challenged a Koch administration program to hospitalize mentally ill street people forcibly, was arrested yesterday by the New York City housing police at a Harlem housing project and charged with illegal possession of heroin and hypodermic needles, officials said.
LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up for the week ended yesterday, but the strength of these increases appears to be easing.

LEAD: Mike Tyson was discharged late yesterday from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after undergoing three days of care following an automobile accident Sunday in which he suffered a concussion. His treatment apparently included a psychiatric consultation.

LEAD: WHEN the Gillette Company agreed last month to retire about 15 percent of its 112 million shares to appease its largest and most nettlesome shareholder, Coniston Partners, the Boston-based consumer products giant could have offered to buy the shares in one fell swoop. But such highly publicized partial tenders have put some companies into play inadvertently.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Reebok International Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent debentures due 1998 at a price of 99.90, to yield 9.766 percent through Kidder, Peabody & Company. Noncallable for seven years, the debentures are priced to yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
LEAD: Eleanor Gottheil Kubie, an author and artist, died of acute leukemia Sunday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 89 years old.
LEAD: Are they bored, jaded or just restless waiting for the playoffs to begin in three weeks? And are they a sure thing or still vulnerable?
LEAD: Is this any way to run a pennant race?
LEAD: Shipyard workers staged a 24-hour strike in this industrial port outside Athens today after four maintenance workers were killed when an explosion split a Greek oil tanker in half.

LEAD: Jean P. Baltzell, a retired New York lawyer who was active in Democratic politics in Manhattan in the 1950's and 60's, died of cancer Saturday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: Pakistani jet fighters shot down an intruding Afghan warplane today and Afghan aircraft bombed three Pakistani villages near the Afghan border, Pakistani authorities said.
LEAD: A New York State board adopted a ''doomsday'' plan today for cutting city services here to provide money to pay contempt fines that will reach $1 million a day by Friday.

LEAD: In his first public appearance since records of his official dealings with campaign contributors were subpoenaed last week, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, today announced a new policy for employees of his office that would prohibit them from having ''even minimum dealings'' with his fund-raising activities.
LEAD: Hazen G. Werner, a retired Bishop of the Methodist Church, died of heart failure Monday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 93 years old.

LEAD: A K.G.B. official, in an article published this week, says that excessive secrecy in the Soviet Union has produced abuses of power, crippled scholarship and left citizens ignorant of basic information about their own country.

LEAD: A woman was stabbed to death in her home and her husband, the village constable in this exclusive North Shore community, was critically wounded this morning, and their 17-year-old son was arrested in the attack hours later, the police said.
LEAD: Iran's Prime Minister has withdrawn his resignation under orders from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, official Iranian news outlets said today.
LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company reportedly has decided not to contest a record $1.25 million fine levied because control room operators slept on duty at the Peach Bottom nuclear plant.

LEAD: A headless body found in the Hudson River in April has been identified as that of a Bronx woman whose former husband, a police officer, retired after refusing to answer questions about her disappearance, the authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Activated Rick Aguilera, pitcher, from the 30-day disabled list. BASKETBALL MIAMI (NBA) - Signed Rony Seikaly, center, to a multiyear contract. FOOTBALL NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Suspended Calvin Thomas, Chicago Bears fullback; Richard Dent, Chicago Bears defensive end, and Charles White, Los Angeles Rams running back, for 30 days for violations of the league's substance-abuse policy.

LEAD: A recently completed study commissioned by the State Department recommends that the United States tear down the heavily bugged new American Embassy chancery in Moscow and build a replacement, Government officials said today.

LEAD: Salvador Collazo, 40. Born in Puerto Rico. In private practice. Graduate of Fordham College and Seton Hall Law School. Assistant district attorney, 1977-83. President, Puerto Rican Bar Assn. Former regional president, Hispanic National Bar Assn. Member, Mayor's Committee on Judiciary. Counsel to Hispanic Court and Corrections Officers Associations and Police Hispanic Society.

LEAD: Looters raided Government offices and warehouses in Burma today, as the United States and other countries drew up plans to evacuate relatives of diplomats endangered by growing turmoil in Rangoon.

LEAD: H. R. (Bum) Bright, who has been unsuccessful in his efforts to sell the Dallas Cowboys, has asked the team's general manager, Tex Schramm, to find a buyer. Schramm performed a similar role for the club's original owner, Clint Murchison, when Murchison sold the club to a group headed by Bright in 1984.

LEAD: The director of the nation's anti-missile program has prepared a new proposal that would cut its budget substantially but would preserve the Reagan Administration's goal of deploying the system, including the first weapons in space, in the late 1990's.
LEAD: James T. Dresher, who helped pull off a turnabout at the York International Corporation, has been named chairman and chief executive of the air-conditioning manufacturer.

LEAD: Smiling, tanned and almost bashful about all the fuss, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. returned to the Senate today, seven months after a brain aneurysm and subsequent complications nearly took his life.

LEAD: Earl Benner Jr., the owner of the land, and Louis Smither, a neighbor with a crop of his own, looked on with satisfaction as Ronnie Moppin, a sharecropper, led a harvesting crew through a yellowing field of burley tobacco.

LEAD: Taubman Holdings Inc. has appointed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Morgan Stanley & Company to explore the possibilities of selling the two Taubman store divisions -Woodward & Lothrop in Washington and John Wanamaker in Philadelphia - retail executives said today.
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday set Jan. 16 as the start of the third racketeering and drug-trafficking trial of Gene Gotti and two other defendants. Two earlier trials ended in mistrials.

LEAD: Lester Lewis, a radio and television producer and a talent agent, died of cancer Aug. 24 at the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo vetoed a bill tonight that was intended to prohibit ''coercion'' of dairy farmers by dairies seeking to assure their supplies of milk in the state.

LEAD: A play that gives a viewer something to chew on is good news for the start of yet another season on the tube. Such a treat is on tap tonight at 9 P.M. on CBS in the shape of ''Open Admissions,'' a powerful and splendidly performed drama about issues that must trouble many thinking people in America these days.
LEAD: A man from Southington who heard ''a command from God'' to kill his 7-year-old daughter was found not guilty by reason of insanity Tuesday.

LEAD: The advertisements for exercise clothing and fitness classes would have you believe that physical activity is exclusively pursued by people with beautiful bodies for the sole purpose of keeping them that way. For years this image of exercise only for the already trim has kept millions of overweight people off running trails and bicycles and out of sweats and swimsuits.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had reached agreements with the nation's major steelmakers on new purchasing contracts. G.M. would not disclose the terms of the agreements, but steel industry officials said the increases averaged about 3 percent.

LEAD: The Rev. Silvester Mooney, who headed Douai Abbey in Britain for 40 years and was believed to be the world's oldest Roman Catholic monk, died Monday night, the abbey said today. He was 102 years old.

LEAD: WOOD paneling adds warmth and charm to a room. But conventional paneling, consisting of individual boards of the desired wood, is usually expensive and requires much skill and time to install. An alternative is veneer-covered plywood paneling. This is made of ordinary plywood to which a thin layer of desirable wood has been bonded.

LEAD: ''Burning Questions: The Poisoning of America'' is a straightforward, forceful and only too timely documentary for the torrid, dry and dirty summer of '88. The ABC News special, which can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 7, reviews in punchy fashion the assaults on air and water that threaten health and recreation today and that may threaten existence tomorrow.

LEAD: Sales among several leading New York retailers continued to languish in August, averaging 2.4 percent ahead of August 1987 in the city and seven-tenths of 1 percent behind in the metropolitan area, a spot-check this week found. Sales failed to keep pace with inflation, which has been about 4 percent in the retail sector.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis today proposed a college loan program that would allow students to pay back their loans over a lifetime through payroll withholding of a small fixed percentage of their income. He said the program would ''open wide the door of college opportunity'' to American youths.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board granted the Bank of New York another extension late yesterday to its application to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation. Irving had opposed the extension and had stated in a letter to the Fed last week that if it were granted it would create ''the unavoidable impression that the Bank of New York has been granted special, favored treatment.

LEAD: ONCE household words, the terms lambrequin, hassock and antimacassar have gone the way of the hoop skirt and the bustle. But in 19th-century America, they - rather than the built-in stereo system and the recliner - were the staples of fashionable middle-class interiors.

LEAD: WHENEVER a young man came to call, Ida would insist that he stay for dinner. LEAD: Trying to harness the excitement over Presidential politics, several savings associations are offering bonuses to depositors who pick the winner of the election.

LEAD: The Miami Heat yesterday signed its top draft pick, Rony Seikaly of Syracuse. The expansion club would not disclose terms of the contract for the 6-foot-11-inch center, but The Miami Herald has reported the deal to be worth $4 million over five years.(AP)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As far as the commander of New York City's hostage negotiating team was concerned, it was the worst situation in the book: an emotionally disturbed man besieged in a barricaded apartment with a shotgun and two small children.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A county judge has prohibited a woman from obtaining an abortion during a divorce proceeding, calling her estranged husband's bid to block the abortion a type of custody fight.
LEAD: Fofo I. F. Sunia, nonvoting delegate to Congress from American Samoa, officially resigned Tuesday, a month after he pleaded guilty in a payroll padding scheme.

LEAD: Flood waters swept a motorist away in Tampa today, closed schools in several towns and forced the evacuation of at least 1,000 people after three days of heavy rain on Florida's central Gulf Coast.

LEAD: Warning that the United States is ''not out of the woods'' in dealing with the Soviet Union, Vice President Bush today urged the continued modernization of American nuclear forces as the only way to achieve further arms reductions.
LEAD: A California jury has found the Southmark Corporation liable for more than $130 million in damages in a civil suit brought by a San Diego businessman and his wife, the company said today.

LEAD: A bill to limit the growth of imports of textiles, clothing and shoes cleared a major hurdle in the Senate today, virtually assuring its passage and setting the stage for another election-year trade confrontation between Congress and the Reagan Administration.

LEAD: Q. I have a screened room on the side of the house that has a vinyl roof. On sunny days this room gets hot and uncomfortable. Would the room be cooler if it had an insulated wood roof, with regular shingles that matched the rest of the house? A. It probably would. However, you may also get a good deal of relief by installing vents or louvers in the existing roof - the kind that will let the hot air escape but will not allow rain to come in.

LEAD: A real estate broker who said a middle-class person ''always needs money,'' presented a winning Lotto ticket today to claim a record $55 million prize.

LEAD: Among new competitive corporate issues priced yesterday was a $125 million debt offering by the Southern California Edison Company, which was won by a winning bid from an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton, a unit of the American Express Company.

LEAD: LOCKED away in a laboratory in Benton Harbor, Mich., far from the ring-around-the-collar crowd, is an ordinary-looking clothes dryer. Its almond-colored enamel finish is as shiny as any other dryer just off the assembly line at the Whirlpool Corporation plant there. It dries clothes as fast as any other dryer: 30 minutes for permanent-press fabrics, 60 minutes for terry-cloth towels.
LEAD: Werner Felfe, a member of East Germany's ruling Politburo and the nation's Agriculture Minister, died after suffering a heart attack today, the state press agency reported. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: MUCH of the talk at the recent Worldesign conference in New York of the Industrial Designers Society of America centered on how American business might be made more receptive to good design, particularly in light of foreign competition.

LEAD: BASEBALL Cuba 4, United States 2: Lourdes Gurriel hit a game-tying two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth and Lazaro Vargas singled in the winning run as Cuba rallied for a victory over the United States yesterday to win the world championships in Parma, Italy. Cuba, the defending champion, beat the Americans with a ninth-inning rally for the second time in the tournament.

LEAD: Mark Jackson, the Knick guard who was the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year last season, today will be become only the second sports personality to receive a certificate of appreciation from New York City. The certificate will be presented by Mayor Koch at 12:30 P.M. today on the steps of City Hall.

LEAD: Two Florida Democrats face three and a half more weeks of campaigning to decide which of them will face a Republican Congressman for a seat in the United States Senate.

LEAD: In 1972, the 102 men on San Quentin's death row got a new lease on life when a landmark court decision reversed the juries in all their cases and commuted their sentences to life imprisonment. Forty of them have since been paroled, and several of the parolees are the subjects of ''Life After Death Row,'' which will be broadcast tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 7.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Javier Sotomayor Sanabria of Cuba broke the world record for the men's high jump in a minor track and field meet today.

LEAD: AS much as New Yorkers take jazz clubs for granted, noticing them only when they close, they are one of the things that make New York distinct among the world's cities. An integral part of the cultural life, the clubs are also one of the city's better faces. So there's good news: New York, in the midst of a miserable year for clubs and restaurants, has seen, in the last six months, a small explosion of new rooms featuring jazz.

LEAD: THE great surprise in world financial markets this summer has been the sharp rally of the dollar. Few economists had expected it after private foreign investment dried up last year and the United States had to depend on foreign central banks to finance its external deficit. But, after dropping more than 15 percent against a trade-weighted average of other currencies in the latter half of 1987, the dollar stabilized and then took off this summer.

LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. is preparing to introduce a more powerful version of its popular Macintosh II Computer on Sept. 19, reports in several industry trade newspapers said. The upgraded Macintosh will be based on Motorola's 68030 microprocessor, a chip that more than doubles the performance of the 68020 microprocessor used in the current Mac II.

LEAD: The Mets, who have pined and whined over their missing bats all season, got them back today with a clatter that produced 13 runs, 20 hits, 4 home runs, the season's best offense and a 13-6 hammering of the Chicago Cubs.

LEAD: Portraits of 20th-century personages and experiments in photographic abstraction are the main parts of a retrospective of 150 works by the photographer Arnold Newman, opening today at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. The show will run through Oct. 30. Hours are 10 A.M.

LEAD: AS an artist, Philip Guston was blessed with two successful careers, two equally defined identities. During the 1950's, he was a prominent Abstract Expressionist, known for paintings in which simple straightforward horizontal and vertical marks - painting at its most basic - accumulated into vibrant light-filled surfaces.

LEAD: Frank Robinson will return as the Baltimore Orioles' manager in 1989, the club announced yesterday. LEAD: S. Herbert Riesner, a real-estate executive and hotel owner, died of heart failure Wednesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: As a high-ranking Soviet bureaucrat, Andrei Smirnov is a man of surprising contradictions.

LEAD: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the advertising agency that lost six top executives in March and the International Business Machines Corporation account last week, yesterday announced the dismissal of about 90 people, about one-third of its staff.

LEAD: For Joel R. L. Ehrenkranz, the war against drugs has taken a new turn. Eighteen months ago, the founder of Franklin Diagnostics Inc. of Morristown, N.J., began selling what he said was a tamper-proof kit for collecting urine specimens used in drug testing.

LEAD: Reagan Administration officials today stood behind their charge that Iraq had used poison gas against the Kurds, relating Kurds' descriptions of seeing small clouds of either white or yellowish gas and adding, ''That's when they began feeling sick.''

LEAD: The Boeing Company announced orders for seven 767 passenger jets for at least $421 million. increasing the company's total jetliner orders for the year to more than $21 billion. Statements issued by Boeing said four 767-300 extended-range aircraft had been ordered by Gulf Air, the national carrier of Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, for delivery in April, May and June.

LEAD: In his sharpest attack yet, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today compared the Republicans who are ''attacking my patriotism'' to those who cheered the tactics of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and challenged the patriotism of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
LEAD: A group headed by Roy E. Disney today revised its bid for the Polaroid Corporation and began a hostile $2.4 billion tender offer, raising the possibility of a bidding contest.

LEAD: Manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, whose managing contract is in its final year, said he was not going to concern himself now with statements by Marge Schott, the owner of the team, about Rose's chances of keeping his job. Schott told reporters this week that if Rose is to return as manager in 1989, it will be under a one-year contract and for less money.
LEAD: The enforcment chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Congressional panel today that the S.E.C.'s investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was continuing.

LEAD: Rock groups from the United States, the Soviet Union and several other countries plan to present a benefit concert next month in Tokyo to promote world peace and fight drug abuse, it was announced at a luncheon here today.

LEAD: An Air Vietnam passenger plane crashed and exploded in a rice field today on its approach to Bangkok's international airport, and officials said 75 people were killed and the other 6 people aboard were seriously injured.

LEAD: Pat Verbeek, who led the Devils with 46 goals last season, agreed to a multiyear contract yesterday and reported to camp in West Orange, N.J., with the rest of the veterans. The Devils followed the team policy of not revealing details of the contract, but the agreement is believed to be for two years plus an option year.

LEAD: Led by a significant upturn for energy, prices of goods ready for the final individual or business user climbed a hefty six-tenths of 1 percent in August, equaling the highest increase so far this year.
LEAD: The Turkish Government said today that its examinations of recent Kurdish refugees had produced no evidence to support claims that Iraq used chemical weapons against the Kurds.
LEAD: Window service at post offices, cut last February to save money, is being restored starting Saturday.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company cleared its largest remaining hurdle to licensing the Shoreham nuclear power plant today when a Federal agency said an emergency plan the utility would use in case of an accident would protect public safety.

LEAD: Fredd Young, a linebacker who has made the Pro Bowl in each of his four seasons in the National Football League, could not get the Seattle Seahawks to pay him what he thought he was worth. But he did succeed in finding someone who would. Young left the shadows of Brian Bosworth's 10-year, $11 million deal at Seattle with a huge new contract from his new employers, the Indianapolis Colts.

LEAD: A case of mistaken identity spurred a $2 million run on a Chinatown savings institution Thursday. Hundreds of customers lined up at the Elmhurst Federal Savings and Loan Association to withdraw money after confusing the association with a financially troubled bank in the suburb of Elmhurst. The assets of that institution, the United Security Bank, were frozen by a judge last week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Golf Two Tied for Lead: Jim Gallagher, who had to win a playoff in the qualifying round to enter the tournament, shot a second straight 67 yesterday to tie Dave Barr of Canada for the lead after two rounds of the $700,000 Greater Milwaukee Open in Franklin, Wis. Gallagher and Barr, who shot a 68, were tied at 10-under-par 134 after two rounds on the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course.
LEAD: In an effort to dispel the perception that Senator Dan Quayle is a man of great wealth, his campaign today released an accounting firm's statement that lists his net worth as $859,700.
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: Marshall Cogan, chairman of Knoll International Holdings Inc., said yesterday that Knoll had sold its General Felt Industries subsidiary to Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. and Rocco A. Barbieri, Knoll's president. The agreement to sell the unit, which makes carpeting and pads was reached last month.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company and the Japanese auto maker Nissan are expected to announce plans next week for a joint venture that would manufacture mini-vans at a yet-to-be-built Ohio plant. Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio , who will be in Japan from Sunday through Thursday, has scheduled a news conference with Ford and Nissan officials in Tokyo on Monday to announce the venture, according to an itinerary released by Governor Celeste's office on Thursday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Shana Alexander has been signed by Random House to write a book about the troubles of Bess Myerson, who resigned under fire as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

LEAD: ''The platform states the position of the platform, but nobody in our party takes a litmus test that says that everybody has to agree on every issue. I expect the Democrats could say the same thing.'' - Vice President Bush. [ 1:5. ]

LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, campaigned today in the swing state of Ohio, telling steelworkers that he identified with them, had worked to limit imports and had co-sponsored a bill to retrain the unemployed.

LEAD: The growing debate in the capital and on the campaign trail over the cost of President Reagan's anti-missile program is in many ways a debate over whether Mr. Reagan's dream will ever be fulfilled.
LEAD: The bracing breezes of recent days are reminders that it's time to think about making homes snug.
LEAD: In the sole judicial contest in next Thursday's New York primary, two Democratic candidates in the Bronx vie for a countywide seat on New York City's Civil Court.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of a front-page article yesterday about the Yonkers housing crisis omitted two lines. The passage, beginning with a quotation from a resident of Yonkers, should have read: '' 'Right now, there's no garbage collection on my street. It's time for integration.

LEAD: Dec. 1, 1980: Justice Department sues Board of Education, City of Yonkers and Yonkers Community Development Agency, charging that the city racially discriminated in education and public housing.

LEAD: Reports of illness and deaths from gastrointestinal diseases began to rise suddenly today, increasing fears of an epidemic even as the waters of this country's devastating flood continue to recede.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor of the Giants has begun a rehabilitation program for substance abuse, a source close to the team said yesterday. The source, who requested anonymity, said the rehabilitation was not taking place in the metropolitan area.

LEAD: The marriage of Stephanie Boyle, a daughter of Beverly Bates Boyle of New York and John G. Boyle of St. Thomas, V.I., to Thomas Aquinas Harrigan, a son of Jacqueline Bose Harrigan and Judge Dennis F. Harrigan, both of Milford, Conn., took place yesterday at the Lapham Estate in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev.
LEAD: The Yonkers City Council voted early today to approve a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, ending a crisis that had threatened to bankrupt the city.
LEAD: The film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' opened in London today to poor reviews, a small protest outside a theater and a ban on advertising in the London subway system.

LEAD: Texas A&M's football program was put on probation today for two years and banned from a bowl appearance this season after the National Collegiate Athletic Association said it found rules violations. The N.C.A.A. order did not prohibit television appearances. Six schools in the nine-member Southwest Conference have been investigated by the N.C.A.A.
LEAD: Because of a computer transmission error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated Henry Kaufman's view on the dollar's range. He said the range was now 130 to 135 yen.

LEAD: Macmillan Inc. and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm, have been discussing a possible leveraged buyout of the publishing concern, several people familiar with the situation said yesterday.

LEAD: When Dennis Conner stepped aboard Stars & Stripes today, he had the look of a sure winner, with confident smile and purposeful walk. The skipper then did what he had set out to do: defend the America's Cup against the most unorthodox challenge in the 137-year history of the competition.
LEAD: ''I know that this is not the most glamorous job in the world,'' Joe Lobosco allowed.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Motoda Electronics Company of Tokyo received a United States patent this week for a bladeless windshield wiper that uses ultrasonic vibrations to clear rain and snow.
LEAD: Eleven major companies sided with the Irving Bank Corporation yesterday in its appeal of a court ruling that found its ''poison pill'' anti-takeover measure a violation of New York State law.

LEAD: The army announced today that in recent weeks it had arrested 200 Palestinians and crushed a network of political committees that had been used to organize the nine-month Arab uprising in the Gaza Strip.
LEAD: The Jerusalem International Book Fair, which is held every other year, is scheduled for the week of March 12, 1989, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Teddy Kollek.

LEAD: International 2-5, 28 A papal visit to Africa is not slight to Pretoria, the Vatican said. Pope John Paul II wants to visit South Africa, but cannot on a visit to five neighboring countries because of scheduling problems, the Vatican said. LEAD: BASEBALL
LEAD: Talk about an equal-opportunity sport: the leading candidate for Horse of the Year meets the winner of the Kentucky Derby today at Belmont Park, and both of them are fillies.

LEAD: The days may grow short when you reach September, but retailers hope that the days have been long enough to buy something for Grandma and Grandpa. In case you have not heard, tomorrow is Grandparents Day.

LEAD: Sherry Ann Thornburg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale O. Thornburg of Modesto, Calif., and Samuel Ellison Belk 4th, the son of Joanne Belk and Mr. Belk 3d, both of Washington, were married yesterday at El Capitan Meadows in Yosemite National Park in California. The Rev. Kenneth Hoover, a Seventh-day
LEAD: Mayor Koch was right, and wrong, in his protest to a Brooklyn judge over the sentencing of former collection agents who stole thousands of dollars from New York City parking meters.

LEAD: The Canadian weather station huddling here beside an Arctic fjord is one of the last outposts of habitation before the North Pole. It is so far north that the northern lights, the multicolored aurora that hangs like a curtain across the Arctic sky, are visible on the southern horizon.

LEAD: Maybe it was that surprising 26-7 victory over Michigan to start the 1987 season that made Notre Dame believe it was really a good football team again. But Notre Dame lost its last three games and the truth emerged. Coach Lou Holtz was certain, as he had insisted all along, that the Irish were not among the nation's best teams.

LEAD: The generous sales incentives offered by auto manufacturers and new-cr dealers last year and this summer will not be evident when the 1989 models make their debut in the fall. Car inventories are down sharply, making it less likely that dealers will try to stimultae sales through low car-loan rates or large cash rebates.
LEAD: A picture caption on Aug. 27 about new bus systems that are easing isolation in rural areas misidentified a bus traveling near Norfolk, Neb. It belonged to Arrow Stage Lines, not Greyhound.
LEAD: The House of Representatives voted today to maintain the law barring the use of Federal funds for almost all abortions.

LEAD: The crowd was not as large in the San Diego Yacht Club today as it was on the night last year when Dennis Conner recaptured the America's Cup in Australia. The celebration was not as raucous, the mood not as euphoric.

LEAD: For several years, the cattle industry has used embryo-transfer techniques to enhance breeding. Typically, high-quality cows are fertilized through artificial insemination, and the embryos are then transferred to less well-bred surrogate mothers. With this technique, high-quality cows can produce an almost infinite number of offspring without enduring the strain of carrying calves.

LEAD: Dr. Harvey Kranzler was nearing the Lincoln Square Synagogue last week when the woman approached him. ''My husband just left me,'' she said. ''Could you give me some money?'' For Dr. Kranzler, a child psychiatrist who lived on Manhattan's Upper West Side for 13 years before moving recently to New Jersey, it was hardly the first such encounter, maybe more than the thousandth.

LEAD: In an atmosphere that was part pep rally and part revival meeting, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, held a luncheon yesterday to mark the beginning of the school year. He invited teachers, school guards, custodians, principals, students and others who work in the schools.

LEAD: Three months after the first jury verdict ever against a tobacco company for a smoker's death, the flood of lawsuits that antismoking advocates predicted would threaten the cigarette industry's future has not materialized, new statistics show.
LEAD: Patricia Hearst Shaw was in a dither, homebound in Connecticut with two small daughters on a busy morning.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Nearly six months after the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders agreed on a plan that they hoped would bring peace and full democracy to Nicaragua, death and political imprisonment are still facts of life in the central provinces of Chontales and Boaco.

LEAD: A long-simmering feud between New York City's police and fire officials erupted again yesterday in a flurry of insults, with Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward ridiculing the Fire Department as misguided and underworked and the head of the firefighters' union accusing Mr. Ward of failing to keep the streets safe.

LEAD: Employees can no longer assume that if they work hard and do a good job, the company will take care of them, warns George E. L. Barbee, executive director of the Consumer Financial Institute, a division of Price Waterhouse, in Waltham, Mass.

LEAD: The National Football League today lifted Richard Dent's 30-day suspension for refusing to take a drug test. Dent, a defensive end for the Chicago Bears, was given permission to play Sunday against the Colts.

LEAD: An article in Weekend yesterday about a food tasting that continues today and tomorrow in Battery Park misstated ticket availability. American Express cardholders may charge tickets at the site or at restaurants participating in the tasting, but not at American Express offices.
LEAD: BREATHING LESSONS By Anne Tyler 327 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
LEAD: The battle lines have shifted in Britain's long internal struggle over its membership in the European Community.
LEAD: OUT OF THIS WORLD By Graham Swift. 208 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $16.95.

LEAD: Emily Ann Egan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Egan of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Douglas Pierce Thomas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Thomas of Old Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Donald W. Kraus performed the ceremony at St. Scholastica Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: The singer Adelaide Hall will open a four-night cabaret series at Weill Recital Hall on Oct. 12 at 8 P.M. Karen Mason will appear on Oct. 13; Steve Ross will offer songs by Coward and Porter on Oct. 14, and Andrea Marcovicci will sing love songs from the theater on Oct. 15. Tickets -which go on sale at the box office on Wednesday - are $15, or $52 for all four nights.

LEAD: In most Olympics, canoeing has seemed to be an after thought for the United States. Americans have seldom reached finals, let alone won medals. Now the United States has become a factor, not on the level of East Germany, but certainly in the next group, with Hungary, the Soviet Union and New Zealand.

LEAD: Having seen and thoroughly enjoyed the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's delightful production of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona,'' I was appalled at the half-hearted, ''damning with faint praise'' review by Alvin Klein (Theater: ''Fun and Games in Verona,'' Aug. 14).

LEAD: I don't know what it actually takes to become a star,'' says the choreographer Agnes de Mille, ''but it is a matter of being given the opportunities and of having the tremendous courage to take those opportunities. You have to have enough belief in yourself to do that, otherwise it's just coloring in the black and white.

LEAD: Earlier this summer when the Edmonton Oilers sold Wayne Gretzky, the hockey virtuoso who is also probably the world's best-known Canadian, to the Los Angeles Kings, many, perhaps most, of his countrymen were hurt and some truly mourned. His departure injured the nation's self-esteem and aroused thoughts of apostasy and betrayal.
LEAD: Burlington's Minor Confusion

LEAD: Golf King Leads by One: Betsy King, winner of last week's Rail Charity Classic, took the second-round lead by one stroke yesterday at the $250,000 Cellular One-Ping Championship in Portland, Ore. King, who started the day at one-under par, shot a two-under 70 for a two-day total of 141 over the 6,285-yard course at Riverside Golf and Country Club.

LEAD: A couple of weeks ago I read in the newspaper that the 11 lighthouses in the United States that are still tended by keepers will be automated by the fall of 1989. Well, I thought, there goes the last symbol. There'll be no more ''To the Lighthouse,'' just as there'll be no more Don Quixote, because the windmills too are gone.
LEAD: WHEN it comes to owning a home, few people in the world pursue the dream with as much vigor, desire or penny-pinching thrift as Americans.

LEAD: THERE IS SOMETHING extremely peculiar about the messages women are getting this election year. A rat, presented with the same set of contradictions, would simply keel over in its little maze, toes up, circuits blown. Women are expected to press on and vote.

LEAD: MORE than a year has passed, so Oscar Schmidt can afford to be generous about Brazil's upset victory over the United States in the men's basketball final of the 10th Pan American Games. ''They had the better team,'' he said. ''In the second half, we grabbed our chances.''
LEAD: Scores of boats, from leisure craft to charter fishing rigs and giant tour boats, gathered in New York Harbor off Battery Park yesterday morning to protest ocean pollution.

LEAD: The modern form of judo, consisting of throws, hold-downs, choking techniques and armlocks, was introduced in Japan in 1882 by Jigaro Kano, a student of jujitsu, the martial art that predated judo. In 1964 judo became an Olympic sport in - appropriately - Tokyo. The Japanese have dominated the sport until recently, when several European countries and South Korea began to produce formidable competitors.

LEAD: At St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L.I., Maryann Tarzian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Tarzian of Port Jefferson, L.I., was married yesterday to Patrick Eugene Britt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Britt of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Untzag Nalbandian performed the Armenian Orthodox ceremony.

LEAD: A letter from the President of El Salvador has asked the United States to grant temporary refuge to a half-million Salvadorans already in this country, and the letter warned that many of them would support leftist guerrillas if they were forced to return home.

LEAD: Hans K. Maeder, a maverick in secondary education who briefly headed the Walden School in New York City before founding his own preparatory school in the Berkshire Hills, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: This was a special summer for Arthur Ashe. In 1968, when tennis lifted the barriers to professionals, he won the first United States Open, becoming the first black man to win a Grand Slam event. But Ashe hasn't had a chance to celebrate the 20th anniversary. He is in New York Hospital, undergoing tests to determine why his right side became numb last week.

LEAD: ''We hope today to alert the public to what is clearly the 'fraud du jour' - the fools' gold rush of 1988.'' - James E. Meyer, president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, on estimates that fraudulent gold-mine schemes will take in $250 million this year.

LEAD: Barely a century old and now Canada's third largest metropolis, this energetic port city of British Columbia is about to embark on a development spree that will dramatically change its look, character and style.

LEAD: THE show's title is ''Presence and Perception, Architectural Investigations,'' and its location is the City Without Walls Gallery, at 1 Gateway Plaza. This, along with the names of the chief organizers, Ron Petersen and Martin Acampora, and the closing date, Thursday, is about it for hard information.

LEAD: Senator Lloyd Bentsen accused the Republican Administration today of conducting a ''popgun war on drugs.'' He said that Vice President Bush had been responsible for leading this battle ''and he blew it badly.''

LEAD: In the article ''Emergency Pet Care'' [ Aug. 21 ] , it was stated that the County Animal Clinic provided the only 24-hour emergency care in Westchester for injured pets. This statement is far from accurate. Dr. Theodore Hoch and Dr. Arnold Remson provide 24-hour emergency service at the Yorktown Animal Hospital, at 271 Veterans Road in Yorktown Heights.

LEAD: IT won't be long now. We will awaken on a chilly morning with a blue, cloudless sky. By noon, the wind will die and the air will grow colder and colder. Frost will be coming during the night.
LEAD: When Penn's dynasty collapsed last year, after five championship seasons, the Ivy League crown was out there for anyone to wear.
LEAD: THE BOSS J. Edgar Hoover and the Great American Inquisition. By Athan G. Theoharis and John Stuart Cox. Illustrated. 489 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $27.95.

LEAD: Ursinus College, a small private liberal arts college in Collegeville, Pa., has been awarded a $5.37 million grant to build a humanities center.

LEAD: The marriage of Bibiana Hernandez, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valentin Hernandez of Washington, to David Nerkle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Nerkle of Ocala, Fla., took place yesterday at the Nunciature of the Holy See in Washington. Archbishop Pio Laghi, the Apostolic Pro-Nuncio to the United States, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A Superior Court judge has ordered a trial to decide whether Boston University must relinquish its collection of the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to his widow. The judge has also denied the university's claim to the slain civil rights leader's papers in Atlanta.

LEAD: The credits accompanying Richard N. Goodwin's article on Lyndon B. Johnson on the Aug. 21 issue mistakenly omitted the name of the publisher of Mr. Goodwin's latest book, ''Remembering America: A Voice From the Sixties,'' from which the article. The publisher is Little, Brown.

LEAD: IN the Pinkham Notch base camp at the foot of Mount Washington, my son and I found we couldn't fit everything into our pack. What to take, what to leave out? It was a moment of reckoning. While some people on vacation would find climbing to 6,000 feet a form of masochism, to us it was a way of determining the essentials, learning to travel light.
LEAD: A chapter of Russian history was covered up this week, as Soviet officials decided that discoveries of the past had to yield to needs of the present.

LEAD: A Republican official selected by Vice President Bush to be deputy of the Republican National Committee said today that in 1971 at the direction of President Nixon he had conducted a census of the political affiliation of senior officials at the Bureau of Labor Statistics and whether they were Jewish.

LEAD: I read the Aug. 14 article ''Labor Shortage Challenges Employers,'' and I for one find it hard to believe there is a labor shortage.

Upon entering the park, the car began to stall when we slowed down. I was able to reach the valley where there are two garages.

LEAD: IT IS EARLY MORNING AND most of the top leaders of the nation's personal computer industry are jammed into a hotel banquet hall in Naples, Fla. The annual, late-winter gathering is one that industry insiders can't afford to miss - 72 hours of closed-door deal-making, hushed corridor conversations about technologies gone amiss, and arguments over the future course of America's most visible high-tech industry.

LEAD: VISITORS to White Plains in the early part of this century found the Roger Smith, the city's only hotel, an elegant accommodation. The 125-room hotel, later renamed the Coachman, had its share of prominent guests and notable conventions.

LEAD: RENTING a home - an English cottage, Caribbean villa or Parisian apartment - can offer vacationers privacy, flexibility and sometimes even economy. On the other hand, you may or may not have someone coming in to make the bed every day; room service as such is rarely available, and there's no tour desk to arrange your sightseeing.

LEAD: A GENERATION gap has formed in diving; the age of world-class talent has been dropping precipitously, so that suddenly veterans with two decades of training - and the maturity and grace that come with it - are finding themselves upset by tiny acrobats barely half their age.

LEAD: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: SINCE Seattle already has built a park and a convention center over a freeway, it seems appropriate that the next big residential project to be developed here will be erected over eight lanes of Interstate 90.

LEAD: I ONCE TUTORED JUNIOR-high geometry, and one of my most difficult pupils would sit at the kitchen table - wild hair flying, bubble gum popping - as she insisted again and again that she didn't understand.

LEAD: Several spells of intense heat have inflicted additional damage on the nation's already drought-ravaged grain crops in the last month, leading agricultural analysts say, and a tiny parasite has aggravated the harm the drought has done to critically important soybean yields.

LEAD: Taekwondo, a martial art indigenous to Korea, is a demonstration sport selected by the host nation for inclusion in the Olympics this year. Like other demonstration sports, if it proves popular enough, it could be voted onto the permanent Olympic agenda by the International Olympic Committee.

LEAD: Richard N. Kaplan, executive producer of ''Nightline,'' explains the reason for Ted Koppel's practice of not letting those he interviews have eye contact with him: ''To watch yourself talk out of synch is mind-boggling.''

You can't leave more than 15 feet between you and the guy ahead before someone cuts in. It's worse up in Paramus.) It's a Friday afternoon in the summer.

Some analysts think this will drive prices down sharply, while others believe OPEC will reassert discipline among members at the November meeting.

Thus most of this repertory grew out of a tonal, melody-accompaniment tradition, and a lot of it by way of American popular culture.

Though recognizing the many differences between humans and animals, they think they have similar and transferable souls.

LEAD: The less one knows about baseball - and I happen to know less than almost anybody - the more one is apt to notice in movies about the game. LEAD: In weight lifting, there are separate competitions in 10 body-weight classes in which competitors weight from 114 pounds to over 242 pounds. LEAD: FOR many jobholders, for many reasons, one is not enough. A schoolteacher by day becomes a theater usher by night. There are thousands of Connecticut residents who moonlight - work a part-time job in addition to a full-time job - in order to make ends meet or maintain their styles of life.

LEAD: I have to take exception to the article ''Full Life, Empty Values'' by Linda Gass (Opinion page, Aug. 21). I, too, live in the same community as Ms. Gass. However, I do not feel the same way she does. My children have been taught, not that appearances are important, but rather that if they work hard and try to be good people they have a better chance of achieving their goals and dreams than if they think everything just comes to them on a silver platter.

LEAD: Teresa Ann O'Sullivan and David Allan Martland, associates in the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, were married yesterday at the Peacham (Vt.) Congregational Church by the Rev. Stanford G. Blankin.

LEAD: FIGURING that panic on Wall Street might deflate property prices throughout New York City, Douglas P. Klassen decided to halt his search for an apartment indefinitely when the stock market plummeted last October.

LEAD: THE United States has lost control of its financial markets to foreigners and has run out of easy policy options to regain it. The American financial tune is no longer being called in New York, but rather in Tokyo, London and Frankfurt. In fact, this loss of control had a lot to do with the timing of the stock market crash last fall.
LEAD: Pepper Johnson returned to his New Jersey home late last Monday night and discovered that his telephone answering service had been bombarded with messages.

LEAD: At a time in fashion when most designers cautiously refrain from making pronouncements on the nature - and the future - of their craft, Geoffrey Beene remains as tartly outspoken as he was 15 years ago. Then, he decreed, silhouette be damned, ''the challenge of any collection is the fabric.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Last year, when my son went away to college, I cried bittersweet tears. I felt that although this was a happy milestone, it marked the end of our little family as we'd known it for 18 years. First we were four; now, with just our high school-aged daughter at home, we would be three.

LEAD: An 800-pound propeller that dropped from a C-130 aircraft last week in a wooded section of Winhall was found Friday by Air Force officials. The propeller and other parts fell off a transport plane at 7:05 P.M. Sept. 1 as it headed for Loring Air Force Base, Me., from Davis-Monthan Air Force Base at Tucson, Ariz.

LEAD: SOONER or later it seems to happen to most middle-class house owners. The kitchen looks dingy and old-fashioned, the house gets smaller as the kids get bigger, and anyway, a lot of the neighbors seem to be adding new familiy rooms off the living room, sun rooms off the master bedroom and decks off the dining room.

LEAD: One recent Sunday afternoon, those who provide shelter for the homeless at a church here found Andrea DiMaggio in the fetal position between a row of bushes and the parish fence. She had resisted the shelter's attempts to help her. She was twitching. Her face was bloodied with self-inflicted scratches.

LEAD: WRIGHTSTOWN AIR SHOW The Thunderbirds, the Air Force aerial demonstration team and their F-16 fighters, will be the stars today of McGuire Air Force Base's annual air show, which last year drew 400,000 spectators.

LEAD: From the jewelry aisles of I. Magnin to the gilded elevators of Marshall Field's, the chatter along North Michigan Avenue these days has been of little else but this: The New Yorkers are coming and the name is ''Bloomingdale's.''
LEAD: ''All we lost was a good night's sleep,'' Wade Guice, the Harrison County civil defense director, said this morning of Hurricane Florence, hours after the storm made a quiet landfall.
LEAD: THE other morning, a pair of secondhand eyeglasses sold for $16,830, and almost no one in the packed auction house here seemed surprised.
LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers have become believers in life after death because as far as they were concerned, they died six weeks ago and here they are alive again.
LEAD: THIS week the state will publicly reveal its plans for establishing a dump for the 22 tons of low-level radioactive waste generated in Connecticut each year.

LEAD: THE National Association for the Advancement of Colored People still sometimes engages in battles that recall the height of the civil rights era. Last week, for example, its Mississippi branch picketed and boycotted schools in Greenville in protest of policies it believes are racist.

LEAD: ANYONE returning to Pearl of the Atlantic will be surprised to find the space has been occupied for four months by a new restaurant, Harbour Square, in the restored complex of the same name in Stamford.

LEAD: Chris Warren scored touchdowns on runs of 37, 20 and 5 yards yesterday as Ferrum College routed Wagner, the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III champion, 40-13, at Fischer Field on Staten Island.
LEAD: Three new cabarets have opened in New York in recent months.

LEAD: An article in the Long Island Weekly on Aug. 28 incorrectly reported the book-club distribution of Susan Isaacs's novel, ''Shining Through,'' published by Harper & Row. It is a selection of the Literary Guild.

LEAD: Richard Diebenkorn is by general consent a painter much loved and not like any other, but he does not look like most people's idea of an artist. If we were told that he was the head of the department of moral philosophy at an ancient and low-key university, we would have no trouble believing it. He has the large, heavy-framed glasses, the well-cut tweed jackets (neither old nor new), the corduroy pants of standard cut, the capacious and comfortable shoes and a general air of continuous but soundless rumination.

LEAD: Chester, Conn. $155,000 Straits Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new Cape Cod; close to town, private setting, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Essex, Conn. $145,000 53 Pond Meadow 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; screened porch, custom construction, 0.75 acre; taxes $846.

LEAD: Slowly, tentatively, painfully, the Palestinian uprising is finding its way into art in Israel. Pop singers, painters and craftspeople - both Arabs and Jews - say they simply can't separate their anguish from their work.

LEAD: Nearly four weeks after Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, and the United States Ambassador to that country were killed when a Pakistani Air Force plane crashed in eastern Pakistan, Pakistani and American investigators have so far found no conclusive evidence that a missile or a bomb was responsible.

LEAD: Talks between the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders, which broke down amid mutual accusations three months ago, could resume in the coming weeks, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said Friday night.

LEAD: The 1984 American harvest of nine gold medals, and Greg LeMond's 1986 victory in the Tour de France, have stimulated cycling interest in the United States, among participants and spectators. But this time, the Soviet Union, East German and other Eastern bloc riders will be competing. And LeMond and other male professionals are not eligible for the Olympics.

LEAD: The schedules for the 1988-89 television season announced by the major networks last spring had a heavy dose of the familiar. Television stars like Dick Van Dyke and Mary Tyler Moore, each long since removed from the domestic bliss that they shared as Rob and Laura Petrie from 1961 through 1966, would be returning to CBS; the recent hit films ''Baby Boom''(NBC) and ''Dirty Dancing'' (CBS) would be turned into weekly series, while old weekly series such as ''Get Smart'' (ABC), ''Mission: Impossible'' (ABC) and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.

LEAD: John Cooper's first game as head coach at Ohio State turned out to be perfect today. Before the largest opening-game crowd in Ohio Stadium history, 89,768, the Buckeyes trounced Syracuse, 26-9, and terminated the Orangemen's unbeaten streak at 14 games.
LEAD: Maria Kathleen Simson and Michael Kimmelman were married yesterday at the Friends Meeting House in New York by Don Johnson, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of New York.

LEAD: The 1988-89 art season has a rare urgency. There are shows that we need to see, on contemporary artists we can't stop talking about. And there are shows that provide a historical perspective in an unusually provocative way, by charting one of the most irresistible of all national artistic traditions.

LEAD: BORROWED TIME An AIDS Memoir. By Paul Monette. 342 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.MORTAL EMBRACE Living With AIDS. By Emmanuel Dreuilhe. Translated by Linda Coverdale. 162 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $15.95.

LEAD: A STRANGER'S HOUSE By Bret Lott. 256 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.
LEAD: AS Westchester's prisoner population reached another record number last week, the county searched for new ways to relieve overcrowding.

LEAD: Hours after the Yonkers City Council approved a court-ordered housing desegregation plan early yesterday, many Yonkers residents expressed relief that the crisis that had threatened to bankrupt the city was over. But the relief was tinged with apprehension that the new housing would lead to slums and crime, as some opponents have long feared.

LEAD: Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles. The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile. Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''SAY goodbye to Moscow; you're going off to Siberia!'' It wasn't in keeping with glasnost, but with that announcement, our four-night train trip to Irkutsk began. The overtones of ''going off'' started a nervous giggle.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, once viewed as dangerously ''moderate'' by the political right, has now won substantial credibility among conservatives and thus the leeway he may need to move to the political center to win this fall's Presidential election.

LEAD: You're not alone, Columbia University. We at Macalester understand the frustration of losing and losing and losing some more. We understand how it is to smile through tears. We understand how some - even some at your own university - take some perverse pleasure in the losing. We understand how tired you get of the media poking around your campus, wondering when the streak will end.

LEAD: Reagan Administration officials in the Department of Education have criticized a new college loan proposal by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis because the loan repayment plan would make graduates in high-paying careers subsidize the loans of those in low-paying ones.

LEAD: There is little doubt that it will require a huge upset for the United States' men's team to surrender the gold medal it won in 1984 in Los Angeles. LEAD: Nguyen Anh Tuan and Giui Thi Le could not believe their eyes, but somehow they were back in Southeast Asia.

LEAD: MARTIN P. HACKER says he has always considered himself a private man of simple tastes, never one to mix in politics, certainly not somebody who would single-handedly do battle with a giant commuter railroad authority.

LEAD: Track and field may have Carl Lewis, Florence Griffith Joyner and Edwin Moses and all those other glamorous athletes. Gymnastics may have all those doll-like successors to Olga and Nadia and Mary Lou. But if you like to see Americans win Olympic medals, swimming will be the sport to watch in Seoul.
LEAD: ONE expects the Goodspeed Opera House to unearth vintage musicals, develop new works and revive fondly remembered ones.

Bouquett, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gaston Bouquett of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Gerald Chapman, a Baptist minister, officiated in the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh.
LEAD: U.C.L.A. gave Nebraska a taste of California flash and a 41-28 trouncing before 84,086 tonight in the Rose Bowl.
