LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WORK is set to begin soon on a $105 million project to create 530 residential units and 125,000 square feet of office and retail space in a five-block area of downtown New Haven.
LEAD: Connecticut is trying to solve a fiscal puzzle. Its economy still seems to be perking briskly, but the flow of tax money to the state has turned sluggish.

LEAD: The second annual New Jersey Seafood Festival was held at this seaside resort today, and though the seascape was serene, the festival itself was awash with concerns and conflicting views about the danger that pollution poses, or does not pose, to fish and to people who eat fish.
LEAD: TRAVELERS over 60 years old need not pay full price - not on most airlines, nor in many large hotel chains.

LEAD: The Israeli Army imposed a curfew and other restrictions today in Nablus, the largest city in the occupied West Bank, after a Palestinian was fatally stabbed and troops reportedly shot and wounded 14 other Arabs.

LEAD: ''THIS is a neighborhood,'' said Alexandra Corbin describing Carroll Gardens, ''where an investment banker can move in next to a plumber and a sanitation worker, and everybody becomes friends.''
LEAD: Dave LaPoint won his seventh straight decision tonight, pitching a six-hitter as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-1.
LEAD: College football's new rule regarding blocked conversion attempts helped convert a possible St. John's defeat into victory yesterday over Iona.

LEAD: CHIEF JUSTICE WILLIAM HUBBS REHNQUIST stared stonily out at the crowd in the marble-columned chamber from the Supreme Court's center chair, the chair in which Ronald Reagan had put him two years before. It was June 29, the last day of the Court's 1987-88 term, and one decision remained to be handed down - the big one.

LEAD: There are two apparently polar but equally valid ways of looking at Nicholas Nixon's photographs. His images are remarkable demonstrations of how the traditional (and by now archaic) tools of the medium - a view camera, black-and-white film, contact prints - can be used to venture into uncharted artistic territory.
LEAD: Waterborne Radar ''He's going 30 miles per hour. But look, he sees us! Now he's slowing down! Now he's down to about 15!''

LEAD: Unexpected results from a recent Soviet-American experiment on monitoring nuclear tests have raised questions about the Reagan Administration's stance in negotiations over restrictions on such tests, some geologists say.

LEAD: SHE IS KNOWN AS THE ''Mona Lisa of Roman Palestine.'' The portrait is part of a mosaic floor, dating to the third century - nearly 30 feet long and more than 20 feet wide - revealed in an excavation of the ancient city of Sepphoris, once the capital of Galilee, in what is now northern Israel. Discovered in August 1987 by an expedition led by two Duke University professors, Eric and Carol Meyers, and Ehud Netzer, an archaeologist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, the mosaic was re-interred over the winter while financing was sought for its preservation.

LEAD: The marriage of Barbara Alice Hopkinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald F. Hopkinson of Smoke Rise, N.J., and Jupiter Island, Fla., to Kevin Lawrence Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Kelly of Auburndale, Mass., and Duxbury, Mass., took place yesterday in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Last month, President Reagan signed into law a national act of contrition for a grievous lapse in this country's cherished standards of liberty almost half a century ago: The wartime incarceration of more than 100,000 Japanese-American citizens and Japanese resident aliens in concentration camps. The legislation provided for recompense of $20,000 to each surviving internee, whether citizen or alien, and, more significantly, an unprecedented apology by the United States Government.

LEAD: The British tidal wave will subside this season. No large musicals are scheduled to sail across the Atlantic, unless one includes ''Legs Diamond,'' a multinational creation, composed by and starring Peter Allen as the title gangster. Maggie Smith is to arrive in Peter Shaffer's ''Lettice and Lovage,'' her West End comedy vehicle, with her London co-star, Margaret Tyzack.

LEAD: As pop music moves back indoors, arenas in the New York area are offering an unusually inviting array of pop, rock and soul talent. From the freewheeling West Coast folk-rock of the Grateful Dead (beginning Friday) to the glitzy merry-go-round pop of Elton John, due Oct. 17, Madison Square Garden will be a busy musical hub.

The Rev. Julian Deeken performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: TEN years ago, executives at Central Fidelity Bank of Richmond, Va. began looking for ways to attract customers. Someone suggested a program of special benefits and services for the elderly. It was a novel idea.
LEAD: The deer population of New York State has risen to a record 800,000, state game officials estimated this week on the eve of the opening of a new hunting season.
LEAD: Eastern Airlines eliminated 4,000 jobs today in a move it says it needs to survive.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The United States Olympic Committee is considering the possibility of allowing Angel Myers to seek a second opinion regarding the positive drug test that caused her to be removed from the Olympic swimming team. Myers, who qualified for the team in five events, was found to have used a banned substance, believed to be steroids.

LEAD: Keith Haring's cartoonish new mural on East Houston Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side bears watchwords from Public Enemy's latest rap single, ''Don't Believe the Hype.' The artist and video director Robert Longo's yuppies twist and grimace in black and white on MTV's ''art breaks.'' William Wegman's Weimaraner Fay Ray, the art world's top dog, cavorts in the video clip for New Order's ''Blue Monday.

LEAD: ''Master Mind,'' a thunderous piece by the saxophonist Greg Osby on Jack DeJohnette's newest recording, ''Audio-Visualscapes'' (Impulse!, MCA 8029, all three formats), begins and ends with an ominous, machinelike drumbeat. In between, saxophone lines, radically disfigured by electronic instruments that double and triple the sound of the instruments, riff away unmercifully.

LEAD: IF a partnership is unbalanced, with one player clearly a better cardplayer, there is a tendency to maneuver the bidding so that he, or she, can be the declarer. Provided this is not carried too far, the better player will play more than his share with a profitable effect on the score.

LEAD: THE vast web of waterways that make up the Amazon - rivers, lakes, swamps, streams, waterfalls, bayous and igapos or flooded forest land - are, as Brazilians put it, peixoso or full of fish. Fish is the principal source of protein for Indians living in the Amazon region as well as for the caboclos, descendants of a mixed population of Europeans and Indians who farm and fish in the more populated and accessible areas near Manaus, the capital city of the state of Amazonas.

LEAD: FOR molding to present a neat appearance, individual pieces must be joined skillfully. The technique most often used to accomplish this is mitering (cutting the ends of pieces off at an angle and joining them by placing the angled ends together). Creating professional-looking miter joints requires practice; however, by working patiently with appropriate tools, even beginners can produce excellent miter joints after only a few tries.

LEAD: Olympic shooting's two newest events are men's and women's air pistol competitions, bringing the total to 13. Though the various rifle, pistol and shotgun events have a larger following in Europe, Americans have done well over the years.

LEAD: It could easily be just another tournament on the globe-trotting tennis tour, the Korean Open for the men, the Virginia Slims of Seoul for the women. Setting this tournament apart, though, is that it is part of the Olympic spectacle. It is the first time in 64 years that ennis players will compete for a gold medal.

LEAD: After four decades, Taiwan has modified the practice of referring to the People's Republic of China as a ''bandit'' regime. Until August, all goods imported from the mainland had to be labeled as ''bandit goods.'' Now, according to the Free China Journal, they will be called ''products from the Chinese mainland'' or ''products from Communist China.

LEAD: Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Laird McGovern, the daughter of Mrs. William B. Cutler of Stonington and James W. McGovern of New York, to Philip MacLaren Johnstone, a son of Rodney S. Johnstone of Stonington and Frances D. Johnstone of Worcester, Mass.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Whatever the outcome of their historic discrimination trial, whatever the judge's final ruling later this month, Hispanic agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation say they know that bigotry has made them second-class citizens in an agency responsible for enforcing the nation's civil rights laws.

LEAD: RARELY have so many news reports strengthened the case for strong implementation of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975, which gave auto companies 10 years to reach an average fleet mileage level of 27.5 miles per gallon.

LEAD: BABY boomers have had their day. Now, it is the turn of the ''empty nesters,'' people generally over the age of 50 who find themselves with more money and more time to spend it. Freed from the burdens of raising children, paying college tuition and making mortgage payments, empty nesters have become good business.

LEAD: SoNo is neither SoHo nor NoHo, the neighborhoods south and north of Houston Street in Manhattan, nor is it the invention of rampaging neighborhood-namers. SoNo is South Norwalk, a harborside district of Norwalk, Conn., that has what some see as a trackside gold mine.

LEAD: If the coverage of the Winter Games is any criterion, I expect to see a tremendous number of commercials. Since my patience with commercials wears thin very quickly, I expect to see what is on the other channels or in my bookcase. STEVAN LEVINSON Forest Hills, Queens
LEAD: Labor Day marks the beginning of the Presidential campaign. The conventions are over, the lazy days of August past.

LEAD: The 60-year survey of the sculpture of Ibram Lassaw currently on view at the Guild Hall Museum sums up a body of work that will never rank very high in the annals of 20th-century art history. At the same time, this show, which is titled ''Ibram Lassaw: Space Explorations,'' presents a long, dedicated career worthy of attention.

LEAD: In Park Slope, the brownstones are the prime properties; the restorers are busy, and the builders are highly revered and generally dead. Several residential buildings have been started recently on the western and southern fringes of the prosperous Brooklyn neighborhood, but a $9 million condominium, Sterling Court, at 100 Sterling Place between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, will be the first new construction in the core of Park Slope in years.

LEAD: Scott Erney passed for 239 yards and 2 touchdowns, and Doug Kokoskie made a key fumble recovery today as Rutgers stunned 15th-ranked Michigan State, 17-13, in the opener for both teams today.

LEAD: THERE'S AN OLD Greek saying,'' said Michael Dukakis, responding to a question about whether President Reagan and Vice President Bush could be held personally accountable for their Administration's ethical lapses, ''a fish rots from the head first. It starts at the top.'' This scrupulously bipartisan column takes no position on the accuracy of any political accusation, but is ready to examine the roots of all colorful adages used in campaigns.

LEAD: ONE balmy evening several days ago on the plaza outside the city opera house, a group of Armenians were playing Yerevan's favorite guessing game: What if Armenia broke off from the Soviet Union and declared its independence?

LEAD: Three times since the last week in August, the Hungarian press has carried unusual reports of brief strikes in a coal mine, a printing plant and an optical factory. Even more surprisingly, the articles have indicated that the outcomes have favored the strikers.
LEAD: Roger Clemens held Cleveland hitless for seven and one-third innings today as the Boston Red Sox beat the Indians, 6-0, for their fifth victory in six games.

LEAD: A firestorm of political opportunism and incendiary rhetoric is racing through the treetops of Congress. It's scorching good science, laying waste to common sense and leaving nothing in its path but smoke and hot air.

LEAD: To the Editor: Amtrak's cross-country service may be enchanting for William Borders and Nancy M. Debevoise, but for the commuter on Amtrak's crowded Northeast Corridor Boston to New York route, the ride is at best an inconvenience. During the 1987 holiday season, Amtrak passengers who had paid the full $40-plus fare were forced to take commuter trains; I saw elderly citizens and families with small children endure the five-hour trip sitting on bags in the aisles.

LEAD: Modern dance by old and new trailblazers promises to be a highlight of this dance year. The season gets off to a formal start when the Martha Graham Dance Company opens a three-week engagement at City Center (Oct. 4-23) with a gala featuring guest artists Mikhail Baryshnikov, Maya Plisetskaya and Kathleen Turner.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: I expect the Olympics to follow the pattern of the past - the usual bad feelings whenever there is physical contact and in all other competition, with suspicion of drug abuse, the prejudiced and incompetent - irrational official and judges decisions - the usual foul claims and disagreements and objections by biased coaches.

LEAD: THE attention of the computer industry is soon to be riveted once again on the Byzantine inner roads of the PC, specifically the internal data path known as the bus. The mind-numbing technical debate over a bus standard warrants study, because it could affect corporate computer buying decisions into the 1990's.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the enterprising Penguin Repertory goes in for the new and the unfamiliar, it has a certain fondness for the plays of A. R. Gurney Jr., which seem to pop up every couple of seasons. ''The Middle Ages'' is the third of Mr. Gurney's works to be seen here in six years - after ''What I Did Last Summer'' and ''The Dining Room.

LEAD: The 3,500 residents of St. Basile-le-Grand began returning home today, 18 days after they were told to leave their homes in the town near Montreal because of a fire in a warehouse used to store oil contaminated with chemicals known as PCB's.

LEAD: Without a wind instrument in sight, the Ray Brown Trio and Ernie Andrews summon the unmistakable sound of big-band brass. Mr. Brown, a bassist, and Mr. Andrews, a singer, have brought the elegant dynamics of the Count Basie Orchestra to their sets at the Blue Note, where their engagement ends tonight.
LEAD: A janitor who contended he had won the nation's largest Lotto jackpot has been arrested and charged with two felony fraud counts, the Florida Lottery Department said.

LEAD: It is to my friend Chris that I owe my experience at Writer's Prep, the now celebrated school for authors, because he wouldn't take no for an answer. A novelist himself as well as an alumnus of the program, he had watched in horror when, several years ago, I went through the nightmare so many writers endure with the publication of a first book.

LEAD: On a quiet wooded hilltop high above the bustle and the politicking, a handful of experts and devoted amateurs toil at an exacting task that began half a world away and many lifetimes ago - nurturing the National Bonsai Collection.

LEAD: THERE will be no mistaking who they are and how they came to afford fancy cars and all the modern conveniences. There is no need to hide their net worth in a trust fund. The tennis players who are coming to Seoul, South Korea, are professionals by any definition the International Olympic Committee chooses to use.
LEAD: TEACHERS in the Ardsley Union Free School District were officially on the job by the end of August to prepare for the reopening of school last week.

Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Albert Rizzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Amedeo A. Rizzo of Broomall, Pa. Msgr. John R. Ryan performed the ceremony.

LEAD: AS A FOOTBALL STAR AT Palisades High School in Los Angeles, Forest Whitaker was eagerly recruited by colleges that wanted to armor their defensive lines with his 6-foot, 2-inch, 245-pound body. A gifted tenor, Mr. Whitaker also received a scholarship in music. When a Hollywood agent saw him in a professional production of ''The Beggar's Opera'' and urged him to audition for a movie, the 20-year-old college student promptly got the part.

LEAD: The chances that the United States will win its first gold medal in fencing are probably better in Seoul than at any other Olympics in decades, given the caliber of the 1988 team. But the likelihood is still considered remote.

LEAD: LATELY it has made news for other reasons, but Tompkins Square Park has long been a place for freewheeling fashion expression. It remains so, in spite of its recent troubles. In Tompkins Square, the dress mode is good-natured anarchy. The exuberant group that troops through the park may be giving a collective nose-thumb to more conventional styles, but it's done with a smile, not a smirk.

LEAD: BROADCAST NEWS Starring William Hurt, Holly Hunter (in photo), Albert Brooks, Robert Prosky, Lois Chiles, Joan Cusack, Peter Hackes, Christian Clemenson, Robert Katims. Directed by James L. Brooks. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 132 minutes. $89.98. Rated R.
LEAD: To the Editor: I read, with great interest, your article on children who fly alone (Practical Traveler, July 24).

LEAD: A number of recent studies confirm that autopsies still discover unexpected major findings about 10 percent of the time. The reason fewer of these examinations are done is that autopsies are not reimbursed by third-party payers. Second, in these litigious times, when any less- than-perfect result can lead to years of involvement with the medicolegal system, many doctors prefer to bury their mistakes, and who can blame them?

Bussinger, Harald Dietl, Peter Fitz, Reinhard Glemnitz, Dieter Groest, Dietrich Mattausch, Martin Luttge, Gerd Bockmann. Directed by Heinz Schirk. 1988. Prism Entertainment. 87 minutes. $79.95. Not rated.

LEAD: SPRAWLING across a vast delta where three of the world's great rivers meet, Bangladesh is the drainpipe of Central Asia. In bountiful times, the rich alluvial silt that covers most of the country yields as many as three rice crops a year. But when the drainpipe overflows, as it did two weeks ago, Bangladesh becomes a land reminiscent of
LEAD: WE call it the Shubert, but the theater in New Haven is actually the Shubert Performing Arts Center and it presents its own ballet and theater seasons. Now, it has added opera.

LEAD: It's not like one-wall handball in a Brooklyn playground or four-wall handball in an exclusive Manhattan club. The Olympic sport of handball, also known as team handball, is an indoor sport in which the idea is to throw a ball into a net. It has been called hockey without ice or sticks, water polo without water, indoor soccer without kicking.

LEAD: A group of New York City firefighters and their friends and relatives will perform the musical ''Oklahoma!'' later this month to raise money for the burn unit of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

LEAD: So here I am, one block and maybe a couple of light years away from the apartment where I grew up. The neighborhood was terrible then, but it has been broomed and polished. It has been reclaimed and the floor of this Victorian mansion gleams.
LEAD: A DILAPIDATED sardine packing plant on the Royal River in this Portland suburb has been transformed into 42,500 square feet of space for professional offices, shops and port-related businesses.

LEAD: Women's judo became an Olympic sport largely through the efforts of a Brooklyn woman, Rusty Kanokogi, who, after her marriage to a Japanese judoka - a judo fighter - in 1964, became a crusader for women in the sport. She organized the first world championships for women, a prerequisite for consideration on the Olympic agenda, in 1980 with 149 athletes from 27 countries.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE quadrennial hand-wringing over the vast number of Americans who choose not to vote - nearly half the people who are eligible -has several new twists this year.

LEAD: Carmen Malpica remembers Jan. 5, 1986, very well. That was the day, as an illiterate, unemployed, single 23-year-old mother of two, she walked into the offices of Bronx Educational Services, a school devoted to teaching adults how to read and write.
LEAD: A New York City program under which homeless people who show signs of dangerous mental disturbance can be hospitalized against their will is to be expanded to Brooklyn, city officials say.

There is nothing incongruous about this: After all, the Music
LEAD: NEW collectors are frequently baffled by the rich variety of albums designed to organize stamps, covers and other material.

LEAD: THE FRONTIERS OF PARADISE A Study of Monks and Monasteries. By Peter Levi. 224 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson.
LEAD: In 1945, a beatific lost boy was befriended by a madcap sailor with a penchant for tap-dancing in the breezy M-G-M musical ''Anchors Aweigh.''

LEAD: After more than five years as the principal spokesman for private business in Nicaragua, Enrique Bolanos Geyer relinquished his post this week but promised to remain in Nicaragua and continue his anti-Sandinista militance.
LEAD: I have always admired Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' (''Ted Koppel's Edge,'' by Marshall Blonsky, Aug. 14).
LEAD: There are some dishes that - no matter how appealing - will never be served in a restaurant. And vice versa.

LEAD: OVER the last decade, residents of this growing capital city have flocked to new housing developments in its surrounding suburbs. Now, one of the largest local suburban developers has turned to the downtown area for a $70 million mixed-use project that includes the renovation of 17 former brewery buildings, the oldest dating to 1858.

LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S public financing law for gubernatorial elections, the first in the nation, is in danger of being undermined by the rising cost of campaigning and is badly in need of an overhaul, several people who monitor the elections and distribute the money said.
LEAD: Stephen Huneck is a wood-carving artist who could be called an afternoon success. The afternoon was in May 1984, when he quite unwillingly sold his first sculpture.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There are those who say that the intellectual guides, the figures of learning and probity who enlightened the public during such times as elections campaigns, are gone, replaced by flashy media pundits better able to make a fetching image on camera than to reflect on the wisdom of the ages. Bill Moyers, a rare television pundit of a less flashy, more probing stripe, agrees that modern times have been hard on what the British used to call pop dons.

LEAD: IN the first years of his Presidency, Ronald Reagan's so-called social agenda - including a Federal ban on abortions, the legalization of organized school prayer and an end to court-ordered busing - was pushed by conservatives on Capitol Hill at every opportunity. But no longer.
LEAD: THE Second Company of the Governor's Horse Guard, which dates from he 19th century, is moving to permanent quarters in Fairfield County, after having been in rented stables for 25 years.
LEAD: Men and women can compete on an equal basis for all the equestrian medals: team and individual jumping, team and individual dressage and team and individual three-day events.

LEAD: I enjoyed John Stone's article ''The Frozen Room'' (Body and Mind: Aug. 7), but I strongly disagree with his statement that autopsies are less needed now that ''more accurate premortem diagnosis is possible.'' The data don't bear that out. It is only through the autopsy that we test the accuracy of our premortem diagnosis, see the additional diagnoses that we didn't think of, and maintain our humility.

LEAD: In the United States, field hockey is primarily a women's sport, but is played by both sexes in the rest of the world, especially in the former countries of the British Empire. An Olympic sport for men since 1908, field hockey became one for women in 1980, when the United States boycotted the Games.

LEAD: I expect to see hype, promotion, show business and flackery, and hope that I will dismiss it in the search for the talented, the practiced, the determined and the skilled.
LEAD: JEALOUSY has an underserved reputation, according to Peter Salovey, a Yale University psychology professor and researcher who has been studying the emotion for five years.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis fired back again at Vice President Bush on the patriotism issue today, citing reports that some top Bush campaign advisers had worked for the Bahamian Government and declaring, ''In a Dukakis White House, the staff will pledge allegiance to only one flag - Old Glory.''
LEAD: THE CARETAKERS By Bernard Mathias. Translated by Freeman G. Henry. 221 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: Nobody thought avant-garde music could pay a club's rent until the Knitting Factory came along. A few months after it opened, it had become a center for improvisational music, at the nexus of risky, format-defying new jazz, new rock and the postmodern assemblages of downtown composers - the tumultuous piano solos of Cecil Taylor, the quick-change artistry of John Zorn, the geometrically proportioned slabs of noise composed by Elliott Sharp, the dreamlike performance-rock of Hugo Largo or the skewed, clattery funk of Curlew.

LEAD: What worked on Friday for his teammate Richard Dent didn't work yesterday for Calvin Thomas. The Chicago Bears' fullback lost a bid that would have allowed him to play in today's game against the Indianapolis Colts pending a hearing on his appeal of a 30-day suspension by the National Football League for violating the league's drug policy.

LEAD: AFTER HALF A DOZEN YEARS IN WHICH THE classical record business took on new life as a result of the boom in compact disks, the competition both in classical sales and in pressing CD's has become fierce.

LEAD: Gusto House is a feisty and atmospheric little club in the great ''Hey, kids, let's put on a show'' tradition of the Lower East Side. It is housed in a loft that serves as home to Andy Kollmorgen, Daniel Cohen and Bill Callihan, writers and performers who founded the Gusto. The first floor is cut away -originally to accommodate the printing presses of The Guardian, a radical newspaper - to reveal a stage below.

LEAD: Thousands of people jammed a broad avenue today for the first large rally organized by leftist groups since the bloody military coup 15 years ago.

LEAD: For popular music, this season brings a paradox. Six giant conglomerates have their strongest hold ever on the $5 billion record business, yet those companies are searching frantically outside their own confines for music that draws loyal listeners. They're still grinding out intensively marketed Top 40 fodder, such as forthcoming albums by Tiffany, Bon Jovi, Duran Duran and Patti LaBelle.

LEAD: A Soviet and an Afghan astronaut were stranded in space last week when a malfunctioning navigation system interfered with the split-second calculations required for a successful landing. On the third attempt, the Soyuz TM-5 capsule touched down safely in the Soviet Republic of Kazakhstan, leaving Soviet and American scientists to reconstruct the sequence of errors that led to a harrowing 25 hours.

LEAD: Ben Yagoda's article ''Tense Talk'' (On Language, Aug. 14) notes the tendency among many professionals to take solace in the fact that what they do is not brain surgery. But when the going gets tough in my job, what do I say? ABBOT J. KRIEGER, M.D. Chief of Neurosurgery New Jersey Medical School

LEAD: Some of the tiniest competitors have made gymnastics one of the biggest sports of the Olympics. Olga Korbut of the Soviet Union in 1972, Nadia Comaneci of Rumnania in 1976 and Mary Lou Retton of the United States in 1984, twisted, turned and bounced their way into Olympic memories and record books.
LEAD: This fall was to have been the time when Marilyn Quayle finally went back to work.

LEAD: IN 1978, when Iris Moore first decided to take in a foster child, she said, she was lonely. She was divorced, and her former husband, a Black Panther Party leader, Richard Moore, was serving 20 years for the attempted murder of two policemen. Her brother, with whom she had put a down payment on a house, had been killed in a car accident.
LEAD: Howard University doesn't even have to match its 9-1 won-lost record of last year for Coach Willie Jeffries to join the ranks of college football coaches with 100 victories this season.

LEAD: Q. We have a ceramic tile floor in our bathroom consisting of one-inch square tiles. The floor is even and in good condition, but it is not attractive, and so we would like to put down new ceramic tile. Can we put new tile on top of the existing tile, or must we rip up all the old tile first?

LEAD: The era of synchronized swimming as a frilly exhibition event has ended. Most competitors now spend at least six hours in the pool six days a week. They no longer wear real flowers in their hair; they slick it back with gel to allow for easy head movement. They run and ride bicycles to build lung capacity, since half of the competition is performed completely underwater without any contact with the bottom of the pool.

LEAD: Some 200 years ago, a party of 24 men and nearly a dozen families settled on the banks of the Ohio River in a place called Losantiville. Two years later, in what is now testimony to the ease with which whims could be satisfied on the frontier, Gen. Arthur St. Clair, Governor of the Northwest Territory, decided he didn't like the name.
LEAD: In a victory for anti-Government protesters, the Burmese leadership said today that it would end 26 years of one-party rule and hold multiparty general elections.
LEAD: Bobby Humphrey, the senior tailback, ran for 91 yards and a touchdown as Alabama opened its season with a 37-0 rout of Temple tonight.

LEAD: Invention has traditionally been the operative word at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the world's most important furniture fair, which is held in Milan each September. It is here that the latest designs from all over the world are previewed. And it is at these fairgrounds and at showrooms in the center of Milan that store buyers and design experts look for the latest trends the market has to offer.

LEAD: Your article of Aug. 21 on Heritage Hills [ ''The View From: Heritage Hills'' ] gave an unbalanced description of life in this semiretirement complex. As more and more young people purchase homes here this is a mixture of working and nonworking residents. Certainly there are many here who think they have died and gone to heaven because of the availability of free tennis and swimming and other carefree activities but there are also many who, as volunteers, are giving much time and effort in hospitals, libraries, to people who are homebound, to literacy programs and other selfless activities.

LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of Iran and Iraq met today for their first face-to-face peace talks in more than two weeks.

LEAD: AT no time in New York City's history were grander apartments built than in the late 1920s, and, by near universal agreement, no architect designed them better than Rosario Candela, the immigrant son of a Sicilian plasterer whose elevated concepts of layout, amenities, spaciousness and luxury set a new standard for the way rich people should live in multiple dwellings.

LEAD: AS the anniversary of Black Monday approaches, investors are reviewing their stock portfolios, assessing the past year's performance and charting a course for the future. But given the uncertain economic outlook and the looming Presidential election, many people want to minimize risk without abandoning the market.
LEAD: IN the past month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has committed billions of dollars in its campaign of closing down, merging or rescuing bankrupt savings and loan associations.

LEAD: THE advertisements are for Chanel and Chevrolet as well as hearing aids and ''a face lift without surgery, at last!'' Articles chronicle a leisure cruise to the Antarctic and include an interview with Shere Hite, who writes about human relationships.

LEAD: Reading Ben Yagoda's article brought back memories of my medical internship, when I was astounded to discover that even brain surgery is not that difficult. Neurosurgery is more like real estate. There are only three important things to remember in the human brain: location, location, location. Once the skull is open, the tumor is resectable or not; the hematoma can be evacuated or not.

LEAD: BUILDERS across the country contend that the scarcity and high cost of land approved by local governments for new residential construction is the chief obstacle to producing the elusive new single-family house affordable to the younger American household.

LEAD: Separated from their birthplace by 4,969 miles, six time zones and a culture gap that can seem as broad as the Pacific Ocean, former Brooklynites who have settled here might be excused if they occasionally long for the shores of Coney Island.

LEAD: At the start of a five-nation tour of Africa, Pope John Paul II today offered his approval of the strict economic sanctions against South Africa now under consideration by the United States Congress. He said such measures are morally acceptable as a last resort in the struggle against apartheid.

LEAD: THERE is something unobtrusive about interrupting a natural-looking series of moves by inserting a move that suddenly introduces a new and powerful tactical idea. It may be that such interpolations escape attention just because they are so different from the original idea.

LEAD: The Personal Finance column on Aug. 21 about tax planning misstated the cutoff point for the exemption to the Alternative Minimum Tax. For a married couple filing a joint return, the exemption is reduced at the rate of 25 cents for each $1 of alternative minimum taxable income above $150,000 ($112,500 for single taxpayers).

LEAD: SOMETIMES you can't win. That's to be expected, but the no-win situations seem to come with increasing frequency. No matter how agreeable you are, no matter how winning or open your smile, no matter how pleasant and sincere your ''Good morning,'' you are met with a stone wall. Well, not really a stone wall, but a stone face.

LEAD: ELYSIAN FIELDS. By Sally Savic. (Scribner's, $14.95.) Alice Bettonville, the narrator of this first novel by Sally Savic, is an Ohioan working for a New Orleans newspaper and living in a house she has inherited from her step-grandmother, a family outsider with whom Alice identifies. It seems that the naive Alice has fallen in with some unsavory characters.

LEAD: The story entitled ''At the Grocery, I Was the One Checked Out'' (Opinion page, Aug. 14) sounds apocryphal to me. Getting locked up in an office by a giant who spied a card in a pocket? Being looked upon by another shopper as a possible drug dealer? Sure, hyperbole in a humorous piece is a good tool, but it just doesn't wash here.

Jeremy Irons, who will play twin psychotic, drug-addicted gynecologists in ''David Cronenberg's Dead Ringers,'' may have the role (or roles) that best captures the spirit of the season.

LEAD: Samuel S. Beard defeated Delaware's Lieutenant Governor tonight in a Democratic primary election for the right to challenge the Republican incumbent, Senator William V. Roth Jr. Mr. Beard won 53 percent of the vote to Lieutenant Governor S.B. Woo's 47 percent. Mr. Beard runs a nonprofit company that helps attract grants and designs plans to attract economic development.

LEAD: HUNDREDS of co-ops and condos in New York City are expected to apply for tax abatements as a result of fundamental changes in the city's J-51 program that were signed into law by Mayor Koch last June.

LEAD: ON THE eve of the 1989 model year, we find ourselves handcuffed by the Corporate Average Fuel Economy program - the CAFE rules. This 1970's law was intended to deal with anticpated oil shortages, but now it threatens American jobs, diminishes consumer welfare and gives foreign auto makers an edge in the marketplace.

LEAD: Fortune Garden Pavilion, tucked away on 49th Street, is an anomaly of a jazz club. First, it serves Chinese food. Second, it serves good Chinese food. And third, with its glass-enclosed, airy, second-floor dining room, elegant and restrained, it's as far removed from the cliched, smoke-filled jazz dive as possible.

LEAD: Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the French nobleman who founded the modern Olympics in 1896, designed the modern pentathlon to give soldiers something better to do than wage war. It didn't work. The sport made its debut at the Stockholm Olympics in 1912, two years before the outbreak of World War I. The competition features five events in five days.

LEAD: MADAME'S dog has come down the dusty road and over a bed of dahlias to our Loir valley farmhouse for an early morning visit. He crushes underfoot the last of the plums that have fallen from the tree at the corner of the low stone building, and sniffs like a connoisseur at the ruby grapes hanging from vines growing characteristically around our doorways.
LEAD: POWERBOAT SHOPPING Some 400 exhibitors will display more than 700 boats at the Norwalk International In-Water Powerboat Show, Thursday to next Sunday at Cove Marina in East Norwalk.

LEAD: EVEN though the orange glow of pumpkins is beginning to dot the fields around some farmstands, and baskets of crisp apples are already on sale, it's too early to discard summer's tastes. The corn, peppers, tomatoes, peaches, eggplants and plums are still abundant.
LEAD: Steve Gutman will not be wearing short pants today, not in the visitors' v.i.p. box at Cleveland Stadium, where the Jets face the Browns.
LEAD: FOR more than a decade, the 20-story Blue Hill office tower loomed nearly empty over the wooded hills of southern Rockland County, a symbol of a commercial development whose time had not come.

LEAD: WHAT'S the most economical way to pay your expenses on an overseas trip? The answer is parallel to the old saw about success in the stock market: Buy low, sell high. That is to say, when considering whether to convert dollars or traveler's checks into the local currency to buy things, or to use a credit card and pay later, your goal should be to pay at the moment when the dollar is worth the most in terms of the currency involved.

LEAD: After three days of stormy debate, the Mexican Electoral College formally certified Carlos Salinas de Gortari as the country's President-elect today, bringing to an official end the electoral drama that has gripped Mexico for more than two months.
LEAD: TO a dyed-in-the-wool Mets fan, the equivalent of Manna from Heaven is four field-level box seats for a game at Shea Stadium. The source? A friend of a friend.

LEAD: When Harvey Lichtenstein opened the refurbished Majestic Theater last fall, two blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was perceived as a New York home for Peter Brook and other innovative theater directors. But now it is emerging as a concert hall and opera house as well. Pierre Boulez's appearances there in June with the Ensemble Intercontemporain proved the excellence of its acoustics, and now a number of other musical and operatic events are being negotiated, not the least of which are the Metropolitan Opera's Brooklyn experimental seasons, starting in 1991.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, who calls Texas home, continues to be hounded as a carpetbagger. Polls suggest that more than half the registered voters in Texas don't think he is a ''real Texan.'' LEAD: For more than a decade now this city in which architecture is a subject of everyday conversation has been in a kind of identity crisis. Chicago has always prided itself on being America's great city of modern architecture - the city in which the average person knew who Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright and Mies van der Rohe were and the average real-estate developer was expected as a matter of course to put up first-class modern buildings.

LEAD: DONALD BYRNE, a state fisheries biologist, stood with anticipation as the crew engaged the clanking winches on the stern of this 81-foot commercial trawler. A few more minutes and the huge net, which the vessel had dragged off Sandy Hook, would be brought aboard.

LEAD: HAVING no place to call home, the Stone Sculpture Society of New York makes itself known by its exhibitions, one of which is now at Blue Hill Plaza here. LEAD: WINNING MONEY, fame and status in Hollywood is never easy. The quickest overnight success usually takes years. But there are always a few actors, directors, producers - and even a few movie executives - who insist on making it harder. They handicap themselves by making unconventional choices. Those who depart from whatever formulas are in fashion may end up with terrible mistakes, but their movies won't be boring.

LEAD: OWNERS of certain closely held corporations may achieve significant tax savings if they liquidate and distribute their companies' assets to shareholders or make other basic changes in their companies' structure before the end of the year. LEAD: The Romantic movement was in decline a century ago, but its weight still sits uncomfortably on us all. Most of all, however, they resent their inability to find overshadowing alternatives.

LEAD: Edwin Meese, who resigned as Attorney General in a hail of criticism over his ethics, blamed his troubles on political partisans, disloyal and ambitious underlings and an overzealous special prosecutor who said he probably committed crimes. He took comfort from President Reagan's constant support.

LEAD: Jim Gilrain resigned yesterday as the football coach at St. Peter's College just three days before the Peacocks' opener against Iona. Gilrain did not give a reason for quitting, said Jim Hague, sports-information director at the school. Three assistant coaches -Joe Dolinski, Bob Thomas and Ben Scholz - will run the team in the interim, Hague said, adding that a new coach will be appointed shortly.

LEAD: The deafening silence of governments on Iraq's use of chemical weapons has provoked serious concern among defense experts. A major thesis that emerged from the annual conference of the International Institute for Strategic Studies here last weekend was that wars in the third world are not likely to diminish if the East-West conflict wanes, but increase in scope and intensity as sophisticated weaponry spreads.

LEAD: The great walls of fire in Western forests, and the blackened expanses in their wake, are a devastating sight. Some four million acres of the West have been ravaged, including 40 percent of Yellowstone National Park.

LEAD: More than three million children are starting kindergarten this month, and for many it will be the first opportunity to fail. Depending on their district, it is estimated that 10 to 60 percent of those 5-year-olds will not be allowed to enter first grade a year from now. They will remain in kindergarten for a second year.

LEAD: Why is Dan Quayle refusing to let the public know what he did at college and law school? Why won't he allow those schools to state the facts? Why does he fear the truth?

LEAD: The Republican platform says that Reagan-Bush economic policies have created an ''economic wonder,'' an expansion of unprecedented length and strength. True, the aggregate statistics used to measure economic performance indicate that we have recovered from the deep recession caused by the Reagan Administration's ''cold turkey'' remedy for inflation.

LEAD: New devices that automatically detect and interpret abnormal heartbeat and deliver electrical jolts to restore the normal rhythm could save many of the 400,000 Americans who die each year of cardiac arrest, according to a new report.

LEAD: The House of Representatives today unanimously voted for much stiffer penalties for insider trading. The measure, approved 410 to 0, would affect people and brokerages whose employees violate the law.

LEAD: John S. Walton, president and chief executive of Placer Dome Inc., one of the world's major gold-mining companies, has resigned in a difference with the board over the future course of the company.

LEAD: Lawrence D. Ornitz, who developed a worldwide market for California beachwear fashions, died Monday of complications following coronary bypass surgery at Western Medical Center in Santa Ana, Calif. He was 53 years old and a resident of nearby Tustin.
LEAD: One day later this month, in the gloomy hours before dawn, a group of investigators will assemble near the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan to carry out a mission against the underworld.

LEAD: The strongest hurricane to hit the Western Hemisphere in this century slammed into the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico today with 23-foot waves and wind gusts of up to 218 miles an hour, devastating coastal cities and resorts and forcing the evacuation of tens of thousands of people.

LEAD: Jean-Noel Jeanneney sits in a disheveled office with stacks of books piled up on the floor next to unhung framed prints depicting tumultuous scenes from the French Revolution. Although they have had 200 years to prepare, the French are dreadfully behind in organizing the bicentennial of their epic revolutionary upheaval.

LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday on the strength of a larger-than-expected decline in the United States trade deficit. But several traders said they did not think the spurt, following a general decline since the end of August, signaled a new rally.

LEAD: Douglas Robert Owens, 35 years old, pleaded guilty Tuesday to drunken driving and vehicular manslaughter in the traffic accident on July 30 that killed the actor Trinidad Silva Jr. Mr. Owens was held in lieu of $25,000 bail for sentencing Oct. 4. Mr. Silva's wife, Sofia, 28, and 2-year-old son were injured in the accident, but not seriously.

LEAD: In Coral Gables, Fla., the topic of conversation is known as the P-word. The Miami Hurricanes would prefer not to discuss the news-agency polls, which, depending on one's view, rewarded or targeted them after their shockingly easy 31-0 defeat of Florida State.

LEAD: SAKS Fifth Avenue waved the flag for American fashion Tuesday night. LEAD: Fred Lynn, the man whose mad dash in a chartered plane got him to Chicago 10 minutes too late, will be eligible to play postseason games if the Detroit Tigers go that far, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth ruled today.

LEAD: Another alarm: cancer-causing radon gas in the home. It's a serious and widespread hazard, but one that individuals can protect themselves against. Homeowners can quite cheaply prevent the gas seeping into their basements. And smokers, who are at extra risk, have another reason to stop smoking.

LEAD: As mass demonstrations and attempts at political consolidation by the Burmese opposition reportedly continued today, a struggle was under way for the allegiance of the armed forces, the nation's most powerful institution.

LEAD: The first wave of an outpouring of advertising that J. Walter Thompson has created for its new client, Bell Atlantic, will be seen on television in the company's seven-state region tomorrow during the Olympic telecast. It will mark a radical change for the company.

LEAD: Tai Babilonia, the former Olympic skater, was hospitalized yesterday morning after taking an overdose of pills, authorities said. Paramedics took Babilonia to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where she was treated and released in good condition, said a hospital spokeswoman, Paula Correia.

LEAD: Today is primary election day in New York State. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties and from noon to 9 P.M. in the rest of the state.

LEAD: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had intercepted Iraqi military communications indicating that Iraq had used poison gas against Kurdish guerrillas.

LEAD: Court filings this week by defendants in the Drexel Burnham Lambert securities fraud case strongly suggest that their defense will be based on an assault on the credibility of the Government's main witness, Ivan F. Boesky.
LEAD: Palestinians stabbed to death an Arab man suspected of collaborating with the Israelis and dumped his pajama-clad body on a West Bank street today, the police and Arab reports said.

LEAD: Medical experts say that the small number of athletes they expect will test positive for performance-enhancing drugs during the Seoul Games does not reflect the true number of athletes involved with the drugs.
LEAD: Nowhere are the recent changes that have swept San Francisco more apparent than along Folsom Street in this city's gritty warehouse district south of Market Street.

LEAD: The Pennsylvania National Guard is sending a letter to the state's soldiers and airmen reminding them of regulations prohibiting their participation in partisan political activities, officials said today.

LEAD: Rejecting Vice President Bush's recent assertion that he is an environmentalist, the political arm of the nation's major conservation groups will endorse the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

LEAD: Judith Farris, a contralto who has been singing opera around the country and who has appeared locally as a soloist with Musica Sacra, made her debut as a recitalist on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, with a program that for the most part was well tailored to her abilities.
LEAD: A Federal judge agreed yesterday to consider changes in his housing desegregation plan for the city of Yonkers, but he set a final deadline of Sept. 30 for any revisions.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Elections yesterday rebuffed Mayor Koch and rejected an unusual agreement he had made with Governor Cuomo and the Rev. Jesse Jackson to influence the selection of an executive director.

LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett and Professor Allan Bloom, two of the most outspoken critics of American higher education, plan to start a foundation to promote study of classic Western thought.

LEAD: The partnership that acquired the Pneumo-Abex Corporation for $1.3 billion last month said it planned to sell the company's Jetway Systems division. LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has entered final negotiations with New York City over the possibility of moving 4,000 jobs from Manhattan to Brooklyn amid speculation that it is considering sites elsewhere and leaning toward the New Jersey waterfront.
LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, seeking to squeeze some good news out of the state's shaky budget situation, said today that Massachusetts had ended its 1988 budget year in better shape than expected.

LEAD: Pierre Larouche, the only player in the National Hockey League to have a 50-goal season with two different teams, has retired. Larouche suffered a back injury in the first month of last season and never recovered, missing the rest of the season.

LEAD: JUST eight weeks ago the cat found a dark place and gave birth to her first litter: three pathetic miniatures of herself, their eyes sealed shut, their voices weak falsettos. For two weeks the new mother was manic, moving them from place to place because of imagined dangers. For two weeks more she was solicitous, slipping out for a meal and returning immediately to the writhing pile of fur and blunt faces, grooming them even when they were clean.

The opening volleys of a new music season were fired last evening at Avery Fisher Hall by the New York Philharmonic under the command of Zubin Mehta, to the easily audible delight of a black-tie benefit audience. The orchestra, fresh from what the publicity department inevitably and possibly justly described as ''a triumphal Grand Tour of Europe,'' seemed in a mood to extend that triumph by at least one more night.

LEAD: Three years after the management of the New York City Transit Authority's $2 billion subway-car overhaul program was found in a shambles, the authority has tightened controls and raised performance in the rebuilt fleet, according to a report released yesterday.

LEAD: Joan Benoit Samuelson, who flew down from her ''saltwater farm'' on the Maine coast to announce that she will attempt to make her racing comeback in the New York Marathon on Nov. 6, flew right back there yesterday as soon as an obligatory luncheon appearance ended.

LEAD: Space agency officials yesterday delayed making a decision on when to schedule the first space shuttle launching since the Challenger disaster because the hurricane threat in Houston was interferring with the work of key engineers on the project.

LEAD: Elizabeth Mead Steig, Margaret Mead's sister, was once quoted as saying: ''You can tell your sister to go to hell in 10 different langauges, but if you need a dime she'll give you one.''

LEAD: The mood in the cramped, steamy little clubhouse was one of complete relief. At last, the Yankees could turn their attention to the Red Sox. And most satisfying of all, they could do so without having to look back in anger.

LEAD: Edward L. Gaylord, an Oklahoma publisher, said yesterday that he had decided to exercise his option to purchase Eddie Chiles's 58 percent interest in the Texas Rangers. Gaylord's Dallas-based Gaylord Broadcasting Company owns about one-third of the club. Gaylord indicated that a major factor in his decision was to insure that the Rangers would remain in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Jackie Gleason developed his comedy talents on the old Dumont network's ''Cavalcade of Stars.'' Then, wooed with multimillion-dollar contracts, he moved to CBS, where he presided over 10 different shows in 23 years. Mr. Gleason was good for CBS, and the network is acknowledging that fact with an ingratiating two-hour special tomorrow at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds decreased by $347.4 million, to $266.58 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds fell $166.4 million, to $68.56 billion, while the 223 general purpose funds fell $53.5 million, to $84.92 billion, and the 103 broker-dealer funds fell $127.5 billion, to $113.1 billion.

LEAD: James M. Cannon, who in early 1987 was an adviser to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that he had seen a ''serious document'' on which President Reagan's initials had been signed by someone else.

LEAD: THE Federal budget deficit remains the great submerged issue in the 1988 Presidential campaign. Vice President Bush cannot hit the issue hard without acknowledging the Reagan Administration's role in swelling the deficit to $2.5 trillion from $1 trillion eight years ago. The one Bush phrase that will not die is his 1980 attack on Mr.

LEAD: Retail sales dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Many economists said the small decline should not arouse any serious concerns about the economy's health.
LEAD: Lieut. Gov. S. B. Woo won a 71-vote victory today in a recount in Delaware's Democratic senatorial primary race, five days after a clerical error left his opponent claiming victory.
LEAD: The Senate again approved a bill to limit textile imports, voting 59 to 36 today in a procedural step. It approved the same wording last week, 57 to 32.

LEAD: Boris Becker will not attend the Olympic Games in South Korea after all, chiefly because some other West German athletes criticized his plans to visit Seoul as a nonparticipant. Becker withdrew as a tennis player earlier on the advice of his doctor, who is treating the two-time Wimbledon champion for foot problems.
LEAD: Dave Parker drove in three runs with two singles as the Oakland Athletics beat the Texas Rangers, 6-2, today and moved another step closer to the American League West title.

LEAD: For years the National Rifle Association enjoyed friendly relations with police, but now the cops are estranged - for reasons that became clearer than ever yesterday. The big gun lobby appears bent on giving aid and comfort to criminals.

LEAD: Pentagon officials today confirmed that the price of the secret Stealth bomber had grown 16 percent from previous estimates, but they said the program was now being managed in a way to control the aircraft's costs.

LEAD: The family and friends of Dolores Huerta, the co-founder of the United Farm Workers, expressed outrage today over what they said was her severe beating by the police. She suffered broken ribs and the loss of her spleen.
LEAD: Iraq will not agree to lower its oil output, the country's oil minister said in an interview published today. The minister, Issam Abdul-

Admission: children, $2; adults, $3.75. Information: 769-5900.

LEAD: A year after a Navy F-14 Tomcat shot down an Air Force reconnaissance jet, the Navy has released an investigative report that attributes the accident to a ''basic error in judgment'' and ''an illogical act'' by the young fighter pilot.

LEAD: Cases of salmonella food poisoning that are attributed to eating raw or undercooked eggs are appearing in parts of the country other than the Northeast, where they were previously reported, Federal health officials said today.
LEAD: The House Veterans Affairs Committee today approved a bill that would give veterans a limited opportunity to appeal to the Federal courts over denials of benefits.

LEAD: An internal review of the Red Cross blood service regions indicates that more than 2,400 blood products were improperly released over a six-month period, 518 of them without complete testing for deadly diseases.

LEAD: A two-day strike over wages by 1,165 unionized workers at the Bergen Pines County Hospital in Paramus, N.J., the largest public hospital in the state, ended last night when both sides agreed to a tentative new contract, officials said.

LEAD: After being hospitalized for a week, Arthur Ashe was released from New York Hospital yesterday. The former tennis champion underwent tests last week for a condition his agent described as a severe bacterial infection in his head. The infection put pressure on nerves, causing numbness in Ashe's arm, according to Ted Ewanciw, a spokesman for ProServ, Ashe's agent.

LEAD: The Raiders were stretching before practice today, a line of silver and black, bending knees and backs and chanting cadences between grunts. Three players, all quarterbacks, stood near the front in bright red jerseys. Steve Beuerlein was on the left. Vince Evans was on the right. Jay Schroeder was in the middle.

LEAD: About 10,000 worshipers, a tiny crowd by papal standards, gathered around a big altar in this small mountain kingdom today for the religious highpoint of Pope John Paul II's trip through southern Africa, At the solemn Mass, John Paul beatified the Rev. Joseph Gerard, a French missionary who spent 60 years among the Zulu and Basotho people before he died in 1914.
LEAD: A week ago Monday, on the first day of school, Carole Tomlinson talked to her children on the island of Jamaica.

LEAD: Horace Henderson, a pianist, arranger and composer who often collaborated with his brother, Fletcher, died after a short illness on Aug. 29, at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Denver. He was 83 years old and lived in Denver.

LEAD: Dr. George H. A. Clowes Jr., a surgeon and researcher who studied activity in human cells that causes tissues to waste away, died of a cerebral hemmorrhage Saturday at his summer home in Woods Hole, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Dover, Mass.

LEAD: A state appeals court has suspended Mario Biaggi, the former Bronx Congressman, from practicing law in New York State and begun a process that could lead to disbarment. He has been convicted twice on Federal Corruption charges in the last year.

LEAD: Dance Theater Workshop presented its fifth annual New York Dance and Performance Awards -known as the Bessies - last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, honoring achievements in choreography, performance, design and music for the 1987-88 season.

LEAD: In May 1986, Carnegie Hall closed its doors for a renovation that took 30 weeks and cost $50 million. LEAD: It's past time that the media quit using the jeering word ''WASP'' in their pages. This ethnic epithet is often employed in print (and conversation) with a prejudice that is intended to sting. It's a cudgel, though some people do express with it only a sort of playful irony or sloppy abbreviation without sneering intent, as has been the case with similar sobriquets such as ''Mick,'' ''Wop,'' ''Spick,'' ''Kike'' ''Bohunk,'' etc.

''Mama Turns 100'' was shown as part of the 1980 New Spanish Cinema Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Jan. 11, 1980. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place. The big, airy old country house is not especially handsome but it occupies an imposing site atop a high hill and is clearly in charge of all that it surveys. In the distance, one sees the blue silhouette of a modern city that, as yet, has not imposed its needs on the people living here. The family inside the house is not aristocratic but representative of the rich, upper bourgeoisie whose manners and morals have for decades dominated the life of Spain. Time, as it always is in such fiction, is running out.

LEAD: Business inventories in July rose at the slowest rate in 11 months, suggesting to analysts that underlying economic growth remains strong despite a pause in business sales.

LEAD: Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, running a clear second in his campaign for the United States Senate, took the offensive today in his first debate with Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., characterizing the three-term incumbent as a political misfit masquerading as a maverick.

LEAD: Firefighters battling wildfires contended with higher winds today while awaiting an approaching Canadian cold front that was expected to bring showers and cooler temperatures to burning woodlands this weekend.

LEAD: Jay Edwards, voted the basketball player of the year in the Big Ten Conference last season, denied that he was a drug addict, said he never enrolled in a chemical dependency treatment program and that he had not left Indiana University. But all of that is contrary to what his coach said recently.
LEAD: The annual Steuben Day parade will begin at noon at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Second Avenue, where it will disband.

LEAD: Starting on Monday, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, will be increased to 35 cents. The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper. The newspaper's Sunday price will not change, nor will its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

LEAD: A man whom Federal officials say ran the biggest cable television piracy ring in the nation and defrauded cable companies of almost $5 million in potential fees pleaded guilty today to mail fraud and income tax evasion.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Former Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. today called for the mandatory registration of consultants involved in military procurement, but he said the Navy's procurement policies were not to blame for possible fraud in contracting.

LEAD: Carlos Santana's show at Pier 84 on Wednesday night was filled with sounds and ideas that wafted in from the past. Mr. Santana's guitar tone, tightly distorted, soared above the juicy sounds of Gregg Rolie's organ; combined, they make up a classic sound of the 1960's. And Mr. Santana's eclecticism, mixing rock, latin and jazz - and the mainstream popularity to go with it - unfortunately also seemed like something from an earlier, more optimistic age.
LEAD: A doctor who treated Michael K. Deaver for alcoholism in 1985 said that the former aide to President Reagan ''remained quite alert'' in the hospital despite heavy sedation.

LEAD: The records set in the Seoul Olympics for the number of athletes participating and for the number of events held are likely to be broken four years from now in Barcelona, Spain, officials of the International Olympic Committee said today. But after that the numbers could be cut back.

Treiki, chief representative to the United Nations from Libya - forever complaining, explaining and dogmatically disdaining everything from the latest accusation of terrorism to American attacks, verbal and otherwise. Moreover, it is 5,000 miles from his dusty home.

LEAD: Gertrude Golden, a publicity agent for many postwar feature films imported from Italy and France, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75 years old and also lived in East Hampton, L.I.
LEAD: When the gates for American Airlines flight 2645 to New York opened this afternoon, a cheer went up and scores of sweaty, weary Americans dashed for the jet.

LEAD: The Burmese ruling party, which has controlled most aspects of public life for a quarter of a century, announced today that those serving in the armed forces, civil servants and government employees would no longer be party members.

LEAD: A group of House Republicans charged today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential nominee, had appointed three ''anti-Israeli, pro-Palestinian'' members to the party's ruling body and challenged him to dismiss them.

LEAD: Dr. Ralph D. Lach, a cardiologist in Columbus, Ohio, has invented a mechanical device that provides cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, to victims of heart attacks. According to the patent, the device is safer and more effective than conventional CPR, in which a hand is pressed against the victim's chest every few seconds to pump blood through the body.
LEAD: Endorsing a check? A new Federal law says you have just 1 1/2 inches in which to do it.

LEAD: Mail service to Britain is being restored today, the United States Postal Service announced. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said he had been advised by the British Post Office that the strike there had ended and that the agency was again accepting mail. LEAD: An advisory committee of the National Institutes of Health concluded today that it is morally acceptable to use human fetal tissue obtained from legal abortions for research and therapy.

LEAD: The House of Representatives passed three amendments to a major drug bill today, including one that budgets $125 million for grants to states that suspend the drivers' licenses of people arrested on charges of drunken driving after a breath or blood test. The money would be used for programs to curb drunken driving.

Sitting East and West were Jim and Norma Borin of Melbourne who have long been one of the world's best mixed partnerships.
LEAD: A memorial honoring the 5.7 million Americans who served in the Korean War will be placed on the Mall in Washington, near the Lincoln Memorial and opposite the Vietnam Memorial.

LEAD: A Soviet newspaper accused the Polish leadership today of mismanaging the economy and said the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski might be forced to resign.

LEAD: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press to delay their partial merger, which could have begun as early as this weekend, as the judges consider whether the deal should be scrapped altogether.

LEAD: An article on Sept. 9 about a strike by clerical employees of New York University described the strikers' salary figures incompletely. The figure given by the union is $17,400, but the university says the average salary is $19,763.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis today outlined a battle plan for his war on drugs, saying that as President he would double the number of Federal drug enforcement agents, add 800 Federal prosecutors and send a message to drug kingpins that ''as far as Mike Dukakis is concerned, there's nowhere you can run.''
LEAD: The New York City Police Department reported yesterday that murder and manslaughter rose to a near-record level in the first six months of the year.

LEAD: In dark hotel bars along China's coast, young women in tight dresses and carefully coiffed hair wiggle their ankles as they linger for hours over a single Coke. Nearby, young men in ostentatious jewelry look for clients to whom they can offer the women's services.

LEAD: The hurricane that jolted the Mexican coast today for the second time in three days has left a trail of devastation in the Yucatan Peninsula, including the deaths of at least 17 people, the official Government news agency reported.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company could temporarily match the special discounts on long-distance rates that its smaller rivals offer to large business customers.
LEAD: A review of the artist Clemens Weiss in Weekend yesterday mistated his birthplace. It was Germany, not Austria.
LEAD: The White House said today that the Soviet Union must tear down the Krasnoyarsk radar and that turning it into an international center on space research would not be good enough.

LEAD: The retrospective of the work of the Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti, which opened Thursday at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, is the first to be held in this country in nearly 15 years. The exhibition surveys Giacometti's 40-year career with 51 sculptures, 30 paintings and 24 drawings.

LEAD: Golf Britain-Ireland Grabs Lead: Britain-Ireland, six strokes behind Sweden overnight, moved into a three-shot lead over the United States yesterday at the midway point of the men's world amateur team championship in Stockholm. Peter McEvoy shot one-under-par 71 to lead his team. He had a 72 Thursday and held second in the individual standing.
LEAD: IN recent years, plastic surgeons have developed increasingly lifelike artificial hands, covered with a skin-like material, that can hold and manipulate objects much like real hands.

LEAD: Dr. Chin Tang Huang, professor of medicine and chief of the division of pulmonary diseases at the Lincoln Hospital Center, died of gastric cancer Thursday at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sands Point, L.I.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said tonight that the United States would oppose any ''declaration of independent Palestinian statehood or government in exile'' that might be established for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

LEAD: If ''Messenger of Death,'' the Charles Bronson movie that opened yesterday in neighborhood theaters, were a novel, it could be called a decent page turner, one that holds the eye and makes one wonder whodunit.

LEAD: Mayor Koch issued a sharply worded warning yesterday to 3,000 city inspectors, vowing to prosecute corrupt employees. But some members of the audience responded with more jeers than applause.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that the United States was reducing its diplomatic presence in Panama because of concern for personnel stationed there. He said the move was ''probably temporary'' but officials of the State Department disagreed.

LEAD: China has announced that it will no longer lend giant pandas to zoos in the United States.

LEAD: New York's Democratic politicians yesterday looked beyond their party's primary returns to their impact on next year's mayoral election, power shifts in the Bronx and even a rivalry between the city's most prominent prosecutors, who are not normally involved in political maneuvering.

LEAD: As part of an effort to stimulate lagging personal computer sales, the International Business Machines Corporation will reportedly put the head of its Asian operation in charge of its Personal Systems Group.

LEAD: The news that Yale University has received $1 million from an alumnus to endow the position of football coach invites irreverent speculation. What's next, a tenured tuba player? A lifetime annuity for Handsome Dan, the ineffably ugly bulldog who serves as Yale's mascot? And somebody will surely ask whether the money should not be put to uses more obviously consistent with Yale's larger mission of marinating its students in civilization's highest values.
LEAD: Rowena Reed Kostellow, a professor of design at Pratt Institute, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Beekman Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: If part of the art of politics consists of donning the cloak of insurgency while building bridges to the establishment, Eliot L. Engel is something of a master.

LEAD: Interest rates were little changed in very quiet trading yesterday.

LEAD: A memorial service for the actor and director Duane Jones, who was artistic director of the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art in Manhattan, will be held on Monday at 7 P.M. at the Church of the Intercession, 550 West 155th Street. Mr. Jones died on July 22 at age 51.

LEAD: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. LEAD: The Halliburton Company said it had extended its tender offer for all outstanding rights of Gearhart Industries to next Thursday. The offer had been scheduled to expire on Thursday of this week, Halliburton said.

LEAD: The number of subway turnstiles being broken into, jammed or vandalized has risen sharply this year and has now become a critical problem for the Transit Authority, with record one-month revenue losses of $150,000 in August alone, the president of the authority said yesterday.

LEAD: A retired New York City health inspector who pleaded guilty to extorting a $500 payoff from a restaurant was sentenced by a Federal judge yesterday to three months in jail and a $1,000 fine.

Mr. Prude, who was active in concert management for more than 40 years, died on Aug. 29 at the age of 78.

LEAD: It would be difficult to overestimate the impact that the National Geographic magazine had on the formative years of someone raised in postwar America. From the perspective of small-town U.S.A., the wild animals, tribal cultures and mountain vistas pictured on its pages seemed utterly foreign and completely fascinating.

LEAD: BALLADEER OF SENEGAL Much like Europe's medieval troubadors, Djimo Kouyate - a griot, or balladeer, from Senegal - translates the history, foibles, politics and cultural traditions of West Africa into music, dance and storytelling. He will give a free performance at 3 P.M. today in the Yale University Art Gallery as part of the gallery's Celebration of African Art and Culture exhibition.
LEAD: Below are answers to recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.
LEAD: NEW life has been pumped into Ristorante Orlando, an old favorite in Huntington Village. The efforts of the new owners of this 30-year-old standby are dazzling regulars and first-timers alike.

LEAD: Sense, not sentiment, moved organized baseball to change the rule that barred Fred Lynn, recently traded to the Detroit Tigers, from postseason play because he joined the team a few minutes past the deadline of midnight Aug. 31.
LEAD: Derek Mills headed home the goal with less than six minutes remaining as Harvard defeated Columbia, 1-0, today in the Ivy League men's soccer opener for both teams.
LEAD: As many as 120 people fleeing Hurricane Gilbert were feared dead today in the industrial city of Monterrey after four buses overturned in flood waters, trapping most of the passengers inside.

LEAD: Forty-five university presidents from around the world have adopted a resolution to develop common curriculums on disarmament and the theory and practice of international conflict management in their universities.
LEAD: The way the British boxer, Frank Bruno, now sees it, he no longer has any reason to fear Mike Tyson.

LEAD: There was something desperate in their voices, something that said the Yankees are running out of time and hope. They were euphoric Thursday night, but today they were glum and uncertain. They knew it as they dressed and left under a darkened sky at Fenway Park.
LEAD: Margaret Nathaniel, 10 years old, helped her mother stock their gray tent with sleeping bags, thin mattresses and a cooler. They worked in a steady rain.

LEAD: Hidden behind a brown curtain, a member of Britain's elite Special Air Service regiment, identified only as ''Soldier A,'' testified in clipped tones how he fired five bullets at close range into two Irish Republican Army guerrillas here in March.

LEAD: Just when so many of us had begun to hope that biological determinism had fallen out of fashion, Melvin Konner informs us in ''The Aggressors'' (Body and Mind, Aug. 14) that biological imperatives compel men to behave more violently than women. It is such a tired argument that one might have assumed it would not be dragged out unless there were new evidence.

LEAD: You are sitting in a taverna surrounded by cobblestone streets, pastel-colored houses and Baroque churches, sipping a copito or two of port or vinho verde. The warm breezes are scented with sweet cinnamon and saffron, turmeric and soy.
LEAD: CONNECTICUT is experiencing a big increase in the smallest of people. Like the nation as a whole, the state is in the midst of a baby boom, with consequences both present and future.

LEAD: Next to picture quality, perhaps the most decisive consideration in choosing video equipment is convenience. Two recent innovations, both developed by Panasonic, stand out in this respect - a wobble-free camcorder and a phone-programmable VCR.

LEAD: President Reagan's choice of Lauro F. Cavazos of Texas to become the nation's next Secretary of Education has been approved by a Senate committee, clearing the way for expected easy confirmation by the full Senate.

LEAD: DESPITE the opposition of 700 irate residents at the first public hearing, 15 years ago Greenburgh changed its zoning and created public housing for low-income families, scattering 100 units on six sites in the town.

LEAD: THE county has lost another farm market. A few months ago the Square Deal Farm in Hartsdale announced that it would not open this year. The land is apparently for sale, with the asking price in seven figures.

LEAD: A man who Federal officials say ran the biggest cable television piracy ring in the nation and defrauded cable companies of almost $5 million in potential fees pleaded guilty Friday to mail fraud and income tax evasion.

LEAD: Burmese troops fired today on demonstrators who surrounded a Government building the troops were guarding, then surrendered to students and Buddhist monks, witnesses said.

LEAD: WITH nurses in short supply, Danbury Hospital in Connecticut considered an offbeat aid to make its nursing staff more efficient: Roscoe, a three-foot-tall robot designed to do some of the drudge work.
