LEAD: The Pall Mall Gazette was the center of what Matthew Arnold called ''the New Journalism.'' It was edited by W. T. Stead, who used the paper to produce an emotional bond between himself and the public. Together with Frank Harris, who edited The Evening News, Stead altered the character of daily journalism in Britain during the mid-1880's.

LEAD: Golf Palmer Leads Seniors: Arnold Palmer, five under par for the day after the first five holes, rolled in a 25-foot birdie putt on the final hole yesterday to salvage a four-under-par 68 for a three-shot lead after two rounds of the $325,000 Crestar PGA Seniors Classic in Richmond. ''I kind of pulled it back together,'' said Palmer, who had a 36-hole total of nine-under-par 133.

LEAD: INSIDE A WINDOWLESS ROOM in the heart of the Pentagon, a set of antiquated encryption/decryption machines suddenly start to percolate. The whir prompts a gray-haired Army colonel to glance up at three oversize digital clocks labeled ''ZULU'' (Greenwich mean time), and, in Russian, ''WASHINGTON'' and ''MOSCOW.

LEAD: A slowing of the economic pace seemed to be registered in the week's statistics. Far from being alarmed, most economists welcomed signs that the strong growth of earlier this year, and its potential for inflation, might be easing. The statistics included a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales in August.

LEAD: WHEN I WAS A SMALL child - I cannot recall exactly how small - my favorite toy was a narrow box full of records. It was the original cast recording of the Broadway musical ''South Pacific.'' I don't know how many were inside, but this was in the days before long-playing records, so I know there were a good many of them.

LEAD: YURI V. FEOFANOV has written about Soviet legal affairs for Izvestia, the Government newspaper, for 33 years, often criticizing his colleagues in the press for publicly prejudging the outcome of criminal cases. He returned to the theme recently, as Yuri M. Churbanov, the son-in-law of the late Soviet leader Leonid I.

LEAD: DINNER at Randall's Ordinary in North Stonington is a unique experience, as close to dining in Colonial times as most of us will ever know. The dishes served are from authentic 18th- and 19th-century recipes, and most are cooked in the fireplaces of three small, low ceilinged dining rooms with exposed beams.

LEAD: Fundamentally, what these newly minted liberal arts graduates are suffering from is reality shock [ ''Brand-New Degree and No Place to Go,'' Aug. 28 ] . For the first time in their lives, they have to get real jobs and support themselves, but no one has told them - not parents, friends, or teachers throughout their 16 years of schooling - that without marketable office skills, they are virtually unemployable.

LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.

LEAD: To the Editor: Dale Brown's account of a trip to southern Greenland should encourage travel to that interesting island, though he visited only a small part of it.

LEAD: Time and distance are enemies of the inquiry into whether mustard gas was used on Kurds in Iraq. The chemical degrades rapidly in tissue samples, and the area of the supposed attacks is off-limits. Page 14.

LEAD: Spas have generally been known for their facials and Jacuzzis and have appealed mainly to women who want to be pampered. Now spas are trying to provide stress reduction and fitness for busy executives who combine corporate conferences and relaxation.

LEAD: CHASING after the glittering prize of India more than 400 years ago, Mogul invaders used both military might and statecraft to subdue those who stood in their way. Today the legends surrounding their battles and alliances with the powerful Rajput warlords in north central India are among the most romantic features of the nation's history.

LEAD: The famous are different from you and me - they receive more attention. Looking at them, we are conscious of how many times they have been looked at before. The images they project are inseparable from our knowledge of what they are; and as their fame grows, their features evolve into something more than faces - into masks, trademarks, icons.

LEAD: IF Abstract Expressionism was the atom bomb of art, maybe the revival of artists eliminated by the explosion can be likened to the rebirth of the natural environment. In any case, they keep coming, these pre-bomb artists, and, as someone recently remarked to the reviewer, it's as if they, or the historians espousing them, are scurrying to beat the deadline of the century's end.
LEAD: A wildflower never before seen in New York, the Michigan lily, has been discovered growing in a singular prairie in the state northwest of Watertown, not far from Lake Ontario.

LEAD: They could have called it ''Age Against Youth,'' or just maybe, ''Beauty and the Beast,'' but to the officials at Canterbury Downs in Shakopee, Minn., the ''Duel of the Downs,'' match race scheduled for Sunday, Oct. 2, is nothing less than a battle of the sexes.

LEAD: NOTHING HAS MORE SIZZLE ON television these days than ''reality.'' Don't bother asking for a coherent definition. Television's reality formats include everything from the nightly news to talk shows to ''based on fact'' movies to the Summer Olympics to Phil, Oprah and Geraldo. The only productions definitely not admitted under the reality umbrella are sitcoms and action-adventures.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''The Naked and the Dressed in Provence'' by Mickey Friedman (Travel, June 26): Was this mixture of furtive voyeurism and prudish distancing for real (''stunned, shock, widened eyes, shame''), or (now I get it) just a satire of those oh so noncosmopolitan Florida citizens who have not yet become suave New Yorkers?

LEAD: ROCK LOVES OVERNIGHT SENSATIONS - the singer who swoops out of nowhere and draws a dedicated national following, and preferably a hit single, to reinforce the great American myth of the untutored genius. LEAD: THE rain was still pouring down - for the fifth straight day - as I awoke on that morning of Wednesday, Sept. 21, 1938. Soon after reaching my office at the phone company's state headquarters in New Haven, a group of us gathered to consider problems that might lie ahead.

LEAD: Companies may be under pressure to control costs, but the amount they are spending on meetings continues to rise. LEAD: ONCE again this season, the wise (and thrifty) music lover would do well to check the performing agendas at the many colleges, conservatories and other centers of learning in the county. LEAD: LIVING OUT LOUD. By Anna Quindlen. (Random House, $17.95.) When Anna Quindlen was 22 years old and wanted to write a column about her life, her editor at the time said she ''hadn't lived enough to be qualified for 'living out loud.' '' This collection from Life in the 30's, Ms. Quindlen's syndicated New York Times column, is all about ''muddling through the middle,'' her definition of life.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. LEAD: BEIJING, which in recent decades seemed content to ignore its dynastic past and culture as somehow corrupt, has, even as it rushes toward modernity, taken to collecting accounts of the customs and mores of the past century from its elderly citizenry. A recent collection of these reminiscences, ''Talks on Beijing's Recent Past,'' contains the recollections of one Yin Runsheng, who is otherwise unidentified but who remembered the capital's two great duck houses for nostalgic readers.

LEAD: Gary Buealmont was a company man in a company town. An eight-year veteran of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plant in this Connecticut River Valley town, he had a good job at good wages. He expected to work there forever.

LEAD: THERE'S a lot to do in Hong Kong besides eat, but perhaps nothing so worthy of attention, so all-consuming, nothing that offers as great a share of its everyday life. The lure of the five- or six-course lunch, followed after a decent interval by a 10-course banquet in the evening, calls for a breakfast strategy.

LEAD: LAST October, at the Loma Linda University Medical Center in California, Dr. Leonard L. Bailey transplanted the heart of a Canadian infant, known as Baby Gabrielle, into the chest of another Canadian baby. Baby Gabrielle was anencephalic, born without the part of the brain responsible for consciousness, memory and thought, and doomed to a quick death.

LEAD: There are 37 million Americans uninsured for health care. Two-thirds of them are working, or are dependents of those who work. About 19 percent of all children under the age of 18 are not covered by health insurance. In addition, an estimated 2 million people suffer from pre-existing or excluded conditions that preclude them from coverage, regardless of their employment or income status.

LEAD: WHILE New Jersey suffers from a severe shortage of low-cost housing, tens of thousands of tenants across the state face eviction because their apartments are being converted to condominiums or cooperatives. Mounting opposition to the evictions has generated fierce legislative and legal debates.
LEAD: FAIR PLAY CBS, General Westmoreland, and How a Television Documentary Went Wrong. By Burton Benjamin. Illustrated. 218 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $17.95

LEAD: KINGDOM'S END AND OTHER STORIES. By Saadat Hasan Manto. Translated by Khalid Hasan. (Verso/Routledge, $18.95.) Saadat Hasan Manto never lived to see his work translated; given the quality of this English edition, he was probably lucky. Born a Moslem in the Punjab region of India, Manto was forced by the violence that accompanied partition to leave for Pakistan, where he died in 1955 at the age of 43.

LEAD: In Jerusalem last June several dozen Israeli and Palestinian writers, artists and academics signed a symbolic peace treaty. It called for peace between Israel and a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza, each respecting the other's need for security.

LEAD: The paintings of Alan Turner may not seem to be rooted in this postmodern decade but they are. Certainly they have a traditional feel to them. LEAD: NEARLY two years after a Sandinista missile downed a cargo plane and detonated the Iran-contra affair, doubts continue to linger about whether the full story has emerged.
LEAD: ''Euphoria'' is a shack made of castaway shingles and facing an ocean vista from a dune on the easternmost tip of Cape Cod. It is a spot rarely touched by the noise of modern life.
LEAD: The Circle K Corporation has canceled a plan to limit medical care coverage for employees who contracted AIDS or suffered from drug or alcohol abuse.

LEAD: In the brilliant sunlight of the French Riviera, Steve Martin, the comedian-turned-movie-star, hides under a baseball cap, behind his ''go away'' shades. Although he has been shooting a comedy, ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' along the Mediterranean for six weeks, his complexion has remained trademark pale.
LEAD: With two jerrycans in hand, Muklesha Khatun waited impatiently for about four hours for the water trucks to arrive, and finally took home her allotted daily quota, two gallons.

LEAD: Unchallenged and almost untouched, the Mets continued their countdown to the playoff yesterday when they beat the Montreal Expos, 6-2. And in one afternoon's work, they put the Expos out of the race and put Davey Johnson into the baseball record books.

LEAD: Back to Colonial Basics FOR some, getting back to the basics in cooking means popping a potato into the wall oven, rather than nuking it in the microwave. For Alice Ross of Smithtown, getting back to the basics means the basics. She spends two to three hours feeding wood into a brick and stone oven before she even begins baking that Long Island potato.

LEAD: Susan Beth Etterbeek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Etterbeek of Midland Park, N.J., and Carl Robert Soderlind, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Karl Soderlind of Duluth, Minn., were married yesterday at the Preakness Reformed Church in Wayne, N.J., by the Rev. Timothy Mulder. Mrs. Soderlind is a purchasing agent and her husband the vice president of corporate communications and investor relations for the Witco Corporation, a chemical and engineering products concern in New York.

LEAD: NEW CHAMBER SERIES As far as Bruce Adolphe is concerned, there is never enough chamber music. And since Mr. Adolphe, a composer who teaches at the Juilliard School and New York University, is also the music director of the Unitarian Universalist Church of Central Nassau in Garden City, he has the chance to practice what he preaches.

LEAD: FOR A DANCE WRITER, ONE OF the unpredictable pleasures of interviewing is that moment when, without fanfare, words tumble out of a dancer or choreographer that offer a fresh or codifying insight into a body of work, a career or dance itself. Alexander Kolpin, a young principal dancer with the Royal Danish Ballet, Martha Graham and Erick Hawkins are all articulate and, often, poetic.
LEAD: THE state's five largest cities will be receiving special help to meet recycling requirements that are to go into effect in 1991.

LEAD: Cruise ships are now being designed with the lucrative corporate market in mind. Introduced in January, the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line's $180 million Sovereign of the Seas, the largest passenger ship in the world, has 11 lounges and movie theaters that can double as corporate meeting rooms. Two Royal

LEAD: To the Editor: As one who shares Margaret Shakespeare's enthusiasm for key limes and recently read her Fare of the Country (Travel, May 22), I was sorry she did not note that all limes found in the Keys are not Key limes. The yellow lime is not a true Key lime.

LEAD: YOU can get an air ticket to China cheaper than you might expect, even as more and more Americans are traveling there. There is a round-trip ticket from New York for $900 or slightly less (not counting customs and landing fees) - and it is on a scheduled airline with a name you have heard of. To get this fare, instead of the usual $1,400 or $1,500 round-trip AP

LEAD: In its zeal to Get That Story, along with its phobia of seeming like a flag-waver, NBC-TV opened its Olympic coverage by combining the joy of the event with a certain heavy portentousness.

LEAD: Fenway Park, goes the belief that dies hard, eats left-handed pitchers for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Midnight snacks, too, when the games last that long. Bruce Hurst, though, has given Fenway indigestion.

LEAD: 'RUNNING ON EMPTY'' IS Sidney Lumet's family drama about radicals who, 15 years after blowing up a research laboratory that made napalm, are still on the run. Why is this idea so undeniably compelling? In part it's novelty, since Hollywood has left the radicalism of the 1960's relatively unexplored.

LEAD: The only time Tom Browning had to work out of trouble was after it was over. Browning had just retired the last of 27 straight Dodger batters and he remained trapped under a pile of teammates for nearly a minute late Friday night in Cincinnati. At last he emerged, disheveled and a little disbelieving.
LEAD: INSIDER My Hidden Life as a Revolutionary in Cuba. By Jose Luis Llovio-Menendez. Translated by Edith Grossman. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

LEAD: Following is a selective guide to travel in New Zealand. American citizens visiting the country do not need a visa for stays of less than three months. They must, however, show that they have onward or return tickets and sufficient money for their stay. Prices throughout the chart are given in United States dollars, figured at a rate of 2.37 New Zealand dollars to $1.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Martha Jackson remembers her teachers washing her mouth out with soap because she had spoken in her native tongue, Navajo, at a boarding school run by the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
LEAD: Objections by a group of House liberals have imperiled a welfare bill that is languishing in a House-Senate conference, leaders of House and Senate conferees say.

LEAD: Hurricane Gilbert has cut a 2,500-mile swath of devastation through the Caribbean and Gulf Coast since it formed a week ago, making the extent of its destruction the worst recorded for an Atlantic storm, the director of the National Hurricane Center said today. At least $10 billion in damage has already been reported in six countries.

LEAD: Blues, noise, ostinatos and plain funk all vied for attention on Tuesday at the Knitting Factory. Herb Roberts, a cellist, led an acrobatic group through long pieces that exposed section after section of different textures, from compressed noise to fragile melodies carefully presented on just cello and trombone.

LEAD: The marriage of Elizabeth Helena Gaynor to John Andrew Caputineanu Minden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Caputineanu Minden of New York, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Schoonover Gaynor, the bride's parents, in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: It has been so neglected that it has the air of an abandoned building, even though 3,400 passengers use it daily. But now the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has put out to bid plans to renovate its 125th Street station at Park Avenue, which was built in 1897. Sometime next year the exterior will emerge from decades of neglect, but the long-hidden golden oak interior will simply get another coat of paint.

LEAD: Over the objections of the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, several hundred prominent political figures and others from Western democracies plan to come to Chile to observe the Oct. 5 presidential plebiscite.
LEAD: CHILDHOOD YEARS A Memoir. By Junichiro Tanizaki. Translated by Paul McCarthy. Illustrated. 181 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $17.95.

LEAD: European officials, East as well as West, are unusually relaxed about American elections this year. They don't feel they have a big stake in the outcome, not because U.S. decisions are any less vital to them nowadays but because they don't expect much change whoever wins.

LEAD: At least 160 manufacturing workers at a Lockheed Corporation plant here, many of whom are believed to be involved in building a top-secret fighter, have become sick, spawning a whirlwind of questions that begin with the materials used in the plant.

LEAD: RESEARCH on the autumn beach begins for me on Aug. 31 and continues on into October. On a typical day in the fall there might be cirrostratus clouds overhead, all streaked and fine, with lumpy little cumulus clouds clumped on the horizon.

LEAD: A coalition of church and civic leaders is converting a former Y.M.C.A. in the heart of the tourist district as a shelter for the homeless and other needy people.

LEAD: ME-VT-CT-MA-NY REFUND 5. When I first encountered this obscure message it did not strike a chill in my heart. There was no foreboding, only a smug sense of participating in a virtuous and civilized system. To be precise, the message did not at that time include NY; perhaps it read only ME-VT-CT, or something of the kind.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''Explorations in a Land of Glaciers'' (Travel, Aug. 21): We returned to Narssarssuag in a small boat (someone laughingly called it the Titanic), sailing for three hours amid icebergs, alone in the visible world. The emergency radio told of a boat accident and subsequent drownings.

LEAD: ALAN D. McNEELY and his colleagues work in places that few people ever see but that many pass regularly. They work on instruments that few play but that many expect to hear. They do work that few understand and that fewer know how to do.

LEAD: VELAZQUEZ: Painter and Courtier, by Jonathan Brown. (Yale University, $35.) The masterpieces of Velazquez, including his haunting, self-referential ''Las Meninas,'' were completed while he was becoming increasingly consumed by his duties in the court of King Philip IV, where he was finally knighted in 1659.

LEAD: With Arthur Dennis returning for his senior year at John Adams after gaining 1,418 yards as a junior, the Spartans were everyone's pick to repeat as the Public Schools Athletic League champion. They did not disappoint in the first big weekend of football.

LEAD: He lost the United States Open and the No. 1 ranking he had held for 156 weeks, but Ivan Lendl, who is now ranked No. 2 behind Mats Willander, cited another ailment in withdrawing from this week's Volvo-Los Angeles tournament: an injury to his right shoulder joint incurred during the Open. Other withdrawals from the tournament include Pat Cash, Aaron Krickstein, John Frawley and Eliot Teltscher.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis counterattacked today on environmental issues, accusing Vice President Bush of ''more somersaults than an Olympic gymnast'' and of changing his positions as he changes time zones.

LEAD: AUDIO IS PROBABLY THE only field in which it is always safe to believe what you hear. Playing it by ear, so to speak, is what audio is all about, and casual listeners rarely go beyond that. But those who hope to evaluate sound equipment with real critical discernment need more than ephemeral impressions as a basis for judgment.

LEAD: The Islanders commenced their exhibition season tonight to the syncopated tune of Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia goaltender-percussionist, who pounded his goalposts less merrily as the evening wore on.

LEAD: It is not within the power of architecture to guarantee that we have a good time - except, perhaps, at Wrigley Field. For this extraordinary baseball park, this amiable pile of steel and bricks and concrete that despite careful maintenance still shows every one of its 74 years, seems to radiate more joy than all the domed stadiums of the last generation put together.

LEAD: I was intrigued and then dismayed by Richard N. Goodwin's article ''The War Within'' (Aug. 21), about Lyndon B. Johnson. From the depth of his analysis, it sounded as though Mr. Goodwin was one of the President's closest advisers. Mr. Goodwin met or talked with the President 127 times in 1964 and 1965, according to my research using the Presidential daily diaries.
LEAD: SO, YOU THINK YOU'RE WELL-informed? A new weekly television series making its debut tomorrow evening at 7:30 on Home Box Office may test that conviction.

LEAD: For most of this decade, Arab members of the United Nations have made a September ritual of asking the General Assembly to expel Israel. And every year, an increasing U.N. majority disposes of the proposal and hews to the charter's principle of universality. Last year, 80 nations opposed the Arab move, 39 voted aye and 10 abstained.
LEAD: The celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah last week marked not only the beginning of the Jewish New Year but also, for many children, a rite of passage into a whole new world, that of dressing up.

LEAD: Michele Mitchell and Wendy Lian Williams of the United States put off the projected domination of 10-meter platform diving by the Chinese for at least another four years today as they took the Olympic silver and bronze medals behind Xu Yanmei of China, who won the gold.
LEAD: I am writing in response to several aspects of James LeMoyne's article ''Testifying to Torture'' (June 5).

LEAD: The United Nations has lately shown a resolve to tackle its longstanding organizational problems, and has begun playing a more conspicuous and constructive role in resolving regional conflicts. In belated response to these welcome trends, President Reagan last week announced he would stop the U.S.

LEAD: Hempstead House is falling down. Decay is not visible on the outside, with seemingly immutable granite and limestone walls, or on the inside, with 40 rooms that have served as lavish showcases for prominent designers, but in its crevices, where rain has seeped for 76 years. In summer, water rusted the building's steel frame.

LEAD: Grace Stark should never have put up the $30,000 bond for that cocaine dealer. What does a 52-year-old suburban housewife from western Massachusetts know about the bail bond business anyway? She's only supposed to be minding the store until her husband, Phil, a professional bondsman who has filed for Chapter 11, can make good on some forfeits and get his license back.

LEAD: TWO PLACES IN TAIPEI lend themselves perfectly to contemplation of the split personality of modern Taiwan: the National Palace Museum and a night market cum red light district known as Snake Alley.
LEAD: Recent signs of a pulse in the stock market have brokers and traders hoping that the retail investors who fled Wall Street this summer may start to trickle back, looking for bargains.
LEAD: The end to a long war for independence for this sparsely populated, largely desert region now hinges on votes, not bullets.

LEAD: Intervening in a critical debate, Egypt has urged the Palestine Liberation Organization to avoid a rapid decision on declaring a government in exile for the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, according to officials and diplomats here.

LEAD: The drug violator could draw on his or her sick time, and thus continue to be paid. After that is exhausted, vacation time. If there is no provision for leave time in the professional athlete's contract, or if such leave time has been exhausted, then that person should go on leave without pay. Professional athletes are no different from anyone else; they sign a contract to work and they ought not to be coddled.
LEAD: An article in The Week in Review on Sept. 4 about mental institutions misidentified the Commissioner of the Texas Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation. He is Dennis R. Jones.

LEAD: ''I REMEMBER one year, I think it was 1980, and all the white houses turned gray from it,'' recalled Dr. Paul Brauer, referring to the hydrogen sulfide that is said to be coming from the deteriorating Sherwood Mill Pond, an estuary along Westport's shore.

LEAD: TOURS OF ESTATES Eleven homes in the Great Estates region of the Hudson Valley, a 20-mile district stretching from Hyde Park north to the town of Hudson, will be opened to the public in a series of tours Thursday through next Sunday. The ones that are still privately owned are being been shown for the first time and each will be open on only two of the four days.

LEAD: LAST call to dig, divide and replant spring-summer flowering perennials especially phlox, daylily, astilbe, hosta and columbine. Seed or sod new lawns; keep moist to speed germination and rooting. Continue moving house plants indoors; check plants for insects and discard those infested with white flies as these insects are hard to control if taken indoors.

LEAD: In another patriotic tableau for his campaign of American symbols, Vice President Bush today rang a model of the Liberty Bell along with schoolchildren to commemorate the 201st anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.

Heyward of Great Neck, L.I., and Paris. The Rev. William R. Mueller, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

LEAD: NOW that cool, damp weather has thankfully come to Yellowstone, the giant fires raging out of control in and around the park during the last several months have finally slowed. And although no one knows when the blazes - which have already consumed 1.5 million acres - will finally be extinguished, the political debate over wildfire policy has already begun.

LEAD: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe sat in his suite at the Helmsley Palace hotel yesterday and described how his nine-year-old nation has confounded the gloomy predictions of old Rhodesia's white rulers by increasing overall agricultural production while leading millions of black peasants from subsistence farming into the commercial food chain.

LEAD: THE DAY I learned what happened in the operating room while I slept, the season's first snow was falling. As my neurosurgeon set up the videotape player, I could see flakes the size of half dollars tumble by the window. I'd known that at New York University Medical Center, as at all academic hospitals, surgeons videotaped their operations as teaching aids.

LEAD: In July, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts signed into law a bill mandating universal health care for all workers in that state. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced legislation in Congress calling for universal health insurance on a nationwide basis. John J. Motley, director of Federal Government Relations at the National Federation of Independent Businesses, spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about why small businesses are opposed to mandatory health care coverage.

LEAD: In the Hollywood of the 1920's through the 40's, a man's clothes were cut to play up his assets - and play down the rest. And the fashions made popular by the studios' most celebrated leading men conveyed the message that, on celluloid at least, style and substance were synonymous. It wasn't easy, for example, to separate Robert Montgomery's suave authority from the elegant white dinner jackets he wore in his portraits.
LEAD: NUMBERS 3 and 4, from the Slavonik Dances by Antonin Dvorak.

LEAD: ON THE MORNING OF last Oct. 20, Laurence A. Tisch, the president and chief executive officer of CBS Inc., sat in his office on the 35th floor of Black Rock thinking pessimistic thoughts. In the background, a single television set was tuned to the Financial News Network, which was airing a Wall Street report.

LEAD: More than a year has passed, but the repercussions are still being felt. When the United States men's basketball team is not answering questions about the Soviet Union, talk invariably centers on a 6-foot-8-inch Brazilian folk hero who played a major role in leading his team to the second-biggest upset in the history of the amateur game.

LEAD: WILLIAM EVERSON: The Life of Brother Antoninus. By Lee Bartlett. (New Directions, $25.95.) The poet William Everson has had a dramatic life. As a teen-ager in 1930 he started a sexual affair with a girl in his California hometown that lasted eight years before they were married. But then, fearing his Oedipus complex would make him a bad parent, he had a vasectomy.

LEAD: The Senate has approved legislation to modernize the designs of the nation's pocket change and to issue coins commemorating the centennials of six states and the 100th birthday of President Eisenhower.
LEAD: Adam Walker ran for 179 yards and 3 touchdowns, scoring twice in the first six minutes of play following Ohio State mistakes, as Pitt routed the Buckeyes, 42-10, tonight.

LEAD: The National Endowment for Democracy, a private group financed by the Federal Government, has approved a plan to disseminate in Poland a book that accuses the Soviet Union of the massacre of more than 4,000 Polish Army officers at Katyn Forest in World War II.
LEAD: Greg DiFelice rushed for two touchdowns and Princeton's defense accounted for 9 points this afternoon as the Tigers defeated Cornell, 26-17, in the season opener for both teams.

LEAD: Even in a negative campaign for President, one topic that ought to be off-limits is questioning an opponent's loyalty to country. The Bush-Quayle campaign has been operating close to the borderline of decency in its carping about the flag and the American Civil Liberties Union. That such techniques may be working, at least temporarily, does not dignify them.

LEAD: Harold Eugene Davis, a Latin American scholar and professor emeritus at American University, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in this Washington suburb. He was 85 years old Mr. Davis served on the American University faculty from 1947 until he retired in 1973. He continued to teach part time until the fall of 1986.

LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.

LEAD: Ramon Simpas Subejano, a native of the Philippines who became a highly decorated United States war veteran, died after a brief illness Friday at a Veterans Administration hospital here. He was 83 years old, said a close friend, Al Livingston.

Archbishop Theodore E.

LEAD: Lester Piggott, the jockey jailed for three years last October after a conviction for tax fraud, will not face further penalties from the Jockey Club, the sport's ruling body, the club announced today.

LEAD: Alvah H. Chapman Jr., a Southern patrician with deep pockets, does not like to lose. But to win what could be the most dazzling prize of his long career - huge and steady profits from one of his most important markets - he must prove that the biggest newspaper under his control is a failure.

LEAD: I RECENTLY RECEIVED a card from Ireland. It simply said, ''Hello,'' and was not signed. I suspect it was from a man I was once related to by marriage. More than 10 years have passed since my divorce from his cousin. I had met him briefly one night while on a family visit. He wanted me to feel at home in his country.

LEAD: BECAUSE of their weight and the fact they have many parts, garage doors need periodic lubrication and adjustment - and sometimes repair - to keep them operating smoothly. The job is usually easy, but some adjustment procedures may require two people.

LEAD: Nowhere along Hurricane Gilbert's path of destruction did the storm hit with greater force and fury than here in the Yucatan. When it made its first landfall around dawn on Wednesday, it was with sustained winds of 180 miles an hour as well as gusts of wind measured at 218 miles an hour and waves of 23 feet or more.
LEAD: ''COMPANY,'' the Tony Award-winning musical by Stephen Sondheim and George Furth, is now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale.

LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter, taking issue with Republican campaign attacks centered on the Pledge of Allegiance, says he respects the flag but would probably refuse to recite the pledge if ordered to do so by the Government.

LEAD: ''1962 to 1988: Contemporary Art from the Paine Webber Collection,'' which was to open Friday at the Paine Webber Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street, has been postponed indefinitely.
LEAD: CHAPIN IN RUTHERFORD Tom Chapin, the folk singer and songwriter, will do two shows Saturday in the partially restored Rivoli Theater at the Williams Center in Rutherford.

LEAD: AS Connecticut's state agencies tighten their belts to live within new budget constraints ordered by Governor O'Neill, state fiscal officers are searching the Federal tax code for some possible explanations of why tax revenue is not flowing to Hartford as fast as expected.

LEAD: Eric Jones was an efficient general on attack and a superb passer today, just as Vanderbilt has said of its senior quarterback and just as Rutgers knew from last year. Jones had to be outstanding because Rutgers countered with a record performance by its quarterback, Scott Erney.

LEAD: After several weeks of pondering, Governor Cuomo is expected this week to name David Emil, a deputy commissioner at the state's Social Services Department, as president of the Battery Park City Authority.

LEAD: Lonnie Mack, the semi-legendary rock guitarist, brought himself and a three-piece band to the Bottom Line on Thursday night. Mr. Mack plays roadhouse music, rock that easily blends country and blues into a functional style meant to make people have a good time and dance.

LEAD: IT WAS ONE OF THOSE DAYS - fractious throughout, satisfaction in short supply. If I'd had enough money, a new suit might have mollified the mopes. I didn't, so I shaved off my beard. Less is sometimes more.

LEAD: Q. Seven years ago, we built a redwood deck and left it untreated, as we expected it to weather to a uniform gray color. After the first year, the wood darkened with fungus and moss and there was no graying. The deck was scrubbed and a gray deck stain applied, but two years later the wood was again dark with fungus and moss.

LEAD: MANY Americans have received their most vivid impressions of New Zealand from the descriptions in the mystery novels that the late Ngaio Marsh set in her native country.

LEAD: The list of places where the University of Miami has won football games during the past four seasons would trace a roadmap to dominance. The Hurricanes of Jimmy Johnson's brief but stunningly successful era as coach established credibility in Norman and South Bend. They earned hard-fought recruiting prestige with victories in Tallahassee and Gainesville.

LEAD: Reviewing Robert Wright's ''Three Scientists and Their Gods: Looking for Meaning in an Age of Information'' (Aug. 7), George Johnson refers to the information theory of Claude Shannon as an entry into the search for meaning behind the book: '' [ Mr. Shannon's ] suggestion that information is the opposite of entropy - the principle that can explain why there are islands of order in a universe doomed to increasing randomness by the second law of thermodynamics - caught the imagination of theologians and philosophers.

LEAD: Fred D. Thompson, a former vice president of advertising for The New York Times and later the assistant to the president of the Times Company, died of a heart attack yesterday while vacationing in Fort William, Scotland. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: HIS VISION OF HER. By G. D. Dess. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) To the glut of enervated first novels set in downtown Manhattan, G. D. Dess has provided a tonic voice of irony. His hero, Stephen - idiosyncratic, vaguely misanthropic, bisexual - becomes obsessed with Gilberte, a manipulative and ambitious young photographer.

LEAD: THE romantic yearnings that sent Wordsworth through England's Lake District and Lawrence through the Alps also, in part, impelled the writer Katherine Mansfield to tour her native New Zealand's Urewera country in 1907. Then as now, the Urewera and neighboring towns of Rotorua and Taupo on the North Island lured visitors with a vast variety of topography, flora and wildlife.

LEAD: There was anguish in Chelsea in the 1960's when the United States Postal Service wanted to build a maintenance center for its trucks on the site of its Morgan annex on Ninth Avenue at 29th Street. Opposition killed the plan. But the need remained, and the Postal Service looked elsewhere. Eventually, more hospitable territory was found to the west.
LEAD: A 94-unit residential development under construction here will complete the redevelopment of a 70-acre downtown urban renewal site prepared by the city 26 years ago.
LEAD: From a low-flying helicopter, the systematic leveling of Kurdish Iraq becomes evident.

LEAD: A GENERAL INTERNIST practicing in Lakeville since 1966, Dr. Peter Gott combines medicine and writing. He is the author of the book ''No House Calls,'' published by Simon and Schuster, and his syndicated newspaper column appears daily in 400 newspapers around the country.

LEAD: For many men, a manicure is a supreme but necessary indulgence, even an inexpensive thrill. Some desire short, meticulously groomed nails for professional reasons; others enjoy the soothing qualities of the experience. For instance, Charlie Rosner, creative director for a New York City advertising agency, favors very short nails for drawing, and delights in his periodic pilgrimages to Manhattan's Gio Hair Stylists because the manicurists there, he says, ''are kind enough to give me half an hour of complete silence once every 10 days to two weeks.

LEAD: THEN AGAIN. By Sue McCauley. (Hodder & Stoughton/David & Charles, $22.95.) Even when outcasts find each other, that may be all they find: society has usually closed and locked the door. In her very good first novel, ''Other Halves,'' the New Zealand writer Sue McCauley vividly portrayed two of society's rejects struggling to build a life in a highly industrialized country that is secretly sick of itself.

LEAD: After quarreling with bankers and creditors for weeks, the Mayor of Rio de Janeiro has publicly declared the city in a state of bankruptcy.

LEAD: For the buyer whose empty nest must still hold a brood of furniture, a Stamford, Conn., project offers condomium houses. A $285-to-$325 monthly common charge replaces weekend weed pulling and gutter cleaning, but, unlike a line of town houses or a stack of apartments, large - 3,000 to 3,400 square feet - single-family homes give this condominium cluster a subdivision look.

LEAD: Ben Calderone's letter (The 'Safest' Ship Was the Titanic, Sept. 11) raises two key points in the discussion of public safety. Even though the Titanic sank, a movement to destroy ocean shipping did not result. Since then, means to detect and avoid icebergs have been been improved, leading to safer marine transportation.

LEAD: In New York's most ambitious cultural venture since Lincoln Center was built in the 1960's, city and state officials plan to transform six 42d Street theaters into what they call a ''populist'' theater complex for low-priced and widely divergent forms of live entertainment.
LEAD: CELEBRATING its centennial, the National Geographic Society cooperated with the writer C. D. B. Bryan on a history of the organization and its magazine.

LEAD: The McMillin Theater at Columbia University is dead. Long live the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater. Although McMillin, the 64-year-old hall at West 116th Street and Broadway, enjoyed a long and honorable run as a center for campus activities and especially as a home for electronic music and other varieties of contemporary art, it has been in recent decades a depressing place to hear concerts.

LEAD: When the Commerce Department released the trade figures for July last week, imports showed an unexpectedly large 8.9 percent drop from the previous month. The overall deficit, $9.5 billion, also showed improvement over June's dismal showing of $13.2 billion. Do July's gains signal a closing of the trade gap?

LEAD: Michael Stonebreaker, a linebacker, returned an interception 39 yards for a touchdown and Tony Rice, the option quarterback, scored on an 8-yard run to lead unbeaten Notre Dame to a 20-3 victory over Michigan State today.

LEAD: ASKED THE OBVIOUS - WHY? -Greg DeWolf says: ''When I was a kid, my father told me work was something that shouldn't make you smile. I wanted to prove he was wrong.'' DeWolf teaches people more or less how to fly. He's the founder of Fly America, an organization dedicated to popularizing the sport of hang gliding, all four of whose members are now involved in the first cross-country hang-gliding excursion.

LEAD: Al Toon spins and leaps, twists and turns in territory where many receivers fear to tread.

LEAD: Stuart Davis (1892-1964) was an artist whose biography is that of American 20th-century art. It is not that Davis was at the center of the mainstream art world. Rather, as we learn in Karen Wilkin's book STUART DAVIS (Abbeville, $85), a lavishly illustrated and handsome coffeetable volume, he was an important and representative figure, one who started in the socially conscious Ashcan School tradition and became an outstanding Cubist.

LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett plans to pay his 107th and last official visit to a school on Tuesday in New Hampshire. LEAD: DANGLING like an irregularly shaped pearl in the Andaman Sea off Thailand's far southern peninsula, the island of Phuket has been blessed with jungle-topped mountains, planted on their lower slopes with rubber trees and coconut palms, and valleys patterned with lush rice paddies. Its coastline is studded with more than a dozen white sand beaches, each on a self-contained bay formed by rocky outcrops that jut into the translucent sea.

LEAD: In their first two games the Giants have allowed 298 yards rushing, 518 yards in the air and an average of 408 net yards per game. Early last week, Coach Bill Parcells conceded that his defense needed help and that he didn't care where it would come from.

LEAD: Ms. Gass's article made for very interesting reading. While I do believe that some of her feelings are justified, I also feel she has overgeneralized some unattractive traits of an attractive community. Assuming economic levels are relative, does a place exist that is void of the shallow, materialistic individual?

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the official certification of Carlos Salinas de Gortari as Mexico's President-elect misidentified a group that jeered President Miguel de la Madrid during his State of the Nation address. The hecklers were from the National Democratic Front, which ran Cuauhtemoc Cardenas for President; they were not from the National Action Party of Manuel Clouthier.

LEAD: ONE old Asia hand likes to tell of an encounter at the airport restaurant in Guilin, China. The left side of the menu was printed in English, the right in Chinese. Entrees were identical, prices were not.
LEAD: There is no real Democratic machine in Hudson County, no proper heir to Frank Hague, the famous boss of the 1930's and 1940's who used to brag, ''I am the law,'' and prove it every day.
LEAD: The Course

LEAD: ALMOST half a mile beneath the desert in southern New Mexico, Federal engineers believe they have found a solution for disposing of nuclear waste that is as eternal, as elemental and as invisible as the atom itself. Since 1983, they have been mining from salt beds the nation's first permanent repository for radioactive garbage, a tomb as vast, splendid and concealed as any ever built.

LEAD: Kirk Gibson's run-scoring single in the ninth inning tonight gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Any combination of Dodger victories and Houston defeats totaling seven will give Los Angeles the National League West title.

LEAD: THE YOUNG MR. LINCOLN Starring Henry Fonda. Directed by John Ford. 1940. Key Video. 100 minutes. $19.98. (Closed Captioned). If Abraham Lincoln were half the man that Henry Fonda makes him in ''The Young Mr. Lincoln,'' he could have settled the Civil War with a jest. LEAD: A transient suspected of accidentally igniting a fire that destroyed 102 homes has been charged in the blaze.

LEAD: WITH a mighty and explosive burst, the wind split the giant elm, sending it crashing through the garage; the lights went out, the trolleys stopped and my whole birthday party was forced to sleep over. It was 1945, the night of my seventh birthday. It was a night of cozy excitement and as the wind whistled, my family sat around the candle-lit kitchen table.

LEAD: Mothers Against Drunk Driving wishes to commend Assemblywoman Dolores G. Cooper of Atlantic City, who sponsored the new law that requires youths 16 or younger to pass a state-approved boating safety course before they operate motorboats in New Jersey (''New Law Takes Aim at Young Boaters,'' Aug. 21).

LEAD: A front-page article Sept. 4 on the Presidential campaign gave an incorrect affiliation for Professor Samuel Popkin. He is at the University of California at San Diego, not the University of San Diego.

LEAD: BEFORE SHE WENT OUT TO WORK WITH the gorillas, Sigourney Weaver said, she stopped by the small gorilla cemetery, at the grave of Dian Fossey, the prickly American naturalist who devoted 18 years of her life to befriending, studying and protecting the rare mountain gorilla. Fossey, whose murder in Rwanda in 1985 remains a mystery, is buried near

LEAD: IN the days after the emergency closing of the Williamsburg Bridge last spring, New York City transportation officials pondered how things could have reached such a state. There was talk of a mysterious rapid-corrosion process in the bridge's 85-year-old steel, of the deleterious effects of road salt and of flawed construction.
LEAD: AS much a technological marvel as a theatrical miracle, ''Dreamgirls,'' as conceived by Michael Bennett, can hardly be contained on an ordinary stage.

American World Jewish Services, 729 Boylston Street, Boston, Mass. 02116, Attn: Jamaica Recovery Program. Americares, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: Last year a sign in front of the electronics-luggage-carpet store at 565 Fifth Avenue read: ''Going Out of Business - Building Coming Down.'' Much later, the perpetual clearance sale was still on. Then recently, behind rising scaffolding, a new sign was tacked up: ''Last Two Days.'' In two days the store closed.

LEAD: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., Carole Anne Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Kennedy of Tenafly and Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian T. Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Jones of New Hyde Park, L.I. The Rev. John Magdziak performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Texas Democrats with national political aspirations have often identified themselves as Southwesterners. Lyndon B. Johnson particularly favored this approach after he decided that his party would never nominate a Southerner for President.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of Joyce Purnick, the daughter of Jack Purnick of New York and the late Charlotte Leah Purnick, to Max Frankel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Frankel of New York, has been announced by the future bride's father. Ms. Purnick is the urban affairs correspondent of The New York Times and a former City Hall bureau chief for the paper.

LEAD: IF NOT EXACTLY TANTAMOUNT to Isaiah's promised reconciliation of wolf and lamb, a concert featuring the Minimalist composer-pianist Philip Glass alongside jazz ensembles like the Max Roach Quartet and the Henry Threadgill Sextet may itself be prophetic.
LEAD: Vandals broke into a synagogue in the Midwood section of Brooklyn early yesterday and set on fire at least five Torah scrolls, the most sacred objects in Judaism.

LEAD: WHAT some call ''the magnificent magnet'' and others consider an expensive alternative to X-rays will soon become standard equipment in three Westchester hospitals, regional health officials said last week.

LEAD: THE recycling industry on Long Island is refusing to dispose of most refrigerators, dishwashers and other large appliances, following a warning by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency that older models of some of these items may contain unacceptable levels of PCB's.

LEAD: MARGARET MITCHELL called it ''the dump'' - a Victorian-style building in Atlanta where she lived in a basement apartment from 1926 to 1932 and wrote ''Gone With the Wind.'' In January, when a developer sought a permit to demolish the building as an eyesore, Mayor Andrew Young declined to approve it.

LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the United States rather than the Philippines must decide whether to accept a Soviet offer and close American bases here in return for a Soviet pullout from a strategic base in Vietnam.

LEAD: Fall 1988 marks the coming of age of the American look, an eminently easygoing style whose roots - and influence - stretch across the Atlantic. A timelessness and a graceful nonchalance define this home-grown way of dressing. Western boots, a chambray work shirt or, on a more formal note, a three-button suit worn with cordovan brogues are a few of the badges of Yankee style updated for this season.

St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Priscilla Corwith Barker, the daughter of Mrs. John William Veitch of Montreal and the late William Crichlow Lamond Barker, was married yesterday to Donald Keith Miller, a son of Mrs. Clinton R. Miller of Akron, Ohio, and the late Mr. Miller. The Rev.

LEAD: Before deciding to play football this season, Chris Thorpe checked with three medical specialists. That's because Thorpe, a 21-year-old senior safety for Penn State who had missed the 1986 season with a severe neck injury, wanted to make sure he would be at no special risk this year even though he had played in nine games last season.

LEAD: Wally Lamb writes in ''The Shadow of a Stranger'' (About Men, Aug. 21) that parents must protect their children from strange men. As a woman, though, I am also viewed as a dangerous stranger in many situations.

LEAD: In a series of recent cases, state courts across the country have overturned what had been hailed as trailblazing criminal convictions of companies and their executives for workers' deaths and injuries.

LEAD: In a booklet that has already become a best seller, cartoons show Superman battering foreign trade barriers and a timebomb labeled Agricultural Subsidies ticking away under a trade negotiating table.

LEAD: ''We could have done other things, maybe hijack an airplane, but we don't think that is nice,'' said Muhyeddin Abdula, a representative of the Kurdistan Democratic Party in the United States and Canada. ''We're trying to do things the nice way, the peace way.''
LEAD: West Germany's trading partners have long urged it to become a locomotive for European economic growth, but now some people are joking that it has become the caboose.

LEAD: Only hours after two boys, aged 12 and 15, were arrested for vandalizing and setting fire to a Brooklyn synagogue, about 10,000 people gathered on the nearby streets yesterday to attend a funeral service for the five Torah scrolls destroyed in the Sabbath blaze.

LEAD: Phylicia Rashad and Denzel Washington will be the hosts of a celebrity reading Sept. 26 at 8 P.M. at Theater Four of the Negro Ensemble Companyas part of the 1988 McDonald's Literary Achievement Awards. The winners of the competition will be announced at the fund-raising event for the dance company.

LEAD: Mothers carrying infants screamed and children cried today when the thousands gathered among the bamboo shacks of a refugee slum surged violently toward a white-robed figure on a little stage. As with the other crowds that have come to see Pope John Paul II across this devastated land, their enthusiasm was born of despair.

LEAD: On Thursday night, 2,000 men and women who work in the financial district will end their day by donning their running shoes and entering the Rat Race. In the second Carey Limousine Wall Street Rat Race, which will begin at 6:30 from the World Financial Center at Battery Park City, runners will wear business suits and carry briefcases.

LEAD: Sweden's governing Social Democratic Party retained its dominant position in national elections today, enabling Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson to claim a mandate to go on governing the country for the next three years.

LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: Arnold Palmer coasted to a two-under-par 70 today to win his first PGA Senior Tour event since 1985 with a four-stroke victory in the $325,000 Crestar Classic.

LEAD: Eight boxes of correspondence and memorandums from the People's Temple commune at Jonestown, Guyana, where 913 members of the American cult people died by suicide or murder 10 years ago, have become available for scholarly review.
LEAD: The Senate, in the next two weeks, and the House, shortly afterward, will decide how much to increase the minimum wage of millions of American workers at the lowest end of the economic scale.
LEAD: A high-stakes board-room drama with all the intrigue, glamour and bold moves of a Hollywood plot has captivated the French business community this summer.

Arne Skilbred of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric Paul Jorgensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Jorgensen of Northfield, Minn. The Rev. LEAD: China's leadership is locked in a major struggle over the direction of economic policy, a clash of wills that may have reduced some of the authority of Zhao Ziyang, the Communist Party leader, according to diplomats and Chinese familiar with discussions at the highest levels of government.

LEAD: * Boston Co., Boston, a subsidiary of American Express Co.'s Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., named Josephus Long, senior vice president, to the additional post of deputy group manager for its Corporate Operations Group.

LEAD: Some of the men who lived with Johnny in the hollow core of a walkway support next to the Harlem River Drive were philosophical yesterday about his death.

Accompanied by a tambura, a stringed instrument which projects a shimmering, metallic sound, Mr.
LEAD: Reebok International Ltd. said Friday that it expects its earnings for the third and fourth quarters to be lower than in the comparable periods last year.

LEAD: Paul Steinle, the new president of United Press International, hopes to make the news service profitable by the end of 1989, and he thinks that the unused space in any television signal will help him do it.

LEAD: Nearly three out of four juveniles in correctional institutions were from broken homes and nearly half were under the influence of drugs or alcohol when they committed their offenses, the Government reported today.

LEAD: In a weekend sweep, the Nassau County police arrested and charged nine Brooklyn men, four of them with murder, in a robbery spree at a Uniondale rap concert Sept. 10 that left one man dead and 14 injured.

LEAD: 985 November: Although President Jean-Claude Duvalier had announced a series of political reforms earlier in the year, anti-government rioting breaks out when several teen-agers are killed during a demonstration. December: President Duvalier reshuffles his Government, shifting power to an inner circle of hard-liners.

LEAD: The Futurity Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday had an ugly beginning and a dispiriting finish. A ragged start may have compromised the favorite's chances, and the entire field then staggered home in unimpressive time, looking like a very ordinary bunch of 2-year-olds.

LEAD: The great days for the Italians were the mid-1950's to the mid-1970's, when their Blue Team dominated world championship play. Recently, they have been in relative eclipse, although they came within a hair of winning the Bermuda Bowl title in Stockholm in 1983.
LEAD: There are words that a Jewish spokesman just doesn't use, like saying someone was ''just following orders.''
LEAD: Rarely have so many players skirmished so often in a National Football League game as the Jets and the Oilers did today.

LEAD: FOR centuries, mankind has been fascinated with the idea of perpetual motion machines. Obtaining something for nothing is a seductive idea.

LEAD: A partnership led by two New York arbitragers said yesterday that it would not meet with the board of the Zenith Electronics Corporation because the board had not responded to the group's proposal to sell the company.

LEAD: Because of a production error, an article yesterday from Los Angeles on issues in the 1988 campaign contained misplaced lines and paragraphs in some copies. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street,

LEAD: Next Sunday night America will finally tune in to the 1988 Presidential race. Millions of voters will be watching, certainly millions more than will see any other single event of this campaign. Live and on stage, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will confront each other, or maybe not, in the first of two televised debates.

LEAD: We are periodically obliged to resurrect the operas of Giacomo Meyerbeer, but one suspects it is more out of a duty to history than flat-out enthusiasm. People wanting to make their way from opera's origins to the present inevitably find him in their path. Meyerbeer was a giant figure and is not to be ignored.

LEAD: Walter P. Chrysler Jr., one of the country's leading art collectors and benefactors whose reputation as a shrewd judge of talent was tainted by suspicions that he knowingly attained forged works, died of cancer Saturday at Sentara Norfolk General Hospital in Norfolk, Va. He was 79 years old.
LEAD: Seven people protesting the denial of a medical visa for a Soviet man were arrested after blocking traffic outside the Soviet Embassy yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: Did you hear the one about Jerome Robbins and the comedian Joey Faye?

LEAD: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Friday about a financing backed by boat loans described the underwriting of the issue incorrectly. Chemical Bank Investment Banking was the lead manager; First Boston was co-manager.

LEAD: Is it possible that Yasir Arafat will finally acknowledge Israel's right to exist, and that his Palestine Liberation Organization will renounce terrorism? For months, rumors have swirled and hopes expanded. But at Strasbourg last week, Mr. Arafat only repeated the old, tired formulations. As with Godot in Beckett's play, the ''new''

LEAD: The marriage of Maria Domenica Palazzola, a daughter of Louise Palazzola of Ann Arbor, Mich., and the late Guy Palazzola, to John Gregory Wald, took place yesterday in Spencertown, N.Y., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Calder, stepfather and mother of the bridegroom. Roberta Davis, a justice of the peace in Spencertown, officiated.

LEAD: United States Customs agents seized 1,000 pounds of cocaine and arrested eight men in a raid of the sport-fishing boat ''What's Up'' Saturday, the Customs Service reported. A Customs spokesman, Cliff Stallings, said the cocaine was worth about $12 million whosesale. Also seized were the boat and five vehicles.

LEAD: GANNETT's Four-Color Newspaper Network, a national advertising representative for the company's papers as well as for independents, has increased its total circulation to a point where it is pursuing national manufacturers' couponing money, much of which goes into free-standing inserts.

LEAD: SWIMMINGJanet Evans won the United States' first gold medal of the Games in the 400-meter individual medley. Kristin Otto of East Germany, Adrian Moorhouse of Britain and Duncan Armstrong of Australia also won golds. BASKETBALLYugoslavia scored a surprisingly easy 92-79 victory over the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Police officers swept gang territories and arrested more than 870 people to curb violence that caused one death and left at least four people wounded over the weekend, the authorities said today.

LEAD: Robin Lesley Tannenbaum, a daughter of Steven Tannenbaum of Great Neck, L.I., and Arlene Reitman of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to David Alan Jacobs, a son of Peter Jacobs of Los Angeles and Marina Engel of New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated at the Harmonie Club.
LEAD: A soft-spoken man with a successful law practice and two flags standing guard over his desk, State Senator Ralph J. Marino hardly seems the sort destined to shake up the establishment.

LEAD: Toward midnight, with the 24-hour sun of the Arctic summer hovering above the horizon, a dilapidated wooden cabin came into sight on the shore of the Mackenzie River. Its roof caving in and walls askew, the cabin is all that remains of a community that took its name from a gunfight between two fur trappers in the 1920's.
LEAD: Turning a Presidential campaign is like turning a battleship; great exertion is required for small shifts in direction.

LEAD: ''Tartuffe'' is unfailingly timely, especially so whenever those who are outwardly sanctimonious are revealed as inwardly impious. With hypocrisy flying high in politics as well as in religion, one should be able to turn to Moliere for comic relief. Unfortunately, R. Jeffrey Cohen's production flattens the play into a one-dimensional cartoon.
LEAD: Bulletin from the Bush campaign! The contest is escalating. Not the Presidential contest - the other one, the tie contest.

LEAD: Leonard N. Stern, chairman of the Hartz Group, plans to give more than $25 million to New York University this fall to strengthen its schools of business, which would be named after him and consolidated in a large new building on the Washington Square campus.
LEAD: Credit market analysts said that short-term interest rates are likely to move higher during the remainder of the month, without the prodding of the Federal Reserve Board.
LEAD: Roman Catholic priests in the Baltimore Archdiocese were urged use their homilies to encourage support for the state's law controlling pistols.
LEAD: Seven days ago, the fiercest hurricane of the century swept across the beaches here on the easternmost tip of Jamaica, beginning a wild, thrashing journey that devastated the island.

LEAD: The rap group Run-D.M.C. held a news conference on Friday to defend rap music against criticism that it encourages violence, and the group blamed news organizations for focusing on the negative side of rap.

LEAD: Part of the wonder of fishing is being able to get away from it all, but transporting a boat to remote places can be troublesome. Porta-Bote International, a company based in Mountain View, Calif., claims it has a solution. The firm markets a collapsible boat, a polypropelene skiff that looks like a banana and folds like an accordian.

LEAD: The Service Merchandise Company said yesterday that an investor group that includes members of its senior management might acquire the company through a leveraged buyout. The investors include Raymond Zimmerman, the chairman and chief executive of the Nashville-based catalogue and retail chain.

LEAD: FLYING home after a recent round of sporting clays at the newly established Pawling Mountain Club, I almost persuaded myself that some strange malady had deprived me of hand-eye coordination since last year's upland bird and waterfowl seasons.

LEAD: The international storm over Iraq's supposed use of chemical weapons against its Kurdish minority may create new obstacles for the fledgling peace talks under way between Iraq and Iran, Western diplomats and Iraqi Government officials here say.

LEAD: In a column five years ago that deserves a retroactive Pulitzer prize, Rowland Evans and Robert Novak revealed a whopping violation by the Soviets of the ABM treaty: a huge phased-array, battle-management radar complex in Krasnoyarsk.

LEAD: Employees at the worldwide satellite consortium Intelsat here will have their hands full for the next two weeks. More than 170 countries representing three-quarters of the world's population - the largest audience ever - have booked more than 7,500 television hours for the Summer Olympics, up about 35 percent from the number of hours four years ago.

LEAD: Mary Bitterman, a former director of the Voice of America who is seeking office for the first time, defeaated two other Democrats Saturday in Hawaii's primary election for the urban Honolulu Congressional district and will face Representative Patricia Saiki in November.
LEAD: The Presidential race is downright mellow compared to the one in Chicago.

LEAD: Quality Inns International Inc. must stop using the name ''McSleep Inns'' for the economy hotels it plans because the public would believe the hotels were owned by the McDonald's Corporation, a Federal district judge has ruled.

LEAD: QUESTION: How many basketball players have been on teams that won a national collegiate championship, an Olympic gold medal and a National Basketball Association title?
LEAD: A 23-year-old rookie police officer was seriously injured in a hit-and-run accident last night, the police said.
LEAD: There is more woe ahead for Columbia.

LEAD: Even after the assassination of Olof Palme two and a half years ago, a Swedish Prime Minister mingles with election crowds here in a way that would be unthinkable for American Presidential candidates.

LEAD: Steve Largent broke the National Football League career record for receiving yardage today but the Seattle Seahawks lost to the San Diego Chargers, 17-6.
LEAD: HE'S different from all the other 9,626 athletes in these XXIV Olympic Summer Games. But he learned to play baseball the same way just about every kid does: playing catch with his father.

LEAD: Executives of companies that provide radon detection and testing services say their prospects received a lift from a public health advisory issued by the Government last week.

LEAD: Edward Regan, New York State's Comptroller, finds himself embattled over serious allegations that he misused his position as sole trustee of the state's $38 billion pension fund. Whether or not the allegations result in criminal charges, they raise legitimate concerns about Mr. Regan's integrity and judgment.

LEAD: It was the type of game that made several of the American players wonder whether they had come to the right venue. Basketball, international style, can often appear as if it is incorporating elements of wrestling, boxing and taekwondo. Teams learn to shoot and play self-defense.
LEAD: Officials at Yellowstone National Park say several inches of snow blanketed parts of the park over the weekend and may have finally taken the fight out of wildfires there.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Land Management has ordered an end to free mass adoptions of wild horses, a practice that critics said attracted people who sold the animals for dog food and other commercial purposes.

LEAD: Richard W. Murphy, the United States envoy to the Middle East who has been trying to defuse a political crisis in Lebanon, said today that he was confident the country's bellicose leaders would meet a Friday deadline for the election of a new president.

LEAD: ''The McLaughlin Group,'' one of the noisier talk shows, takes on Presidential elections in a special program tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13. The stentorian John McLaughlin and his regular cadre (the columnists Robert Novak and Patrick J. Buchanan on the hard right, and Morton Kondracke of the New Republic and Jack Germond of the Baltimore

LEAD: It took 110 seconds and one punch to end Kelcie Banks's bid for a gold medal in boxing. It took less time and no punches to scotch Anthony Hembrick's. It would be difficult, though, to say who felt worse when it was all over.

LEAD: Caroline Lehmann Meuly, an assistant Middlesex County prosecutor in New Brunswick, N.J., and Marc Bruce Leavitt, an editor, were married yesterday at the Onderdonk House in Piscataway, N.J., by Rabbi Irwin Fishbein.
LEAD: A table in Business Day on Thursday, with an article about proposed accounting rule changes, misstated the 1987 net income of Bell Atlantic. It was $1.24 billion.

LEAD: Counterfeiting and copying of brand-name products appears to be on the decline this year, the makers of these products say, as a result of their tough litigation policies, new laws here and abroad, and the weaker dollar.

LEAD: Katie and Jimmy, two 15-year-old gorillas, are the big ''item'' here at the San Diego Zoo. Lovers, the two have been courting for months - climbing together on rock formations in their outdoor enclosure, frolicking in a nearby pool of water, even mating publicly.
LEAD: Stanley M. Friedman's bribery and conspiracy trial is scheduled to open in State Supreme Court in Manhattan today. Perhaps you're wondering why.

LEAD: The Mets kept fitting the final pieces into the puzzle yesterday: They defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-3, moved to within a game or two of clinching the Eastern championship of the National League and named Dwight Gooden to open the playoff for the pennant two weeks from tomorrow.

LEAD: Iran said today that it lost 123,220 soldiers and 11,000 civilians in the eight-year war with Iraq. The announcement marked the first time that Teheran has reported casualty figures for the war.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation is expected to introduce today a powerful line of mainframe computers in an effort to revive its aging Sperry line and slow the defection of customers to competing mainframe computer makers.

LEAD: Elle magazine has reached the People's Republic of China, where young people appear eager for a peek at the latest in Western fashions. Officials at the magazine say it is the first international fashion and style publication to appear regularly in China.
LEAD: Dave Henderson drew a bases-loaded walk in the 11th inning and Jose Canseco hit his 40th home run today as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-2.

LEAD: Authorities in Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian republic, have authorized construction of what would apparently be the first Holocaust memorial in the Soviet Union, according to an American involved in the project.
LEAD: Bill Elliott held off Dale Earnhardt and Rusty Wallace by a little over a second today to win the Nascar Delaware 500 yesterday at Dover Downs International Speedway.
LEAD: Five Miamians accused of trying to smuggle 243 birds of protected or endangered species into the United States are to go on trial Monday in Federal District Court in Key West.

LEAD: Well, it wasn't George Gershwin. Friday evening's broadcast of the opening ceremonies of the Games of the XXIV Olympiad did not feature several dozen pianists playing ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' Instead of the King Kong-like chest thumping that predominated in Los Angeles four years ago, South Korea offered a gentler spectacle, stressing the themes of space, openness and reconciliation.

LEAD: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Brunswick, N.J., Terri Ann Sullivan, a financial journalist, was married yesterday to Steven Edward Moses, a cinematographer. The Rev. Louis Grenier, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg.
LEAD: The United Nations will gather Tuesday for the 43d General Assembly, closer to agreement than a year ago on many of issues, and with the United Nations itself enjoying new esteem.

LEAD: A 37-year-old crack addict on parole for a manslaughter conviction has been charged in the slaying of an art student who was shot to death in a robbery in Brooklyn not long after she arrived in New York City, the police said.

LEAD: The plunge of an Italian stunt plane into a crowd of spectators at the Ramstein air base three weeks ago has aggravated a lingering resentment among West Germans at limits on their sovereignty, some 43 years after the end of World War II.

LEAD: Merkin Concert Hall in the Abraham Goodman house on West 67th Street opened its 10th anniversary season Saturday night with an event that was as good a specimen as any of what the hall is about: a ''Pianorama'' of little-heard American music played by four excellent nonstar pianists.

LEAD: ''There are people who are saying that if the price of German-American friendship is so high, do we need the risks? Next they'll ask, do we need the burden? And then, do we need that friendship? I don't want that last question.'' - Rudolf Scharping, a West German politician, about reaction after the Ramstein air show disaster.
LEAD: The Washington Redskins defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 17-10, today in a battle between two of the four 1-1 teams that were leading the National Football Conference's Eastern Division.
LEAD: An off-duty correction officer was shot and wounded in Brooklyn early yesterday while riding in a car, the police said.

LEAD: With increasing reports of some students drinking themselves unconscious and others getting drunk and hurting themselves, a University of Connecticut committee will review the campus alcohol policy and consider possible changes including a ban on alcohol, the school officials said.

LEAD: With its warning last Monday that tens of millions of people should test their homes for the presence of carcinogenic radon gas and make repairs, the Government in effect proclaimed a national emergency, according to Government officials and spokesmen for consumers' organizations.

LEAD: David Del Tredici, the American composer whose extravagant preoccupation with ''Alice in Wonderland'' has led to best-selling records and a Pulitzer Prize, has been appointed composer in residence with the New York Philharmonic for this season and next.

LEAD: Starting today, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on weekdays within 75 miles of New York City, and on all of Long Island, is increased to 35 cents. The change is prompted by rising production costs, including an increase in the price of paper. The newspaper's Sunday price is unchanged, as is its weekday price outside the 75-mile area.

LEAD: Ammirati & Puris of New York has become the agency for Steven Jobs's new company, Next Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., which plans to introduce its first computer on Oct. 12, Edward Vick, the agency president, said.
LEAD: While rarely seen in public, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril has wielded power in Haiti for years. Until now he had been content with influencing his poor country from the shadows.

LEAD: Diana Rachel Loomis, the daughter of Gloria C. Loomis and Robert D. Loomis, both of New York, and William Scott Leeds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Leeds of New York and Phoenicia, N.Y., were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Parrish in Sag Harbor, L.I.
