LEAD: As the first full day of competition in the Olympic Games came to an end, the domination of the men's gymnastics competition by the Soviet Union was even more complete than expected.

LEAD: In moments of frustration, Arvidas Sabonis chose to stare at his sneakers, shaking his head, sometimes bouncing the basketball as if he wanted to punish it for his plight. By the time he left the game with 2 minutes 28 seconds to play, however, even those mild displays of discontent had ended, Sabonis quietly taking his seat at the end of a long line of glum faces.
LEAD: The Burmese armed forces removed the civilian leadership of the Government Sunday, banned street demonstrations and ordered striking workers back to their jobs.
LEAD: Three people whose bodies were found in a fire were determined to be homicide victims, and the police were searching today for clues in the first murders in this town in nearly four decades.

LEAD: In this village of vineyards, mulberry trees, piglets and geese, cradled between snow-patched ranges of the Caucasus Mountains, one of the largest collective farms in the Georgian republic has experienced profound changes as a result of efforts by the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to restructure the economy.

LEAD: The Big Ten Conference not only took it on the chin again Saturday but its four best teams - Michigan, Iowa, Ohio State and Michigan State - were beaten. Six Big Ten teams lost yesterday and only four won, leaving the conference with a 7-15 record against the outside world.

LEAD: St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Virginia Marie Moe, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Moe of Glen Ridge, N.J., to Dennis Robert Floss, the son of Dale J. Floss of Buffalo, and the late Ross Taylor Floss. Msgr. Franklyn M.

LEAD: Day 1 Riding: Entrants ride 600 meters over a 15-obstacle course on a horse drawn by lot. Riders start with 1,100 points, with deductions for knocking down barriers, falls and balky or slow horses. A clean ride in 1 minute 43 seconds earns the maximum points. Day 2 Fencing: One touch of the epee anywhere on the body decides a match.
LEAD: The Yankees probably took their last gasp today. It is only a matter of days before the race will be officially over.

LEAD: If the United States Olympic diving team matches the eight medals won four years ago or even comes close, Michele Mitchell and Wendy Lian Williams will have contributed more than the silver and bronze medals they won in the 10-meter platform.
LEAD: Lech Walesa told 50,000 pilgrims at a workers' Mass today that the Government is close to recognizing Solidarity, the banned independent union movement that he leads.

LEAD: The backbone of Koreatown, the largest Korean community outside Korea, is Olympic Boulevard. But at first glance, there are few signs that the inhabitants of the Los Angeles district have any special connection with the energetic celebration of the Olympics in their homeland.
LEAD: Vice President Bush generally supports off-shore oil drilling but he has urged that the policy be deferred in at least one area off Northern California.

LEAD: The history of jazz is filled with eccentrics, and the saxophonist Anthony Braxton, who brought a quartet to the Knitting Factory for a rare engagement, qualifies as one of them. Though he represents jazz's pedagogic side - his liner notes are as arcane and indecipherable as the densest semiotic text; he labels his compositions with line drawings that look algebraic - his music is often playful, with lines shooting out from all angles, and tempos picking up only to slow down.

LEAD: In the surreal world of nuclear politics, events often mean little. A court decision often results in years of additional judicial appeals. Regulatory actions seem to mean even less. Nothing, it would appear, is concrete.

LEAD: The New York City Opera, which has an honored history of taking chances with new works, tossed the dice bravely on Saturday evening with Jay Reise's ''Rasputin.'' Sorry. Snake eyes. The odds against success are always high in such a game, and this time the gamble did not pay off. ''Rasputin,'' which had its world premiere at the New York State Theater, is the 38-year-old composer's first opera and no worse than many a less visible failure.

LEAD: Saturday morning has long been the playground of network television, the place where Smurfs, Chipmunks and other cartoon creatures reigned over a time period given over by all three networks to children viewers.
LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 18,1988: MONDAY
LEAD: Sevdalin Marinov of Bulgaria set two world records today to win a gold medal in the 114-pound division of weight lifting.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There's a prominent Democrat running for statewide office in Texas this year who is campaigning all over the state but almost never mentions the job he is seeking or asks voters to give it to him instead of his Republican opponent.

LEAD: Pearson P.L.C., a London-based publishing, banking and industrial group, said yesterday that it had been approached by Reed International P.L.C., another British publishing company, about a possible takeover.
LEAD: * AC&R/DHB & Bess Advertising will change its name to AC&R Advertising on Oct. 1.

LEAD: Along Washington Square North, 20 protesters held banners and chanted, ''The park belongs to the people.'' Two hundred others who became spectators milled, and dozens of uniformed and plainclothes police officers watched from the curb across the street.
LEAD: Bruce Hornsby is such an unassuming stage performer that it would be easy to overlook his solid contributions to adult mainstream rock.

LEAD: The last traces of Hurricane Gilbert were being felt on both sides of the border today as the United States Coast Guard helped villagers flee treacherous flood waters in northern Mexico and residents in several Texas towns cleaned up debris from tornadoes spawned by the storm.
LEAD: The calendar is right. This is not 1978.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis inadequately described the position of Vice President Bush on offshore oil drilling. A corrective article is on page A16.

LEAD: Before today's game with the Dallas Cowboys, a number of Giants players talked about, even dwelled on, the bad luck that seemed to haunt the team whenever it visited Texas Stadium. After the Giants' 12-10 victory, even the most superstitious Giant might believe that fate switched sides. At least for an afternoon.
LEAD: A LEADING manufacturer of asbestos has decided that, when it comes to litigation, a strong offense can be a powerful defense.

LEAD: New York City reasserted its claim to literary pre-eminence yesterday, as tens of thousands of books and several hundred thousand of their devotees thronged onto a half-mile of Fifth Avenue and adjacent blocks for the 10th annual New York Is Book Country street festival. More than 160 publishers and booksellers displayed and sold their wares on the avenue, from 48th to 57th Streets, and four noted authors spoke at a literary brunch at the Plaza Hotel.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ida W. Richard, a philanthropist who was active in charities in New York and Cleveland, died Friday at the Margaret Wagner Nursing Home in Cleveland. She had a severe stroke in early 1987. She was 86 years old and lived in Cleveland.

LEAD: The New York City Opera's solid production of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' took on a share of magic at the Saturday matinee performance at the New York State Theater when Sheryl Woods joined the cast in the title role. This was the soprano's first Lucia with the company, but there was not the slightest tentativeness in her performance.

LEAD: SOME of the best tennis lessons you'll ever get about how to play and win matches are those you see during a major championship. Three matches at this year's United States Open were fine examples of, for lack of a more positive phrase, how not to lose a match. In two cases, the student lost, and in one case, the student won.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The terms of a financing package for Brazil through 1989 have been reached with 16 commercial banks, and the agreements are scheduled to be signed on Thursday, a representative of the banks said yesterday.

LEAD: American officials said today that the coup in Haiti may have been a response to the breakdown of public order and the re-emergence of the Tontons Macoute, a paramilitary security force suspected of savage attacks on a church in Port-au-Prince earlier this month.
LEAD: It is report card time again for members of Congress, and some of them are not amused.

The obligation is dictated by the fact that the cold war, with the arms race as its most characteristic expression, has become the greatest threat to

LEAD: Just when the University of Miami seemed certain to lose its top ranking in the national college football polls, when a 33-game regular-season winning streak appeared doomed and the Hurricanes were apparently headed for the third-worst defeat in the Jimmy Johnson era, the coach's pleadings came true.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Oscar Wilde could resist everything except temptation. University presidents, it seems, can resist everything except money. Last week came news that Carnegie Mellon University and Stanford University have invested in Next Inc., the computer company founded by Apple's Steven Jobs. Even Harvard, having resisted the apple for eight years, has finally succumbed: it proposes to raise $30 million by joining in a partnership to exploit the ideas of its medical school faculty.
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Hospital Corporation of America misattributed the estimate that a proposed buyout deal would require close to $5.4 billion in financing.

LEAD: Attention must now be paid to the Jets, who today crushed a playoff team for the second straight week. But this time, in a 45-3 rout of the Houston Oilers, they threw punches as well as footballs.

LEAD: Louis Quinn, a veteran gag writer turned character actor who became known to millions of television viewers as Roscoe the horse player on ''77 Sunset Strip,'' died Wednesday of lung cancer. He was 73 years old.
LEAD: Sometimes it's hard being a famous athlete . Ask Carl Lewis.
LEAD: Rick Davis, who has seen it happen before, said the United States soccer team is still naive about playing with a lead.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Carol Ruth Mann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mann of Chicago, and Howard Warren Helene, the son of Lillian Kingsley of the Bronx and the late Robert Helene, were married yesterday afternoon at their home in Ghent, N.Y. Rabbi Leslie Freedman performed the ceremony.

LEAD: RANDOM HOUSE's recent surprise purchase of Crown Publishers and McGraw-Hill's decision to get out of the trade book business are only the latest examples of the book publishing industry's march toward consolidation.
LEAD: The fire began in a department store and quickly spread through the historic Chiado district, a neighborhood of steep, narrow streets.

LEAD: Near the end of the first of two shows at the Bottom Line on Friday evening, Toni Childs requested that the lights in the house be extinguished while she lit a candle and sang ''Dreamer,'' a beautiful romantic lament from ''Union,'' her debut album. ''I sometimes run and chase the moon, I just can,'' the singer exclaimed in a half-strangulated shout against a crystalline electronic accompaniment suggesting an amplified autoharp.

LEAD: An article in SportsMonday Sept. 12 about the Phoenix Cardinals incorrectly attributed critical comments about the football team's departure from St. Louis to the editorial page of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. The comments appeared in a column in that newspaper's sports section.
LEAD: Landslide The Unmaking of the President, 1984-1988 By Jane Mayer and Doyle McManus Illustrated. 468 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $21.95.

LEAD: Rescue workers reported finding 90 drowning victims left behind by the floodwaters spawned by Hurricane Gilbert. But they said they may never know how many people were on the buses that washed away in a swollen riverbed Saturday.
LEAD: NL Industries announced Friday that it planned to undertake a restructuring in which its petroleum-services division would become a publicly held company.

LEAD: When they were students at the High School of Music and Art in the early 1960's, Leslie Dorsey and his classmates used to stride through Manhattan, singing arias and cantatas, their voices resonating between buildings and inside subway cars. It was as if the city was theirs.
LEAD: The United States, which had started badly in Olympic swimming, received a big boost today from 17-year-old Janet Evans, all 5 feet 6 inches and 105 pounds of her.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Police raided a social club north of Miami Saturday and arrested 175 people for taking part in gambling at a cockfight, a Metro-Dade police spokeswoman said. Seventy-five of the fighting birds were seized. The charges included gambling and partaking in the baiting or fighting of game cocks, midemeanors, and managing, promoting or directing a cockfight, a felony, said a police spokeswoman, Lucy Fitts.
LEAD: The leaders of Angola, Angola's neighbors and South Africa have agreed to meet in coming weeks to discuss peace in Angola, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said in an interview here today.
LEAD: The former No. 2 executive of Intelsat pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy to defraud the global satellite giant of $4.8 million.

LEAD: Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman and newly elected chief executive of BBDO New York, has appointed Gary de Paolo, 46, and Joseph Barrett, 53, managing directors, and Ted Sann, 43, and Charles Miesmer, 46, executive creative directors. All are already executive vice presidents and members of the New York board.

LEAD: Burton Benjamin, former vice president and director of CBS News, and a longtime documentary producer who wrote the report about the preparation of the controversial CBS television documentary critical of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, died of a brain tumor last night at his home in Scarborough, N.Y.

LEAD: Chris Miller passed for 130 yards and ran for Atlanta's third touchdown today in a 21-point second-period outburst that carried the Falcons to a 34-17 upset victory over the San Francisco 49ers.
LEAD: California's Attorney General, John Van de Kamp, has led inquiries on Asian gangs, drug peddlers and fraudulent AIDS remedies.

LEAD: One of the problems facing the millions of visitors who flock each year to the museums on the Mall is the lack of eating places, a situation alleviated somewhat with the opening last weekend of a huge restaurant at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum, which hopes to feed 9,000 visitors a day.
LEAD: A motorcyclist was dragged to his death when caught between two cars racing on the Bruckner Expressway in the South Bronx, the police said.

LEAD: At economic meetings starting this week in West Berlin, industrial nations are likely to call for the dollar's continued stability, to salute the world economy's good health and to promise more help for poorer countries, American and foreign officials say.
LEAD: A Man in the News article yesterday about Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, the new military leader of Haiti, misstated the year in which Leslie F. Manigat became President. It was this year.
LEAD: SOME retirees aged 60 and over have returned to the job market on a temporary basis, drawn by boredom, fears of rising inflation, a desire for extra money and attractive part-time wages.
LEAD: * American Medical International Inc., an operator of hospitals in the United States and abroad, appointed L. Stanton Tuttle as president and chief executive of AMI Psychiatric Inc., Houston.

LEAD: Diving Greg Louganis, who required four stitches in his scalp after hitting his head on the board yesterday during a dive in the preliminaries of the 3-meter springboard, got all the comfort he needed when the gold medal was wrapped around his neck today. It was the third gold medal of the American diver's career.

LEAD: Saying Haitians ''legitimately want proof'' that the army can ''work in permanent contact'' with civilians, the country's new military leader named a 12-member Cabinet that includes only one military officer. LEAD: It takes only a few moments into the overture to ''Maometto II'' to realize that Rossini was up to something beyond his then-accustomed scope. LEAD: In a letter to Arthur Schnitzler, written in 1906, the year after the premiere of ''Intermezzo,'' Sigmund Freud expressed his admiration for the playwright's intuitive discovery of ''that secret knowledge'' about ''psychological and erotic problems.'' Though less familiar than ''Anatol,'' ''La Ronde'' and other of Schnitzler's plays, ''Intermezzo'' is one of the playwright's more provocative examinations of modern marriage - as is clear in Gitta Honegger's production at the Yale Repertory Theater.

But the score by Rod Beauchamp, a linebacker for the Golden, Colo., school, should not have been permitted to stand, the historian, Steve Boda.

LEAD: When patriotism in America increases, the people at Annin & Company see a lot more red, white and blue.
LEAD: A handful of players trickled in and out of Giants Stadium this morning. Most of them were treating minor bumps and bruises and stretching sore muscles.

LEAD: Two Sports in One The game is a combination of soccer and basketball, played indoors on a varnished hardwood floor, with six players and a goalie on each side. The object is to throw the ball, which is about the size of a cantelloupe, into the goal, either in the air or on a bounce. Players dribble, pass and shoot with their hands, and cannot shoot from closer than 6 meters from the goal.

LEAD: GYMNASTICS The exercises may have been optional, but the rest of the competition had little choice but to watch in admiration as the Soviet Union won the gold medal in the men's team competition. The Soviet athletes, the dominant force in men's gymnastics, put on a stunning display of individual talent and collective strength, garnering at least one perfect score in five of the six events and three from Dmitri Bilozerchev as they easily outpointed East Germany, which took the silver.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: For days this week, more than 60 sailboats have marched up and down Cayuga Lake, the longest of the Finger Lakes and the body of water that borders this bucolic city in upstate New York.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had opened a kidnapping inquiry based on a couple's charge that their healthy baby was swapped for a child with a heart defect in a hospital nursery nearly a decade ago.

LEAD: Steve Walsh, the Miami junior who passed for a career-high 335 yards and 3 touchdowns to rally the top-ranked Hurricanes to a 31-30 victory over Michigan last Saturday, has led Miami to 14 straight victories as a starting quarterback. But as Bernie Kosar did in 1985, Walsh is considering the possibility of forgoing his final year of eligibility as a fifth-year senior to turn professional.
LEAD: Reams of copy offering sage advice on debating technique will be directed at both candidates before they climb into the arena in Winston-Salem this Sunday. Not in this space.

LEAD: Hundreds of jubilant residents spilled into the streets here Tuesday to celebrate Costa Rica's first Olympic Games medal, the silver won by Silvia Poll in the women's 200-meter freestyle swimming race.

LEAD: The archaic low-technology turnstiles of the New York City subway - built mostly in the 1930's and 40's to collect five-cent fares - are being plundered as never before by organized gangs and individual thieves who cruise the system and break the aging mechanisms faster than the Transit Authority can keep them repaired.

LEAD: A private development company said today that it had purchased 96,000 acres in the Adirondack Park, an announcement that embarrassed state officials because New York State had planned to acquire much of the land as wilderness.

LEAD: Matt Biondi broke an Olympic record today and moved closer to his fourth swimming medal in four events. Chris Jacobs, so disgusted with his cocaine addiction that he almost committed suicide two years ago, held an Olympic record for six minutes until Biondi broke it. And Janet Evans moved toward the second of her projected three gold medals.

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it planned to lease a closed aircraft plant in Columbus, Ohio, to produce parts for its C-17 transport plane. The plant will eventually employ 2,000 workers.

LEAD: LISA HEISER knows that in the next nine months she will see a lot of very anxious college students and, occasionally, hear from upset and frustrated parents. As director of the career development office at the University of Minnesota College of Liberal Arts, Ms. Heiser helps students figure out how they can earn a living once they're through with school.

LEAD: There was a time when players would travel to a tournament and be content to play bridge for 7 hours in each 24. Nowadays, however, many enthusiasts choose to add morning or late-night games, or even both, to the normal afternoon and evening sessions. Team events are popular, in part because a group with five or six members is slightly better off in terms of sleep.

LEAD: Solid Brass, an ensemble composed mainly of players in New York's dance and opera orchestras, played a concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon and proved itself not only virtuosic but also imaginative. In a suite of medieval pieces that opened the concert and in a Wagner excerpt that began the second half, the 11 players were deployed in several groups -onstage, in the wings and in the hall's corridors - but their coordination was unfailingly precise.

LEAD: Personal bankruptcy documents filed here by William Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt offer glimpses into the assets now held by the two Texans who once controlled enough oil, real estate, silver and sugar to make them among the world's wealthiest men.

LEAD: Pilots and the airline industry are controlled by the Federal Aviation Administration. Nuclear power plants are overseen by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Teachers, barbers, accountants, architects and electricians need licenses or certificates to work in most states.

LEAD: The trapped housewife was replaced by superwoman, who somehow managed to rear her children while catapulting ahead in a career. Now, with legions of superwomen worn out and discontented, a new model has been suggested for married professional women: ''the sequencer.'' Some experts are already warning that the sequencer is just another doomed variation of women trying to do it all.

LEAD: Israeli troops fired live ammunition and plastic bullets today to put down widespread Palestinian unrest, including an attack by masked, ax-wielding youths. Twenty-four Palestinians were wounded, Arab hospital officials said.

LEAD: Last December, Robert Townsend got his very own television special. Now, using basically the same format, HBO is presenting, taped, ''Take No Prisoners: Robert Townsend and His Partners in Crime II.

LEAD: As the final leg of a restructuring begun last October, First Interstate Bancorp plans to spin off $400 million in problem loans into a separate entity, the company said today. After this move, $20 billion in poorly performing assets will have been swept from the company's books.

LEAD: Entering the final days of an exhaustive yearlong campaign, the Episcopal Diocese of New York is preparing to select a successor to its Bishop, the Right Rev. Paul Moore, since 1970 a New York institution with a national reputation.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It does not take long before the initial amusement that overtakes a visitor to an exhibition of quirky kinetic sculptures by Rebecca Horn disappears, and a sense of considerable unease takes over. Entitled ''An Art Circus,'' it is a show not of clowns and prancing horses but of lion tamer's whips and high-wire suspense.

LEAD: For weeks, senior Democrats have been saying it privately: Although the Dukakis campaign has finally begun to lift itself out of its August torpor, the effort has failed to reach out to Democratic leaders across the nation. And it's hurting Mr. Dukakis. Now, some Democrats are saying so publicly.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Tickets for the Knicks' two home exhibition games and the first 19 home regular-season games will go on sale at Madison Square Garden and all Ticket Master sites next Tuesday at 10 A.M.

LEAD: Are Soviet-American relations taking a new turn, owing to the much- celebrated changes now stirring the Soviet Union? ''Global Rivals,'' a thoughtful four-part series that begins tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, sets out to address the question with a review of the beginnings of the Cold War and the competition of the superpowers ever since.

LEAD: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, a holding company for energy concerns, elected William R. Hutchinson treasurer, replacing James E. Allard, who was named senior vice president for finance at Amoco Canada in Calgary, Alberta.

LEAD: A five-alarm fire roared through a drugstore under construction in the Haight-Ashbury District Wednesday with heat so intense that paint on buildings across the street caught fire. The blaze, two blocks from Golden Gate Park, forced residents of several apartments to flee. No injuries were reported.

LEAD: Sheldon Coleman, chairman of the Coleman Company, the family enterprise that created the Coleman lantern, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the Wesley Medical Center in Wichita, Kan., after complications from lupus, a skin disease. He was 86 years old and lived in Wichita.

LEAD: The landmark 1986 tax revision increased the total taxes paid by 250 of the nation's largest corporations by $9 billion last year, but 16 of the corporations surveyed legally paid no Federal income tax, a private research group said today.
LEAD: Doug Baldwin will play guitar solos, with tape loops, tonight at 9 at Lunch for Your Ears, 25 Prince Street (941-1774). Admission is free.
LEAD: Brute force appears to be succeeding in Burma, at least for the moment, in cowing a population that had begun prematurely to sense victory over its Government.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency announced a broad strategy today to cope with what it called a ''staggering'' garbage crisis, setting a target of reducing the nation's solid waste by 25 percent within four years through recycling and other methods .
LEAD: At least 22 black trade unionists and anti-apartheid organizers have been detained and the activities of five others have been restricted in a nationwide security crackdown this week.

LEAD: All the improvements in New York subway service brought by Robert Kiley and David Gunn are imperiled by a new trend: seizure of turnstiles by thieves and thugs. The heads of the Transit Authority need to respond as forcefully as they did to the defacing of cars with graffiti.

LEAD: The Federal Government posted a $23.08 billion deficit for August, up almost 6 percent from a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.

LEAD: Outside, under a setting sun, the faithful at Fenway Park rose together and cheered; the Yankees had been left in a heap. Inside, the Boston Red Sox gathered in the comfort of their clubhouse and smiled. If there had been champagne somewhere, corks surely would have popped.

LEAD: Prowling a cabaret stage, wearing a sorcerer's robe embellished with stars and moons, the magician Jeff McBride is definitely not David Copperfield: clean-cut is hardly the description that leaps to mind. It is instantly apparent, too, that this magician is no cheery Doug Henning, as he peers through a forbidding whiteface mask and performs a show dense with drama, mystery and occult symbolism.

LEAD: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, today categorically denied that he had revealed classified intelligence information this week when he told reporters that Congress had ''clear testimony'' that the Central Intelligence Agency was inciting opposition activities in Nicaragua.

LEAD: Before the American weight lifters came to Seoul, they gathered in a Los Angeles hotel room to drink beer and have their hair cut. A barber came to the room, set up shop in the bathroom and gave each of them the same punk coif, long on top, bristly on the sides. The lifters wanted the barber to cut little barbell-shaped patterns in their hair, but he told them he did not have the tools for custom work.

LEAD: The Army and a Congressional committee are investigating whether the Unisys Corporation illegally supplied computers to the National Guard in 1986 without having received a valid order for the equipment, committee officials say.

LEAD: A suspenseful, brutal and tautly told tale measures up to the title of the film ''Murder One,'' which opens today at the Cine Twinand other theaters. It is a drama based on the cold-blooded killing of seven people in 1973 during a wild journey through the South by three brothers and their friend.
LEAD: Three games into the season, Lionel Manuel has emerged as one of the National Football Conference's most productive receivers.

LEAD: Patrick Swayze, lately of ''Dirty Dancing,'' gets a chance in ''Tiger Warsaw'' to be brooding and boyish, soulful and shaky and to show off his chest. He plays a fellow in his early 30's who returns home 15 years after having made a mess of the family household and tries to pick up the pieces. What the young Charles (Tiger) Warsaw did, we gather through quick flashbacks, was shoot his dad after being caught peeping at his sister, who was in her undies at the time.

LEAD: W. R. Higginbotham, a former correspondent and news executive for United Press, died Wednesday at District of Columbia General Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Fort Worth.

LEAD: In recent years, seafood prices have jumped higher than dolphins at a Florida marine park. Almost extinct are the clattering old-fashioned fish houses, where simple, grilled fillets (usually dyed with paprika) were served up with a salad, boiled potatoes and cole slaw. Today's seafood restaurants are more likely to be genteel places with French or Italian accents and princely prices.

LEAD: Patty Hearst, a k a Tania, a member of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army, and two of her S.L.A. comrades sit on a bed in an anonymous Los Angeles motel room and watch a ''live'' telecast as the police storm their S.L.A. hideout in another part of the city. Everyone in the house is finally killed.

LEAD: Combining the elegance of a prima ballerina with the stunts of a circus acrobat, Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union commanded perfect 10s from the judges in the floor exercise and vault today to win the women's individual all-around gold medal in gymnastics.

LEAD: Roy Kinnear, a British actor best known for his comic roles, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Ruber International Hospital in Madrid after falling from a horse. He was 54 years old and lived in London.
LEAD: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that he would appear on the November ballot in Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey and Pennsylvania as a candidate for President.

LEAD: The sleek, icy elegance of ''Dead Ringers,'' David Cronenberg's film about twin gynecologists teetering on the brink of madness, is unexpected. Both the director, whose past films include the much gorier ''Scanners'' and ''Videodrome,'' and the highly unusual subject suggest a more lurid approach.

LEAD: The plays presented in the annual Young Playwrights Festival have often dealt with young people going through rites of passage. In this season's festival (at Playwrights Horizons) there are indications that, at age 7, the series itself has reached its artistic maturity. Each of the three new playwrights whose works are produced demonstrates a definite theatrical talent, as well as an ability to treat perceptively such subjects as religion, sex and suicide.

LEAD: Twenty years ago, leaders from three New York counties joined with three Pennsylvania counties across the border to take advantage of a new Federal grant program. They formed a regional health-planning agency, NY-Penn. Key goals were reducing health-care costs by preventing the overbuilding of hospital beds in the area and making sure that local hospitals planned care for their share of the poor.

LEAD: Jim Wright charges the Reagan Administration with conducting covert operations in Nicaragua that would provoke the Sandinistas into acts of repression. The aim of this policy, he says, is to undermine the Sandinista Government and undercut the peace negotiations with the contras.
LEAD: A former Mexican police officer was found guilty by a Federal jury today in the 1985 kidnapping and murder of a United States drug law-enforcement agent.
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered airlines today to equip all their planes with devices that will help pilots detect and escape from deadly shifts in the wind.

LEAD: The United States decided today to halt $12 million in aid to Burma to underline its displeasure over the shooting of unarmed protesters by the country's armed forces, a State Department official said.
LEAD: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: The House today overwhelmingly passed drug legislation embodying a range of civil penalties for people who use relatively small amounts of illegal drugs. The vote was 375 to 30, with 27 members not voting.

LEAD: Does it make any difference who's elected President in November? Of course it does, but not perhaps on as broad a range of issues as the candidates and their most fervent supporters would have you believe.

''Kansas'' sets itself up as a suspense story entangled with the people and values of America's heartland. Here is what happens in one supposedly sleepy little town. A wheat field-wholesome young man named Wade (Andrew McCarthy) is on his way to New York City. After his car burns up, he jumps on a freight train where he meets a drifter named Doyle (Matt Dillon) and is so unfazed by his sinister looks - the gold tooth and the panther tattooed on his forearm might have made most folks suspicious - that he hops off the train with his new friend. Following Doyle's lead, the impressionable Wade breaks into a house, goes to a parade where he spots the girl of his dreams and robs a bank. But while he is fleeing the bank, a car carrying the Governor's small daughter falls into the river, so Wade saves the child from drowning, runs away and hides the money - all this before lunchtime. Soon he finds work at a farm owned by the father of the girl of his dreams, a convenient place to roll in the hay, literally, while the town searches for the mystery hero. The plot slows down after that, but does not get less incredible. The characters never become intriguing, though we're supposed to wonder about Wade's moral direction when he hangs onto the money, lies to Doyle and is uncovered as the hero.

Mota, who finished third at the Los Angeles Games in 1984, completed the course in 2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds.

When Iran announced last week that its forces would begin clearing mines, an American official said that was ''tantamount to admitting that they laid the mines'' during the eight-year-old war with Iraq.

LEAD: No matter who wins the Presidential election, a cure to the woeful financial shape of the nation's savings industry has moved to the forefront among the issues that Congress and the next President must tackle upon taking office.

LEAD: Vice President Bush led Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts in two polls released today, and one of them, by NBC News and The Wall Street Journal, showed that one of Mr. Bush's greatest advantages over the Democratic Presidential nominee was on the issue of the national defense.

LEAD: A man ''who never said a word'' shot and killed two people in an auto parts store here today, then fatally wounded a police officer and a custodian at a nearby school before the police killed him.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Yonkers will have to establish a ''compelling need'' for a church-owned piece of property before condeming it for use as low-income housing in a desegregation plan.

LEAD: Lucien Obed Hooper, a retired securities analyst who was known as the dean of Wall Street market-letter writer, died of heart failure Monday at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

LEAD: After asking Seoul's 10 million citizens to reduce traffic congestion during the Olympic Games by alternating the days they drove their cars, Mayor Kim Yong Nae switched the license plates on his car so that he could be on the road every day.

LEAD: Bobby Ojeda sat in his hospital room yesterday and remembered how it happened: He was shearing the hedges with an electric clipper about 11:15 Wednesday morning, happy and healthy, earning $750,000 at the age of 30 and scheduled to pitch the fourth game of the playoff for the Mets.

LEAD: As chairman and founder of System Integrators Inc., a leading maker of electronic publishing systems, James P. Lennane has been one of the computer industry's most feisty and flamboyant executives. He once took the floor for three minutes at a meeting of shareholders of the Eastman Kodak Company to attack the company for throwing away money on its subsidiary Atex Inc., his archrival for big sales to newspapers and magazines.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Soviet troops were deployed in Armenia. They sealed off official buildings and several central squares in the latest move to contain spreading ethnic unrest in two Soviet republics. Page A1

LEAD: The Lebanese Parliament failed to meet today to elect a successor to President Gemayel and put off the session for 24 hours to allow time to break a deadlock over the succession and resolve its crisis.

LEAD: ''They break their legs in half, they break everything. These people struggle a hell of a lot more than the able-bodied athletes.'' - David Balsey, track coach, on American amputee athletes headed for Seoul. [ B2:2. ]

LEAD: Tom Brookens hit a two-run double to highlight a four-run fourth inning as the Detroit Tigers pulled within 4 1/2 games of first place in the American League East by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 7-4.

LEAD: When Sigourney Weaver, as the naturalist Dian Fossey, is first seen arriving in Africa, she towers over everyone else in view. A trim, impatient, utterly confident white woman, she is instantly at home giving orders to the impoverished black tribesmen who gather around her. This supreme self-assurance of Miss Weaver's, sometimes less than helpful in other films, is perfect for ''Gorillas in the Mist,'' the story of a smart, determined, well-bred and physically commanding woman who brooks no frailty in others.

LEAD: ''The humanities may not receive as much attention as politics but they are alive and well in Washington,'' Hermione de Almeida said from her study in the Smithsonian Institution's red sandstone castle on the Mall.

LEAD: The authorities deployed troops and armored vehicles today in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, in the latest move to contain spreading ethnic unrest in two Soviet republics.

His repertory will consist largely of songs about New York. The festivities are sponsored by several preservationist organizations.

LEAD: For the second time in three months, Honeywell Inc. has surprised investors with news of substantial write-offs. With Tuesday's announcement, the Minneapolis-based manufacturer conceded that its earnings for the year would decline as a result.

LEAD: Federal financing for the Legal Services Corporation, which provides lawyers for the poor, has diminished since President Reagan took office. In 1981, Washington appropriated $321 million; in 1988, after seven years of inflation, the figure was $306 million. In its Oct. 1 issue, The A.B.A. Journal asked the Presidential candidates what they view as the proper balance between programs like the Legal Services Corporation and the use of private lawyers who volunteer their time.
LEAD: This is a story about American athletic heroes from the New York metropolitan region and their hopes for victory in Seoul, South Korea.

LEAD: Israel is offering more than $4.8 billion of Government trust certificates in four parts through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as lead manager and Salomon Brothers Inc. as co-lead manager.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds increased $654.2 million, to $267.24 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds rose $496.9 million, to $69.06 billion. The 223 general purpose funds fell $102.4 million, to $84.82 billion.

LEAD: Vice President Bush swooped into Michael S. Dukakis's territory today to revel in the endorsement of a Boston police union, but Mr. Dukakis counterpunched by mustering law-enforcement officials from around the nation for a red-white-and-blue rally on the Statehouse lawn.
LEAD: To get more life into his Columbia team, Coach Larry McElreavy will start three more sophomores tomorrow against Lafayette at Baker Field, bringing to seven the sophomores in the lineup.

LEAD: Vice President Bush proposed tonight that the United States seek to counter the Soviet Union's advantage in conventional forces by not matching Moscow ''bullets for bullets'' but by more effective strategic planning that would take advantage of this country edges in technology and some weapon systems.

LEAD: E. Stewart Jones Jr. of Troy, N.Y., an attorney representing Dave Pallone, has confirmed that the former National League umpire was questioned yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., as part of an investigation of a sex ring involving teen-age boys. ''There is an investigation under way. The D.A.'s office has not confirmed or denied that, but in fact it is involved,'' Jones said.

LEAD: Fencing Simple yet Complex Game It is a simple game to understand, but a difficult one to master: touch your opponent and avoid being touched. Five touches decide a match in early rounds, 10 in later rounds. Bouts are fought on a piste, a strip of metallic mesh 2 meters wide and 14 meters long for foil and 2 meters by 18 meters for epee and sabre.

LEAD: The huge man shot down as he raged murderously in St. Patrick's Cathedral Wednesday evening was described yesterday as a severely disoriented street dweller who had been arrested at least 11 times and hospitalized as a mental patient 7 times.

LEAD: The Presidential campaigns of Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis agreed today on whom they would allow to ask questions Sunday night at their first debate.
LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that its board had named Robert J. Vlasic to succeed William S. Cashel Jr. as chairman.

LEAD: An agency of the nation's largest Protestant denomination has decided to stop distributing the Surgeon General's report on AIDS because it does not reflect the group's conviction that only heterosexual relations within marriage are moral.

LEAD: HOPING for a takeover battle, some Wall Street traders several months ago loaded up on shares of West Point-Pepperell, the big Georgia textile company. Now they are worried that Pepperell may not be a takeover target after all.

LEAD: Carl Frederick Farbach, a retired lawyer and former Federal counsel, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Sept. 15 at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 87 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, came to South Africa today and offered his assurances that the United Nations would be impartial in assisting with the transition of Namibia to independence.

LEAD: GYMNASTICS: Yelena Shoushounova of the Soviet Union, with a perfect 10 in the vault, won the women's all-around gold. She edged Daniela Silivas of Rumania by .025 point. TRACK: Jackie Joyner-Kersee set an Olympic record in the first event of the heptathlon, the 100-meter hurdles. Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson, the world record-holder, reached the 100-meter dash semifinals.

LEAD: A new button appeared Thursday on Capitol Hill: ''President Quayle.''

LEAD: Yes, you can have a sumptuous buffet without driving everybody's cholesterol level right through the Capitol dome, maintains Public Voice for Food & Health Policy, a consumer research organization here.

LEAD: As Emperor Hirohito lay seriously ill, Japan filed a formal diplomatic protest in London today over items in the British press that called the monarch ''a worse butcher than Hitler'' and said that ''he will surely be guaranteed a special place in hell.''

LEAD: The space agency said today that the proper nozzle inlet rings were in the rockets attached to the space shuttle even thought it had been discovered that an outdated ring was used in the final test of the redesigned booster rocket for the shuttle.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has announced that the Loves Park Federal Savings Bank of Loves Park, Ill., has been acquired by the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rockford, Ill. Loves Park is the 106th troubled savings institution to be disposed of this year. Home Federal received $4.9 million in assistance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a badly needed victory today when it beat out the Boeing Company for most of a huge aircraft order from Delta Air Lines.

LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would consider easing rules covering purchases of 10 percent or less of a company's stock.

''It could be a final flowering like the Austrian Empire when things were about to go under, or France before the French Revolution,'' Mr.

LEAD: Over the objections of the Reagan Administration, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved legislation today that would impose economic sanctions on Iraq as a penalty for the use of chemical weapons against Kurdish guerrillas.

LEAD: Nine people were injured when a metal piece from an engine sheared off a Pan Am Express airplane and punctured the skin of the aircraft as it approached the Albany County Airport Wednesday night, officials said yesterday.
LEAD: Dr. Seymour R. Kaplan, a professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his office in the Bronx. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: ''THIS is the renaissance of the Middle Ages,'' proclaimed City Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern, whose department is co-sponsoring a fanciful foray into the 15th century on Sunday in Fort Tryon Park in upper Manhattan.

LEAD: Wearing the purple vestments of a Mass for forgiveness, John Cardinal O'Connor strode rapidly up and down the aisles of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, sprinkling holy water throughout the church in which two men were killed the evening before.
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh tonight accused the American Civil Liberties Union of adopting a ''political agenda'' that led him to resign from the organization sometime ago.

LEAD: After months of a backstage struggle for control of the world's largest luxury-goods conglomerate, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, shareholders today accepted the nomination of a 12-member supervisory board that will name a new management board on Monday.

LEAD: In a long-awaited document on women's issues, Pope John Paul II will reaffirm his opposition to the ordination of women as priests, Vatican officials said today. The text is to be issued next week. The Pope also offers a vigorous defense of women's dignity as equal to men's, the officials said. The document was described by the officials as a theological and anthropological meditation on the roles that women play in the Roman Catholic Church and in secular society.

LEAD: Coach Vince Dooley and his Georgia team were not too pleased when they escaped with a 42-35 triumph over Mississippi State last week. It should have been easier for the undefeated Bulldogs, who are thinking of a Southeastern Conference championship.

LEAD: ROBERT S. STRAUSS, the veteran Texas lawyer who serves as co-chairman of the bipartisan National Economic Commission, set off a storm this week when, at a Washington monetary conference, he disclosed his thinking about the combination of tax increases and cuts in military outlays and in Social Security and other entitlement programs required to eliminate the

LEAD: Haiti suffered through another coup last weekend only to sink into new turmoil. One general had barely replaced another when soldiers mutinied, workers struck and killing returned to the streets. Yet the soldiers who engineered the coup appear to share with the public a wish to rid Haiti of the brutal, arrogant daily lawlessness.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When Bobby Watson, the 35-year-old alto saxophonist appearing at the Village Vanguard this weekend, plays, he might as well be driving a gospel audience to salvation. He's an old-style burner, someone who manages to turn every solo into an uproarious event. Hunched over, he'll send blues phrases reeling into the audience; be-bop trickery shows up, and everything he plays swings.

LEAD: In his current exhibition at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery, Kenny Scharf sets out on a new path as a painter. It's not an entirely untrammeled path - in fact, it's rather trammeled -nor is it certain that these new paintings aren't transitional. Nonetheless, it is always encouraging to see an artist set aside a successful style before it becomes old hat and yet remain true to it at heart, and this is what the 29-year-old Mr.

LEAD: Susan Sarandon, Jeff Daniels and Elizabeth Perkins play residents of a small, picturesque, rather too ingrown Vermont village in ''Sweet Hearts Dance,'' and Don Johnson is there, too. So there arise some blunt but inevitable questions: can Mr. Johnson hold his own in this company? Has television stardom made him too much of a commodity to fit comfortably into an ensemble film like this?
LEAD: Military Regime in Lebanon

LEAD: Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader who lost control of a Democratic judicial district convention last year, staved off another challenge last night and succeeded in nominating three of his choices for the State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

LEAD: Though David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow'' and David Henry Hwang's ''M. Butterfly'' were among the most highly acclaimed productions of last season, the praise was balanced, at times even drowned out, by dissonant strains of ridicule. Gregory Mosher, the director of ''Speed-the-Plow,'' took his lumps for the seemingly hypocritical casting of Madonna in a play that mocks the kind of cynical Hollywood moguls who wouldn't think twice about casting Madonna as Eleanor Roosevelt.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Harness Racing

LEAD: Southeast Asian nations, suspecting that the well-armed and brutal Khmer Rouge are preparing to seize control of Cambodia again, are planning new action at this year's United Nations General Assembly aimed at forestalling a Khmer Rouge return to sole power, according to diplomats from these countries.

LEAD: As Vice President Bush and Governor Dukakis curtail campaigning and prepare for their nationally televised 90-minute debate Sunday in Winston-Salem, N.C., both sides are looking toward that all-important post-debate spin. That is, sending high-profile surrogates into the press room to feed reporters and tell them that their candidate was, well, nothing short of Lincolnesque.
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. suffered several court setbacks yesterday in its defense against the huge securities fraud case filed earlier this month by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The banking industry's quest to win new securities powers suffered a severe setback today when a House committee voted to prohibit banks from underwriting corporate debt, corporate equities and mutual funds.

LEAD: Four suspects in the killing of a 19-year-old man and the wounding of an 18-year-old woman in Brooklyn Wednesday were released yesterday. The police recovered a 9-millimeter pistol, which they believe was used to shoot Robert Nepolitano of Brooklyn and Lisa Ciullo, also of Brooklyn, who was hit in the leg.
LEAD: Reagan Administration officials today continued to call for presidential elections in Lebanon despite the appointment of a military Government.

LEAD: Amid continuing questions over the chain of command in the Haitian military, diplomats and soldiers here agreed today that the situation was gradually returning to normal, five days after a coup led by noncommissioned officers.

LEAD: State officials and nationally recognized authorities on AIDS who met in New York City yesterday failed to resolve the dispute over the number of New Yorkers infected with the deadly virus, but all agreed that services are woefully deficient and must be expanded to meet the growing caseload.

LEAD: The state official in charge of enforcing New York City's rent-control and rent-stabilization laws was arrested yesterday in Manhattan on bribery and grand larceny charges stemming from an undercover operation organized by the Manhattan District Attorney.

LEAD: A dividend listing in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the value of the regular quarterly stock dividend declared by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Stockholders of record on Oct. 1 will receive 82 cents a share on Oct. 25.
LEAD: Pertti Karppinen, the Finnish singles sculler who is a three-time Olympic champion, won his race in the consolation finals of Olympic rowing Friday. It placed him seventh in the competition.

LEAD: NBC's ratings for the Olympic Games have been so disappointing during the first week that the network yesterday began the process of ''make-goods'' for most of its more than 70 sponsors. That is the industry term for free advertising to compensate for lower-than-projected ratings.

LEAD: It hasn't been Pepa's day, or even week. Ivan, her longtime lover and a male-chauvinist rat, walks out on her, leaving only a bland message on her answering machine. Planning suicide, Pepa spikes a blenderful of garden-fresh gazpacho with sleeping pills, but forgets to drink it.

LEAD: The Jets and the Detroit Lions, who face each other Sunday in Pontiac, Mich., have played only four times since the realignment of the National Football League in 1970. The last time was on Thanksgiving Day in 1985, and Jet memories are dim.
LEAD: Hollywood loves comebacks.

LEAD: William J. McCarthy, president of Kroch's & Brentano, the oldest and largest bookstore chain in Chicago, died Tuesday of complications resulting from a liver transplant at the University of Chicago Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Evanston.
LEAD: Twins in Toronto
LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the overwhelming favorite in the heptathlon, got off to a record-breaking start today in quest of the Olympic gold medal that barely eluded her in 1984.
LEAD: The Ordinaires, an instrumental rock band, will perform tonight at 9 and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $8.

LEAD: It's that time of year again: horses with mediocre form in Europe are piling onto airplanes to plunder America's richest grass races. This year, even more than in the past, they are likely to come away with most of the booty, beginning with the $596,000 Man o' War Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.
LEAD: The Xerox Credit Corporation, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, tapped the corporate debt market yesterday with a $100 million issue of notes due 1993.

For each 100 shares in the existing company, stockholders will receive 22 shares in the new Henley Group, as well as one-half share that will be redeemed in cash.

LEAD: Robert Strauss, the prominent Democrat, was speaking simple truth. The way to shrink big budget deficits, he said, is to look for savings in the biggest programs, ''because that's where the money is.'' He hinted that the National Economic Commission, of which he is co-chairman, might cast its eye on Social Security.

LEAD: ''Manifest Destiny: An Evening of Yankee Panky,'' is a musical comedy about United States involvement in the Philippines at the turn of the century, written by someone with definite expertise on the subject. Raul S. Manglapus, the Secretary of Foreign Affairs of the Philippines, wrote the work in 1974 during a self-imposed exile in the United States.

LEAD: Commuters come and commuters go, but the Grateful Dead has endured for more than 20 years, pursued by a hardy group of followers called Deadheads. And for the last 10 days, those followers, who wear their hair long and their shirts tie-dyed, have been lounging around Penn Station.

LEAD: Maximilien Cardinal de Furstenberg, former head of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Eastern Churches, has died in a clinic in his native Belgium, the Vatican reported today. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: Kathleen Collins Prettyman, a film maker, playwright and professor of film history and production at the City College of New York, died of cancer Sunday at Memorial Hospital. She was 46 years old and lived in Nyack, N.Y.

LEAD: Doug Williams, the Redskins' quarterback hospitalized in Arlington, Va., after undergoing an emergency appendectomy, anticipates returning to the lineup by late October. ''Hopefully, in three or four weeks I'll be practicing and in five weeks I'll be playing again,'' Williams said.(AP)
LEAD: Jose Canseco of the Oakland Athletics became the first major league player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases in the same season. Page 53.

LEAD: In an effort to address the growing crisis in the savings industry, the Senate today passed legislation that would create a national commission to study how to bail out the beleaguered Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

LEAD: Rod G. Martin of San Jose, Calif., has invented a polyurethane football that is lighter and softer than a standard pigskin. Designed primarily for young players who have trouble gripping and passing a standard ball, Mr. Martin's ball comes with a set of curved grooves in which players can plant their fingers for passing.

LEAD: Niels Lan Doky on piano, Niels Henning Orsted-Pedersen on bass and Billy Hart on drums will play trios tonight and tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight, at 8 and 10 P.M. tomorrow. There is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

LEAD: South Africa said today that it would allow a United Nations technical team into Namibia to start planning the deployment of United Nations military and civilian personnel there once the territory's transition to independence begins.

Fiorentino of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Fiorentino, was married yesterday to William Harrison Givens 3d, the assistant manager of pension underwriting for Mutual of America Life Insurance Company in New York.

LEAD: Bond prices showed only a slight decline yesterday after drops in both oil and gold prices spurred a recovery in late trading.

LEAD: A court-martial today convicted a Navy instructor of negligent homicide in the drowning of a panic-stricken recruit who was forced under water in a training exercise here last winter. He was also found guilty of conspiracy to commit battery.

LEAD: Fresh from a month's vacation, Mikhail Gorbachev has launched his second major initiative toward Asia. His speech last week in Siberia, like his 1986 Vladivostok address, featured some headline-grabbing hokum. But it also had other layers and audiences. Together with other recent gestures, the speech affirms his eagerness to strengthen Soviet ties in Asia much as he has improved his relationships in the West.

LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc., a unit of the Campeau Corporation, has cast some doubt on its ability to repay the bank loans and interest payments used to finance its $6.6 billion acquisition earlier this year by the Toronto-based concern.
LEAD: A furor has erupted in Nicaragua over charges by the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, that the Central Intelligence Agency is manipulating opposition political parties here.
LEAD: Solving a 10-day-old Wall Street mystery, Coniston Partners said yesterday that it might seek to acquire TW Services Inc., a food services company based in New York.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's explanation of his reasons for resigning from the American Civil Liberties Union was disputed yesterday by a member of the group who was host of the 1969 meeting at which Mr. Thornburgh quit.

LEAD: Clowns, mimes, face painters, fortune tellers, musicians and rope jumpers will provide entertainment for children at the 1988 version of the Union Square Park Carnival, starting at noon today at Union Square Plaza, 17th Street between Broadway and Park Avenue South. The event will end at 5 P.M. with a parade.

LEAD: Mother Margarita Maria, a Roman Catholic nun who founded a religious order of Carmelite nuns and turned a farmhouse sanitarium into Santa Teresita Hospital here, died Wednesday. She was 85 years old. She became administrator of Santa Teresita after founding it as a tuberculosis sanitarium in 1930.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, expanding his effort to court black voters, has signed up the Rev. Jesse Jackson for radio advertisements and named a prominent Jackson aide to his staff of advisers, the Governor's Presidential campaign organization said today.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 1 about an American warning to the Soviet Union over a disputed radar station described the American complaint incorrectly. The Reagan Administration contends that the radar, near Krasnoyarsk, is not on the periphery of the Soviet Union and oriented outward, as such installations must be under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

Panic is such an unflappable pickpocket that he can steal a man's wallet and then stand there, switchblade in hand, rifling through the wallet's contents while silently daring the victim to challenge him.

But an occasion that in most places would be cause for national celebration is being treated gingerly by both church and state here.

LEAD: Senator Lloyd Bentsen today swung through the Middle Western territory of his Republican opponent, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, with a strong offensive on the issues of trade, Social Security and education.

LEAD: David Palmer, whose season with the Phillies ended Aug. 30 because of a torn rotator cuff, has had arthroscopic surgery on his ailing right shoulder and is expected to recuperate by the beginning of spring training. Bryan Harvey, a rookie right-handed relief pitcher with the Angels, has also undergone successful arthroscopic surgery to remove two bone chips in his right elbow.

LEAD: At Vice President Bush's mock debates at his Victorian home here, Richard Darman mimicked Michael Dukakis with relish. At the end of Wednesday's 90-minute session, Mr. Darman, the former Treasury Department official who is now an investment banker, reached behind a curtain in the dining room that had been converted into a studio.

LEAD: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia says he is tired of questions about his personal life and does not plan to answer any more questions about it as he campaigns for a seat in the United States Senate.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump will pay about $29 million more for the unfinished Taj Mahal hotel-casino and Merv Griffin will contribute an additional $25 million in equity when he buys Resorts International Inc., the two men announced late Thursday. The two moves taken together will increase the amount of cash and reduce the amount of debt that Resorts will have after the various transactions are completed.
LEAD: A second Bulgarian weight lifter was stripped of his gold medal today after tests showed he took a banned weight-loss drug, and Bulgaria then pulled its weightlifting team out of the Olympics.

LEAD: France and China this week approved marketing of a new drug that induces abortion early in pregnancy, and two family planning experts said they believed an American company would soon apply for permission to market the drug in the United States.
LEAD: ''Felix'' was conceived, it seems, as a somewhat solemn stunt of a movie but turns out to be a surprisingly jolly entertainment.

LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, a leader in Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign in the Farm Belt, said today that if Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's farm policies become law, the 1988 drought would ''look like a Sunday picnic.''

LEAD: A Sea World killer whale went into labor minutes before showtime today and delivered her baby to the shouts and cheers of thousands of people who witnessed the birth. Park officials knew that the mother was pregnant but the baby arrived about a month sooner than they had expected.

LEAD: The Government recently told Americans that their homes may be collecting dangerous amounts of odorless, tasteless, invisible radon gas, which causes about 20,000 lung cancer deaths a year in the United States. As disturbing as the warning was, communication specialists say most people will ignore it unless the message is reinforced with credible publicity and extensive education.

LEAD: Professional money managers have stepped up their emphasis on gold as part of a diversified investment portfolio. For the small investor, investments in gold can come in the form of mutual funds, gold stocks, coins or ingots. The rate of return can be attractive, but experts say fortunes change quickly and advise a conservative 5 percent investment in precious metals during stable economic periods to about 10 percent if inflation is heating up.

LEAD: Philip Glass has been accused, with some justification, of fulfilling his numerous commissions by cannibalizing his earlier material. Indeed, listening to the clusters of scores Mr. Glass unleashes periodically, one is often struck not only by the presence of the composer's trademark moves, but also by the fact that specific chord progressions and effects are frequently grafted from one work onto another and that harmonic turns that were striking in their original context seem lazily derivative the second or third time.
LEAD: Several people watched as a 36-year-old woman was raped under a commuter-train platform during rush hour, but nobody moved to help her, the police said today.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 248 to 150 by which the House of Representatives today approved tightened curbs on textile, apparel and shoe imports. LEAD: Few balls can do as much injury as a baseball. This week, a California company, Incrediball Inc., won patent approval for a softer, safer ball made with a core of densely packed polyu rethane foam. Incrediball says the ball will rebound almost as well as a regulation hard ball but is safe enough to use indoors and has never been known to cause an injury.
LEAD: Senate Democrats failed today on a second attempt to stop a Republican filibuster of a bill that would increase the minimum wage by $1.20 over the next three years, to $4.55.
LEAD: J. Turner Hunt, an aeronautical engineer at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, has invented a five-bladed boomerang that he says is easier to use than the original Australian type.

LEAD: Theodore and Cheryle Branch, a couple from nearby Summit Township who emigrated to the Soviet Union last fall when he could not find work, have returned to the United States, Mr. Branch's mother said today.
LEAD: The painstaking process of selecting jurors for the Bess Myerson trial ended yesterday with the seating of seven men and five women.

LEAD: The family of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, has allowed the Drug Enforcement Administration to use its Texas ranches and other properties in anti-drug operations, the agency said today.

LEAD: Certainly, Matt Biondi attracted attention in Olympic swimming tonight by winning his fifth medal (third gold) and anchoring the United States to a world record in the men's 400-meter freestyle relay.

LEAD: The Koch administration, already urging fiscal restraint on the City Council, said yesterday that New York City was facing a ''substantial decline'' in projected tax revenues. It said the decline may represent a threat to budgetary reserves and city programs.

He was Clement VII, a claimant to the papacy who sat in Avignon in the 14th century, a time of schism in the church. His claim to the papacy was disputed, and he has been widely considered an ''antipope.

LEAD: The Olympics haven't captured America's attention this year the way they did in 1984, and not just because NBC's cameras flit around too much. Seoul can't hope to duplicate the excitement, or the hype, of games at home in California. And U.S. athletes can't hope to match the gold they got when the Russians stayed away.

LEAD: A prime assailant in the Howard Beach racial attack was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail as the final step in a plea bargain in which he received leniency for cooperating with prosecutors.

LEAD: John Winters, the usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral who was killed in the church by a deranged man Wednesday night, used to regale and worry his wife with stories about ''weirdos'' coming into the cathedral from the streets, mumbling to themselves and trying to steal nickels and dimes from the collection box.

LEAD: Secretary of State George Shultz has promised to open America's doors to more refugees next year. This is welcome news, reaffirming the nation's commitment to help those seeking asylum. But there's a catch. Because Congress has already set a ceiling on financial aid, the new refugees will receive less help getting started than did many of their predecessors.
LEAD: With the Presidency vacant, a Christian-led Cabinet and a Moslem-led Cabinet each claimed to be the legitimate government of Lebanon today.

LEAD: State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn of Newburgh was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on five counts of mail and bank fraud after officials investigated allegations that the Senator had accepted campaign contributions from organized-crime figures.

LEAD: The price of oil fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with traders doubting the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will make any progress toward cutting production and raising prices.
LEAD: * Armor All Products Corp., Irvine, Calif., acquired the car-care division of Borden Inc., New York, for about $27 million.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the former Cabinet post of Drew Lewis. He was the Transportation Secretary.

LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service is trying to stop PTL's religious broadcasting because of financial problems.

LEAD: The room is dark except for the rows of small television monitors filling the front wall, making it look like a giant flashing checkerboard of bright images, blinking soundlessly: swimmers splashing, runners running, horses jumping, boxers punching. Eight or nine people mill about the room, chatting quietly and sometimes stopping to watch a small, harried-looking woman seated at a console with a telephone at her ear.
LEAD: It appeared today that Jeff Criswell is going to be the Jets' starter at left tackle against the Detroit Lions on Sunday.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve's chief policy-making body voted, 10 to 1, in mid-August to forgo further credit-tightening moves until it could study the effects of a series of previous anti-inflation measures, including a half-point increase in the discount rate just seven days earlier.

LEAD: A human brain will compete against an electronic one this weekend in a chess match at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. The Hitech computer, which can evaluate 165,000 chess positions a second and which has been ranked among the 100 top chess players in the United States, will accept the challenge of Arnold Denker, a chess grandmaster.

LEAD: When Angel Cordero Jr. was handed a 10-day suspension for careless riding in the closing days of the Saratoga meeting, the jockey immediately appealed the ruling and the ban was stayed. He said at the time that he was not merely trying to ride out the Saratoga meeting, where he eventually won his 13th riding title, but that he believed the suspension was unjust.

LEAD: Stuart Symington Janney Jr., one of the nation's leading horse breeders and the owner of Ruffian and Private Terms, was killed in an automobile accident Thursday while driving home to Locust Hill Farm in Glyndon, Md. He was 81 years old.
LEAD: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks remained at a strong level in mid-September, rising 9.9 percent from the comparable period last year.

LEAD: The City Manager today attributed the deaths of five firefighters here last July to a failure of government, agreeing with a report's finding that the five died needlessly when the roof of a burning car dealership collapsed.

LEAD: A witness to the shooting deaths of three unarmed Irish Republican Army members in March swore before a coroner's inquest today that British soldiers shot two of them as they raised their hands to surrender.

LEAD: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission plans to overhaul the electronic meters in the city's 11,787 yellow medallion cabs in an effort to cut down on overcharging, the commission's acting chairman said yesterday.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration proposed today that standardized absorbency testing and labeling for tampons be established to help women minimize the risk of toxic shock, a syndrome characterized by high fever, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness and rash.

LEAD: Track and Field Everything else had been broken -the world record, the Olympic mark, the American standard - so Ben Johnson completed the amazing collection of physical performances by cracking something really surprising: a smile. Johnson, the superb sprinter from Canada, left Carl Lewis in his tailwind and his world record in the past when he won the men's 100-meter dash in a breathtaking 9.79 seconds.
LEAD: Legislation intended to spur development of motor vehicles that can operate on fuels other than gasoline was passed by the House of Representatives today and sent to the White House.

LEAD: A 78-year-old Chicago man was deported to West Germany for concealing his pre-World War II service as a lieutenant colonel in the Nazi SS at two concentration camps, the Justice Department said today. Conrad Schellong, deported Thursday, had been the target of a 7 1/2-year legal effort by the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, which said he served in SS guard companies at the Sachsenburg and Dachau camps from 1934 to 1939.

LEAD: Different Strokes In the clean and jerk and the snatch, the bar must be held overhead for two seconds. In the snatch, the lifter cannot turn his wrists over until the bar is overhead, or extend his arms unevenly or incompletely. Top lifters can usually lift 100 pounds more in the clean and jerk than in the snatch.

The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly.

LEAD: Two past Olympic champions from the United States were defeated in their quest of another gold medal today. But their losses were balanced for the American team by the fact that they each lost to teammates setting Olympic records.

LEAD: The Pentagon is testing Soviet, Chinese and Warsaw Pact jets and other military equipment at a nearby air base to see how well they operate and what problems might turn up.

LEAD: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer. Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long. The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly.

LEAD: Beyond an enigmatic remark to a bewildered colleague and a few ambiguous lines about the mercies of his own forgetfulness, Paul de Man never expressed the slightest remorse for his eager little contribution to the intellectual underpinnings of the Nazi Holocaust.
LEAD: The Streetscapes column of Sept. 11 misstated the ownership of the Russian Tea Room and its building at 150 West 57th Street. The sole owner is Faith Stewart-Gordon.

LEAD: THE frustrations of modern life ''seem designed to generate quantities of anger,'' Dr. Willard Gaylin writes in ''The Rage Within -Anger in Modern Life'' - an observation anyone made late by a traffic jam might share. But expressing that anger is increasingly unacceptable in a civilized world, according to the author.
LEAD: For liberal arts majors with no place to go [ ''Brand-New Degree and No Place to Go,'' Opinion, Aug. 28 ] , nursing is a profession that offers ''rewarding work.''

The designer, at right, wears a black and white wool houndstooth toque; $35 at Bergdorf Goodman, $40 at Barneys.

The lamas, teachers with an obligation to help rid the world of suffering, are venerated by Tibetan Buddhists because they are believed to return to this world voluntarily to enlighten others.

Educators, predicting a possible 50 percent failure rate and heightened dropout problem, criticized the shift from testing minimum basic skills to a more advanced level of basic skills testing.

LEAD: Murray Cohen, who retired two years ago as senior partner of the New York law firm of Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, now Rosenman & Colin, died of complications from kidney disease on Friday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: NOTHING IN HER CREAM-COLORED OFFICE - WITH the exception of the Financial News Network reports flickering on the television screen - hints at her occupation. And Elaine M. Garzarelli likes it that way. Settling back on the plump sofa and fanning out her hair, the Manhattan-based securities analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton (she clinched her reputation by predicting last October's market crash a week in advance, on Cable News Network's ''Moneyline'') says she has always avoided working in a place that looks too obviously ''officey.

LEAD: RELUCTANTLY, landlords in troubled office markets are reducing their dependency on ''free rent,'' a financial gimmick that allows tenants to move into office buildings without paying rent for several years.

LEAD: DEPENDING on your point of view the arrival of the small, dark purple to blue Italian prune plums signals either the end of summer or the debut of fall. These seasonal fruits, traditionally in the market for just a few weeks, inspire great baking.

LEAD: THE movement to ban many categories of plastics unless they degrade in the environment is not founded strictly on logic. After all, plastics make up only about 7 percent of the garbage in waste dumps. But to the casual observer, that is a highly visable 7 percent. ''What the public is reacting to is the fact that the first plastic clam shell that was ever thrown out is still lying there,'' said John Angus, a director of the Eco Corporation, a Canadian maker of additives that make plastics degrade.
