Findlay Jr. of New York and New Canaan, Conn., to Jonathan Bostwick Davis, the son of Dr. E. William Davis Jr. of New York and Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Lillian Bostwick Davis, took place yesterday at the Charlotte Congregational Church.

LEAD: The police arrested 158 anti-abortion demonstrators for blocking entrances to a medical clinic in this Seattle suburb. Those arrested, who refused to identify themselves, were among about 180 protesting at the Cedar River Clinic, where officials said about 2,400 abortions are performed annually.
LEAD: SKANSKA U.S.A., a Swedish builder based in Greenwich since 1982 that has yet to build anything in Connecticut, carries on its business with such quiet efficiency that few have heard of it.

Dean, U.S.A.F. retired, and Mrs. Dean of Sacramento, Calif., was married yesterday to Bret Edwards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton G. Edwards of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Eric Markman performed the ceremony.

LEAD: It almost seems to have been a conspiracy. On the eve of the 26th New York Film Festival, which opened at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night, Manhattan's movie theaters were suddenly offering more films by talented and innovative American film makers than have been seen here at any one time in years: Jonathan Demme's ''Married to the Mob,'' Francis Coppola's ''Tucker,'' Paul Schrader's ''Patty Hearst,'' Martin Scorsese's ''Last Temptation of Christ,'' Errol Morris's ''Thin Blue Line,'' Sidney Lumet's ''Running on Empty'' and John Sayles' ''Eight Men Out.

LEAD: ON MAY 15, MARK GOODMAN was serving the last days of a brief sentence for burglary in the Palm Beach County, Fla., stockade. That night, a Sunday, Goodman and his fellow inmates turned on the cellblock TV set to watch ''America's Most Wanted,'' one of the hottest, and most controversial, shows on television.

LEAD: ON Oct. 20, 1983, Lillian Goldman moved out of the Waldorf-Astoria suite she shared with her husband, Sol, and began a divorce proceeding. She asked for half of Mr. Goldman's $1 billion in assets, New York City's largest private real-estate empire.

LEAD: WITH its busy waterfront, outstanding food shops and picturesque 13th-century Old Town, Boulogne is the most attractive of the French Channel ports convenient for day trips from England. The trip takes 35 minutes by Hovercraft from Dover, an hour and 50 minutes by ferry from Folkestone. If you rise early and stay late you can have seven hours ashore.

LEAD: A woman wearing a huge jeweled and feathered headdress and a man in Ben-Hur garb paraded around Macy's in New York last month. There were togas and trumpeters; in short, it was business as usual in the fragrance department.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John J. McDonald of Hackettstown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Frances McDonald to Kurt Timothy Doctor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ivan S. Doctor of Southfield, Mich.
LEAD: So the man in Susan Jacoby's life calls her face - and, presumably, her wrinkles -dear to him (Hers column, ''Appearance Anxiety,'' Aug. 28).

LEAD: THE next Presidential Administration - Democratic or Republican - must take on a role akin to the cleanup crew the morning after a big party. Over the last several decades, we Americans have been consuming more than we are producing, borrowing more than we are saving, and spending more than we are earning.

LEAD: A LANDMARK HOME The most advanced techniques have been employed in the $500,000, 4-year restoration of the Stanley-Whitman House at 37 High Street in Farmington, a colonial home with National Landmark status. An open house will be held from 1 to 4 P.M. Saturday. Admission is free.
LEAD: JIM MCKAY went shopping in a supermarket the other day and someone asked him, ''Why aren't you in Seoul?''
LEAD: A former debt collector who wrote a how-to crime book while in prison has been sentenced to more prison time for credit-card fraud and told to repay American Express $35,000.

LEAD: A freshman at Columbia University plunged to his death from his 14th-floor dormitory room in an apparent suicide early yesterday, the third student in New York City to die that way in the last week, the police said.

LEAD: Dr. Frances Daly Fergusson, the president of Vassar College, and Dr. Michael Moohr, the chairman of the department of economics at Bucknell University, were married yesterday at St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr. performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IT WAS AN EARLY SPRING. I remember stopping to smell the blossoms on a neighbor's plum tree while out walking with my husband during the early hours of my labor. An earlier pregnancy had ended in miscarriage, but our hopes had grown again when my doctor picked up a strong heart-beat three months into this pregnancy.

LEAD: Gregg Jefferies steps up to the plate. Gets a fourth hit in four times at bat. Pandemonium at Shea. McCarver is yelling, Kiner is yelling, and on my radio, Thorn is shouting, and the Murph is ecstatic. Disregard the technicalities that say Mr. Jefferies does not have enough times at bat. Not only do you have the rookie of this year, but the rookie of last year, the year before, and next year as well.

LEAD: THE annual phenomenon of colorful autumn foliage takes place wherever there are deciduous forests, abundant rainfall and a succession of hot sunny days followed by nights in which the temperature drops well into the 40's. For it is the sugar, formed by the leaves in the heat of the sun and later trapped by the cold night, that turns the leaves to brilliant reds and oranges.

LEAD: FROM its beginnings just after World War II, United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau has been guiding the helpless toward as normal a life as is possible and teaching them to cope with a largely uncaring, if not intolerant, world.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY does not want to be at a competive disadvantage with neighboring states when it comes to higher-education opportunities.
LEAD: It was supposed to be the weekend of the great Yankee comeback, but the whole thing was spoiled Friday night. Now, it has become the great Yankee tease.

LEAD: Handel's operas have suffered strange vicissitudes. Many of them enjoyed great success in their day, yet they were soon so completely forgotten that between 1754, when Handel was still living, and 1920 not one of them was staged anywhere. Even after the publication of the scores more than a century ago, no attempt was made to revive them, though anyone could see that they were full of superb music.

LEAD: When Dr. Vernon Sylvest, a pathologist in Richmond, Va., lost $60,000 in several oil and energy ventures in the early 1980's, he decided he wanted more to show for his money than worthless pieces of paper. He bought land because, he said, ''I figured land was a sure thing.''

LEAD: HYDRAULIC door closers, the metal tubes mounted horizontally on the interior side of most lightweight storm and screen doors, seldom break, but they sometimes malfunction and their mounting brackets often come loose. Repairing them is usually not difficult.

LEAD: I must correct James Atlas's informative article ''The Case of Paul de Man'' (Aug. 28) on one point. I never stated that members of the comparative literature department at Yale ''knew all about'' Paul de Man's past. On the contrary, most of Mr. de Man's colleagues, including myself, knew nothing about his wartime past.

LEAD: MAX HOLLAND, A WASHINGTON writer, began missing letters and magazines when he got a new postman last spring. Two months later, he went to a party at an office building nearby. In the lobby, he found a stack of mail that included his missing letters and magazines. Even after he had notified the post office of the error, his mail continued to go to the office building.
LEAD: As the Presidential contenders prepare for the debate here Sunday night, they know full well that the tone a candidate strikes can be as influential as any specific words he says.

LEAD: JOHN SCHMIDT and Richard Kinney sat at the Spring Lake Bath and Tennis Club on a recent morning discussing medical waste, beach closings and what some see as the tainted image of the New Jersey Shore. As officials of the New Jersey Shore Foundation, Mr. Schmidt, its president, and Mr. Kinney, a member of its board of trustees, were optimistic about eventually changing that image and supplementing what local and state governments are doing to save the shore.

LEAD: Carlos Andres Peres is campaigning for president, too - of Venezuela. He came to the U.S. with some new ideas about dealing with what he calls ''the historic misunderstanding'' between the U.S. and Latin America. He is almost certain to be elected, but the visit here may help.

LEAD: GRIM news for the savings and loan industry keeps coming. American thrifts lost $3.6 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported last week, bringing losses for the last 12 months to $13.5 billion. Congress is moving toward consideration of a Federal bailout to close down or merge the industry's insolvent institutions: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said last week that a $20 billion bailout would be in order.
LEAD: The staccato tweet of the paging beeper, which is the latest in high-technology gear for today's enterprising drug dealer, is being squelched in schools around the country.

LEAD: In this town's 250-year history, few situations have warranted a special town meeting, except for those called to discuss revolt against the British. LEAD: ''I probably spent too much money,'' said Santo Fulmino of his nine-unit rehabilitation project in Hoboken, N.J. It was, after all, his first development. It was also a learning experience. The costs were $725,000 to buy a five-story, walkup of railroad flats at 1214 Washington Street and $700,000 to turn it into the Patrician condominium.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: STATE officials want to renew a ban on importing bees from states infested by a mite deadly to the insects. The officials are seeking to safeguard the production of honey and the cultivation of fruits and vegetables, as well.

LEAD: Weight-lifting officials announced two more suspensions for positive drug tests today after Bulgaria, stung by the loss of two gold medals because of drug use, pulled its entire weight-lifting team out of the Olympics.

LEAD: When this writer was a student accompanying in vocal studios at Northwestern University, there came to the music school a talented undergraduate, not a music major, who sang countertenor and wanted lessons. Nobody knew what to do with him; a tenor on the faculty taught him for a while, but concluded that countertenor singing was beyond the ken of the conventional instructor, and remanded the young man to the liberal arts.

Dostoevski and Turgenev had tried their luck in its ornate rooms.

LEAD: AT dawn, rattling through Paraguay's rural interior on the Ferrocarril Presidente Carlos Antonio Lopez, I was dogged by the pungent aroma of burning wood - not a smell I'd previously associated with trains. Hot grease, steam, coal smoke and diesel exhaust: those, in my experience, were proper train smells.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE train had stopped at the Continental Divide and we were hurrying toward the doors when I noticed the elderly woman beside me gasping for air. Some travelers before her must have felt similar problems, for the porters carry an ample supply of oxygen. ''But I didn't want to take the time,'' she said later.
LEAD: American-style philanthropy seems to be taking root here.

LEAD: Most waterfowlers have long known that the drought that has plagued breeding habitat in Canada and this country has resulted in a near-record low in duck production this year. They also knew that seasons and bag limits would be reduced and that there would be no special or bonus seasons for such species as teal and scaup, that the highly prized canvasback would be off limits across the nation, and that shooting hours would be shortened from sunrise, instead of a half-hour before, to sunset.

LEAD: As Burma settles in for what could be a war of attrition between the military Government and the popular opposition, reports from Rangoon portray a city struggling to survive after six weeks of strikes and shortages.

LEAD: ''This society,'' writes Dudley Clendinen in HOMELESS IN AMERICA (Acropolis Books, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $19.95), ''with all its computers and all its enormous wealth of resources and research, cannot count the homeless.'' Do they number 300,000 (one of the Reagan Administration figures), asks Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An article on page 21 in some copies of the Travel section today, about botanical gardens, misstates the admission charge for the Summer Palace gardens in Beijing. It is 3 cents, not $3.

LEAD: It's almost October, the first Presidential debate is upon us, but where are the issues in the campaign? There's plenty of posturing, like Michael Dukakis posing helmeted aboard a tank. There's no end of puffed-up patriotism, like George Bush, dauntless defender of the Pledge of Allegiance, mis-reciting ''and to the liberty for which it stands.

LEAD: When Spike Owen batted for Jim Rice earlier this season, Rice got into a tussle with the Boston manager, Joe Morgan, and was suspended for three days. In an even more unusual move, Rice batted for Wade Boggs yesterday, but no confrontation followed.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Nancy Lynne Scurlock, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arch Chilton Scurlock of Arlington, Va., and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, was married yesterday at Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, to Michael Weld Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Collins of Bethesda, Md.

LEAD: President Reagan is asking Congress to divert up to $150 million in defense or foreign aid money to help launch new United Nations peacekeeping operations in the coming months. The funds would be transferred to the State Department to meet ''urgent requests that may arise'' before March for contributions to peacekeeping and truce operations planned in Afghanistan, between Iran and Iraq and possibly in Angola, South-West Africa, Cambodia and the Western Sahara.

LEAD: There will be no festivals, tributes or gala concerts to commemorate Vladimir Horowitz's 85th birthday on Saturday. This is the way he wants it. His plans are to spend the day as he spends most days, at home. During the recent heat spell he stayed inside for six weeks reading the letters of Mozart, which have become a near obsession, listening to recordings, receiving friends, anything but practicing the piano.
LEAD: IN a Tel Aviv museum is a caricature of an American Jewish family, portraying it from shtetl generation to golfing suburb to counterculture commune.

LEAD: BRUCE D. HENDERSON created the Boston Consulting Group 25 years ago and turned it into one of the nation's premier management consultants. But in 1979, at the age of 64, he fell victim to a palace revolt and was deposed as chief executive officer.

LEAD: At first, I thought it was a joke. How could anyone seriously propose a law in the United States making it illegal for one group of people to express an opinion directly to another group of people?

LEAD: A Federal jury has begun hearing testimony in a lawsuit seeking damages from members of the Ku Klux Klan who were part of a violent confrontation with civil rights marchers on a rural Georgia road last year.

LEAD: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts meet tonight in a debate that could be pivotal for a Presidential contest in which voters are uncertain and dissatisfied with how the candidates have discussed the issues.

LEAD: THEY are called ''People of the Book,'' and Jews lived up to their name last week at an extraordinary funeral service in Brooklyn for five Torah scrolls destroyed by vandals. As rabbis delivered eulogies over the plain pine coffin holding the charred scrolls, it was almost as if the People of the Book had made a person of the Book.

LEAD: THE illustration is of a poster for the Odeon Cafe, in Zurich. Done by Hugo Laubi, in 1920, this is one of the 27 Swiss posters now at the Hiram Halle Memorial Library in Pound Ridge, and it is as bold in color - the table is vermilion with everything else either black or white - as it is in design.

LEAD: The Bronx detective who was the ''point man'' in the group of seven police officers who confronted Larry Davis in a shootout in a cramped Bronx apartment almost two years ago is expected to provide a dramatic climax this week to the prosecution's case in the Davis trial.

LEAD: THE MEN AND WOMEN OF YESHIVA: Higher Education, Orthodoxy, and American Judaism. By Jeffrey S. Gurock. (Columbia University, $35.) In the spring of 1970, when college campuses around the nation were exploding in the wake of Kent State and Richard Nixon's bombing of Cambodia, Yeshiva University was faced with a dilemma.

LEAD: The marriage of Mari Louise Christiana Nakakuki, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Masafumi Nakakuki of Englewood, Colo., to Michael Patrick McAndrews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. McAndrews of Kennett Square, Pa., took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Frances-Kelly performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 8 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 2 4 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III.
LEAD: Bedside Manner Counts Here
LEAD: Compromise, not litigation, appears to be the best way for embezzlement victims of a Danbury Probate judge to get back their money, a judge said.

LEAD: Nancy Adele Ameen, who is to join the New York law firm of White & Case as an associate Oct. 31, and Alan George Hoden, a product manager with the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, were married yesterday at the Congregational Church of the Redeemer in New Haven. The Rev. Thomas Burgett-Lentner performed the ceremony.
LEAD: THE TOWER STRUCK BY LIGHTNING By Fernando Arrabal. Translated by Anthony Kerrigan. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Douglas Huff Jr., who resigned his seat in the Illinois House of Representatives two weeks ago after being convicted of Federal tax evasion and admitting a cocaine habit, died Thursday. He was 57 years old.

LEAD: A week after Cris Carter admitted that he had received $5,000 from an agent while playing for Ohio State, the agent pleaded not guilty to a charge that he lied in telling a grand jury that he had not made such a payment. He also pleaded not guilty to a charge that he had urged Carter to deny the payment.

LEAD: FOR THE EMPLOYEES OF THE Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, it was the worst of times. On Aug. 28, 1986, the company announced a massive restructuring plan to foil a takeover threat mounted by Sanford C. Sigoloff, chairman of the Wickes Companies. In the months that followed, Owens-Corning sold off some of its divisions and reorganized others; the work force was cut from 28,000 to 17,000.

LEAD: ON the campus of Rutgers University in New Jersey, students at the business and engineering schools are participating in an unusual experiment: sifting through barrels of discarded plastic garbage.

LEAD: Jean de Florette Starring Yves Montand, Gerard Depardieu, Daniel Auteuil, Elisabeth Depardieu, Ernestine Mazurowna, Marcel Champel, Armand Meffre. Directed by Claude Berri. 1987. Orion Home Video. 121 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG. Contains two violent scenes that could trouble young children.
LEAD: THE AGES OF GAIA A Biography of Our Living Earth. By James Lovelock. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: Two of the more respected practitioners of the British espionage novel are Gavin Lyall and Ted Allbeury, and both are represented by new books, Mr. Allbeury by THE STALKING ANGEL (Mysterious Press, $17.95) and Mr. Lyall by UNCLE TARGET (Viking, $16.95).

LEAD: At the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn., Elizabeth Couch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur W. Couch of New Preston, Conn., was married yesterday to Eric Allen Forstmann, a son of Carol Millar Forstmann of Warren, Conn., and Peter Allen Forstmann of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Richard C.
LEAD: Lebanon's rival Moslem and Christian governments were engaged in a power struggle for control of the country's public affairs today.
LEAD: A chart on Aug. 7 comparing health care spending in eight countries misstated the total spending per capita in the United States for 1986. It was $1,926.

LEAD: I carried a manual typewriter and a certain Olympian innocence to Mexico City 20 years ago. I didn't fully understand that the Games I was covering were not the only games being played. I thought that Bob Beamon's great leap forward and the black power salutes of Tommie Smith and John Carlos were entirely separate incidents, one a sporting event, the other a political statement, and that the Olympic Movement itself was so swollen with pretension and hypocrisy that it would soon explode in the atmosphere like one of its ceremonial balloons.
LEAD: North Carolina
LEAD: IF a star should be born in Robert Cottingham Jr. at the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, it would be ironic, since his father's Olympic dreams died there 36 years ago.
LEAD: The widow of Salvador Allende, Hortensia Bussi, came home today after 15 years of exile, through the ''wide open door'' that she had wanted.

LEAD: The Japanese developed judo, ''the gentle way,'' as an alternative to the more violent jujitsu. One competitor, a judoka, is allowed per country in each of eight weight classes. The strategy is to use an agressor's weight and momentum to your advantage (pushing when being pulled, pulling when being pushed) and defeat him through a series of holds and throws.
LEAD: IS IT fair to deny auto insurance to drivers who own radar detectors?

LEAD: Lynne R. Hyman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Normand Hyman of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Caird Forbes-Cockell, a son of Mrs. Seton Forbes-Cockell of Ascot, Berkshire, England, and the late Mr. Forbes-Cockell. Joseph Chuman, an Ethical Culture Society leader in Bergen County, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel in New

LEAD: One aspect of Bangkok that strikes almost everybody, visitor and resident alike, is the bewildering speed with which the city is changing. Except for temples and a few royal landmarks, little seems as it was even five years ago - from the skyline, now impressively studded with high-rise office buildings, condominiums and hotels, to the favorite haunts of locals in search of what the
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's predecessors would have known how to handle the tense standoff that now prevails in the southern Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan.
LEAD: I FEEL bitter and sad. It's hard to feel any other way after your 9-month-old baby has died.
LEAD: ''Dance is an international language, an international form of poetry. That is why I wanted to be a choreographer.''

LEAD: COMMUTERS trying to squeeze through the increasingly congested White Plains-Stamford highway corridor could get help from a privately operated express bus service, local transportation officials said last week.
LEAD: BURIED in the historic center of Rome is what may be the world's smallest stamp-issuing authority.
LEAD: WHEN the Department of Housing and Urban Development labeled this city's West Side as ''no longer viable'' in 1972, residents refused to let their historic neighborhood die.

LEAD: ON THE one hand, there was Bob Lord, the gentle, compassionate coordinator of shelters and soup kitchens for the homeless. He often worked around the clock, helping people, recalled an official of Project Hospitality, a nonprofit New York corporation that sponsors the shelters on Staten Island.

LEAD: Admittedly, it was not the most auspicious way to start the competition. The best-known boxer on the United States team was knocked out in the first round, while one of the medal favorites missed a bus and was disqualified. But since those embarrassments last week, Team Chaos has been doing quite well, slowly repairing its image, showing that the Americans may have a stronger

LEAD: N.H.L Rangers Top Devils: Tomas Sandstrom and Ulf Dahlen scored first-period power play goals yesterday to lead the Rangers to a 3-2 victory over the Devils in an exhibition game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Sandstrom opened the scoring at 9 minutes 43 seconds with a 10-foot shot over the stick of the Devils goaltender, Sean Burke.
LEAD: Michael Fessier, a movie and television scriptwriter as well as an author of short stories, died Tuesday. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: WORSE THAN THE DISEASE Pitfalls of Medical Progress. By Diana B. Dutton with Thomas A. Preston and Nancy E. Pfund. 528 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press.

LEAD: ABORTION BUSH: Would allow abortion only in cases of rape, incest or to protect life of mother. Opposes public spending on abortion. DUKAKIS: Supports women's right to choose. Favors Medicaid financing for abortions for low-income women. AGRICULTURE BUSH: Opposed Harkin-Gephardt bill, which sought to increase prices by limiting production through mandatory controls.

LEAD: BRIDGE organizers have struggled for years to deal with the problem of slow play. There have been players who have thought for 20 minutes over a single bid or play, upsetting their opponents and dislocating time schedules. A variety of regulations have been tried with limited effect.

LEAD: Yitzhak Shamir differentiates the Israeli struggle against the British mandatory administration from the Palestinian struggle against Israeli rule, saying, ''But we never attacked civilians, women and children. . . .'' One wonders if it was geographic inaccessibility to the British civilians that accounts for this forbearance, since Israeli forces, including the Lehi (of which Mr.

LEAD: Elizabeth Davis Otto, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Otto Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Christopher Jean Paquette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Paquette of Manchester, N.H., were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Oxford, Mass. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd officiated.
LEAD: SWIMMING: Kristin Otto of East Germany kept her perfect record intact: five golds in five events.
LEAD: Gao Min and Li Qing, teen-age symbols of China's rise toward diving supremacy, won Olympic gold and silver medals in women's springboard competition today.

LEAD: Joel Brinkley described Yitzhak Shamir's background as a Jewish rebel against British rule in Palestine during the 1940's (''The Stubborn Strength of Yitzhak Shamir,'' Aug. 21). He interviewed former British policemen with bitter memories of their comrades slain by Mr. Shamir's forces.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT'S two arboretums are parts of educational institutions, but they are also oases of peace in busy areas. They attract many who have no course of study in mind, but simply want to stroll and savor nature.

LEAD: THE Art Moderne Lane Theater in New Dorp has an unusual decorative scheme, but most of it has been painted over. It is also the last single-screen movie house on Staten Island, at a time when the multiplex theater dominates movie-house economics.

LEAD: When the last man had flung himself through a spinning, twisting dismount from the high bar Saturday afternoon, ending the men's Olympic gymnastics competition, it had never been clearer that the Soviet Union is the dominant country in this sport.

LEAD: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Claire Wood Streeter and John Curtis Carlson were married yesterday by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee. Marianne Spafford, a cousin of the bride, was the maid of honor, and Brian Carlson was the best man for his brother.
LEAD: Pamela Elizabeth Newman and Eric Arthur Pooley were married yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Avery Manchester.

LEAD: A brief obituary by The Associated Press last Sunday about Harold Eugene Davis, a Latin American scholar and professor at American University, misstated the cause of death. His widow, Audrey, says it was pneumonia, not cancer.

LEAD: EVERY weekend in July when many of his friends and colleagues are preparing for their long drives to the Hamptons, Si Newhouse boards a jet and heads for his house in Palm Beach to spend the weekend reading.

LEAD: The walls of the Dia Art Foundation exhibition space at 77 Wooster Street have been painted blackboard gray and smeared with chalk. A grade school regulation clock oversees one wall, the American flag another; and rows of school chairs, replete with carved initials, march across the floor. These props set the stage for ''Education and Democracy,'' an exhibition that juxtaposes, among many other things, the efforts of blue chip art stars and junior high school students from
LEAD: INSOFAR as orchestras in the state can see the future, it is at least partly pops, and many are expanding or adding to their programming to reflect the vision.

LEAD: DESPITE Drexel Burnham Lambert's ubiquitous television and magazine advertisements, portraying the company as the investment bank of the common man, its most famous product, junk bonds, have not overcome the stigma of their name.
LEAD: When the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank chose to hold their annual meeting in a city divided, they should have expected a meeting divided.

LEAD: American and Brazilian pop have enjoyed a cultural exchange for decades, but since the early-1960's bossa nova craze no Brazilian singer has managed to grab the ear of the American pop public directly. Djavan, who performed to a full house Thursday night at the Ritz, is the most likely contender for that long-awaited crossover.

LEAD: In her excellent article, ''Old, Old School Buildings'' [ Opinion, Sept. 11 ] , Edie Brown Eisenberg showed the folly of the destruction of the Hewlett-Woodmere school complex. It is now due to be replaced, in part, by ''additions'' to the existing schools if the voters approve a bond issue she cites at ''$20 million to $30 million.

LEAD: Even though Gregg Jefferies has been a superstar hitter, batting .400-plus, and also a great fielder, I'm sure that he doesn't have enough games to be eligible to win the award. [ To qualify for the award, a rookie must have been on a major league roster for at least 45 days and have at least 130 times at bat.

LEAD: MONEY manager Ken Heebner, vice president of Boston-based Loomis, Sayles & Company, once held more than a million shares of Home Shopping Network in his portfolio. This had an unusual impact on his life: in 1986 and early 1987, when the stock's price was in orbit, he developed an odd ritual.

LEAD: SANCTUARY A Story of American Conscience and the Law in Collision. By Ann Crittenden. Illustrated. 410 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $21.95. CONVICTIONS OF THE HEART Jim Corbett and the Sanctuary Movement. By Miriam Davidson. 187 pp. Tucson: University of Arizona Press.

LEAD: If he had snookered the world, he laid the groundwork more than a year ago. After Ben Johnson of Canada lowered the world 100-meter record to 9.83 seconds in the world track and field championships in Rome in 1987, he said the time would probably stand another 50 years. He was off by 49. So what is the world to make of his miscalculation?

LEAD: THE unceremonious ouster last week of Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who had twice ruled Haiti since the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship, was an event that soldiers on the street appreciated most.

LEAD: JAZZ is king at Syosset's Cafe Royale. Food is secondary. That as obvious when, at 7:30 on a Saturday night, ours was the only occupied table. After the talented jazz trio (piano, bass and saxophone) began to play, we had lots of company.
LEAD: West Virginia established itself as the No. 1 team in the East today when the undefeated Mountaineers, the highest-scoring team in the nation, handed Pitt its first loss of the season, 31-10.

LEAD: THE Andrus Planetarium of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers is the only public planetarium in the county. The planetarium presents five shows a year in addition to six school shows for kindergarten through college students that are based on the state's science syllabus.

LEAD: Q. We recently had our kitchen cabinets refinished with a Formica veneer. Several months later, we noticed that the veneer on one five-foot-long cabinet door was starting to come loose in the middle, forming a blister or ''balloon'' about six inches long. The adhesive above and below this is adhering tightly.
LEAD: The soul singer James Brown was arrested today after a two-state auto chase that ended after authorities shot out two tires on his truck, the authorities said.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Murray Oratz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ann Oratz to Carl Siegel, a son of Mrs. Maurice T. Siegel of Baltimore and the late Mr. Siegel. The couple plan to marry Nov. 19.
LEAD: IN Westbury, at the half-empty, dimly lighted radar approach center that monitors most aircraft flying through the New York-Long Island area, night shifts can stretch on and on.
LEAD: Tourist guidebooks call it Congo's ''Little Colorado,'' a stunning gorge of plunging, pink cliffs draped with green Central African jungle.
LEAD: To many people who live in this small seacoast community, seagulls are a dirty, noisy nuisance, but to members of the GULL fan club, one bird rises above the rest.
LEAD: Timothy Flynn started sailing as a child and did so just for the fun of it until he was 19, when he lost the use of his limbs in an automobile accident.

LEAD: Todd Philcox threw for three touchdowns to the wide receiver Rob Moore and scored on a flea-flicker play today as Syracuse (2-1) routed Virginia Tech, 35-0. Philcox, a fifth-year senior, completed 9 of 18 passes for 167 yards in three quarters.

LEAD: When Petr Klima showed up late for a midweek practice and his teammate Bob Probert missed a team flight from Chicago, Jacques Demers, the coach of the Detroit Red Wings, decided he'd had just about enough. So in an effort to teach the players a lesson, the coach ordered them sent down to the club's Adirondack farm club in Glens Falls, N.Y., on a ''day-to-day basis.
LEAD: MY SON TEDDY IS 16, and I have been teaching him how to drive. It's the hardest thing we've done together since he was born.

LEAD: When the Town of Islip began to have second thoughts about the industrial zoning of some land near Long Island MacArthur Airport, Racanelli & Associates, one of Long Island's largest industrial builders, had second thoughts about holding on to it. Instead, they sold the 75-acre, factory-sized lot in Holbrook to the Holiday Organization, one of Long Island's largest residential builders.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Newman of Westport, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Clea Olivia Newman to Marshall Field 6th, the son of Mr. Field 5th of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mrs. Samuel Tatnall of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: Four years ago, my husband told me he was offended that I was rejecting - and altering - the face that he called beautiful. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, he argued. But I couldn't hide from the fact that, although love might be blind, I wasn't. I forsook Henry V in favor of Hamlet's Polonius, and to my own self was true: there was nothing ''pretty'' or ''dear'' about the excess cartilage on the tip of my nose or the absence of a discernible chin.

LEAD: Kathleen Helen Clarke, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin B. Clarke of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Theodore Cacouris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias M. Cacouris of Abidjan, the Ivory Coast, and Athens, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. John A. Lynn of the American Fellowship Service performed the ceremony.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about Campbell Norsgaard and Ernestine Jaediker Norsgaard, husband and wife nature writers, misidentified the publisher of their book ''How to Raise Butterflies.'' It is the Putnam Publishing Group.

LEAD: IN the parts of the state where the living are many, final resting places for the dead are becoming increasingly few. Most of the shortage of cemetery space is occurring in the most intensely developed areas of the state: the cities and in Fairfield County.

LEAD: WHEN television was still a rather new form of entertainment on my block, millions of Americans watched mesmerized in 1954 as the first televised Miss America Pageant came into our homes. I was a very young boy when this event captured my heart and hooked me for life.
LEAD: A senior Army official has acknowledged to Congress that the Army was lax in overseeing contracts with Bell Helicopter, thus allowing the company to charge excessive prices.

LEAD: Tuesday marks the beginning of the combined annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which are to be held in West Berlin. The I.M.F., which lends money primarily for balance-of-payments shortfalls, and the World Bank, which lends to third world countries for economic development, still must grapple with the continuing debt problems in Latin America and Africa.

LEAD: With their empty-nester condominiums, the communities north and west of Hartford have become magnets for the Connecticut capital's older residents. By 1990, only one in 10 people in Hartford will be 65 or older, but one in four residents of West Hartford will fit that description and, in Bloomfield, one in five.
LEAD: Several people watched as a 36-year-old woman was raped under a commuter train platform at the rush hour, but nobody moved to help her, the police said Friday.

LEAD: THE decline of the American steel industry has exemplified the nation's loss of basic manufacturing muscle. Now, suddenly, American steel exports are on the rise, particularly in specialty products used in aerospace, chemical equipment and nuclear plant construction.
LEAD: CHALLENGED by the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, a small national charity based in Bergen County says it is revising its fund-raising practices.

LEAD: ROBBINS W. BARSTOW formed Cetacean Society International in 1974 after a whale-watching cruise, and has been its full-time volunteer director for two years, since he retired as director of professional development for the Connecticut Education Association.

LEAD: WHAT do bathtubs, boat piers, flower pots and carpets have in common? Answer: they are all products that have been made from recycled plastic bottles.

LEAD: More than 100 drawings and paintings by noted German artists from the 18th century to the mid-19th century are to be on display beginning Nov. 17 at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. This is the first time the artworks, drawn from museums in East Berlin and Dresden, have been displayed in the United
LEAD: Moroccan officials say they are determined not to let a major attack by Polisario guerrillas upset plans for a United Nations-sponsored negotiation to end the war in Western Sahara.

LEAD: I have many problems with the Olympic Games, namely the unnecessary hype of the television coverage and the participation of seasoned professionals such as Chris Evert. But what I viewed last Saturday afternoon took the cake. In order to be comical and to show the poor caliber of athletic abilities of some of the countries, NBC played a portion of the basketball game between Egypt and the People's Republic of China in fast forward with humorous music.

LEAD: With a month and a half left in the campaign, about the last thing Gov. Michael S. Dukakis wanted was Vice President Bush needling him in his backyard, the Massachusetts Legislature defying him and Massachusetts residents grousing about his record. But that is exactly what has happened.

LEAD: The chase is the most compelling part of an antiques dealer's profession - the constant search for that which is unique and undiscovered and appealing. But as fewer great objects come on the market each season, this has become a difficult task, especially for those dealers who specialize in areas little-known even to scholars.

LEAD: At the Princeton University Chapel yesterday, Catherine McVay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Scott McVay of Princeton, was married to Thomas McMaster Hughes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hughes of New York. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: If the prospect of tonight's encounter between George Bush and Michael Dukakis does not set your blood to racing, that probably means you have seen previous Presidential debates.
LEAD: DESPITE the security problems of living on a waterfront, people still want houses there and will pay millions of dollars for them, a longtime real-estate agent says.

Howard was working on de Gaulle's memoires, and the President of the French Republic had invited him to the Elysee Palace on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore for lunch.

LEAD: Chris Evert's dream of Olympic glory was blown away in the wind today as the 33-year-old American lost, 2-6, 6-4, 6-1, to Raffaella Reggi of Italy in the third round.

LEAD: American Washboards - lathe-turned rods, rippled zinc sheets, ridged ceramic plaques, stapled wood panels and polka-dotted cast iron - became one of Ivan Karp's collecting obsessions about six years ago. LEAD: In the controversy surrounding last week's melee in the ring when penalties cost a South Korean boxer a decision against a Bulgarian, South Korea's ruling party has criticized the foreign news media in general and NBC in particular for their coverage of the Games.

LEAD: To the Editor: At the end of his article on Humphry Repton's architectural gem, Sheringham Hall (Travel, July 3), Paul Lewis referred to the late-18th-century controversy over landscape gardening between Repton, Uvedale Price and Richard Payne Knight.

LEAD: Francesca Consagra and John Edward Ray were married yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Sophie Chandler Consagra, in Montchanin, Del. The Rev. John O'Hear, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

LEAD: In the last 28 months, even as Yonkers risked bankruptcy in its battle against a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, the public schools here have moved quietly and methodically to abolish deeply rooted segregation in the system.

LEAD: WHEN Susan M. Garvey worked for MONY Financial Services' personnel department in Manhattan, she took advantage of the company's ''flex-time'' program to beat the heavy commuter traffic to and from her home in lower Westchester.
LEAD: Melody Baldwin poisoned her first child. A second baby is on the way. Now the judge who controls her fate has proposed an unorthodox solution to the troubles of her life - sterilization.

LEAD: Cleaning up the Bronx River is not an easy proposition. In just one sweep of the waterway in the West Farms section of the Bronx several years ago, the catch amounted to 6 cars, 2 horse trailers, 53 refrigerators, 5 sofas and most of an upright piano.
LEAD: One sounds like a cheerleader at an after-hours club. The other looks as if he is the bouncer.
LEAD: Harold Durham sat outside the entrance to the No. 4 mine of Zinc Corporation of America, alone in his Dodge pickup with his cigarettes, coffee and pillow.
LEAD: Faculty members at the University of Maine are protesting a decision to sell a portion of a vast collection of pre-Columbian artifacts to help finance a baseball clubhouse.

LEAD: DONALD TRUMP CHARGES UP A STAIRCASE, kicks open a fire door and greets the blinding summer sun. Surrounded by heavyset bodyguards wearing gold-plated ''T's'' in their lapels, he stands 18 stories above Fifth Avenue on the roof of the Plaza Hotel.

LEAD: The National League cannot have a pennant winner if neither of the teams in the pennant playoff scores a run. The problem for the hitters of the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers, then, will be to figure out how to score runs against the Dodgers' and the Mets' pitchers.
LEAD: For the first time in history, a woman was elected yesterday to be a bishop in the Episcopal Church.

LEAD: FOR the last two years I've been writing about two basic types of 35-millimeter cameras. There are single-lens reflexes (SLRs), which let you compose, meter and focus through an interchangeable-mount lens. And there are point-and-shoots, a.k.a. lens/shutter cameras, which have separate viewfinders beside their fixed-mount lenses.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Massachusetts Institute of Technology tailback, Shane LaHousse, rushed for 260 yards and 4 touchdowns to lead the Beavers to victory in their first game as a varsity team, defeating Stonehill College, 29-7, at Steinbrenner Field today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When Luis Cancel, director of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, was growing up Puerto Rican in New York, he couldn't learn much about the art of his own people. ''There was no information about 20th-century Puerto Rican or Latin American art in the libraries I went to,'' he said, ''and there were no art history courses that could feed my interest at the schools I attended.

LEAD: The ascent of compact disks seems a classic case of virtue triumphant. After all, CD's are supposedly faultless: no clicks, pops or any of the other ills the old LP's were heir to. On technical merits, the success of the silver platters seems well deserved.

LEAD: SINCE fall is officially here, the rush is on to keep up with planting especially conifers, broadleaved evergreens and new selections of containerized perennials. Finish dividing established clumps of perennials and share viable roots with friends. Continue planning bulb displays and select first choices from garden center bins; bulb planting continues until early November, but the sooner the better so new roots can grow.

LEAD: The National Labor Relations Board will hold a hearing on a charge by the Electric Boat company that its striking unions broke the law by not notifying Federal mediatiors of the potential for a walkout 30 days in advance.

LEAD: The French call it le gouter de quatre heures, that sacred moment somewhere around 4 o'clock each afternoon when small stomachs begin to rumble. If you pay attention, you will notice sweet aromas wafting through the damp Parisian air. From one quarter comes the buttery scent of freshly baked croissant dough oozing with sticks of melting, bittersweet chocolate.
LEAD: Gov. Edward D. DiPrete and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency are embroiled in a high-stakes dispute over the future of the state's water supplies.

LEAD: Police Shooting A MOUNTAINSIDE police officer was justified when he opened fire on a fleeing stolen auto that had struck a fellow officer just moments before, a Union County grand jury decided last month. Seriously wounded in the incident, which occurred on July 8 on eastbound Route 22, was a Berkeley

LEAD: 'We're seeing a very serious trend. A year ago, we were losing $50,000 to $60,000 a month from break-ins. But it's now approaching $170,000 for August and, I expect, $200,000 in September.' - David L. Gunn, president of the Transit Authority on the growing loss of revenue from the vandalism of New York City's subway turnstiles.
LEAD: THE bloating of property values in many parts of the country in the last several years is creating a new set of issues for couples to face in separation and divorce.
LEAD: LAST NOTES FROM HOME By Frederick Exley. 397 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

LEAD: She could not recall who the father of her son was, Sarah Bernhardt wrote in her memoir, but she placed Victor Hugo on a short list of possibilities. She once announced she was having a leopard's tail grafted into herself. She continued acting well into old age, a star and a scandal because she adored theatricality on stage and off.

LEAD: Vivian Esther Steir, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Berton Steir of Brookline, Mass., was married last night to Dr. Douglas Stuart Rabin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Charles Rabin of West Chester, Pa. Rabbi Ephraim Greenberg performed the ceremony at Temple Bnai Moshe in Boston.
LEAD: THE SYKAOS PAPERS By E. P. Thompson. 482 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

LEAD: When Leonard Bernstein composed his Symphony No. 3 (''Kaddish'') in 1963, he assigned to a woman the central role of the Job-like Speaker who upbraids God for creating an imperfect world. In his 1977 revision of the score, Mr. Bernstein permits either a male or female to take the part, an ambiguity entirely consistent with the composer's ecumenical view of life and art.

LEAD: Franz Kafka might well be as bemused as some of his improbably situated characters to learn that the coming sale of one of his manuscripts is the talk of the rare-book set. Sotheby's, which is handling the gavel on this one, says Kafka's handwritten version of ''The Trial,'' written in 1914 and published in 1925, the year after the author's death, is the most important modern literary manuscript ever to be auctioned.

LEAD: THE Founding Fathers intended the House of Representatives to be the part of the Federal Government closest to the electorate and thus most responsive to shifts in political winds. Describing the function of the House under the Constitution, Alexander Hamilton declared: ''Here, sir, the people govern.

LEAD: FUNERAL directors in the state who handle fewer than 150 funeral calls in a year face financial hardship because of the increasing demands of new state and Federal regulations on the industry, say several of the directors and an official of their trade association.

LEAD: REGARDLESS of what happens in the Yonkers brouhaha over proposed low-income housing in a predominantly white, middle-income section of that troubled city, I predict that it will have a decided impact upon other towns and villages, with similar housing challenges.
LEAD: Mike Botti, a senior running back for Rutgers, said that the prospect of beating Penn State had been in his thoughts since he first began playing for the Scarlet Knights.
LEAD: A state official is urging that a petition against Donald J. Trump's efforts to buy a prime block here be dismissed. A rival casino owner is also seeking to buy the land.

LEAD: IN THE PARK AVENUE OFFICE of Robert K. de Veer Jr., a managing director of the First Boston Corporation, a caricature holds a place of honor. The setting is Vietnam. Bombs are falling. De Veer and three First Boston colleagues hunker down in a foxhole. The painting celebrates their hard-won triumph, a successful public bond offering for

LEAD: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Woods Hole, Mass., Ann Margaret Pollis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Pollis of North Attleboro and West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Jonathan O'Herron Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Herron of Darien, Conn.
LEAD: THE LIVES OF JOHN LENNON By Albert Goldman. Illustrated. 719 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

LEAD: CHILEANS will vote Oct. 5 on whether to extend Gen. Augusto Pinochet's presidential tenure for eight more years. If he does not win a majority in the one-man plebiscite, he is supposed to call free elections by the end of next year. For outsiders, the decision seems self-evident: The Government is repressive and has been linked to political killings and torture.

LEAD: American officials say House Speaker Jim Wright gave a generally accurate description of American policy toward Nicaragua when he said that the United States was supporting opposition groups there in hopes of provoking an overreaction by the Sandinistas.

LEAD: Two gold-mining giants began a takeover battle. A division of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa offered $4.9 billion for Consolidated Gold Fields, a London-based company with huge mines in South Africa. Anglo American, the Western world's largest gold producer, is controlled by the Oppenheimer dynasty of South Africa, which runs the De Beers diamond operations.

LEAD: Bobby Humphrey, Alabama's career rushing leader and a Heisman Trophy candidate, suffered a broken bone in his left foot today in his team's 44-10 Southeastern Conference game victory over Vanderbilt and will probably miss the rest of the season.
LEAD: I'M worried that I'm a worry wart. I've always had this tendency. One reason I quit as a college English teacher is that it became too worrisome.

LEAD: WE were driving past the Mamaroneck harbor on the Boston Post Road when my 5-year-old daughter, Jamie, said, ''Oh, what beautiful water, is it polluted?'' I was struck by her question, and I had to tell my daughter that, yes, the water is often polluted. No one needed to tell my 3-year-old, Jenny, as she glanced into Long Island Sound one day and proclaimed, ''Looks like dirty.

LEAD: Troy Dalbey and Doug Gjertsen, both double gold-medal swimmers for the United States, were dropped from the squad today following their arrest on charges of stealing a marble lion's head valued at $830 from a hotel.
LEAD: JACKIE MASON: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO ME! Written by Jackie Mason. Produced by Nick Vanoff. HBO Home Video. 58 minutes. $39.99.

LEAD: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, spoke of his battle with alcohol and of the pain that he caused his family when he asked for leniency last week in Federal District Court in Washington. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson was apparently moved. He gave Mr. Deaver, who was convicted of lying under oath about his work as a lobbyist after leaving the White House, a suspended three-year sentence and a $100,000 fine.

LEAD: * How Robert Bass and Donald Trump matched wits over the Plaza Hotel in New York. * Chase's man in Hong Kong. * Investors' fear of buying puts brokers to the test. * The M.D. who would be a tycoon.

LEAD: WHEN he is hard at work, Richard Larson sometimes finds himself watching videotapes, his eyebrows arched in perpetual scrutiny. He doesn't watch ''Top Gun'' or ''Meatballs'' or anything fun like that. He peers at tapes of customers in line at checkout counters at Zayre department stores. People shuffle forward, merchandise gets shoveled on checkout conveyors.

LEAD: IN some respects, the scene in North Carolina last weekend recalled the daily ''minute of hatred'' in George Orwell's ''1984,'' when citizens are required to rise and hurl invective at pictures of a man known only as Goldstein, the Great Enemy of the state.

LEAD: THE devastation wreaked by Hurricane Gilbert two weeks ago may become an important factor in Jamaica's first political campaign in eight years. Neither of the island's two principal politicians, Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga and Michael N. Manley, whom Mr. Seaga defeated in 1980, are openly trying to capitalize on the disaster.

LEAD: The New York City Planning Commission has allowed developers to construct buildings larger than zoning ordinances allow in exchange for amenities like public plazas and subway station improvements, but it has not guaranteed that the amenities are created, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan asserted in an audit last week.

LEAD: Fairfield, Conn. $269,500 133 Orchard Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fieldstone fireplace, near university campus, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,147. Lyme, Conn. $725,000 Tantumorantum Road 6-bedroom, 5 1/2-baths, 2-story, 48-year-old converted barn; pond, pool, 10 acres, taxes $2,695.

LEAD: Gregg Jefferies should not be the Rookie of the Year because he has not played enough. He has not proven himself yet. This year he was in the minors and hit .286. Then he comes up to the majors, gets some home runs, some doubles, and a game-winning r.b.i. Yes, this is good, but the award should go to either Mark Grace or Chris Sabo.

LEAD: BY THE EMERALD rush of the Habur River, on the Turkish frontier, the Iraqi armies of Saddam Hussein raised their banners in late August to signal their victory over the Kurds. But the message of triumph went much further than that. Throughout the eight years of Baghdad's war with Iran, guerrillas from Iraq's Kurdish minority had stubbornly resisted the Baghdad regime's successive campaigns to crush a revolt that had spanned almost seven decades.

LEAD: IT is a bold vision: an overhaul of the welfare laws that would break the cycle of dependency by moving poor Americans off the welfare rolls and onto the payrolls. The notion represents a break with the original tenets of the welfare program, established in the Depression to provide relief for millions of impoverished people.
LEAD: FIREBRAT By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by David Wiesner. 121 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.
LEAD: A six-point program intended to track down about 600,000 New Jersey motorists who drive without insurance has been announced.

LEAD: As concern heightened here today over the condition of Emperor Hirohito, the Japanese press violated one of its unwritten rules, publishing the word that until now no one would say publicly: cancer.

LEAD: LEROY A. PESCH, M.D., HAD A dream. Simply put, he wanted to create an empire that would deliver comprehensive medical care from the cradle to the grave. He had the credentials: a career as professor, medical school dean, Federal official and president of Chicago's Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center.

LEAD: A new survey indicates that as many as 700,000 young American men may have at least 10 sexual partners a year. The Federal Centers for Disease Control said this put them at ''considerable risk'' of contracting sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS.

LEAD: The Colorado punter, Keith English. set a Big Eight Conference and school record today, averaging 59.8 yards on 5 punts during the Buffaloes' 28-21 victory over Oregon State.

LEAD: She invested four years of hard work, testing her will and physical endurance as well as the patience of the coach who became her husband. Now, on a warm afternoon, thousands of miles from where Jackie Joyner-Kersee first envisioned competing in the Olympic Games, she walked to the starting line on the brick-red track for the 800-meter race, only two minutes and a pocketful of seconds from winning an elusive gold medal in the heptathlon.

LEAD: COMMUTERS trying to squeeze through the increasingly congested White Plains-Stamford highway corridor could get help from a privately operated express bus service, local transportation officials said last week.

LEAD: Susan Jacobs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Jacobs of White Plains, was married last evening to Richard I. Lobel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Lobel of Savannah, Ga. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at Bridgewaters at the South Street Seaport in New York.
LEAD: Paris is famous for politics, the arts and polemics, and all three have come together in a battle royal over the futuristic $350-million opera house being built on the Place de la Bastille.

LEAD: Track and Field Maybe age caught up with Edwin Moses. There is no doubt, though, that Andre Phillips plainly outran him. Phillips went out fast, gained confidence while refusing to give ground, and came back with the gold medal in the men's 400-meter hurdles, winning in an Olympic record 47.19.

LEAD: When Dr. Vernon Sylvest, a pathologist in Richmond, Va., lost $60,000 in several oil and energy ventures in the early 1980's, he decided he wanted more to show for his money than worthless pieces of paper. He bought land because, he said, ''I figured land was a sure thing.''

LEAD: The urge toward completion is one of the primal human impulses, not quite up there with thirst and sex, but a strong one, nonetheless. Gestalt psychologists were not the first to recognize this obsession, but they were the first to describe, in graceful Germanic prose, our strange need to see the whole picture.

LEAD: A seemingly relaxed George Bush said today that he was heading into his debate with Michael S. Dukakis on Sunday night hoping to present ''broad principles'' rather than specific proposals to project his differences with the Democratic Presidential nominee.

LEAD: IT'S easy to mistake one of Shakespeare's less accessible plays, ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' for one of his less appealing ones. The memorable Royal Shakespeare Company staging, transposed by the director Trevor Nunn to the Edwardian era and produced on Broadway in 1983, proved, however, that the play's interpretive possibilities are boundless.

LEAD: FIORENZO BARTOLOZZI, say his friends, is a mixture of Geppetto, the carpenter who created Pinocchio, and Einstein. When the ancient Benedictine abbey of Monte Cassino was reduced to rubble by Allied bombs during World War II, it was to the workshop of Bartolozzi & Maioli in Florence that the monks came for help in restoring and carving the wooden choir stalls.

LEAD: There are certain newsworthy subjects - war, natural disasters, starvation - that the camera can illuminate with relative ease. Their effects are apparent to the eye, and their causes can be readily deduced. Other issues of public concern - the national debt, for example, or radon gas - seem to resist any form of photographic interpretation.

LEAD: Concerned that its blueprint for a single market of 320 million consumers is unfairly biased in favor of business, the chief executive of the European Community has started a campaign to shore up workers' rights when national frontiers are eliminated at the end of 1992.

LEAD: This is in response to the recent article ''Panel Finds Excesses in Drug and Alcohol Care.'' As the chief executive officer of Sunrise House Foundation, a freestanding alcohol treatment center in Sussex County, New Jersey, I note my objection to the generalizations concerning ''typical inpatient programs'' as extremely costly.
LEAD: Greg Frey passed 20 yards to Bobby Olive for the game-winning touchdown with 38 seconds remaining as Ohio State upset Louisiana State, 36-33, today.

LEAD: Alla Pugacheva is a woman of many voices - delicate pop chirps, a clear rock mezzo-soprano, dramatic cabaret growls and sobs. A pop superstar from the Soviet Union who has reportedly sold 150 million records, Mrs. Pugacheva wound up her first American tour with a sold-out concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night that offered a fascinating glimpse of mainstream Soviet pop.

Pennoyer of New York and Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE mission: Get out there on the street and find out what color stockings are currently in favor with young women who like to wear their skirts short. This was tough, thankless work, but someone had to do it.

LEAD: In his article on Paul de Man, James Atlas says, ''As for what he did, how can any of us know what we would have done under those same circumstances?'' This amounts to an excuse for Mr. de Man's collaboration with the Nazis.

LEAD: These letters are excerpted from ''The Letters of T. S. Eliot: Volume I, 1898-1922,'' which will be published tomorrow, on the 100th birthday of the poet. In virtually every case, it is possible to give here only short sections of individual letters; for, while the poet said he was often a tardy correspondent, he was seldom a brief one.
LEAD: A DEBATE erupted last week in Washington that highlights the fact that the Federal budget deficit won't go away.

LEAD: IT will soon be harder to get rid of products made with plastic, that substance that has come to symbolize our throwaway society. Discarded plastic bottles, milk jugs and fast-food containers - not to mention the plastic syringes and vials that have washed up on our beaches - are flooding the nation's already-overflowing landfills.

LEAD: To the referees who watched the play and to some viewers who have studied the videotapes, there was nothing improper about the tackle that knocked Steve Largent out of the season opener against the Denver Broncos with a concussion and caused the Seattle Seahawk receiver to have two teeth capped. As they saw it, the hit by Mike Harden, the Denver free safety, came just after the ball arrived on a pass to Largent, who did not hold on to the ball.

Stevens of Great Neck, L.I., and Jupiter, Fla., and Donald Hal Schneidman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Schneidman of Rye Brook, N.Y., were married last night. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck. The bride, who will keep her name, is a certified public accountant with Laventhol & Horwath in New York.

LEAD: IN THE FALL OF 1986, W. DOUGLASS LEE Jr., an American commodities trader based in London, received a call for help from a representative of a major chemical producer. The United States multinational corporation had sold $8 million in chemicals to Zimbabwe and had agreed to take payment in tobacco rather than cash.
LEAD: The United States launched a $54.5 million satellite early today that will study weather conditions and make spy photographs, space agency officials said.

LEAD: FROM a crouch, Bert Schinto rolled a beautiful bowl to within a few inches of the jack on the rink at Bruce Park in Greenwich. Mr. Schinto was ecstatic, but that was shortlived.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency's annual survey of automobile gasoline mileage shows that more models than ever are being charged the special tax on fuel-hungry cars, most of them expensive European luxury models.

LEAD: Setting a Presidential tone will be a preoccupation for the nominees tonight, for voters respond to nonverbal cues and not just to words. Page 24.
LEAD: Economic officials from the largest industrial democracies today endorsed the dollar's current exchange rate and said the world economy was sound and growing faster than expected.

LEAD: After 48 ''crucial'' hours that may have decided his future in baseball, Bob Ojeda reported from his hospital room in New York today that he felt the worst was over ''and I know now that I'll pitch again.''

LEAD: THE UNITED STATES HOLOCAUST Memorial Museum, a tribute to the victims of the Nazis, is scheduled to open in 1990 in Washington. Its permanent exhibition will document the story of the Holocaust from the rise of Hitler through the implementation of his ''Final Solution,'' but its most resonant feature may well be contributed by citizens too young to have any knowledge at all of the century's darkest historical episode.

LEAD: To the Editor: In your article on airport departure taxes (Travel Advisory, July 24), you state that there are no departure taxes in West Germany. I believe this is correct. However, last September I was charged a tax of $7, of which I had not been previously informed, when departing from West Berlin.

Delaware wildlife officers were reported lowering the odds early this year by using decoys - styrofoam deer covered with deerskins and equipped with antlers and reflective glass eyes.

LEAD: THERE are numerous reasons why someone may need to transmit cash in a flash. A son or daughter is stranded with a broken-down car and not enough money to get it fixed. A spouse extends the length of a trip because of unforeseen circumstances. A wallet is lost on a vacation or a business trip. These are just some of the unfortunate situations requiring money to be sent immediately.

LEAD: Halfway through these Summer Games, it's easy to spot the negative parts. Television ratings down in the U.S.? NBC should have known that baseball and football are hot in September and that many American fans don't think it's a good Summer Games unless Mary Lou Retton is winning all the medals.

LEAD: To talk about the condition of children is by definition to talk about the families in which they live. That is why we are going to have to learn to talk about two kinds of children, because - of a sudden, in a flash - we have become a society divided into two kinds of families. Call it a dual family system.

LEAD: AS a boy I often recited the mysterious, multisyllabic names of the great reptiles: Stegosaurus. Triceratops. Brontosaurus. Since then, my fascination has deepened. LEAD: In a major advance, two groups of scientists have successfully transplanted cells from the eye of a rat to the retina of another rat and cured a disease that would otherwise cause blindness. It's a shrewd director who knows the effect of his work as well as Lee Chang Ho. At a press conference after ''The Man With Three Coffins,'' the first South Korean film to be shown at the New York Film Festival, he said through an interpreter, ''Thank you for your patience'' - a bluntly honest remark. ''The Man With Three Coffins'' is the kind of film that must be seen twice before it makes sense. But only the most committed and curious students of world cinema may feel that Mr. Lee's artistic rigor is reward enough for struggling through the film's taxing narrative strategy and its obscurity to most Western viewers. In summary, the plot sounds compelling. Three years after his wife's death, a man travels north to her hometown to scatter her ashes. Along the way he crosses paths more than once with a nurse also heading north with her elderly charge and encounters a prostitute who dies soon after he sleeps with her. All three women, including the wife seen in flashbacks, are played by the same actress, creating mysterious echoes. Is the hero imagining this similarity? Or are the women reincarnations of the wife?

LEAD: DR. JAMES D. WATSON, who won the Nobel Prize for work in deciphering the structure of DNA, has been appointed an associate director of the National Institutes of Health to coordinate efforts to map, identify and define all of the human genes.
LEAD: Charles Strickland's name was not used, but his story was told twice in the debate Sunday night between the Presidential candidates.

LEAD: Three American military trainers stationed in El Salvador fired on guerrillas when the Americans were caught in a crossfire two weeks ago between the rebels and Salvadoran Army troops, a Pentagon spokeswoman said tonight.

LEAD: A freight train struck and killed two 2-year-old children Sunday as they played on railroad tracks that ran behind their homes, the authorities said. Amanda S. Harmon and Brian S. Johnson were pronounced dead at the scene.
LEAD: THE sense of fatigue felt after strenuous physical exercise may differ biochemically from the tiredness felt after a hard day at the office, researchers using a new device have found.

LEAD: Canadians were stunned today by reports from Seoul, South Korea, that Ben Johnson had tested positive for steroids and was to be stripped of his gold medal in the 100-meter dash in the 1988 Olympics.

LEAD: Color, like fashion, runs in cycles. After recent seasons that emphasized ruffles, poufs and a psychedelic clash of colors, designers have reacted with strong, simple silhouettes and bright solid tones. Taking the designers' lead, fashion magazines emblazon the new season's message in their headlines: ''Fall Flash,'' ''Full-Throttle Fuchsia,'' ''Shocking Shearlings,'' ''Color for a Change.
LEAD: Like most Japanese companies, the Bank of Tokyo routinely gives its top officers new jobs every three years, in locations that can range from Argentina to France.
LEAD: A last-minute settlement in a family feud over the $350 million trust left by auto magnate Henry Ford 2dbroke down in court today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''It's a six-ring circus, a six-floor-ring circus,'' said Lyn Gastevich of Chicago, summing up opening day of the new Bloomingdale's store at 900 North Michigan Avenue. It was 10:30 Saturday morning and she was buying a handbag while hordes of customers inched their way through tap dancers, clowns and mimes.

LEAD: In an attempt to remove a tough Federal judge presiding over their case, lawyers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and other defendants in a large securities fraud lawsuit have asserted in sealed court papers that the judge has a conflict of interest involving his wife's family business, several people who have seen the papers said yesterday.

LEAD: Chiron, whose diamter of 150 miles makes it one of the largest asteroids, has increased its brightness 2 1/2 times, leading some specialists believe it is shedding gas in the manner of a huge comet. Some day, in the distant future, it may be thrown into the inner solar system, they believe, producing a spectacular display.
LEAD: Nathan Henry Gates, a lawyer, died after a stroke Sunday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton, L.I.

LEAD: Picture a hospital nursery: rows of healthy infants, some of them sleeping, some of them crying and most of them plump as pigeons. Now picture the neonatal intensive care unit in the same hospital: rows of skinny, stiff-legged little creatures trembling nervously, squalling fitfully. Were these children born equal?
LEAD: The rival Lebanese cabinets, each claiming legitimacy over the country's leadership, worked today to gain international recognition.

LEAD: Kay Sugahara, a Japanese-American who was interned on the West Coast after the Pearl Harbor attack and who later built a worldwide ship-owning business and worked for better relations between the United States and East Asian nations, died of liver cancer Sunday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He was 79 years old.
LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday sued the Bank of New York Company, asserting that it improperly persuaded Banca Commerciale Italiana to withdraw its friendly bid for Irving last August.

LEAD: Correcting some subway safety violations takes at least 14 months, and the Transit Authority's safety unit has not done an effective job of finding hazardous situations, the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

LEAD: After five years of trying to reverse the drop in oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the effort had failed and that it had to search for ''a new approach'' or face the possibility of another collapse of prices next year.
LEAD: Half the new jobs created in the United States in the last eight years were at wages below the poverty level for a family of four, a Senate report said today.

LEAD: Two scientific studies conducted after four members of the Giants football team developed cancer in the last eight years have concluded that there is no link between the cancers and the environment at the Meadowlands sports complex.
LEAD: * American Carriers Inc., Overland Park., Kan., a motor carrier holding company, named John Bigger president and chief executive, succeeding Leon Robertson, who is retiring.

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday postponed until January the tax fraud trial of Harry B. Helmsley, the hotel magnate, and his wife, Leona, leaving unresolved the question of whether Mr. Helmsley's mental state is adequate for him to stand trial.

LEAD: If humorists thrive in adversity, Calvin Trillin is an anomaly. As he describes himself in his one-man show, ''Calvin Trillin's Uncle Sam'' (at the American Place Theater), he is a happy husband, father and author. But he is not complacent, and it is from that fact that he draws his telling comic arsenal.

LEAD: Ben Johnson of Canada, who won the Olympic 100-meter final Saturday in the world-record time of 9.79 seconds, was stripped of his gold medal and today was disqualified from the Games after drug tests showed he had used an anabolic steroid.
LEAD: Before the San Francisco 49ers tackled the Seahawks in Seattle on Sunday, Joe Montana spoke about the times he had been replaced at quarterback by Steve Young this season.

LEAD: The chemise is the chic dress shape of the moment. After several seasons of clothes fitted closely to the body, sometimes too much so, the linear silhouette of the chemise seems fresh and elegant.

LEAD: New Plea for Ozone Shield The head of the Environmental Protection Agency called for complete elimination of chemicals thought to destroy the ozone layer. Page A20. A Refund From Kodak Kodak gained court approval to disburse nearly $200 million to an estimated 3.4 million people who bought its instant-picture cameras.

LEAD: Many politicians looked to Sunday night's televised debate between Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush as an opportunity for one of the candidates to gain a clear advantage in the 1988 Presidential race. That didn't happen. Instead, the contest was left more muddled than before and as open as it has been at any point since last spring.
LEAD: In a farewell speech that was his most laudatory toward the United Nations, President Reagan called today for a new international effort to stiffen the ban on using chemical weapons.

LEAD: The 55th Soviet championship ended last month in Moscow in a tie for first place between the world champion, Gary Kasparov, and his perpetual challenger, Anatoly Karpov. The two giants of the chess world topped an impressive field with identical 11 1/2-5 1/2 scores.

LEAD: The Campeau Corporation had a 2.3 percent decline in its first-half operating profit, to $172 million, from $176 million in the comparable period last year, reflecting its takeover in May of Federated Department Stores, the company said yesterday.
LEAD: The Chicago Pacific Corporation said today that it had recently been approached by a group interested in buying the company at a ''substantial premium'' to current market values.

LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company and Domtar Inc. of Montreal will form a company to recycle plastic bottles. The 50-50 venture will retrieve from the trash of the two countries polyethylene terephthalate and high-density polyethylene plastics, which make up about 90 percent of the plastics used in bottles for milk, soft drinks and other products.

LEAD: The Presidio Oil Company has reached an agreement to acquire a major portion of the properties and operations of the General Atlantic Energy Corporation, an oil and gas company based in Denver, for $100 million in cash and 1.6 million of Presidio's class A common stock. The shares of Presidio, based in Englewood, Colo., closed yesterday at $5.125, down 37.5 cents each, on the American Stock Exchange.

LEAD: Comparing her own experience in Britain to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to reshape the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that it was ''in the Western interest'' for Mr. Gorbachev to succeed in his effort.

His strongest design direction, however, is to slender evening dresses that show off the body. Yet the reduced sweep does not mean the clothes are quiet and unassuming.

LEAD: The eccentric furnishings of the Maxwell's Plum restaurant are to be auctioned Jan. 21, 1989, everything from the Tiffany glass ceiling to ceramic tigers and monkeys, said Warner LeRoy, the owner.

LEAD: THE first dish I ever made for a customer as a cook's teen-age apprentice in France was an omelet. Making the perfect omelet - smooth and lightly browned outside, moist and well seasoned within - is a technique about which I have written often over the years. Italians have their own version of an omelet, called frittata, and it can be equally delicious.

LEAD: The Jackson County Legislature in Kansas City, Mo., has unanimously voted to rename Royals Stadium for Ewing Kauffman, the co-owner of the Kansas City Royals, and his wife, Muriel.
